        to keep the 3 message limit thing in mind, I will combine my two
questions.

1: I heard a rumor that XLR8R magazine is going to do a review of the
Illumination party from back in May. I don't know why, but the party ended
on a very bad note. I met two of the people from XLR8R there, and I hope
they know what they are doing. It wasn't my party, but I am good friends
with the people who threw it, and they tried their best. I would've done a
few things differently, but lots of people flaked out on them, and it really
hurt things. I thought the party was getting REALLY good, the vibe was
there, the music was getting good, and it's too bad things had to end the
way they did. 

2: I am finally confident enough to spin at parties that aren't my friends
parties. How do I get things rolling, basically? I have spun enough to know
that I can do it, and I have a mixtape in works once I can borrow my
friend's professional dubbing deck. Is distributing a mixtape a good way to
get 'noticed'? God, I hate doing all this stuff. Maybe I should just stick
to spinning at friends parties, it's easier and I don't care about not
getting paid since I already have a job.

        -chris

People -

Went to MAD last night & had a really fun time, despite only staying for
about an hour.  Sho spun some nice, really crunchy stuff - I ate it right
up (with a tall glass of rice milk to wash it down :)

Mostly just wanted to express sincere thanks to the MAD people!  MAD has
been an institution for as long as I've been in the city - if your
weekend hadn't been enough for you, you could always go expend the last
of that energy at the Bahia on Monday :)

I don't know where I'll go to boogy on mondays anymore, but MAD's shoes
will be hard to fill.  Thanks!  And I'll try to be out for the last couple
of action-packed MADs... see you there!

busline( very convenient :) ) It's two bedroom, with a kitchen,one bath
, walk in closet, and a little balcony(aka: the fire escape with a bomb 
ass view of the ciy! The neighborhood is safe and the apartment is very 
clean and ultra cute and the rent is only $233 a month! This place is
only available for rent for the remaining months of summer and then the 
original 
owners will be moving back in and Ibukun will return back to school. 
So, if anyone is interested in renting this shared room or know of 
anybody who is interested in this opportunityfor the rest of the

apartment...

situation that needs to be taken care of ASAP :) Let's all of us try to 
help out this fellow raver because she needs our help and if we can all

Subject: Re: MAD
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
References: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970701103313.29815A-100000@atari>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Right on!  

MAD has been a great habit, I will miss you MAD guys.

I will not miss the last MAD, or even the second to last MAD!

~~~~ reminiscing  harp music here~~~~~~

My first MAD.

Matt Lanier had a Monday Night Dinner at his apartment, I brought a
friend, we all ate the best food; Shawna made the most incredible salad,
I think, (or was it vegi-lasanga?)

The guy across the street watched a porno, naked in his living room, as
we each typed our portion of an email to sfraves on Matt's wireless
laptop.

We got to MAD just in time to get in for 2 bucks, I dropped an *,
realized with horror that "nobody does * at a MAD!" I was mortified
beyond words as my friends sat there looking at me, wondering when I
would peak.  The * turned out to be bogus; or rather, my particular
biochemistry rendered it so...

We all walked down the street to get donuts as I figured out that I
liked a certain guy...

The music was sooo great that night!  (I used to feel nervous dancing in
front of others - but MAD nights broke me of that self consciousness.)  

MAD, to me, has always represented a "pure" appreciation for the SF rave
scene.  The only way I can explain that better is to say that it wasn't
about posing, costumes or stuff like that, (not saying that those things
are bad,) but rather, MAD had/has a "family feel" that was so _comfy_
that we didn't even think to worry about what we looked like as we
communed and danced with friends.  

I wish I understood the lingo better to describe the music that I heard
at MAD.  All I can say is the music _never_ sucked.  

I can tell you that the first time I ever got high, (without drugs!) was
dancing to Sho spin some _beautiful_ housey magic...  That experience
was the first of many that convinced me that I could indeed forgo
chemical *nhancements and still PARTY. 

Anyway, enough with the reminiscence!  MAD is still here for two more
Mondays.  I propose that we have, at least, one more, (hopefully 2?)
fantastic Monday Night Din Din's, and off to MAD to show those guys our
support and the appreciation we feel for our favorite ravin' habit! (I
think Mr. M. Lanier is on the case already?)

Diana

When: Thursday noon
Where: Burrito Real, Mountain View

Directions:

- from 101 take Rangstorff Ave. exit (if you are coming from South you will
merge on Rangstorff in the correct direction, if you are coming from North
you need to take a left onto Rangstorff at the first light after the exit)

- go two blocks (2 stop light blocks) and you will cross Middlefield Rd..

- on your right there will be a shopping center with Lucky

- at the far side of the shopping center (close to the street) there will
be a small restaurant standing on it's own.  It's name is Burrito Real

I'd like to say, that the few times I've made it out to the city on a
Monday night, I have loved Mad.  Nowhere else can I enjoy a Guiness served
by people who actually seem to be happy we are there, dance to music that
DJs like to spin and I like to dance to, and enjoy the Brazilian motif's
contrast with the sparse blips clicks and whirrs of the gorgeous music
burping forth from Gateway (they actually seem custom made for each other
after a mere two or three beers btw).

If I didn't have to be at work at 7:00 am in San Jose it would be a
regular thing, but alas... I am usually sleep deprived enough on Monday
without staying out till they kick me out of the Bahia.

AndyW

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Good things from good people.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

    I'm fairly new to the rave scene and SFRaves.  I'm not sure what's going 
on but it seems this list took an ugly turn at about the same time a couple 
weeks ago.  Maybe it had something to do with what Foolish Fish said about it 
being astrologically tense.  (I'm also subscribed to the MW-Raves list and the
same things are happening.)
    What I do know is that even though the list may have gotten pretty nasty, 
the people are still wonderful.  I was at Area 51 on Saturday and that place 
wasn't giving me a very good vibe.  I think it because the place was so big and 
dark and the music was dark and repetitive. It kind of brought me down.  But 
then as a friend and I were getting water, I heard a bunch of people that 
sounded real happy and giving each other hugs.  Lucky me, I stumbled upon the 
SFRaves net meet.  And even though I didn't know anyone there and had only 
lurked on this list, I was welcomed into the group with hugs and smiles.  I know
I'm not good with names, so to remind those of you I did meet, I was the Asian 
guy with the butterfly glasses.  From that point on, my spirits were high, I was
feeling a positive vibe and I had a great time the rest of the night.  Just 
wanted to say thanks to the SFRaves crew that was at Area 51 for bringing me up 
and hope to see you all again real soon.  I also got to meet Ben and Iris and 
are they ever the coolest people you'll meet.  I hope we can hit a happy 
hardcore party together sometime you two.

Positive attitudes and smiles,

Lang

You know..

E hits everyone differently. For me. It was like becoming an acid head all
over agian.

How many times have you heard someone say "I am going to have to smoke two
joints now just to get off"?  Awight then....

With um the weed...Just ask the fruity parrot "Your nose always knows"  You
never know what your getting wid the E.

"I always know what I am getting when I buy E. Maybe your just not getting
it from the right people"
 SHUT-UP! Oh...Sorry.



I don't know. But I do know that E took me way down, there for awhile.

But the weed....Just a major "de-modivator"  Which kinna sucks. Expecially
when your always around un-modivating people. I need some modivation from
time -to- time.




Lets just figure out what were going to do..BEFORE we fire it up. OK?
#2
Jeff

sticky ass floors in the morning. now this isn't all that bad if you're

For those of you who may have missed this post the first time around. . .

ROOMMATE NEEDED IN SAN FRANCISCO!

Our ideal roomate would be a female, or a male with a female spirit, who
can play with us, create with us, question the world, marvel at the
everyday and respect others.  They would know that it is as important to
respect uniqueness and individuality as it is to recognize
interconnectedness and universality.  We are looking for someone who is
true to themselves, intelligent, creative, & an explorer.

We are three raving, jubilant Goddesses, of varying sexuality.  We are all
self sufficient and together we form a warm and caring community.  The
house is often filled with singing, drumming & philosophizing- but it all
quiets down around 10PM Mon-Thur (hey! we've got day jobs, ya' know!).  Oh,
and there are 2 cats and a turtle on patrol at all times!  If you think
that you have a unique element to contribute to our home- give us a call!

E-MAIL: Glittergirl@value.net
Phone: 415-759-9649, hit #3 during the msg. (sometimes ya' have ta hit it a
couple of times)

RENT:  $260  UTILITIES:  $30/Mo.
NEIGHBORHOOD: Ninth Ave area, near Golden Gate Park
Cigarette smoking in the backyard ONLY!
(& we're tryin to sprout a garden too!)

---"just.jer" <jer@best.com> wrote:
> but we pay those massive promoters $20-$25 a night.... why can't they
> fuckin' use that money to decorate and stuff? I this it's BS that
Area
> 51 didn't decorate hardly at all. The UG parties are always decked
out!
> I guess I'm a 'lil biased too though... I hate massives! =)
> 
> there were a few things that were very attractive and nicely
decorated
> at area 51 though.... the booths where they sold crap! bah....
> bahbahabahabasofjklsajksaGTI4WHTY 843Y842^y$#&*%#^t*q@
> 
> ok.. I love you guys.. byebye =)
> 
> 

i thought the money went towards paying off the police...

i love big raves but i must agree i haven't been to a good massive
around here yet. so i'm beginning to understand why everybody hates
massives. why don't you do it differently then? i still have the same
complaint: the mass is not one. there is no focus, no direction in
which to dance in, nothing to bring the crowd together (no stage, no
MC). the trainspotting crowd around the dj makes it impossible for
him/her to see what's going on w/ the crowd. how can the djs have a
connection w/ the crowd like that? how can they know whether people
are dancing or not. i'm beginning to think that dancing is not really
the priority here. i found it so off-putting when i was dancing near
the speakers at one point and openend my eyes and noticed that i was
the only one dancing! oh man, and the music, although good and hard
and fast at times, became sooo monotonous rather quickly.

happy kids last friday was nice (the art of british understatement!),
nice venue, liked the carpet, nice atmosphere, good music upstairs,
and more people were dancing. and so much effort and enthusiasm from
the organizers!

the best thing about going to parties here, however, is that when ben
and i introduce ourselves to someone it sometimes happens that they
say, "oh wow, ben and iris! i've heard about you guys." it's great to
be famous! (hey jeremy, you looked liquid at happy kids)

and we've been here long enough now to always find people we know at
parties (hi to all of you). and it's such good fun to put faces to all
the names on this list (sorry if we don't remember them all after the
first meeting. but i'm sure we'll see them again)

i'm looking forward to freedom (wouldn't mind going to armageddon in
search for hardcore but it is a bit far w/o a car :)

iris

---"just.jer" <jer@best.com> wrote:
> but we pay those massive promoters $20-$25 a night.... why can't they
> fuckin' use that money to decorate and stuff? I this it's BS that
Area
> 51 didn't decorate hardly at all. The UG parties are always decked
out!
> I guess I'm a 'lil biased too though... I hate massives! =)
> 
> there were a few things that were very attractive and nicely
decorated
> at area 51 though.... the booths where they sold crap! bah....
> bahbahabahabasofjklsajksaGTI4WHTY 843Y842^y$#&*%#^t*q@
> 
> ok.. I love you guys.. byebye =)
> 
> 

i thought the money went towards paying off the police...

i love big raves but i must agree i haven't been to a good massive
around here yet. so i'm beginning to understand why everybody hates
massives. why don't you do it differently then? i still have the same
complaint: the mass is not one. there is no focus, no direction in
which to dance in, nothing to bring the crowd together (no stage, no
MC). the trainspotting crowd around the dj makes it impossible for
him/her to see what's going on w/ the crowd. how can the djs have a
connection w/ the crowd like that? how can they know whether people
are dancing or not. i'm beginning to think that dancing is not really
the priority here. i found it so off-putting when i was dancing near
the speakers at one point and openend my eyes and noticed that i was
the only one dancing! oh man, and the music, although good and hard
and fast at times, became sooo monotonous rather quickly.

happy kids last friday was nice (the art of british understatement!),
nice venue, liked the carpet, nice atmosphere, good music upstairs,
and more people were dancing. and so much effort and enthusiasm from
the organizers!

the best thing about going to parties here, however, is that when ben
and i introduce ourselves to someone it sometimes happens that they
say, "oh wow, ben and iris! i've heard about you guys." it's great to
be famous! (hey jeremy, you looked liquid at happy kids)

and we've been here long enough now to always find people we know at
parties (hi to all of you). and it's such good fun to put faces to all
the names on this list (sorry if we don't remember them all after the
first meeting. but i'm sure we'll see them again)

iris

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Wed, 02 Jul 1997 21:43:39 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: stariana <cnielsen@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: RR: THIS IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT!!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

 HEY ALL, THIS IS REALLY IMPORTANT SO PLEASE READ THIS.
        I HOPE THIS IS AS IMPORTANT TO YOU AS IT IS TO ME.
        IT'S KINDA LONG BUT PLEASE, JUST READ IT! IT EFFECTS US *ALL*
 hello, everybody, how are jou? it's me stariana. i just got back from a 
weekend of happy and grumpy kids. it was great to see all of you, and happy
to meet some new people, too. (hey, rubilicious  and mercutio!)
unforunately, there is more to this post. please, before you think badly of
this post, THINK about whether or not it pertains to you. I'M NOT FLAMING,
but only trying to open people's eyes to the BULLSHIT. so reach inside of
yourself and evaluate. 
okay, i started raving for the music and the community of wonderful people.
i felt that the people i met through raving were better than anything else i
can imagine, and my life is much happier and richer because of those people.

but this weekend, a wave of uneasiness washed over me and i was seriously
considering stopping raving, due to the feeing that seemed to overwhelm me.
there has been sooooo much that has changed, most importantly: LACK OF UNITY.
it seems that all that is important now are drugs and being popular.

people constantly speak/write plurriness, but it feels like just a front.
kinda like well "everybody thinks i am just da bomb ass motherfucker and i
am so plurry and cute and lovey" but it's a facade. you start talking shit
about someone and then that person comes up to you to give you a hug and you
act as though you are their best friend until they walk away again. it's not
like talking shit about the homie g in da corner yelling "X" but it's
talking shit about those you consider your FRIENDS. 

c'mon, people, what makes you a raver? i rave to hang out with my friends,
to dance, to play and be silly and love and meet new people. to FEEL the
music, to FEEL the vibe. can YOU feel it? can you anymore? 

you are missing the point if you go to a rave to be seen or to see how many
followers you can get and see how many people you can get with--(by the way,
dry fucking in the dance floor is NOT fun to watch) 

listen, if you are popular, i hope it is because people like you for WHO YOU
ARE, AND WHAT YOU, ALONG WITH EVERYBODY ELSE IN THE SCENE, CONTRIBUTES. that
means: BE YOURSELF, DON'T PRETEND. if people don't like you for you are,
then fuck 'em, you don't need to deal with those people anyway. they don't
need to deal with you. 

COMMUNITY AND FAMILY means working TOGETHER. you know, a team effort. we
always say that everyone is accepted in our scene. that's WHY we have our
scene, so people have a place where you can be accepted regardless of
anything. right?

i see people selling out to popularity and drugs. THAT IS BULLSHIT, STRAIGHT
BULLSHIT. and i along with others are sick and tired of it. BULLSHIT! i
don't go to a rave to hear about who's fucking who or who is a bitch/dick
etc.etc. 

remember that piece of literature passed out a happy kids #3 titled: READ THIS? 
does anybody still have this besides me? if ya got it, go read it. if
someone could post it, that would be good too. that piece of paper said
everything. IT'S NOT ABOUT DRUGS OR FASHION OR ANY OTHER BULLSHIT. IT'S
ABOUT PEACE LOVE UNITY AND RESPECT, RIGHT? RIGHT? 

        IT'S ABOUT US, TOGETHER. 

how can we not practice what we preach? plur applies to all, not just the
people who don't happen to piss you off. 

        LET'S MAKE THIS A COMMUNITY EFFORT, FROM OUR ***HEARTS***

everybody is so segregated and all we're doing is feeding the negative
energy that already surrounds our scene. we aren't sending a good message to
anybody, not even to ourselves. i want everybody to realize that if it isn't
a group effort, we won't have a community to call our own. we will be just
as bad as those who bring us down in the first place. 

don't we all want to come away from our scene with more good memories than bad?
memories of a place where we can be FREE, FREE TO BE OURSELVES, AND FREE TO
BE HAPPY. 

don't come to a rave with a bad attitude, no one wants to hear the bullshit
THINK ABOUT IT: we feed off the happiness that others emanate, so GIVE IT BACK! 
YOU GOTTA GIVE TO GET

I WANT THIS SCENE TO PREVAIL AND TO KEEP ON GROWING INTO SOMETHING SO
BEAUTIFUL THAT NOT EVEN OUTSIDE FORCES CAN KILL IT. 

        ISN'T THAT WHAT WE ALL WANT? THEN LET'S DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT,
                                *TOGETHER*

        *PEACE- NO FIGHTS, NO BAD VIBES, TRANQUILITY, NO SHIT TALKING

        *LOVE- GOOD VIBES, KISSES, HUGS, COMMON COURTESY

        *UNITY- COMMUNITY, F.A.M.I.L.Y., TOGETHERNESS, US, WE

        *RESPECT- GIVE IT TO RECEIVE IT, TREAT OTHERS LIKE YOU WANT TO BE
TREATED, EQUALITY  


if you don't like somebody, fine you don't like them. so ignore them, or
confront them and try to reach compromise. if it's not possible, again,
ignore them. remember, that someone that you hate/dislike may be friends
with someone you do like and that talking shit won't help your situation or
anybody elses, except maybe boost your low self esteem. AND WE, AS RAVERS,
SHOULDN'T HAVE TO WORRY ABOUT OUR INSECURITIES, because we are all ACCEPTED,
or at least we *should* be. 

look, i'm not writing this to be all authoritative or look like i know
everything, because i don't. i only write what i see, and what i feel.
i wouldn't write this if i didn't think it was important. i felt compelled,
as a raver to write this, to maybe get some of you who i am describing to
THINK and change. i only want to help this scene and make it beautiful as we
all want it to be. i hope hope hope i reach some of you. 

also, i didn't write this to be flamed. i am not pointing any fingers, and i
am not talking shit. all of the above is actually true. think about whether
or not you are described in this post. if you aren't, try to encourage
others who are to help contribute to make our scene hella phat. if you are,
please take  a good look and try to change. everyone will be willing to
accept your good attitude. i know i will. 

please,   CHILDREN OF THE NIGHT, UNITE UNITE UNITE! FIGHT THE BULLSHIT

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR LISTENING.

MAD MAD LOVE GOES OUT TO ALL OF YOU FROM ME, UNCONDITIONALLY, ALWAYS. 

sugarkisses,
***stariana***

i am open for positive feedback and constructive criticism.

I've said it before and I'll say it again - the key to the massives [the ones
I've been to at least] is having a large group together so you can have your
own vibe if the overall party vibe isn't there for you.

With that in mind, I'd like to do another sfraves group hug at freedom.  Is
anyone hip enough to the location/setup to be able to suggest a place?  Water
sales booth at say 10 or so?  What do you guys think?

b.

> i love big raves but i must agree i haven't been to a good massive
> around here yet. so i'm beginning to understand why everybody hates
> massives. why don't you do it differently then? i still have the same
> complaint: the mass is not one. there is no focus, no direction in
> which to dance in, nothing to bring the crowd together (no stage, no
> MC). the trainspotting crowd around the dj makes it impossible for
> him/her to see what's going on w/ the crowd. how can the djs have a
> connection w/ the crowd like that? how can they know whether people
> are dancing or not. i'm beginning to think that dancing is not really
> the priority here. i found it so off-putting when i was dancing near
> the speakers at one point and openend my eyes and noticed that i was
> the only one dancing! oh man, and the music, although good and hard
> and fast at times, became sooo monotonous rather quickly.

Holy holy holy Shit, poop of power and might, this weekend is going to
DETONATE for our causa de la selva, nuestra vida junglista.

I don't even know what to do besides give thanks to the heights:

Punckateck's got Soul from Shaolin Fist Crew in NYC, plus Abstract Noel
Spell residentially.

Friday, STEP2K's got R.A.W. from Los Angeles, SWRV from Indianapolis who
did Phunckateck last week, plus Gamekat, Noel, and Push.

There's the Stompin' party with jungle at it, Freedom, I do believe has
jungle going on, and hell *I've* got jungle going on.

Eat it!

Yours truly,
Max McCauley
Grade 5

I'm sending this a little early due to the holiday (and my busy day
Thursday).  Thanks to everyone who's been sending in info - unfortunately
I usually don't have time to respond to each one personally.  

I don't have as much stuff as I would expect for the big weekend, but Stompy
and Freedom should be big enough for everyone, and there's probably other
stuff that I just haven't heard about.  There's a couple of new weeklies of
note - check out the listings for Music Box and Ultra...


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

     _________________________________________________________________

   Friday, July 4th - Stompy Dig-In presents _Indepen-Dance Day_
   Jonene, Preston, Ryan Tapia, Mark Grant (Guidance/Cajual), Push,
   Abstract, UFO, Gamekat.
   10am-then, 21+, $13. 278 11th St, SF.

   Mark Johns.Video and multimedia by Foo-Ku. Sound by EAW.
   21+. the Usual, 400 S 1st St, San Jose.
   
   _Mix Lounge_ - techno, house, jungle w/DJs guest DJs weekly. 9pm-2am,
   . 2513 Van Ness, SF. 415.928.0404
   
   _Dub Mission_ - SF's only dub night w/DJs Sep, J.Boogie, Ludichris,
   other surprises. 9pm-, 21+, $3. the Elbo Room, 647 Valencia @ 17th,
   SF. 415.552.7788
   [7.6 - Stellar Trax DJs Ron & Vanka]
   
   _Stumble_ - Unwind or wind to the finest electronic grooves spanning
   the whole spectrum of new music. w/DJs JB. 8pm-2am, Free. Edinburgh
   Castle, 950 Geary (between Polk and Larkin), SF. 415.885.4074
   
   _float_ - chillin' house beats in a new space w/DJs John Howard, Jason
   Mouse, Erin (409). 10p-2a, 21+, Free. Liquid, 2925 16th @ Mission, SF.
   415.431.8889
   
   _true_ - house, acid jazz w/DJs David Harness, Alain del Corazon, Tim
   Martinez, Henry, Miquel. 10pm-afterhours, 21+, $5. Cat's Grill, 1190
   Folsom @ 8th, SF. 415.339.8444

   DNA Lounge, 375 11th St @ Harrison, SF. 415.626.1409

   21+. DNA Lounge, 375 11th St, SF. 415.437.4099
   
   _Super8000_ - analogus expeririments in the chemical composition of
   celluloid and wax. 21+. Edinburgh Castle, 950 Geary @ Polk, SF.

   abstract vs noel, gabe real, g-most, matty b, tasho, chuck wish,
   kiyoshi. every other sunday starting june 22nd.
   10pm-3am, 18+. cat's alley, 1190 Folsom, SF.

   Free. Club Paradise, 1028 Geary @ Polk, SF. 415.567.7540

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 8-10pm - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

hey, there were these parties for a couple months in la called Smaller and
the last couple times i went, the promoters passed out popsicles for free
to everybody around 4:00 or so. it would be the coolest and most welcome
thing after a couple hours of sweatbox dancing. i trip out on the the icy
steam that emanates from the popsicle whenever i hold it up to a light or
laser.

so, i guess i dont really have a point with this post, just that popsicles
at raves are really cool!

joe

Hrmmmm...ok, I don't want to sound mean or anything but It seems to me
that just maybe...your situation and time at raves right now is unlike
others? It seems as though you might be trying to get some higher meaning
out of raves then they really are? Or maybe not, that's just what I'm
readin in to. You can't really blame the Rave or the Scene in general when
bad vibes come about because there are soooo many different types of
people and sooooo many different ideas that each person has about going to
raves...
	Unfortunately, to some it's just an escape to sneak out of thier
parents house and do drugs. To others, it's a place to listen to really
cool music. Some go to hang out with friends, and some go expecting to
make new friends and are dissappionted when they find out that not
everybody else there wants to go around making friends. Some go for
this...some go for that and so on...get the point? *shrug*

	So even though it's been said a million times, I guess it always comes 
down to the same simple saying...A RAVE IS WHAT YOU MAKE OF IT. You can't 
really expect to have a good time or a good vibe hit you on the head. And 
when things are not going as well as you expected them to, you have to 
try to make the best of it. When I'm having a bad time at a rave here's 
what I usually try to do...
	1) look around at all the people who are having fun, smile, and 
	   think how cool it is to be at a party where people are having fun.

	2) Go dance...listen to the music...lock into the music. Try and 
	   stay there all night. I'm mean, hopefully you came there to dance?

	3) Try to find some of the sober people who helped put on the 
	   party, or try to find a DJ that you can talk to about the party or the 
	   scene in general, and basically make good conversation with as many 
	   people as possible.



...The most important thing is this though...It seems as though you have 
a problem with certain people who might only go to parties to do drugs. 
And from what I've scene on this list and at parties you're not alone. 
And to some extent I agree with you,...BUT, you just can't can't can't 
let that bother you because it's ALWAYS going to be there. Whether we 
like it or not, unless we start having private parties, these people who 
go to parties for the sole purpose of doing drugs are always going to be 
around. As painful as it might be, the best way to deal with it is to 
just try to not let it bother you. Stick to your friends. Stick to 
sfravers (by the way...EVERYONE remember to wear your laminants...case in 
point ) ..... and .....

Instead of being one who tries to catch on to a good vibe that isn't 
there, be one who realizes that party needs a good vibe and create 
yourself, for others to catch on too.


Well, it's late, enough blabbing, off to bed, hope this helped?

and

Staaaaaaaay Cooooooooool!

- Matt, the other one -

dogs were biting each other and the ppl seemed nice, though i was alone and
left early. i saw the sfpd car when i got on the bus around 1145. maybe that

MIME-version: 1.0

Content-type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Matthew Alan Schwartz told stariana that...

>Hrmmmm...ok, I don't want to sound mean or anything but It seems to me
>that just maybe...your situation and time at raves right now is unlike
>others? It seems as though you might be trying to get some higher meaning
>out of raves then they really are? Or maybe not, that's just what I'm
>readin in to. You can't really blame the Rave or the Scene in general when
>bad vibes come about because there are soooo many different types of
>people and sooooo many different ideas that each person has about going to
>raves...

Ok, hold it right there. I don't know if you know star or not, but she's
one of the bestest people to be around at parties. She's not trying to "get
more out of raves than they really are", she's there to enjoy the LOVE that
_should_ be a huge part of the experience. Be it love for music, people, or
whatever. If you love drugs and go to parties to do them, go for it. (of 
course, I'm not saying that drugs are "good", and under no circumstances can
you hold ME responsible for anything that happens to YOU when you do drugs.)
All us other ravers can ask of you is that you're honest. Honest with yourself
as well as us. If you don't like the other people at raves, you just want
to feel the e hit you, or all you care about is the trembling bass or the
tweaks of the 303s, don't pretend that you like us only to talk smack about
us as soon as we're not there.
Is this asking too much? I don't think so. I have raved on both sides of the
Atlantic, and the scene in Europe is pretty much about either looking good or
being a musical elitist. You either wear the latest creations from Dolce &
Gabbana, Tommy (yup, he's big among Euroravers), etc, or you dance for 8 hours
straight. Where's the vibe? There is no vibe. In SF there _used_ to be a vibe.
After two years at Sonoma State, I returned to Sweden this summer. My plans
were to come back for the fall semester. When I got a offered a _very_ well-
paying job over here, I declined because I knew I'd miss the scene in SF so
much. But lately, I've heard a _lot_ of depressing things from my friends over
in CA. I'm not so sure it's a scene worth coming back to. And I really don't
think it's because I'm looking for more in the rave scene than it has to
offer,
do you?

>	So even though it's been said a million times, I guess it always comes 
>down to the same simple saying...A RAVE IS WHAT YOU MAKE OF IT. 

That's very true. But that's not the issue here. Imagine this scenario...
You go to rave X, where you talk to person A, who's hella friendly and
tells you
how much he/she loves you, and you get a really good feeling about them.
The next
day you find out that person A went around telling everyone what a pain you
are.
How can that rave be "good"? No matter how much you try to make it a great
rave,
being deceived like that will bring most people down. 

All I'm saying is...I don't care why you go to raves. We all have our reasons,
and they're all GOOD reasons. I just don't want you to do anything you
don't want
to just because you feel you have to. If you don't want to tell me you love me
when you really hate me, then don't. If you DO tell me you love me even though
you don't, please don't walk around telling people what a jerk I am. I won't
make ANYONE's evening more enjoyable.

*huggies, lots of them. and they're sincere...*
jonas THE SPACEBOY

"it's not easy being cool." - jerry springer

       name: s??n jonas hanning
    aliases: dj spaceboy, dabalhed^, hey you!
    contact: +46-41145749, +46-740142488
now playing: uncle noah "birthright" =)

Hi ben + Iris,

I have never met you guys but I have heard about you and we know
mutual friends (Hi Jer,Ari,Beth,Jelo etc..) You get the Picture. Well
my 0.02 Cents on the trainspotting is. First off for all you Train
spotting up and coming DJ's DO NOT LOOK at what the DJ is playing
trying to hypnotize yourself by seeing what track the DJ is playing.
That is VERY disrespectfull I like for people to watch me play and
have a good time but I dont like when DJ's are trying to trainspot my
rekkids. If there is a crowd of people watching a DJ play you can be
rest assured it is because he is throwing down and 9 times out of 10
you can be sure that people are going off to the beats. Or else people
would not watch the DJ. You don't watch boring people do ya? Well that
is enough from mEE
Take care all...

Macadio

Subject: Trainspotting (was Re: Area 51 review) 
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Iris + Ben (jarmin@rocketmail.com) wrote:
> the trainspotting crowd around the dj makes it impossible for
> him/her to see what's going on w/ the crowd. how can the djs have a
> connection w/ the crowd like that? how can they know whether people
> are dancing or not.

Trainspotters make me extremely nervous.  Mostly because I'm generally
pretty self-conscious and hate to have people staring in my general 
direction...but also because of exactly what Iris + Ben say above.

But I trainspot too, at times, if I hear a track I really like...so I had
an idea while driving to work this morning.  If you're the type of DJ who
plans their set out in advance, why not post the set list where trainspotters
can see it?  That way they can get the track and label names and then 
get out of the way.  (Of course, this only applies if you're not the kind
of DJ who tapes over the labels on all their records to prevent some sort
of state secret from leaking out.)

I know a lot of DJs spin by the seat of their pants, or only plan out the
first few mixes, but I also know a number of them plan out the whole set
(with a few alternate paths in case a change of direction or mood becomes
appropriate).

Opinions?

Another thing that helps break up the "wall of non-dancing voyeurs" is
for the DJ to convince their friends that it is absolutely necessary for
them to come dance right in front of the tables during their set :-).  And
finally, if the DJ himself/herself dances behind the tables, the trainspotters
get caught in this weird vortex of happy motion and hopefully get the point.
Oh yeah, and I've even been known to lean over the tables, make little
shooing motions with my hands, and smile and say "go dance!  it's more fun
that way!"

Laura

From: John Darrow <jdarrow@aa.net>
Subject: Re: RR: THIS IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT!!!
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

> HEY ALL, THIS IS REALLY IMPORTANT SO PLEASE READ THIS.

Hello Stariana-

I just wanted to point out a couple of inconsistancies with your post, or
somehow help you to see that things aren't as bad as you may think.

For one, the negativity that you are now feeling and the vile things you
are seeing at raves now has really been here the whole time. It always has
been here and it always will be. I encourage you to go into the sfraves
archives on hyperreal and read about people saying these exact same things
about the scene in 1992, and in 1993, and in 1994, and in 1995, and in
1996, and now in 1997. About how the initial love is gone and all people
care about now are the drugs and being hip.

and likewise, obviously the cool and wonderful things about raving has also
been here the whole time, and always will be. At the same time as one half
of the people are talking about how negative things are getting, there's a
whole other group who insist that today is the brightest day their eyes
have ever witnessed.

So what's going on... well frankly, it's you. It's not them or the scene.
Everything begins and ends with you. And when you started out you were
amazed at this new way of looking at things, of this new way of interacting
with people, of listening to music and expressing who you are. You chose to
see all the wonders of the good things, and so things were all just great.
But the drugs were still there. The guys in the corner with shifty eyes
whispering X out of the corners of their mouth were there. The cluster of
girls were there in another corner giggling about how outdated girl X's top
was, and how slutty she must be, and the smarmy 24 year old guy was there
macking on clueless 14 year old girls. and Joe Pistol kept getting in Bull
Dog Pete's face about how someone's ass was grass.

But you didn't see those things. You saw the incredible unity of love and
how people's energy can be connected together and how this can propel your
soul upward into other realms and other understandings of the universe. But
then that slowly got old and you started seeing what else was going on. and
it looked like everything that was initially so good was turning sour.

>people constantly speak/write plurriness, but it feels like just a front.
>kinda like well "everybody thinks i am just da bomb ass motherfucker and i
>am so plurry and cute and lovey" but it's a facade. you start talking shit
>about someone and then that person comes up to you to give you a hug and you
>act as though you are their best friend until they walk away again. it's not
>like talking shit about the homie g in da corner yelling "X" but it's
>talking shit about those you consider your FRIENDS.

There's a saying, you are what you pretend to be. So what are you really?
both nothing and everything, except when your pretending... People who
write plurriness are plurryness. Who are you to say that plur doesn't exist
for them and to call them liars. Just because you've lost sight of that
plurry feeling doesn't mean it no longer exists. You signed off your post
saying that you love unconditionally. I seem to feel quite a bit of
conditions in the things you've said, and the ways you're describing all
these other people. You first thought that "ravers were better than
everyone else"... well right there you started off with a condition that is
bound to lead you into trouble somewhere. and what about the person who
gets high and becomes your best friend for a night, and the next day talks
shit. Do you no longer love them... well, perhaps that's why they no longer
love you. People make those kind of drastic changes when you set conditions
on them, and expect them to behave a certain way. They must come to
dissapoint you, because people must always maintain their freedom, and
break through all expectations, good and bad. And then what happens when
you write people off as bad... well, you will no longer give yourself the
opportunity to see the good sides of that person that made them be your
best friend for a night.

>c'mon, people, what makes you a raver? i rave to hang out with my friends,
>to dance, to play and be silly and love and meet new people. to FEEL the
>music, to FEEL the vibe. can YOU feel it? can you anymore?

Can you feel it anymore? When you did feel it did you know what made some
people ravers and some people not? no, you didn't. The reasons you mention
for being a raver are great, but greater than other people's reasons...
must everyone have the same reasons to be a raver, to be a part of unity...
I certainly hope not, or thing would get very boring very fast. The times
when you do feel it are the time when you stop judging and start feeling
all the other things that people and things are. It's not already knowing
what they are and what they should do, it's totally not knowing. That's
where the magic is. My best advice to you is to put all your established
rave notions back in the closet and start from scratch again. The goodness
is there, the challenge for you now is to find the strength to just let
yourself see it, and to make the leap of faith required for you to believe
it.

Don't worry so much about getting the support of the collective and
fighting the bullshit and making everyone go the way you want them to go.
Just be yourself and give yourself the strength to be who you ideally
envision yourself to be, that's all and nothing else, and you will find
that everyone and everything else will follow.

Again, everything, and I do mean everything, begins and ends with you.

and you're not alone in this struggle. I think you'll find that almost
everyone who has been a part of the scene for a while has had to deal with
this collapse of the initial goodness in some way. Some people choose to
leave completely, and some choose to reach way deep within them to find the
strength to push through the darknesss.

good luck-

-john.

John Darrow - http://www.he.net/~swoosh/ - jdarrow@aa.net

*delurking*

I have to concur with Laura on that one.  Trainspotters (at least the ones 
who stare intently at the booth, just waiting to see you screw up, do tend 
to get me out of "the zone" which allows me to achieve anything approaching 
decent mixing.

However, I must admit that I, too, am guilty of the more-than-occasional 
trainspot.  As often happens, you'll go out, hear this fleeting track which 
has eluded your grasp for many a week, and have the opportunity to find out 
"What the hell is that thing?"  That being said, I like to think I'm pretty 
concious about the whole "rude" thing.  If checking out a track means 
totally getting into the DJ's face, then I don't do it.  Period.  I like 
the setup at Stompy (held at club VSF) because you can stand behind the DJ, 
see the record, and they never even knew you were there.  Otherwise, I try 
to grab a glimpse from off to the side of the booth.

The other side to the debate about trainspotting seems to surround the 
protective nature DJs have towards their tunes.  I think that's bullshit. 
 A good track isn't "yours".  Number one, it belongs to the producer who 
spent hundreds of hours getting the thing done, not the DJ who stumbled 
upon it.  Number two, tracks are extremely perishable.  By the time any of 
us poor souls get our hands on the good tracks (when they go to wide 
release) the big name DJs have already had their way with them, and they're 
all "played out".  To think that "secret weapon" tracks will give you a 
"competitive edge" is immature, selfish, and most of all, naive.

End rant.

Oliver

*now returns to his regularly-scheduled lurking*

[SMTP:laura@infoseek.com] wrote:

> > the trainspotting crowd around the dj makes it impossible for
> > him/her to see what's going on w/ the crowd. how can the djs have a
> > connection w/ the crowd like that? how can they know whether people
> > are dancing or not.
>
> Trainspotters make me extremely nervous.  Mostly because I'm generally
> pretty self-conscious and hate to have people staring in my general
> direction...but also because of exactly what Iris + Ben say above.
>
> But I trainspot too, at times, if I hear a track I really like...so I had
> an idea while driving to work this morning.  If you're the type of DJ who
> plans their set out in advance, why not post the set list where 
trainspotters
> can see it?  That way they can get the track and label names and then
> get out of the way.  (Of course, this only applies if you're not the kind
> of DJ who tapes over the labels on all their records to prevent some sort
> of state secret from leaking out.)
>
> I know a lot of DJs spin by the seat of their pants, or only plan out the
> first few mixes, but I also know a number of them plan out the whole set
> (with a few alternate paths in case a change of direction or mood becomes
> appropriate).
>
> Opinions?
>
> Another thing that helps break up the "wall of non-dancing voyeurs" is
> for the DJ to convince their friends that it is absolutely necessary for
> them to come dance right in front of the tables during their set :-). 
 And
> finally, if the DJ himself/herself dances behind the tables, the 
trainspotters
> get caught in this weird vortex of happy motion and hopefully get the 
point.
> Oh yeah, and I've even been known to lean over the tables, make little
> shooing motions with my hands, and smile and say "go dance!  it's more 
fun
> that way!"
>
> Laura

     I think what John Darrow had to say was pretty right on, at least I 
     related to it.  
     
     Often times you see all the good things in an activity, or person, 
     first then start to notice those aspects that you may find less 
     appealing.  For me, I adapted by realizing that these aspects were 
     there before I ever came on the scene, and will continue to be 
     present, so just appreciated and enjoyed the more appealing aspects.
     
     This reminds me (jumping on a little soapbox for a moment) of 
     relationships in a way.  When you first start dating someone you often 
     see mostly the good side of the person and all is fun with no 
     disagreements.  As it is with all people there is both a "good" and 
     "not so good" side to an individual.  After a time you begin to notice 
     that not-so-good side and have to deal with that.  Either severe the 
     relationship if it's just not going to work for both of you or try to 
     overcome the negatives.  There's no one right way, obviously, just the 
     way that you choose.  (clarification...when I use "you" in this 
     paragraph I'm really referring to me since you may have a different 
     viewpoint.)
     
     Off soapbox...I just (and really still am) went through this 
     experience recently so felt like tossing this out in response.
     
     Have a great holiday !
     
      - Robert
     
     P.S., after nearly a year of being off SFRaves I have returned (run 
     for it!), but with a new email address.  (though I'll unsub for the 
     weekend since dealing with 500 or so emails on Monday would be a 
     bitch.)

 >For one, the negativity that you are now feeling and the vile things you
>are seeing at raves now has really been here the whole time. It always has
>been here and it always will be. I encourage you to go into the sfraves
>archives on hyperreal and read about people saying these exact same things
>about the scene in 1992, and in 1993, and in 1994, and in 1995, and in
>1996, and now in 1997. About how the initial love is gone and all people
>care about now are the drugs and being hip.

<delurking as well>
funny this should come up...
i was one of the original sfraves list folks back in '92 and '93... and i
just recently got back on the list 4 years later b/c i was curious what was
going on these days on the list. first thing i noticed was that things
didn't seem to change.... there was still a lot of bitching about big
massives, of bad vibes and too much posing. but there was also still a lot
of talk about peace and love and unity and the joy of community and unity.

hey star - i'm sure i posted almost identical posts as you're posting 4-5
years ago. i still bitch about how much better it used to be. yet, i'm
still going out (albeit, never a massive). the key is finding a scene
within our the now-pretty-much-mainstream rave scene which becomes your
home. fact is, the scenes so big these days that there are tons of folks
that won't share your love vibes - they're just bored folks looking for a
place to get fucked up. so find your own friends, carve your own niche, and
stay away from the places that offer those bad vibes.

it's never as good as it was in the beginning.

janelle

Absolutely--I think it's pretty childish if a DJ shields his record
collection out of fear that someone else will then 'know his/her song',
especially since DJing is built upon the very principle of making music
out of other people's music!

-Timothy

"Frisbetarians believe that when they die their soul gets stuck on the
roof."   -U2's Bono


Earlier, a sfraver wrote:

The other side to the debate about trainspotting seems to surround the
protective nature DJs have towards their tunes.  I think that's bullshit.
 A good track isn't "yours".  Number one, it belongs to the producer who
spent hundreds of hours getting the thing done, not the DJ who stumbled
upon it.  Number two, tracks are extremely perishable.  By the time any of
us poor souls get our hands on the good tracks (when they go to wide
release) the big name DJs have already had their way with them, and
they're
all "played out".  To think that "secret weapon" tracks will give you a
"competitive edge" is immature, selfish, and most of all, naive.
                                                                   



Tim McIntyre
pager: (415) 253-8624
email to pager: tim.page@taos.com

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; x-mac-type="54455854"; x-mac-creator="4D4F5353"

Janelle Brown wrote:

> Hello all -
>
> I'm heading out to Southeast Asia in a month or two. I've heard that
> the
> Thai beaches are kinda like Goa with full moon parties and full-on
> beach
> raves.... was wondering if anyone had been out there recently and knew
>
> where I should go to find said parties? I've also heard that the
> police
> have been pretty harsh on cracking down on them....Any opinion on the
> scene
> out there? See or skip?
>
> thanks,
> Janelle

 

I was in Thailand for 3 weeks this last January (the cool season - man,
do I pity you!) and unless you have somebody who speaks Thai you are
going to be S.O.L.
I spent 2 weeks in Bangkok and if you do not know where to look for such
things (flyers, stuff like that) you probably won't find anything.
Granted, I was there to meet my fiancee's family and I wasn't there
necessarily to party, but I was seriously on the look out for something 
cool to go to.
I suspect that most of these beach raves (if they truly exist on a
regular basis) are organized by people that are not native to Thailand.
The other thing is this: When you go out looking for these types of
parties here, you usually go to record or DJ stores or cool clothing
outlets where people know what is going on. In Thailand those places are
almost impossible to find (I looked unsuccessfully) and record stores
are completely non-existant.

Anyway, if I was you I would look for U.K. sponsored stuff where they
have special events booked over there or something. I wouldn't wait to
get to Thailand to find out.

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

On Thu, 3 Jul 1997, Jonas the Spaceboy wrote:

> Matthew Alan Schwartz told stariana that...
> 
> >Hrmmmm...ok, I don't want to sound mean or anything but It seems to me
> >that just maybe...your situation and time at raves right now is unlike
> >others? It seems as though you might be trying to get some higher meaning
> >out of raves then they really are? Or maybe not, that's just what I'm
> >readin in to. You can't really blame the Rave or the Scene in general when
> >bad vibes come about because there are soooo many different types of
> >people and sooooo many different ideas that each person has about going to
> >raves...
> 
> Ok, hold it right there. I don't know if you know star or not, but she's
> one of the bestest people to be around at parties. She's not trying to "get
> more out of raves than they really are", she's there to enjoy the LOVE that
> _should_ be a huge part of the experience. Be it love for music, people, or
> whatever. If you love drugs and go to parties to do them, go for it. (of 
> course, I'm not saying that drugs are "good", and under no circumstances can
> you hold ME responsible for anything that happens to YOU when you do drugs.)
> All us other ravers can ask of you is that you're honest. Honest with yourself
> as well as us. If you don't like the other people at raves, you just want
> to feel the e hit you, or all you care about is the trembling bass or the
> tweaks of the 303s, don't pretend that you like us only to talk smack about
> us as soon as we're not there.
> Is this asking too much? I don't think so. I have raved on both sides of the
> Atlantic, and the scene in Europe is pretty much about either looking good or
> being a musical elitist. You either wear the latest creations from Dolce &
> Gabbana, Tommy (yup, he's big among Euroravers), etc, or you dance for 8 hours
> straight. Where's the vibe? There is no vibe. In SF there _used_ to be a vibe.
> After two years at Sonoma State, I returned to Sweden this summer. My plans
> were to come back for the fall semester. When I got a offered a _very_ well-
> paying job over here, I declined because I knew I'd miss the scene in SF so
> much. But lately, I've heard a _lot_ of depressing things from my friends over
> in CA. I'm not so sure it's a scene worth coming back to. And I really don't
> think it's because I'm looking for more in the rave scene than it has to
> offer,
> do you?
> 
> >	So even though it's been said a million times, I guess it always comes 
> >down to the same simple saying...A RAVE IS WHAT YOU MAKE OF IT. 
> 
> That's very true. But that's not the issue here. Imagine this scenario...
> You go to rave X, where you talk to person A, who's hella friendly and
> tells you
> how much he/she loves you, and you get a really good feeling about them.
> The next
> day you find out that person A went around telling everyone what a pain you
> are.
> How can that rave be "good"? No matter how much you try to make it a great
> rave,
> being deceived like that will bring most people down. 
> 
> All I'm saying is...I don't care why you go to raves. We all have our reasons,
> and they're all GOOD reasons. I just don't want you to do anything you
> don't want
> to just because you feel you have to. If you don't want to tell me you love me
> when you really hate me, then don't. If you DO tell me you love me even though
> you don't, please don't walk around telling people what a jerk I am. I won't
> make ANYONE's evening more enjoyable.
> 


	Ok, I'm sorry about all this but you've completely misread me. I haven't 
met Start and I'm sure she's a really cool person ( with definately a 
cool name :) ) and she did say in her post that she did not want to be 
flamed and I did take note of that and had no intentions a flaming 
what-so-ever. I might have completely misread her too, I havent been in 
the scene for long, and I was just simply trying to help. I thought maybe 
she had a bad time at a rave and wanted to give her some ideas on how to 
turn it into a good time. 

	On the other hand here, I feel I have just been persecuted by you 
for something that is very unlike me. Everything you've discussed here in 
your post...telling people I love them when I don't really, Call people 
friends then calling them jerks behind thier backs, acting a certain way 
or doings things just to fit in at raves...are things that I would NEVER 
do, and those who know me can vouch for me. So like I said, you 
completely misread me, and the opening paragraph in my post was simply a 
suggestion...once again, I was only trying to help. In fact, I think it's 
pretty safe to say that everyone on this list is trying to help, and 
maybe we should all ( including myself ) think a little about that before 
we blame, flame, reply, or whatever.

One other thing...

Take into account that unless one is a perfect writter, it's very 
difficult to get the exact messages and the exact emotion that he or she 
want's to express out onto thier post. Before replying, please everyone 
make sure you've read the entire messege thouroughly and have a really 
good understanding of what the person is tryin to say...I know that 
sometimes I don't do this...but I think I'm going to start reading into 
post carefully from now on.


Thanks, and...

Staaaaay Cooooool

normal activity is it?? I mean, Star came out with a feeling that she was
having, and thought to bring it to everyone's attention, not intending to get
negative feedback from people who, it seems to me, think that they are better
than her! I haven't been in this community long, but I am appolled at the
responses that Star has gotten! Don't berate her for speaking her mind, don't
ever berate anyone for speaking their mind, when they don't do it to hurt
you! If you want to reply to her post, I for one would not like to see you
write something negative. You are not her, and can't possibly see things
through her eyes, so don't try to tell her what's up! Please keep in mind
PLUR, it should be the basis for everything we do, say, write, eat, sleep,
everything, at least that's my belief. We can't expect to gain respect in
other's eyes, if we constantly tear each other apart. I suppose I might be a
little offensive through saying all this, but I'm a little peeved about the
less than positive posts that have been coming through. Why can't we all just
get along?! ::::duck:::: ok, I've gone too far! I'm out.....

Subject: what i wrote
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

hey all, it's me again!

first of all, i hope everyone is enjoying their day off today!

second of all i wanted to say thank you for all who replied, it means alot
that i have reached alot of you.
 
also i wanted to clear up a few things so i can help you guys understand me
a little bit more.

i wasn't oblivious to the fact that all the points i brought up were there
already, rather, i was only pointing out that it SEEMS to me that it has
gotten way out of control, more so than what i usually see, so that's why i
felt i needed to write. believe me i am no stranger to the drugs, the
dealers, the seedy guys, the 12 yearolds on e, the backbiting, etc etc... it
just feels like poeple are forgetting what used to be important. and the
people i see contributing to it are people who i see are getting sucked into
the drug part of it, where they once didn't depend on drugs as the sole
source of entertainment. 

some people though opened up my eyes a bit wider, making me *reluctantly*
realize that there's not much you can do to stop it. oh well, i guess i will
just have to try harder. anybody with me?

"welcome to the real world" someone mentioned. okay, okay, so we can't
expect to change it entirely, but i guess somewhere in my little naive heart
i thought that maybe we could possibly hopefully reach out and fix maybe
part of the problem. is that too much to ask?


well, i think i have exhausted the topic. 

remember to keep what is important to you close to your heart, and believe
in it.

take care and play safe this weekend. have lots of fun partying.
spread your love 

starpower goes out to all of you,
stariana*

On Fri, 4 Jul 1997, stariana wrote:

> i wasn't oblivious to the fact that all the points i brought up were there
> already, rather, i was only pointing out that it SEEMS to me that it has
> gotten way out of control, more so than what i usually see, so that's why i
> felt i needed to write. believe me i am no stranger to the drugs, the
> dealers, the seedy guys, the 12 yearolds on e, the backbiting, etc etc... it
> just feels like poeple are forgetting what used to be important. and the
> people i see contributing to it are people who i see are getting sucked into
> the drug part of it, where they once didn't depend on drugs as the sole
> source of entertainment. 

No there are people out there that aren't forgetting "what is
important"(whatever that happens to be for you), however as the scene gets
larger and larger you have to look a little harder for people that sync
with your vision of how things "should be," and "what it's all about."
Different people have different opinions on just what is important.  

> "welcome to the real world" someone mentioned. 

That would have been me. Didn't mean to sound harsh(for a change), however
this scene like any other is made up of human beings, and human beings no
matter what scene they are in are going to have their personal prejudices
and biases, rather they be against certain styles of dress, the color of
someones skin, religious preferences, a style of music, etc. etc. And
being human people are going to express those dislikes. And their
audience, whomever they are, are going to make judgements about that
person based on what they say and how the act. Scene, whatever that scene
may be does not transend this in my experience.   


> okay, okay, so we can't expect to change it entirely, but i guess
> somewhere in my little naive heart i thought that maybe we could
> possibly hopefully reach out and fix maybe part of the problem. is that
> too much to ask?

Yes. You cannot change people unless they want to be changed. If people 
want to get wacked out on any chemical cocktail they can devise every
weekend, if Suzy want to dis Jane's hideous dress and her poor choice of
hair style, nothing you do is going to change that unless *they*
want to listen to, or are willing to change their behaviour. You can
reach out all you want, but there has to be someone on the other side that
wishes to be reached, and changed. 

If you were to "fix" part of the problem, how would you do it? Where would
you start? 


> remember to keep what is important to you close to your heart, and believe
> in it.

And share it with those around you that you care about! But just keep in
mind that your vision is not the only one, or the only "right" one, IMHO.

					Black Adder

>Oh my god, my heart is in the bottom of my shoes right now. This is NOT
>normal activity is it?? I mean, Star came out with a feeling that she was
>having, and thought to bring it to everyone's attention, not intending to get
>negative feedback from people who, it seems to me, think that they are better
>than her! I haven't been in this community long, but I am appolled at the
>responses that Star has gotten! Don't berate her for speaking her mind, don't
>ever berate anyone for speaking their mind, when they don't do it to hurt
>you! If you want to reply to her post, I for one would not like to see you
>write something negative. You are not her, and can't possibly see things
>through her eyes, so don't try to tell her what's up! Please keep in mind
>PLUR, it should be the basis for everything we do, say, write, eat, sleep,
>everything, at least that's my belief. We can't expect to gain respect in
>other's eyes, if we constantly tear each other apart. I suppose I might be a
>little offensive through saying all this, but I'm a little peeved about the
>less than positive posts that have been coming through. Why can't we all just
>get along?! ::::duck:::: ok, I've gone too far! I'm out.....

Was my response negative? I really don't think so.

Was I berating her at all? well, it was sincerely not my intention to do
so. I guess it's a matter of opinion though, if someone's feelings get
hurt, I suppose in a way then I am indeed a bit negative. But you must
understand that being harsh or negative is not my intention in the
slightest. Nor is it my thinking that I am in any way better than her. I
thought I was very careful to phrase my words in a considerate and
uncondecending form. But how can I say anything at all if I don't say what
I feel, and respond honestly to the points she brought up in her post. And
what I said isn't "right", but it is my experience. and if there is any
point to my reading all of your posts and posting any of my own then I must
relate my experience as truthfully as possible. Otherwise I might as well
just leave you alone so that you can live in a world of no consequence or
diversity, where everything and every idea conforms to your preconceived
notions.

I understand that Star's message was very important, and means a great deal
to her. and I felt and respected it so much that I related my own feelings
on the matter back. I've gone through the same experience, or at least
something very similar, and felt that I have now come to a point where I
understand it and feel that I have moved through it successfully. How could
I not want to share that success with someone who seems to be struggling in
the same way I did? Sure I am not her, and I don't see through her eyes. So
what... I am not a lot of things, and I understand very little except for
what I think I see. all I can ever do is make my own interpretations and my
own self-conceived actions. Does that mean I shouldn't ever act because I
do not truly see? I saw something that I felt I could help with, and I so I
acted. I might have been wrong, but surely no more wrong than you are in
trying to judge me here and now.

Plur is good but where does it end? Does it end with the person who
"appears" to be unplurlike... or is it up to you to go ahead and respect
that person anyway, even if he doesn't follow the rules.

I am not attacking anyone, except for those people who feel like they're
being attacked. That's my whole point, it's up to you to stop feeling like
you're being attacked. Just like it's up to Stariana to stop her own
feeling like the scene and feelings that she loves so much are decaying.

cause the fact of the matter is that no amount of telling people how bad
things are will ever really make things good again. Rallying the troops and
showing them how to march won't really fix anything. Things will only
become good again when you make them good again. plain and simple.

my sincerest regards-

-john.

John Darrow - http://www.he.net/~swoosh/ - jdarrow@aa.net

Janelle,

Once in Thailand, you should go to an island on the east side called Koh
Samui. You'll eith have to fly from Bangkok or head south towards Suri
Thani and take a boat. From there, you need to take a ferry boat to a
tiny neighboring island called Koh Pangang. That's where there's a big
Full-Moon party each month on the beach.

Have fun!

CU
DS








Janelle Brown Wrote:

raves.... was wondering if anyone had been out there recently and knew
where I should go to find said parties? I've also heard that the police
have been pretty harsh on cracking down on them....Any opinion on the
scene
out there? See or skip?

First I must admit that due to time constraints as of late, I didn't read
*all* of the messages in that thread, but I do want to contribute a few
ideas (which may or may not have been expressed ;)...

I'm pretty new to the rave scene (thanks...many thanks...to beth), and did
e for the first time a couple of months ago after a 3 year moratorium on
psychedelics. I like it a lot, and want to keep liking it, so I don't do it
al the time...but enough of the disclaimers.

I have *very* fond memories of area51, but I can see how some people might
not share that sentiment. The decor was rather anemic and it was kind of
dirty (no...very dirty), and there were a lot of people standing around.
But, I didn't notice that. The group I went with (beth, ari, matt, ed,
gavin, shua, nick, becca), and everyone who gravitated to the same little
area upfront, are what I remember most distinctly.

The only real bummer for me was the fact that there were so many people
that just didn't want to smile. That kind of sucks the energy out of
me...again, it's good to have a home base full of good peoples.

Beth and I went to boomboomBASKET yesterday...and it was proof to me that
e isn't a requisite part of a good time (btw...greetings Jeremy, Jeremy,
Jacob, Forrest, Micron, Astronaut Scott)...it's the immediate surroundings.
I was even able to filter out the foaming-at-their-mouths
hiding-in-the-bushes goth guys later in the evening. Blue skies, great
people, and that cute lil dachsund(sp?) puppy made it one hell of a fourth.

Ok...maybe I'm just green, naive, wet-behind-the-ears as my grandpappy used
to say. But even with all of its flaws, the bayarea rave scene hasn't left
me with a frown on my face yet.

Thanks for listening...hope to see you all at freedom (I'll be wearing a
big puffy Uncle Sam hat)

/justin

On Fri, 4 Jul 1997, stariana wrote:

> hey all, it's me again!
> 
> first of all, i hope everyone is enjoying their day off today!
> 
> second of all i wanted to say thank you for all who replied, it means alot
> that i have reached alot of you.
>  
> also i wanted to clear up a few things so i can help you guys understand me
> a little bit more.
> 
> i wasn't oblivious to the fact that all the points i brought up were there
> already, rather, i was only pointing out that it SEEMS to me that it has
> gotten way out of control, more so than what i usually see, so that's why i
> felt i needed to write. believe me i am no stranger to the drugs, the
> dealers, the seedy guys, the 12 yearolds on e, the backbiting, etc etc... it
> just feels like poeple are forgetting what used to be important. and the
> people i see contributing to it are people who i see are getting sucked into
> the drug part of it, where they once didn't depend on drugs as the sole
> source of entertainment. 
> 
> some people though opened up my eyes a bit wider, making me *reluctantly*
> realize that there's not much you can do to stop it. oh well, i guess i will
> just have to try harder. anybody with me?
> 
> "welcome to the real world" someone mentioned. okay, okay, so we can't
> expect to change it entirely, but i guess somewhere in my little naive heart
> i thought that maybe we could possibly hopefully reach out and fix maybe
> part of the problem. is that too much to ask?
> 
> 
> well, i think i have exhausted the topic. 
> 
> remember to keep what is important to you close to your heart, and believe
> in it.
> 
> take care and play safe this weekend. have lots of fun partying.
> spread your love 
> 
> starpower goes out to all of you,
> stariana*
> 
>

REALLY MISSED OUT LAST NIGHT!
step2k 
was
fucking
SICK!
i left @ around 2/2:30 am cuz we were so damn tired but it was BUMPIN 
when we walked out the door..
SWRV from indianapolis threw down a shitload of rollin bumpin bouncy 
tracks with thick chunky basslines...
and R.A.W... well, how can i explain it.. he started out with "your 
sound" (j majik) on 2 decks and then just exploded into a frenzy of 
scratching and bouncing and just sick sick WICKED MAD SKILLS :)~
he needs to leave L.A. and move up here. 
	and the crowd, well if any of you wanna tell me that junglists 
have attitude, FUCK YOU :)~ cuz everyone there was smilin, bouncin, and 
the dance floor was packed.. ok at first it wasn't, it was a row of 
junglists sitting on a bench but once more people showed up and SWRV took 
the decks, people started to really move..and then when R.A.W. took over, 
he floor was packed!
	major props to step2k for the video game room in the back, and 
the soopercomfy couch :)~ and for giving proof that true junglism does 
still exist -- that a jungle party ccan go off without a shitload of 
cheeseheads walking around with attitude. 
AHH! i am in such love with the jungle scene up here, don't ever let it 
go bad!
	i'm serious, step2k last night was the sickest, raddest party 
i've been to in a LONG ASS TIME. no DOUBT. i'm not gonna be missing a 
step2k again in a LONG time. :)~ i don't think i've danced this hard 
ever! 
	the beats were phat, the skills were mad and the vibe was good.
see u all out,
lara:)~

There was a time when I said I wasn't going back to the ranch, but last night somehow changed my mind, and I'm glad I was a part of something that's been going strong for the past 6 years.

Joe Rice- Props to you guy! For those who missed out, you should give him peeps at Sunset today.  Always a treat to hear.

Daniel from Moontribe- Was it just me, the dust, or was he M.I.A. last night? Curious

Doran- Started me on the groove trip

Spun- A succession of four mixes that almost made me forget I was outdoors! Boy the shoes are ready to go! For those of you who went primitive- barefoot, I give you guys massive props.

Tony- Jamming tunes

Jon Williams- rocking out again; always a fav.

Soulstice PA- AWESOME! The boys in the breakin' circle to the left of the dj booth had some incredible moves in the rough sand pit.  The PA was just as vibe-filling.

What happened towards the end of their PA? Did someone accidentally blow something out, or was that meant to be?

Yes, it was a maze to find yer car in the morning, the dust getting into you system, if you wern't one with the mask, but the pros outnumbered the cons, and I'm glad I made it out this year.

Peace, and zzz's, Mr. 2

At 03:04 PM 7/3/97 -0700, you wrote:
>Hello all -
>
>I'm heading out to Southeast Asia in a month or two. I've heard that the
>Thai beaches are kinda like Goa with full moon parties and full-on beach
>raves.... was wondering if anyone had been out there recently and knew
>where I should go to find said parties? I've also heard that the police
>have been pretty harsh on cracking down on them....Any opinion on the scene
>out there? See or skip?
>

        I visited Vietnam a while back, and notice a Goa party which was
about to happen on a beach near my mom's house. The beach was called Nga Noc
Tran(you guys should hear me say it before you even try to pronounce it,
unless you know Vietnamese of course.) Unfortunately, I had to leave before
it. But I noticed there were lots of college students around(mostly
international business students trying to get the inside track on a new
market) and one told me there were Goa parties in Vietnam all the time,
which was weird because it is still communist. Although it's so rural I
don't know what they could do. I don't know about Thailand though, but it
could be similar. Vietnamese raves. Who would have guessed?

        -chris
