From: exodus@earthlink.net (Austin Woffington)
Subject: Freedom  (: another Perspective :)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Hey All!

Well I got to come up this weekend and do many things.  Dance my ass of was
my main objective and let me tell you I succeded..

About Freedom...

I feel I have come full circle after going to this party.  My first "real
rave" was Freedom in 93 and now I have completed 4 years of "the rest of my
life"..
I partied but I also thought (a lot) about the scene today and came to some
interesting conclusions..

First my party review...

We (my sister Lisa, Jil and friends) arived at 7.30 -the earliest I can
remember ariving at a party.  Sunset ceremony set the vibe and I was happy
all the way through till 9 am (13.5 hours of party WOW!)  We had a tent in
the front.
I think Doran started but for some reason I thought it was Josh.. The music
was fluid but most as inspiring as I had hoped.  Good mixing by Spun, Jon
Williams and Tony - Gotta lov 'em I always do.
I had seen many firends Sarvi, Jan, Raf, Dorena, Eric, etc. etc. I guess I
shouldn't list them all.  But I thought I was going to see alot more
recognizable faces.  (I guess many of my older friends are burnt out
already on the rave scene..)
Noel was sick.  I love that hardstep shit,  got me movin' but I kept
switching from him to tony untill Stacey Pullan came on.  I was tired and
thought I'll dance a few songs and rest but no!  SP would not let me!  My
body would not stop to this man's groove. I love that funky house.  That's
the shit I've been buying from the rekkid store but I don't have as much
quality music as he does.  The man was wicked with the switches and then
Roy Davis Jr. from chicago came on with some more of that funky chicago
house and he even sang to the key boards in the morning too.  Good artist.


        I caught some of Solustices live PA and it was good too but I
couldn't miss SP.  We all caught the sunrise on the hill, nice FREEDOM
touch..
People was all around great, friendly.  I met many people from around Cal.
The only person who gave me bad vibes was some one on this list... I know
cuz I saw the laminate and I tried to talk to him but he brushed me off
"what ever" and kept walking..  Hey, we all know there are assholes every
where, why not on the list too..  oh well.

There were no mounds this time which helped with the rock situation but no
trash cans so in the morning all the water bottles on the dance floor was a
big problem.  Was it me or did they blow some speakers by morning?  Did
anyone else see the guy dive off the scafolding where the laser was early
in the night?  IMHO there weren't enough toliets but I'm a guy so I
improvized.

The vibe: Great but it could have been better and this is where I started
to therorize.  I think that the reason there is no unity and togetherness
in the vibe is because of the diversity of the drugs in our scene.  There
were alot of people frying at this party which IMHO is not the best drug
for a positive vibe.  It can be very frightening, trippy, weird, and fun
all in one...
True the rocks and the dirt discurage many dancers but that doesn't mean
you can't wave your arms, shout, or spread the vibe...  Don't get me wrong
there were many dancers on the floor but there should have been more for
the music was the bomb!  I think it is the drugs that people do in this
scene that get people TOO f@#ked up to dance so they just want to sit and
listen or talk or trip or whatever... (For more on this read my post "Kevin
Saunderson in Lotus")

I've decided I'm going to concentrat more on the music side of our scene by
buying more rekkids and going to less parties.  I've already been doing
this because I live in SLO but I think "rave" is dieing.  Rave as in Peace,
Love Unity and most of all Respect for others, the space we party at and
especially yourself.  The Dancers are getting younger and they need to be
educated by our peers not the drug dealers or money hungery promoters.  I
think Martin does a good job of providing a good environment for the
Dancers but there are promoters out there that don't... It's happening all
over.

Well I haven't seen any events I want to look forward to so if you see me
it might be at an UG.  I might check out LA when I'm in Newport this August
but other wise... Take care all...

  "I love the developement of  '\_0_    Austin Woffington
   our music.  How we've tried   (e)\,
   to develope, y' know?         /|     Exodus@earthlink.com
   It grows.  That's why every   \ \    awoffing@oboe.calpoly.edu
   day people come forward with  ~ ~
   new songs.  Music goes on forever."
                               -Bob Marley

is dried. But it basically means the plant probably as much as it needed to
be, so most of the THC breaks down into CBNs, so more is needed to get high,
which is also different. So it could be made, but why?

---canton <canton@resrocket.com> wrote:
>
> >you sound like me.
> >you're not from around here, are you?

> >p.s. i've gotten used to it now. i even got a theory. anybody
> >interested?

> I am. Go fer it.

o.k., here goes:
iris's theory on the difference between english and sf rave culture: 

(i'm just saying this again: this is a highly subjective view based on
my limited experience of both scenes. so don't hack me to pieces right
away. i'd appreciate some constructive input on this. i'm also not
judging or declaring one *better* than the other. i'm just theorizing.
we're talking different cultures here. ...and i like them both.:)

it took us 4 weeks to figure out that we were taking the wrong drugs.
e just doesn't go w/ the music here. the music is generally slower and
softer here. house and trance goes much better w/ acid. e is a drug
for stomping and bouncing. it requires hard fast music. acid is an
introvert drug while e is an extrovert drug. in england ravers don't
generally take acid at raves, everybody is on e, which binds the whole
mass of ravers into one, due to the enhancement of the empathic and
extrovert aspects. acid is a lonely drug and the house and trance
music takes you on this trip of your own. i think this is why people
here dance alone or in small groups detached from the world around
them. 

so why, i was wondering, do people here like it slow and introvert.
why is the rave scene here based on an acid experience rather than an
e experience. it's obvious. california is the birthplace of the acid
and hippie culture of the 60s. where do you think the candy raver
phenomenon comes from? am i the only one that thinks that candy ravers
are the hippies of the 90s? there is a strong acid/hippie tradition
here which is detectable in the preference for slow spacey music and
the smileys, colors, candies, love and peace and hugs and happiness.
oh, and aliens! england doesn't have this acid history, at least not
to the same degree. you guys are hovering above the earth while
english ravers are stomping the ground.

does that make sense? i'd love some input.

iris

Subject: Re: acid rave culture - my theory
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

At 1:32 AM 7/9/97, Iris + Ben wrote:
>o.k., here goes:
>iris's theory on the difference between english and sf rave culture:
>
>(i'm just saying this again: this is a highly subjective view based on
>my limited experience of both scenes. so don't hack me to pieces right
>away. i'd appreciate some constructive input on this. i'm also not
>judging or declaring one *better* than the other. i'm just theorizing.
>we're talking different cultures here. ...and i like them both.:)
>
>it took us 4 weeks to figure out that we were taking the wrong drugs.
>e just doesn't go w/ the music here. the music is generally slower and
>softer here. house and trance goes much better w/ acid. e is a drug
>for stomping and bouncing. it requires hard fast music. acid is an
>introvert drug while e is an extrovert drug. in england ravers don't
>generally take acid at raves, everybody is on e, which binds the whole
>mass of ravers into one, due to the enhancement of the empathic and
>extrovert aspects. acid is a lonely drug and the house and trance
>music takes you on this trip of your own. i think this is why people
>here dance alone or in small groups detached from the world around
>them.

hmmmm.... i'll have to agree with you about e binding ppl together - and i
really prefer that atmosphere to one in which everyone is off in their own
world. this togetherness is what makes a party, imo. and from my own
experience, e really does turn me into the energizer bunny - i keep going,
and going, and going! gotta love it! i love the feeling i get when i'm
dancing around a room and making eye contact with other dancing maniacs -
it's a unified, happy feeling. warm fuzzy, almost, but a bit harder.
>
>so why, i was wondering, do people here like it slow and introvert.
>why is the rave scene here based on an acid experience rather than an
>e experience. it's obvious. california is the birthplace of the acid
>and hippie culture of the 60s. where do you think the candy raver
>phenomenon comes from? am i the only one that thinks that candy ravers
>are the hippies of the 90s? there is a strong acid/hippie tradition
>here which is detectable in the preference for slow spacey music and
>the smileys, colors, candies, love and peace and hugs and happiness.
>oh, and aliens! england doesn't have this acid history, at least not
>to the same degree. you guys are hovering above the earth while
>english ravers are stomping the ground.

makes sense to me.... my experience in other places has been primarily with
e (or both), and judging from my one sole acid trip at a party - there
really is a different feeling produced. anyway, ppl here are a bit more
laid back - on the east coast we're all a bit more on edge, i think. but
maybe too, it's economics. e costs a hell of a lot more than a little piece
of paper. and my theory on the candy: when you're dancing your ass off all
night your body craves glucose in a big way. sugar is an instant fix. you
can tell when you need it if you start getting a headache. orange juice,
too. never mind the need to have something in your mouth!

cheers - e. :)

                                                               - Nan Goldin

                                              - John Stuart Mill (1806-1873)

Subject: The woopy ball rememebered
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Hi-

I was hanging out with a friend last week and he says,'Hey do you
remember the Woopy Ball??'. 

The woopy ball was a party in march of 92 that a friend of mine was
helping out at- a 2 day warehouse sleepover, basically. Even though I
didn't go, I still have the flier (a cheesy 2-color deal with dr.seuss
guy on front) and totally associate it with my early days of partying.

So yesterday I decided to check out the very first post to sfr in
march of 92.Nostalia time, check this out:

----------------------

From bbehlen Wed Mar  4 11:18:33 1992
From: bbehlen (Vitamin B)
Date: Wed, 4 Mar 92 11:18:24 -0800
Subject: To start things off...


        Here's a list of some upcoming events I've heard about...

        Friday March 6th through Sunday March 8th - The WOOPY BALL - 
                yes, a weekend-long rave, taking place in Oakland.
                info: 1-800-894-9001. Should we have a meeting place?

        Friday March 6th - Primal Scream at the Warfield.
                okay, I know this isn't exactly "underground", but it's
                being billed as a rave, and rumors exist that the Orb
is
                gonna be there, too.....

        Saturday, March 7th - The Gathering
                This sounds great. Jeno, Garth, and Josh. 415-267-4800

        Friday, March 13th - Lunacy - 510-874-4924. Scott Hardkiss'll
be there.

        Friday, March 21st  - The Utopia Project presents Matrix - 
                510-874-4955

        I'd elaborate on each of them but I have to go to class in
about
ten minutes.....:)

        Wow! 35 subscribers in 24 hours! This may get gigantic......

        Brian

--------------------------------

(Sorry Brian, I don't know how many times this has been posted)

Anyways, I started browsing through the messages for that first month
of SFR and I was so psyched! People were posting things like "I just
bought a cd by some band named the orb"- no flames, just a bunch of
people psyched on the music and the scene. 

Noah was telling me yesterday about the first party SFR ever threw at
bonnie dunes...he said there were SOOO many people. It really sounded
like a community. Today, on the other hand, sometimes sfr feels like
several communities all bussed into the same place. 

Don't extract too much out of this. I'm more than aware of the reasons
why everything is different now...in some ways for better and in some
ways for worse. I just wanted to share my little blast of nostalgia.

-alex

I went to party in Thailland and Bali and Hong Kong and Vietnam last year.
Spent 3 months in search of the perfect party...wouldn't you know I found it
in Florida.

Phuket, Chang Ma are great but Pat Pong..now there is a story. Bali...not
worth the trip unless you are in the area. Oh yes...the Aussies know how to
party. Check out Hamilton Island in the Barrier Reef. We danced all night
then went skydiving while on E and then the next day went diving on the
reef..also a trip when you are still flying from the night before.

I have been back to Australia once and Thailand twice. Definately recommend
it. Wonder how Hong Kong is going to change....can you see all those Maoists
raving???

Neal

Received: from [205.178.40.25] (205.178.40.25) by ilpostino.stormtech.com
 (Rockliffe SMTPRA 1.2.2) with ESMTP id <B0000110354@ilpostino.stormtech.com>;
 Wed, 09 Jul 1997 11:36:03 -0700
X-Sender: branka@pop.sirius.com
Message-Id: <v03102801afe98732e9c1@[205.178.40.25]>
In-Reply-To: <19970709083235.7218.rocketmail@send1.rocketmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 9 Jul 1997 11:35:04 -0700
To: Iris + Ben <jarmin@rocketmail.com>, canton <canton@resrocket.com>,
        bert@laren.k.easynet.co.uk
From: *B* <branka@sirius.com>
Subject: Re: acid rave culture - my theory
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

>it took us 4 weeks to figure out that we were taking the wrong drugs.
>e just doesn't go w/ the music here. the music is generally slower and
>softer here. house and trance goes much better w/ acid. e is a drug
>for stomping and bouncing. it requires hard fast music. acid is an
>introvert drug while e is an extrovert drug. in england ravers don't
>generally take acid at raves, everybody is on e, which binds the whole
>mass of ravers into one, due to the enhancement of the empathic and
>extrovert aspects. acid is a lonely drug and the house and trance
>music takes you on this trip of your own. i think this is why people
>here dance alone or in small groups detached from the world around
>them.

My view on your view :).  Gathered from observations at parties in this
area, observing people who engage in both activities etc.

I don't agree that A is a drug for slower music than E.  I think it's the
other way around :).  A is more aggressive, and gives (some) people more
energy to dance to hard-ass sets (that are sometimes very hard to find at
SF parties).

Also, I think that A isn't a lonely drug (unless you are way out of you
head, but the same happens if you are way out of your head on E or whatever
else).  Some people are more talkative on A (true, they get witty and
sometimes talk shit - although it's humorous if you like that kind of
humor), less shy, dance more (if the music is good) etc.

>so why, i was wondering, do people here like it slow and introvert.
>why is the rave scene here based on an acid experience rather than an
>e experience.

Hmmm...  Maybe I haven't been to parties in many other places, but seems to
me that there is still a significant amount of E over A.

>it's obvious. california is the birthplace of the acid
>and hippie culture of the 60s. where do you think the candy raver
>phenomenon comes from?

I think candy ravers are influenced by E more than A :).  Can't imagine
many people on A who would want to walk around covered in glitter, have
tons of things hanging of them, those big lashes etc - many people can't be
bothered while on A - maybe I'm wrong.

>there is a strong acid/hippie tradition
>here which is detectable in the preference for slow spacey music and
>the smileys, colors, candies, love and peace and hugs and happiness.
>oh, and aliens! england doesn't have this acid history, at least not
>to the same degree. you guys are hovering above the earth while
>english ravers are stomping the ground.

Hugs are IMO more of an E thing than an A thing (the touchy stuff is more
appealing from sweaty people you don't know on E rather than A).

Anyway, it's interesting to compare observations and views...

=) *B*

---Beth Jackson <goumada@gene.COM> wrote:

> Do you find that ravers in the UK tend to be older?

no, i think the age groups represented at raves here and in england
are the same, they just look younger here because of the fluff and
candy and glitter and toys. to be honest i don't quite understand why
especially women want to make themselves look like little girlies. i
know it's cute and fun and everything and fun to look at and a release
for the tenseness (am i making words up?) of everyday life, i'd just
personally rather go for tank girl then barbie. (lots of love to my
favorite candy ravers: rubilicious and julie fairy princess :)

> But I do think ravers are the hippies
> of the 90's.  And that e is the acid of the 90's - =)

i don't think e is the acid of the 90s. acid is the acid of the 90s :)

>  Techno music is starting
> to become more and more widely appeciated. 

do you really think that the laid back san franciscans will ever dance
to 180 to 240 bps? (hi gabber girl!)

> I think if ravers had more of a
> united political agenda we'd have a revolution on our hands.

yeah, but we don't all need to dance to the same music. i'm quite
happy to dance to happy hardcore and techno at home and to trance here
in sf (it's just the comeback of disco that does my head in, but
that's a matter of taste). how boring would the rave scene be if it
was the same all over. i kind of enjoy the culture here.
politics? hmmm...the only politics i see in the rave scene is the
lets-do-it-anyway or how-dare-they-outlaw-fun attitude. it's a
hedonistic not a political movement.

i love you all. this vacation has been a lot of fun so far. thanks for
being so nice to us. would anybody like to come to a new years eve
rave in england?

iris

On Tue, 8 Jul 1997, Gabber Girl wrote:

> HI EVERYBODY!!!
> 
> My name is Charmayne, but most people know me as the Gabber Girl.  I just
> joined your list recently . . . I'm from Minneapolis, living in Chicago
> right now with my boyfriend Matter.  We are moving to Oakland, CA at the
> end of the week!!!  I'm really looking forward to being a part of the bay
> area scene!  I went to "Trust:Surrender", and it was the best event I've
> ever been to.  The people were so  great!  Down to earth, smart,
> happy--well, you know who you are!  I hadn't been to a party near that fun
> since the early 1800's . . .
> 
> About me:
> I appreciate every kind of music(despite all my jokes about house), but I'm
> a dj that likes extremes--hard acid, hard gabber, noisecore, speedcore,
> gaabbahaus, old school midwest style hard tekno, and intense, mental
> jungle.  Anything that your mother would not approve of!  I like gettin
> under people's skins as much as I love makin people dance!  Do not be
> afraid--I won't hurt you!  Just cuz hardcore is my favorite doesn't make me
> an icky person.
> 
> In Minneapolis, I was promoting small-scale hardcore events as Warrior
> Princess Productions.  That's how I met Matter--he did a live pa at my last
> party.  We were just crazy enough for each other that it worked out!
>

To: bert@laren.k.easynet.co.uk, canton@resrocket.com, emdash@grin.net,
        jarmin@rocketmail.com
Subject: Re: acid rave culture - my theory
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

>so why, i was wondering, do people here like it slow and introvert.
>why is the rave scene here based on an acid experience rather than an
>e experience.

	Well, I don't know if I agree that the drugs are the reason.
First of all, there are *plenty* of e parties here. At least half or
more of the people at these things tend to dissolve into people piles
(see - ambient rooms) or get into hand orgies, or maybe just run around
hugging everybody. The point is - just because everybody's on e doesn't
mean that everybody's dancing.

	Also, I've been to a *lot* of acid parties where many/most
people were dancing, dissolving ego bundaries in a communal experience.

	I think maybe Americans are just more individualistic.

	Also - raves are more mainstream in the UK than they are here.
People who go to raves in the US are looking for something different,
which may just mean that they're disinclined by mature to do whatever
everybody else is doing.

On Tue, 08 Jul 1997 17:58:21 -0700 FREAK ZONE! <seanc@pacbell.net>
writes:
>
>>I dunno...is it curing or is it THC?  I say curing, anyone else?


the whole point of paying attention to pot plants.   watering, pulling
males, training,  adding co2, grooming,  and very importantly curing and
proper storage,  is to produce as much THC in the plant as possible.  all
plants are different and the genetic makeup of the plant is important, 
but i have smoked from two plants that are genetically identical (cloned)
and found that one was much better because of the grower's attention to
the plant.    but back to the brown question. leave it alone.  sometimes
brown comes across the border in gas tanks or on the tires of cars.   you
just have no idea what it has been through.

ohmigod, the whoopy ball.
my very first rave. i remember sitting and playing with flourescent paint
and freaking out about all the folks in floppy hats. and someone gave me a
candy necklace and i was hooked.

my, times have changed. if there was an all-weekend rave now it'd probably
be at Great America, would cost 80 bucks, and about 200,000 people would
show up. and it'd be busted by morning #1. or maybe i'm just being jaded?

btw, i was trying to find the old sfraves archives last week, but they were
all in gzip format and i could get 'em to open. are there hidden ones that
aren't in that format?

janelle

Alex Ward wrote:
> 
> Hi-
> 
> I was hanging out with a friend last week and he says,'Hey do you
> remember the Woopy Ball??'.
> 
> The woopy ball was a party in march of 92 that a friend of mine was
> helping out at- a 2 day warehouse sleepover, basically. Even though I
> didn't go, I still have the flier (a cheesy 2-color deal with dr.seuss
> guy on front) and totally associate it with my early days of partying.

WOW, Do I ever remember that party!  It was DECEDENT, to say the least. 
The location was at Paradine Studios, on San leandro st.  Some guy
manded Mark used to run the place.  It was also a haven for the local
chapter of the Hells Angels, and other weird things that went on in
there.  That place was wild, part junkyard, part live work space and
many diferent rooms always for rent, and there was always something
hapening there.  I remember that i went to a few small weeklies that
they had there on tuesday nights in the back area, next to this trailer
that the dj would spin out off.  There were several parties that hapened
there...but none of wichy i can remeber, even though i went to all of
them :)
  I loved the whoopy ball... I had such a good time.  the barbaques, the
tents, the matress pitt, the music... it was all so new at the time
(Only my second year raving) that i don't think i will ever forget the
feeling and memory.  48 hours of..... EVERYTHING you can imagine!  And
even though it was so disorganized, everything just seemed to have
fallen into place.  Thats what made it so much fun.  Thanks for the
memories alex :)

keep it real

Ray Vonie

Yeah- *nods*

Also, it's wrong to say that a competitive society is not a natural
society: you find more examples of competition in nature (i.e. outdoors,
plants and animals, etc.) than you do among people--plants compete for
sunlight, animals compete for territory, food, and grazing territory, in
the exacty same ways that human beings compete.  I know what you're trying
to say, megan, and I'm not flaming you or anything, but to me, capitalism
is the most 'natural' of all forms of social structure.  I'm certainly not
saying it's perfect--but it is the most natural: it demands both
competition and cooperation in equal amounts.  

peace and love and healthy competition,
Timothy


Tim McIntyre
pager: (415) 253-8624
email to pager: tim.page@taos.com

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: acid rave culture - my theory
Author:  sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org at SMTPGATE
Date:    7/9/97 11:35 AM


>it took us 4 weeks to figure out that we were taking the wrong drugs.
>e just doesn't go w/ the music here. the music is generally slower and
>softer here. house and trance goes much better w/ acid. e is a drug
>for stomping and bouncing. it requires hard fast music. acid is an
>introvert drug while e is an extrovert drug. in england ravers don't
>generally take acid at raves, everybody is on e, which binds the whole
>mass of ravers into one, due to the enhancement of the empathic and
>extrovert aspects. acid is a lonely drug and the house and trance
>music takes you on this trip of your own. i think this is why people
>here dance alone or in small groups detached from the world around
>them.

My view on your view :).  Gathered from observations at parties in this
area, observing people who engage in both activities etc.

I don't agree that A is a drug for slower music than E.  I think it's the
other way around :).  A is more aggressive, and gives (some) people more
energy to dance to hard-ass sets (that are sometimes very hard to find at
SF parties).

Also, I think that A isn't a lonely drug (unless you are way out of you
head, but the same happens if you are way out of your head on E or whatever
else).  Some people are more talkative on A (true, they get witty and
sometimes talk shit - although it's humorous if you like that kind of
humor), less shy, dance more (if the music is good) etc.

>so why, i was wondering, do people here like it slow and introvert.
>why is the rave scene here based on an acid experience rather than an
>e experience.

Hmmm...  Maybe I haven't been to parties in many other places, but seems to
me that there is still a significant amount of E over A.

>it's obvious. california is the birthplace of the acid
>and hippie culture of the 60s. where do you think the candy raver
>phenomenon comes from?

I think candy ravers are influenced by E more than A :).  Can't imagine
many people on A who would want to walk around covered in glitter, have
tons of things hanging of them, those big lashes etc - many people can't be
bothered while on A - maybe I'm wrong.

>there is a strong acid/hippie tradition
>here which is detectable in the preference for slow spacey music and
>the smileys, colors, candies, love and peace and hugs and happiness.
>oh, and aliens! england doesn't have this acid history, at least not
>to the same degree. you guys are hovering above the earth while
>english ravers are stomping the ground.

Hugs are IMO more of an E thing than an A thing (the touchy stuff is more
appealing from sweaty people you don't know on E rather than A).

Anyway, it's interesting to compare observations and views...

=) *B*

YES! finally!
we've been here 6 weeks now and still haven't set a foot outside the
bay area. what are we going to tell the folks back home?

them: "how was the trip to the states? what did you do?" 

us: "we were in san francisco for 10 weeks."

them: "what? you didn't go see yosemite, the famous redwood forests,
seqouia trees, or drive to the grand canyon or to las vegas or
...(insert other touristy stuff)... what were you doing all the time?"

us: "oh, you know, hanging out with people, going to parties, spending
5 hours a day reading sfraves..." i don't think they'd understand.

now, the problem is, we haven't got a car, but if someone would be
willing to give us a ride, we'd share gas and driving. we've got a
tent and sleeping bags. oh and can we do it before august 5th,
pleeeease?

...and we would finally meet foolish fish, after we missed him 3 times
now!

oh exitement!
iris

Rob Rayle wrote:
> 
> >so why, i was wondering, do people here like it slow and introvert.
> >why is the rave scene here based on an acid experience rather than an
> >e experience.
> 
>         Well, I don't know if I agree that the drugs are the reason.
> First of all, there are *plenty* of e parties here. At least half or
> more of the people at these things tend to dissolve into people piles
> (see - ambient rooms) or get into hand orgies, or maybe just run around
> hugging everybody. The point is - just because everybody's on e doesn't
> mean that everybody's dancing.

It's important to consider the difference in the qualities between whats
here and whats in the UK. From what I understand, E is much much more
pure in the UK than here. I don't think many people in the SF scene have
a lot of experience with pure 100% like-mom-used-to-make E. Hence,
peoples reaction to it is different. It would be better to consider the
E here and E in the UK to be different drugs. I mean, everyone I've talk
to says it's MUCH better over there. That makes a difference.

On Wed, 9 Jul 1997, Rob Rayle wrote:

> 	I think maybe Americans are just more individualistic.

	That is a real generalization... Maybe Sfians (though I would
disagree with that even)... I have met people I think are very
individualistic on both sides of the ocean. I have also met tons of people
that conform to the set way of being on both sides of the ocean. I have
seen it in raves here and the UK. I don't know if this is meant as an
observation or a judgement or both, but in reference to parties
themselves, I have seen as much if not more new inventitive themes/stuff 
done at the parties in the UK than here in SF... But then, maybe I am just
missing stuff here and saw the most diverse range that existed when I
was there...


> 	Also - raves are more mainstream in the UK than they are here.
> People who go to raves in the US are looking for something different,
> which may just mean that they're disinclined by mature to do whatever
> everybody else is doing.

	Yes and no... There are raves that are way out of the mainstream,
kind of like you give up all your shit to follow them and be a part of
them... Then also, there are a lot of students over there going out to
raves... Raves are accepted as being part of the culture there, here they
stand for shitty, boring music and a bunch of wierd drugged out people
either being aggressive, trying to be 2 years old so to shirk
responsiblity for themselves, stuck in the dayglo era, or too drugged out
to notice that they are associating with such types (hmmm, I am sure I am
leaving out one or two categories of "those who attend raves").

	Here are a few other thoughts... It rains a lot in the UK. One
spends a lot of time indoors and you get a bit of energy pent of this
way...

	The British have their heads screwed on pretty fucking straight
eariler in life. Maybe cause when you're 18 you better fucking start
scrounging for yourself (ie, they are not as protected as we americans so
they "mature" quickier)...

	The British I have met and dealt with (including a bunch of
average adults with kids near hexham....) are less centered on what you
say you do and seem to be able to see what type of person you are... Ok, I
assume some wankers out there would look at me with my hair and term me a
worthless traveler, no good squatter... They seem less reactionary and
more grounded in experience (?)... Maybe that has something to do with
their tv programming, isn't really not quite so programming...

	People are people in the european derived world. There will always
be those that into putting up a good show, and those that ould care less
about the show...

	Things (material goods) in general cost more to purchase, cost
more to run (though taxes and power bills and petrol prices and the such)
so people seem to tend to pool their resources a hell of a lot better than
they do in the states (at least those that I have met)... Going out often
meant crashing at someone's flat, or heading to the train station/tube
station and trying to keep one another up til the train came and we
waddled on board...

	It's very green there...

	We are different cultures. Right now in the Bay Area, people tend
to like to do other things then dance at parties (much to the dismay of
those trying to build the energy off of each other til it shoots out of
them, travels round the world and descends back into the pulsing crowd)...
I know there are exceptions to this, though some of those exceptions seem
to be into a single way of getting there... Take what you will, do what
you will I suppose...

dave

Hey y'all.
	Damn, that Freedom thing sounded hella cool.  How come it's always so
jarring switching from one scene to another?  Well guys I don't know any of ya
but I take it from reading the hundreds of messages pouring into my box (sheesh
guys, i mean i forgot to check my email one day and the next day i was greeted
by 170 of your messages!).  Anyhow, from my reading I take it that this FREE
LOVE thing's gonna be pretty cool.  Right?
	What I'm especially waiting for is news of KOXBOX (Blue Room
Released)...
	I've been reading about this whole drug controversy discussion yer
having and it seems this way to me:  however much i love 'em, i've actually
gone sober to some raves.  somehow i've been designated as driver... such are
the downs of car-ownership.  but ya know, all of those raves i really look back
on as great.., sure i got tired faster, but the music just courses through
one's system and keeps it alive.  not proof, but perhaps a suggestion that a
young'un such as this 19 yr old finds a lot in what you nostalgic ravers seem
to be calling 'the good old days'.
not that nostalgia isn't a wonderful thing.
	so unless anyone has any suggestions as to what else a portlander who
loves hardcore, goa, and trance should be doing with the time - short of
working, sigh - then i'll hopefully meet some of you at this True Love event.
	until then merry messagemaking,
Elise

On Wednesday, July 9, 1997 Alex Ward wrote:

>
>Hi-
>
>I was hanging out with a friend last week and he says,'Hey do you
>remember the Woopy Ball??'. 
>
>The woopy ball was a party in march of 92 that a friend of mine was
>helping out at- a 2 day warehouse sleepover, basically. Even though I
>didn't go, I still have the flier (a cheesy 2-color deal with dr.seuss
>guy on front) and totally associate it with my early days of partying.


Most definately!  My first massive party and hit* I was just blown away 
by the whole thing:) I was just coming out of the industrial scene and 
basically didn't care for techno music.  But because my dear friend had 
found a new scene, she persuaded me a night of fun and excitement:) I'm 
very glad I was open to try it.  I still have my best friend and the 
deep love and respect for our raving community.  
5+ years of raving and still going strong!  Since some of us are on a 
nostalgia kick, does anyone remember the Toontown - Jan, 92?

DEAR ALL,
Two thing's:
1).  On July 16th 1997 Spiral Tribe, the original UK underground dance
massive, are doing a one night only party in SF.  $10; 21+.  If you have
any interest in what parties where like back in London in 1990/1/2/3 you
should check it out.
2).  ALSO:  S.P.A.Z. and Spiral Tribe are also doing a massive free
festival this weekend - 11th and 12th of July 1997 - up in the hills
outside Eugiene, Oregon.  This party will be featuring Spiral Tribe's 45k
sound system as well as Jungle and Chill-out tents.  As I was up in Oregon
last weekend for the Rainbow gathering (which was okay - not great, just
okay) I saw the site and it is beautiful and there are an awful of
people who are going to go; especially from the Rainbow gathering and from
Seatlle/Portland area.  In short, it's going to be massive.  I urge
everyone on this list to go because it does not get any more intence or
old school as this.  they will also be doing another festival in the bay
area on the weekend following the July 16th party.
If anyone is interested in going to the Oregon festival (it will be about
an eight hour drive) please call me, Tristan, at 415-252-0454 because I
need a ride and I know how to get their (I have gas $ etc).  It really
should be a great free weekend of great music and beautiful evironments.

For more info on all of these events call 1-888-984-2075.

Peace out,
Tristan.
sandoz@sfsu.edu

hi everyone!!

While in Portland a few weeks ago I picked up a snazzy-looking free mag 
called SWEATER.  It just started being published and I haven't seen it in 
the bay area yet, but I also haven't been looking so it might be here.  
It's a pretty neat rave/club mag.  In the first issue were interviews 
with the Hardkiss bros., Doc Martin, Daft Punk, and a few other DJs.  The 
magazine also had an interesting fashion layout and interviews with a 
couple fashion designers (not neccessarily ones who design 
"typical" rave wear, a plus in my book) including the guy who design the 
W&LT label, some cool stuff.  And of course there were reviews of every 
new record most of which I thought were fairly well written.  The 
articles in all were pretty good, if a little short, except for the daft 
punk one which went on for pages and I just lost all interest after the 
first few paragraphs, those daft punk boys are a bit odd, maybe it's 
language barrier?  At any rate, I would call it a (skinnier) fashion 
concious XLR8R and would recomend it.  two pinkies up....

Megan          Czefir

My name is Joel. Kevin asked me to mention that I was using his account. 
I want to describe a feeling of unity I remember from playing music with
different groups of people. At a point, when the whole band is
improvising, certain psychological barriers between the members are
naturaly and intuitively abandoned. These barriers relate to self.  the
individual no longer exists to represent the individual but to express the
time and harmony so the melody can exist. This time , harmony and melody
exist without the musician or the band. So, as the individual becomes more
in tune and in time, they can relate to musicians who have come and gone
and who are here and who will come. It seems so peacefull to me to give
time and harmony so a melody can exist.If one only plays a single note
but they play in time with the other musicians, and the other musicians
have good time and can make the changes(the harmony) work around that
note, then, for a moment that person can feel the unity of which
I speak.  The psychological barriers I mentioned pretain to the
individuals ability to appreciate what little they can do to support
the melody. If the individual is playing the melody then their ability to
appreciate the chord progression and the feeling of the time, that the
rest of the group is creating will cause an interaction of their minds.
The music may be there without the musician but the acoustic instrument
will not play itself.

 This interaction of minds at an improvisationallevel can
only be described by itself. You have to be there to hear it. It won't 
be on the recording.  There are basic principles that exist when any music
is being created. Any one, even a deaf mute person can learn these
principles and have a voice. Each aspect of music that has time, melody, 
harmony and formm can be described as a voice. So, as one developes their
voice for music, people who are furthur along will recognize you  
and if you are improvising they may attempt to mentor your efforts.
This is when the psychological barriers come back and unity can be lost.
There is only so much a person can give and only so much a person can
take. When the music is playing unity is expressed in the harmony and
melody and the time they exist in.   when the music stops the musician
can attempt to continue hearing the chords, melody and time.  Eventually,
if one is persistent, thoughtfulness will afford the knowledge of the
harmony just before it happens. No one can take that away. We are all
capable. Listening, practicing and playing are all it takes. There is no
hurry. I apologize for going on and on.  This is my goal. to be able to
hear and play music regardless of the instrument. I'm not a purist, I like 
all music especially dance music, if its funky, all the better.

				peace

and LO and BEHOLD i see a guy, saying "excuse me while i go hug a tree!"

the guy run up to a tree and hug it like almost getting ON the tree
and i go
HOLY FUCK! THAT'S OUR SPENCER FROM SFRAVES WHO THROWS WARMTH!
good to see we're representin' in the REAL WORLD Casting, he made it as a 
Semi-Finalist!

you go boy, HUG THAT TREE! :)~

when he was a semi-finalist "i know i'm already on the show, it's set in 
the cosmos"
Spencer, yer DOPE! :)~
it was rad!
love

ones that

> At 9:50 AM -0700 7/9/97, Alex Ward wrote:
> >Hi-
> >
> >I was hanging out with a friend last week and he says,'Hey do you
> >remember the Woopy Ball??'.
> >
> >The woopy ball was a party in march of 92 that a friend of mine was
> >helping out at- a 2 day warehouse sleepover, basically. Even though
I
> >didn't go, I still have the flier (a cheesy 2-color deal with
dr.seuss
> >guy on front) and totally associate it with my early days of
partying.
> >
> >So yesterday I decided to check out the very first post to sfr in
> >march of 92.Nostalia time, check this out:
> >
> >----------------------
> >
> >>From bbehlen Wed Mar  4 11:18:33 1992
> >From: bbehlen (Vitamin B)
> >Date: Wed, 4 Mar 92 11:18:24 -0800
> >Subject: To start things off...
> >
> >
> >        Here's a list of some upcoming events I've heard about...
> >
> >        Friday March 6th through Sunday March 8th - The WOOPY BALL -
> >                yes, a weekend-long rave, taking place in Oakland.
> >                info: 1-800-894-9001. Should we have a meeting
place?
> >
> >        Friday March 6th - Primal Scream at the Warfield.
> >                okay, I know this isn't exactly "underground", but
it's
> >                being billed as a rave, and rumors exist that the
Orb
> >is
> >                gonna be there, too.....
> >
> >        Saturday, March 7th - The Gathering
> >                This sounds great. Jeno, Garth, and Josh.
415-267-4800
> >
> >        Friday, March 13th - Lunacy - 510-874-4924. Scott
Hardkiss'll
> >be there.
> >
> >        Friday, March 21st  - The Utopia Project presents Matrix -
> >                510-874-4955
> >
> >        I'd elaborate on each of them but I have to go to class in
> >about
> >ten minutes.....:)
> >
> >        Wow! 35 subscribers in 24 hours! This may get gigantic......
> >
> >        Brian
> >
> >--------------------------------
> >
> >(Sorry Brian, I don't know how many times this has been posted)
> >
> >Anyways, I started browsing through the messages for that first
month
> >of SFR and I was so psyched! People were posting things like "I just
> >bought a cd by some band named the orb"- no flames, just a bunch of
> >people psyched on the music and the scene.
> >
> >Noah was telling me yesterday about the first party SFR ever threw
at
> >bonnie dunes...he said there were SOOO many people. It really
sounded
> >like a community. Today, on the other hand, sometimes sfr feels like
> >several communities all bussed into the same place.
> >
> >Don't extract too much out of this. I'm more than aware of the
reasons
> >why everything is different now...in some ways for better and in
some
> >ways for worse. I just wanted to share my little blast of nostalgia.
> >
> >-alex

Yeah that was a killer party... and I heard about it through SFRaves...
I only went to one night of it, but I had a great time. I was one of
the initial subscribers -- just reading ba.music newsgroup to find out
what was going in the SF scene. Having had a truly wonderful time
raving in Ibiza and London in the summer of '88... I was thinking to
myself, gee, it's too bad they don't have parties like this here in the
Bay Area... and then I saw BrianB's post to ba.music and SFRaves came
along and I started finding out where the parties were, and so on and
so forth...

PS: speaking of killer parties, Stompy on 7/4/97 kicked ass! Old school
and new out in force, tearing it up. Nothing better than a party where
they're playing top-notch House music. Mark Green's set was like being
in a gospel church where everybody's whoopin it up arms in the air and
vibe-filled and dancing like there's no tomorrow -- it was like there
was a shiny new god up in the sky and people were feeling the spirit
move them. That's house music for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

Stompy! This was an awesome party, and Mark Grant really ripped it up.
Anyone know where he's based out of? Is he out of chicago?

I have to say that stompy is one of my fav parties and always has been.
This is one party that could put the whole club vs. rave debate to rest. If
you haven't been, you should, and if you haven't been in a while, get your
ass down there and shake it!

Speaking of guidance, I've read a review of a CD they just put out called
"Hi Fidelity House, Imprint One." A friend also told me really good things
about this. I can't find it ANYwhere. Anyone got any leads?? If it's
anything like the stuff that Grant was spinning, I've gotta have it.

Here Here for Stompy!

Stompy seems to be the one last bastion for no-nonsense, chunky funky house 
on a phat system!  I'd highly reccommend all house-heads check one out.

As for Mark Grant, he is out of Chicago, and has done lots of remixes as 
well as original tracks.  Check him on out Casual on the recent Andre 
Harris EP and the Chicago Connection EP.  And that one on Guidance is _the 
kind_.

On the Stompy note, does anyone know what's up with Johnny (aka Jonene)? 
 That guy's got the sweet deep sound I love so much, but aside from the 
occasional Stompy, I don't see him out anywhere.  Anyone know where he's 
been playing lately?  He's supposed to have a mixtape (recorded at a Stompy 
a few months back) out, but it's not in any stores.

Thoughts?

Oliver

On Wed, 9 Jul 1997, Just Another Flavor wrote:

> While in Portland a few weeks ago I picked up a snazzy-looking free mag 
> called SWEATER.  It just started being published and I haven't seen it in 
> the bay area yet, but I also haven't been looking so it might be here.  
> It's a pretty neat rave/club mag.  In the first issue were interviews 
> with the Hardkiss bros., Doc Martin, Daft Punk, and a few other DJs.  The 
> magazine also had an interesting fashion layout and interviews with a 
> couple fashion designers (not neccessarily ones who design 
> "typical" rave wear, a plus in my book) including the guy who design the 
> W&LT label, some cool stuff.  And of course there were reviews of every 
> new record most of which I thought were fairly well written.  The 
> articles in all were pretty good, if a little short, except for the daft 
> punk one which went on for pages and I just lost all interest after the 
> first few paragraphs, those daft punk boys are a bit odd, maybe it's 
> language barrier?  At any rate, I would call it a (skinnier) fashion 
> concious XLR8R and would recomend it.  two pinkies up....

you forgot to mention the mega corporate advertising, lots and lots
of full and double page glossy ads for camel, jim beam, harmon/kardon,
absolut, altoids, kahlua, beefeater, bacardi, etc... it's more like
a yuppie lifestyle/fashion mag with some "electronica(tm)" articles
and reviews. i haven't read it so i can't comment on the quality
of the writing, but i was kinda suprised to see reviews of some more
relatively obscure stuff along with the usual chem. bros, orb, daft
punk, etc...

it's free (it better be with all of that $$ coming in from those ads,
i can't imagine actually paying for it), but xlr8r it is NOT.  no
comparison really...

Andy

need the cash for other investments (not to mention the space in
my studio).... so I'm parting with some old friends that some of
you might recognize and want to give a good home to....

ALL my stuff is well cared for one owner stuff ( I even have receipts)

Sequential Pro-1  perfect condition, all knobs etc. manuals incl service
                  have a home-built wooden case for
it....                     $400

Roland SH-09/ with digital sequencer   The SH-09 is a forerunner to the
                 SH-101 - great bass line synthe with the 256 step
sequencer
                 a lot like the pro -1 with it.... manuals etc..
both          $450

Roland D-50    - classic digital synthe - with anvil
case                      $500

Yamaha DX-9    - very early digital sythe like the DX-7 but less
complex       $250

Korg  MS-20    - monphonic synthe with on panel patch bay can process
an       $350
                 external signal...                                     

I have a couple of rack units that I'm up in the air over  Korg M1 and
 a Yamaha TX81z  if any interest you might convince me to part with
them...

sig....

having a synthe museum...

okay so i was fooling myself. i can't seem to stay away 
from you guys.
you're a drug damn you :P

naywoo my dad just bought my brother another turntable
and he went off to work.
woowoo i plopped in his room and started messing around
with it. looked through his records (bone thugs n harmony
and some other rap stuff) looked through my parents records
(engelbert humberdink??? barbara streisand, sarturday night 
fever <yay!> n some other old people stuff)

oh did i have fun fun fun!!!

messed around with my tip records west side story rap stuff
oldies stuff etc etc etc.
matched beats, didn't match beats, jungle and barbara streisand
(it works! just speed her up baby!!!) a record here and a 
record there!
i think that was the happiest july 8th in my whole life!

=)

i don't think i'd ever be able to spin at a rave though.
people would just look at me and think "girl! wtf are you
doin???"

hehe "hi, my name is dj tweEk"

sweetdreams baby 

ve a n n :)

> first few paragraphs, those daft punk boys are a bit odd, maybe it's
> language barrier?  At any rate, I would call it a (skinnier) fashion
> concious XLR8R and would recomend it.  two pinkies up....
> 
> Megan          Czefir

The magazine is put out by the Camel Cigarete Company.  Its a good
Magazine, and its in the first vew issues.  It will be very LARGE!!!!! 
Not just nationwide,  but worldwide.   Probably the same scale as Roling
Stone... But about This Genreations Culture and Music...  Jut another
aspect of the mainstream incorporation of underground Culture.

Keep it real

Ray Vonie

heyhey everyone,

kris and i are lookin for a housemate to share a home in marin... we're 
located in greenbrae, right on the 101 just south of san rafael.

what we need:  someone who is laid back _yet_ financially stable (yeah, 
there's always a catch... =)  , likes music (a lot - as in able to sleep 
to funky housegrooves or ambientgroove, nothin too aggro...), is ok with 
cats (we have three - all are very great), somewhat clean and responsible, 
likes being around people, and wants to live in marin...

what we offer:  kris is a very warm person who is currently working in 
(surprise) the whole web dev scene - she's into spinning ambient, and the
exploration of the role of media in the evolution of culture (yeah, it's 
pretty wordy on the outside but interesting on the inside...)

i dj, primarily house music - anything with a groove and that uplifting 
funk to it...  and jam/compose music (i have a full studio and decks)... 
i've been into house and rave culture for years - up and down the west 
coast, from l.a. to seattle... i'm also doing web dev to pay the rent...

about the house:  nice place, 4 bedrooms (of which you would have two 
bedrooms - one of which is a master bedroom, including private bathroom), 3 
bath, 2 common rooms, washer and dryer, and a swimming pool...  rent is 
$733 + utils per person, which, is a good deal considerin where you are 
and what you get...

email me (leaf@ted.net) for more info or to meet kris and i...

thanks,
phil

Lotsa stuff going off on Saturday...last Monday at Ultra was very cool,
some masters of drum'n'bass mixing it up for a big crowd, should be
good this week too.  Monday's Vanilla Fudge and Wednesday's Spiral Tribe
could be cool too...

   _Super8000_ - analogus expeririments in the chemical composition of
   celluloid and wax. 21+. Edinburgh Castle, 950 Geary @ Polk, SF.
   
   _beats for life_ - jungle, techno w/DJs charlie bucket vs beatjakr,
   abstract vs noel, gabe real, g-most, matty b, tasho, chuck wish,
   kiyoshi. every other sunday starting june 22nd.
   10pm-3am, 18+. cat's alley, 1190 Folsom, SF.
   
   _Phonixs_ - robot music w/DJs O.S.T., selected tossers. noon-2am,
   Free. Club Paradise, 1028 Geary @ Polk, SF. 415.567.7540
   
  Monday
  
   _Electric Fondue_ - trip hop, house w/DJs Electric Fondue Crew, Mark
   E.Quark, Gavin Hardkiss, guests. 10pm-4am, 21+, $5. Cat's Grill &
   Alley, 1190 Folsom @ 8th, SF. 415.289.6838
   
   _rotation_ - jazz, hiphop, soul, acid jazz, funk w/DJs racer x, yamu,
   stef, rasta cue-tip, guests. 10pm-2am, 21+. up & down club, 1151
   Folsom St, SF.
   
   _mad_ - trance, electro, old school, minimal, hard, detroit, acid
   w/DJs Alex, Joe Rice, Monty, Sho, guests. 2$ before 11pm
   10pm-2am, 18+, $3. Bahia Cabana, 1600 Market St, SF. 415.281.9432
   
   _Monday Night Dinner_ - a haphazard collection of ravers who get
   together weekly to properly wind down their weekend or rev their
   engines for the coming week. a different cuisine each week, usually in
   SF.
   info on SFRaves or here (when available). Ask for the SFRaves table.
   after-party at Mad.
   8:30p-All ages.
   
   _Freak Mode_ - Bass, Booty and Beat Trax w/DJs DJ Positive P, Kit
   Clayton (One Jack Mind). 10pm-2am, 21+, Free. The Top, 424 Haight, SF.
   
   
   _Black's House_ - deep house w/DJs Black, David Williams. 10pm-, 21+,
   $4. coco club, 139 8th St @ Minna, SF. 415.626.2337
   
   _Beat Box_ - drum'n'bass, jungle, downtempo w/DJs Val. 9:30pm-, 21+,
   Free. Dalva, 3121 16th St, SF.
   
   Ultra - Drum + Bass, Future Soul, Mutant Jazz, Turntablist Science
   w/DJs guests weekly. a new Drum and Bass weekly starting July 7th.
   21+. v/sf, 278 11th St, SF.
   [7.14 - LTJ Bukem, Blame Conrad, MC DRS]
   
   _Noc Noc_ - Drum'n'bass, downtempo and electronica w/DJs Mohsen. every
   other Monday.
   9pm-2am, 21+, Free. 557 Haight St, SF. 415.861.5811
   
   _Outlet_ - trance, house, disco w/DJs Danny, Nobel, XL, special
   guests. begins July 21st.
   330 Ritch St, SF. 415.541.9530
   
  Tuesday
  
   _Eclectic_ - house, jungle, drum & bass w/DJs Yamu, Siege, Franko,
   Foster, guests. Fresh fruit & condoms to all
   9pm-2am, 21+. Paradise Bar & Grill, 5356 College Ave, Oakland.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 8-10pm - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

> 
> you forgot to mention the mega corporate advertising, lots and lots
> of full and double page glossy ads for camel, jim beam, harmon/kardon,
> absolut, altoids, kahlua, beefeater, bacardi, etc... it's more like
> a yuppie lifestyle/fashion mag with some "electronica(tm)" articles
> and reviews. i haven't read it so i can't comment on the quality
> of the writing, but i was kinda suprised to see reviews of some more
> relatively obscure stuff along with the usual chem. bros, orb, daft
> punk, etc...
> 
> it's free (it better be with all of that $$ coming in from those ads,
> i can't imagine actually paying for it), but xlr8r it is NOT.  no
> comparison really...
> 
> Andy

well, I don't know, I excused the ads 'cause it was free and it did have a wide variety 
of stuff in it.  

(I didn't really like the magazine advertising clubs for major cities either but that's 
just my elitism speaking.)

And I don't know that I would call it yuppie becuase I just didn't get that feel from 
the scope of the mag and where I found it (the only place I saw it) (buffalo exchange, 
not a big yuppie hangout). I felt it catered to more in-the-know people because it did 
cover some more obscure stuff that would bore anyone just reading it for daft punk.  I 
thought through the ads it was aiming for a more frat crowd, something I don't care for 
but I thought originally maybe the mag got money wherever it came from.  But since it 
turns out that it is put out by camel I won't ever pay for it but I would for sure read 
it again if only for the glossy pictures.

there is always a place in my heart for more shiny magazines.

Megan          Czefir

Well lemme see i always found out about raves and stuff from friends of mine at
the college; but one place to look for flyers/info is this little record store
on like 2nd and one of the tree-named streets.  umm, yeah, in those few blocks
on ash, right by the river in downtown (westside) where it's still SW (not NW)
but almost hits Burnside (the division street between north and sourth).  Just
some dingy postered looking place that'd be a good place to check the scene. 
can't promise anything though, but i went to a kick-ass rave through them
(Evolution).
another thought:  
a contact/ friend of mine:  jkemper@reed.edu ; he's mostly into the grateful
dead now but he's still up in portland and can probably hook you up with a few
events.
Elise

So I plot down with the new copy of Lotus and flip to page 29 and who is 
there on an ad for the "Green Party (Vol. II)"?  DJ Noah (of Colour) 
listed as spinning Funky Breaks.  Now, I saw DJ Noah's name for the first 
time about a year ago on a flyer at Beat Non Stop for some party where my 
homeboy Moonpup was also spinning.  I also saw DJ Noah's name on the 
Frosted Breaks flyer.  However, due to random circumstance, I've never 
actually met the guy or heard him spin rekkids.  Does anyone know him?  I 
think it would be fun to meet another 'Noah' who spins funky breaks!  It 
could lead to an interesting vs. mixtape...
Thanks
plur, etc.

Friday July 25th
Drive in from all points (I'm not going to give directions from the 10E !) 
Meet in the valley that night
We're going to commando camp (more on that later)
Maybe party or whatever depending on what time we get in

Saturday July 26th
Climbers
Wake up by 5:00, on the rock by 6am
Climb until 2-3
Hike back down be back on the valley floor by 3
Meet the non climbers for dinner somewhere
Night time event (small music gAthEring? Input is welcome here)
(one thing I want to do is to go to El Cap Meadows at night to lay back under the stars
and watch the headlamps of the climbers waaaay up on El Cal for the night-quite and
experience!) 

Non climbers
Sleep in (lucky bastards)

Meet climbers around 4-5 for community dinner
Night time event (small music gAthEring? Input is welcome here)
(one thing I want to do is to go to El Cap Meadows at night to lay back under the stars
and watch the headlamps of the climbers waaaay up on El Cal for the night-quite and
experience!) 

Sunday, July 27th

(12 miile hike with light backpacks with water, powerbars light lunches etc)
we should be up and back before sunset!  Nice healthy hike (I hope I can do it after
a day o climbing)

after that we can hang out and drive out!

Subject: OFFTOPIC: Save San Mateo Coast, Site of Many Beach Raves
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org

Dear Friends,

Attached is a file for any bay area individuals interested in action on
preserving a stretch of California Coastal area, an area where many raves
are held on the beaches.  Pass it on to interested individuals.


>>------------   ORIGINAL ATTACHMENT   --------
>>SENT 07-02-97 FROM CURRAN_ANNE @MAILMN
>>
>>Hi,
>>
>>As you may have seen recently on Channel 4 News or San Jose
>>Mercury News, a beautiful open space on the San Mateo Coast
>>called Cascade Ranch is in immediate danger of development. A
>>grassroots effort to save Cascade Ranch is underway. The
>>Coastside Habitat Coalition is leading this fight.
>>
>>Cascade Ranch is halfway between Santa Cruz and Half Moon Bay
>>near Ano Nuevo State Park.  Development of 112 RV sites, 76 tent
>>campsites, 130 room resort, 12 cabins, 40 room lodge, store,
>>conference center, multiple gyms, 2 pools, tennis courts, etc. is
>>planned for the site.
>>
>>Issues with the proposed development:
>>-------------------------------------
>>   - One of the most beautiful stretches of California coastline
>>and open space will be marred.
>>   - This campsite/lodge can support about 1000 people per day.
>>Neighboring communities are small (<500 people).   Traffic along
>>highway 1 will dramatically incease.  Impact on local communities
>>and coastside ecology will be major.
>>   - An endangered species (San Francisco Garter Snake) and a
>>threatened species (Red-legged Frog) currently inhabit Cascade
>>Ranch and will probably not survive this development
>>   - A large well will be drilled at the site of a former Ohlone
>>Indian settlement.  This is the place where the explorer Portola
>>first encountered the Ohlone Indians in the 1700s.   It is a
>>potentially valuable archaeological site.
>>
>>What concerned people can do:
>>-----------------------------
>>   - Forward this message to others who may be interested.
>>   - See http://www.outre.com/cascade for more info.
>>   - Join the grassroots effort and contribute in whatever way
>>you can.
>>          Address:  Coastside Habitat Coalition
>>                    P.O. Box 71
>>                    San Gregorio, CA 94074
>>          Phone:    (415) 726-0565
>>          E-mail:   sangregoro@aol.com
>>   - Let your representatives and the media know what you think
>>about preserving the coastside.
>>   - Participate in a *nature hike* July 5.  Join naturalist Joe
>>Barnwell to explore beautiful Cascade Ranch State Park which is
>>adjacent to the private development site. This hike is sponsored
>>by the Coastside Habitat Coalition. Suggested sliding scale
>>donation of $5 - $20.  Meet at the San Gregorio General Store at
>>the corner of Highway 84 and Stage Rd. on Saturday July 5 at
>>10:00 am. Call 415-726-0565 for more information.
>>   - Attend the next *volunteer action meeting* on Wednesday
>>evening July 9 at the San Gregorio General Store at the corner of
>>Highway 84 and Stage Rd. at 7:30 pm. Call 415-726-0565 for more
>>information.
>>   - Come out and have fun at the *Coastal Protection Concert*
>>the first weekend in August. The concert will feature hot Bay
>>Area bands including Box Set, Frontmen, Pele Juju, Harmony Grits
>>and Claddagh Band. This concert will raise money for legal
>>actions to save Cascade Ranch. This all day outdoor concert will
>>be held behind the San Gregorio General Store at the corner of
>>Highway 84 and Stage Rd. Call 415-726-0565 for more information.

From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL18.199707110719590917@msn.com>
To: "funkateers" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Music For Newbies
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

When I first started raving (gee, like, three or four months ago), I was 
having the hardest time finding music.  I didn't want to spend money on CDs 
that I didn't like, but I didn't know what I liked yet, and I wasn't familiar 
w/ a lot of artists and genres.  Well, I'm still not.

But I've gotten some great, no, fantastic CDs  (sorry all you vinyl lovers) 
and compilations, and not only do they contain really good music, but they 
really helped me define my tastes in techno music.

So if there are any other newbies out there who don't know what the hell to 
buy, but are really craving some good music, email me privately and I'll send 
you a list of some of the really good CDs, including price, track listings, 
where they can be found, etc.  They're really easy to find and affordable 
(well, for imports).

Oh, and if there are some CDs that all you oldskoolers know about and would 
recommend, could you let me know about some of them . . . I can never have too 
many cds . . .

xoxo--Miccaela

Subject: *Metta*
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

in the Buddhist tradition, there is a meditation called <<metta>>, 
which best translates as <<loving-kindness>>

i~ll describe how to do it, i wanted to share this w/ you because you 
might want to do this at a rave w/ a friend, obviously someone you 
love and care about, or at home, whatever...

sit across from each other and take a few deep breaths, focus on 
breathing...
Wish yourself well, say mentally 
<<may my heart be peaceful and happy. 
may i be safe from harm. 
may i be kind.>>
then, as the metta phrases are flowing through your mind 
exhale and imagine the energy of loving kindness flowing from you and 
surrounding you and infusing someone you love.
Breath in loving kindness and breath it out to those you love.
Let it surround the globe, send this to all beings
Silently say <<may i be well, may all beings be well>>

goodnight!
~ena~

That's "Ain't Talkin' Bout Dub" by Apollo Four Forty... I have two
different versions of this song on Virgin's "In The Mix 97"
compilation, and the Polygram TV "Dance Zone Level Nine"...  I picked
up these sometimes-cheezy compilations at the London Heathrow Airport
during a layover on my way back from a recent biz-trip to India. I think
I've seen one of these at Reckless Records on Haight St...

I'm up for doing digital-to-digital DAT or CD-R trades of these and 
other CDs I have... for personal use only of course...

I think we should start a DAT (or CD-R) "tape tree" thingie much like 
deadheads and phisheads do... (http://www.atd.ucar.edu/rdp/dat-heads/)

Anthem was AMAZING! The music slammed, the attitude was nonexistent and
EVERYONE was just moving to the beat or rhythm or whatever is it is they
hear.  The floor was thoroughly  doused with talcum powder and all payed
tribute to our house.  It's still giving me chills.

Sorry to bring this feud back up, but I dance 5-6 nights/week and 9 times
outa ten, 1015 or Cats Ally or wherever on a week night is better then any
huge mega rave and co$t$ far less.    What's with gathering in a circle and
watching some show-off jump around anyway?  

Anthem last night could only be compared to an old fashioned (circa '94)
underground rave.  What happened to those raves?  

 --
". . .the beat is pumpin', everybody's there, 
      it's just a feeling, heaven in the air. . ."

Dan Stevens        ~        hiagin@cats.ucsc.edu

Iris, 

Grooverider is not a goa artist, and I didn't mean to imply that he
was. For those who don't know, Groove is one of he most respected drum
and bass dj's and producers in the UK. However, he does do many
remixes for a variety of artists and this remix in particular is for a
goa artist. It sounds, literally, like goa jungle.  Perhaps sometime I
can play it for you and you'll see what I mean...

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: just say no to ghb
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

enough with the bad-rep of ghb. GHB is a drug. I use it/I like it....it's
great. the biggest danger is mis-information and/or irresponsible use.
Continuous daily use can and will result in disrupting the *normal* level of
brain chemistry as the users body fights to adjust to  the fluctuating
levels, if you are using daily you have a problem that may take a couple of
months to self-correct, but it will.
  GHB is not a problem, it's mis-use is. The more we talk about it, the more
curious people become who haven't tried it and that is dangerous. One cap of
GHB can be several times stronger than another cap from a different supply,
so be careful if you usually take four or two or whatever, y'know?? GHB has a
stronger reaction in females than males, so dosage is halved or you may pass
out. Don't mix it with alcohol EVER, you will barf and then pass out,
guaranteed.
  Just say NO is a policy that will not work, we all know that. Being
responsible is a policy that will work. G will bring your e-peak back, G will
soften a bad trip, G will ruin everyones night if you don't have a clue and
just don't care.
  Sorry to beat this thread to death yet again, but was involved in a
conversation where GHB was reffered to as a "bad, bad drug" and after talking
a couple of minutes realized the ppl didn't know, y'know ? just spreading
mis-information
hugs
shawn

I went to party in Thailland and Bali and Hong Kong and Vietnam last year.
Spent 3 months in search of the perfect party...wouldn't you know I found it
in Florida.

Phuket, Chang Ma are great but Pat Pong..now there is a story. Bali...not
worth the trip unless you are in the area. Oh yes...the Aussies know how to
party. Check out Hamilton Island in the Barrier Reef. We danced all night
then went skydiving while on E and then the next day went diving on the
reef..also a trip when you are still flying from the night before.

I have been back to Australia once and Thailand twice. Definately recommend
it. Wonder how Hong Kong is going to change....can you see all those Maoists
raving???

	Hiyaz.  I had asked some people from the list about whether or not an IRC
channel existed.  Well turns out that it does.  I was told it was in it's
earlier stages of development, but all we need are enthusiastic SF rayvuhs
to come and make some noise.  
	If you don't know a damn thing about IRC like me, then I could point you
out to some primers and FAQ's, plus a few tutorials.  Most people are
interested in IRC, they just don't know where to start.  Email me back and
I'd be more than willing to help yaz.  Or if you're one of those types that
like to learn on their own, here's a decent site to start from:

	http://shoga.wwa.com/~edge//newbie.htm

	Anywayz, take care of yourselves and oh yah one last thing, JOCKS SUCK.  : )

because the punishments for even petty crimes are inhumanely severe.
Being cought selling E carries a pretty severe punishment here, what do
you think they would do in a 3rd world country? Hauling them off to jail
is too expensive, theyd sooner have 'em sleep with the fishes.

I haven't been to Hong Kong yet, but after what happend in Tenimen(sp?)
square a few years ago, what do you think they would do to a buncha
ravers? (*SMACK* *SMACK*)

In-Reply-To: <970711132554_1790414615@emout06.mail.aol.com>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

At 01:25 PM 7/11/97 -0400, you wrote:
>  GHB is not a problem, it's mis-use is.

But of course, you can't enjoy the benefits of a drug without actually
using it, so GHB has to be evaluated on how easy it is to "mis-use",
particularly by well-intentioned people.  And GHB just doesn't stack up -
it has many bad interactions with other drugs, can be of unpredictable
strength, and produces many bad side effects at slightly higher dosages.
It's just not a drug that is amenable to "street use" - in very controlled
situations where people can experiment with slightly increasing dosages to
find their tolerance, it might be safe, but how many people out there do
you think do that?

Going beyond philosophy, though, look at what's actually happened - GHB has
sent more people to the hospital from raves this year, it seems, than all
other drugs combined.  

I really don't think people are missing out if they don't do GHB; there are
so many other /marvelous/ drugs out there which don't have this level of
risk, that it seems just kind of silly to do it.  Yes, even drugs which
give a similar reaction.

And thus, I will continue to urge people to not do ghb, unless they really
can handle learning "how".  

	Brian



	Brian


--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--
"Why not?" - TL           brian@organic.com - hyperreal.org - apache.org

At 02:30 PM 7/9/97 -0700, Janelle Brown wrote:
>btw, i was trying to find the old sfraves archives last week, but they were
>all in gzip format and i could get 'em to open. are there hidden ones that
>aren't in that format?

Nope, it's intentional, so that the search engines out there don't have an
easy time indexing them, and so spammers can't mine it for email addresses.
 Most of the common compression software should be able to uncompress them
- pkzip, stuffit, etc.

The Woopy Ball was my first SF party - my favorite was the fact that
admission was free *if you brought a couch for the ambient warehouse*.
Which many many people did!

	Brian

Kinda like heroin... eh.... Its a good drug just misunderstood and
misused....duh

owen virus



>enough with the bad-rep of ghb. GHB is a drug. I use it/I like it....it's
>great. the biggest danger is mis-information and/or irresponsible use.
>Continuous daily use can and will result in disrupting the *normal* level of
>brain chemistry as the users body fights to adjust to  the fluctuating
>levels, if you are using daily you have a problem that may take a couple of
>months to self-correct, but it will.
>  GHB is not a problem, it's mis-use is. The more we talk about it, the more
>curious people become who haven't tried it and that is dangerous. One cap of
>GHB can be several times stronger than another cap from a different supply,
>so be careful if you usually take four or two or whatever, y'know?? GHB has a
>stronger reaction in females than males, so dosage is halved or you may pass
>out. Don't mix it with alcohol EVER, you will barf and then pass out,
>guaranteed.
>  Just say NO is a policy that will not work, we all know that. Being
>responsible is a policy that will work. G will bring your e-peak back, G will
>soften a bad trip, G will ruin everyones night if you don't have a clue and
>just don't care.
>  Sorry to beat this thread to death yet again, but was involved in a
>conversation where GHB was reffered to as a "bad, bad drug" and after talking
>a couple of minutes realized the ppl didn't know, y'know ? just spreading
>mis-information
>hugs
>shawn

All we need to do to get some sort of revolution out of this is to unite
under one same sort of philosophy; PLUR. If we all lived, breathed, shit, and
ate PLUR we could really make that difference that we all want to make! But,
I also believe that timing is everything! In the 60's there was quite a
movement and it was squashed by the government before it ever really made a
difference, we need to remember that the government is still in control, and
that all the people in control of that government, for the time being, are
the same people, with the same ideals that squashed that first movement. We
need to proceed with caution and work subtly. Just a thought...


PLUR
