Precedence: bulk

Ok, here's the story...

I'm driving home on 680 from SanJo and I'm half asleep... it hasn't been
more than 24 hours since I put my "Yes, I am a raver..." sticker on my
rear windshield.
I don't realize it, but traffic is passing me as I am behind an 18
wheeler going 40 in the slow lane (I can never tell how slow I go when
I'm half-asleep...), so i put on my 119k.r.u CD to try and wake myself
up.
As traffic slows to a 5MPH halt around Fremont, this blue mini-truck
pulls up next to me, and the driver goes, "Hey!"
Being 3/4 asleep by now, I hear the yell, but I am too tired to even turn
my head...
And then I hear, "Hey Doughboy!"

All of a sudden, I am awakened...

These two guys in this mini are yelling at me that they remember me from
Freedom and some other partys...

On the 680 freeway of all places!

Could this be any of you guys on the SFR list????

Just wondering... sorry if I wasted your bandwidth.

Mad hugs!
jay
(doughboy!)

P.S. Finally met MEGS (Megan) the other day; she is SO kewl... and I'm
not just saying that 'cause she hooked my sh*t up!!!  Phat waffle cone
full of ice cream and everything....  YUM!  Anyways, if ya ever get to
meet her, make sure ya say doughboy sent ya!

---StimpyTCat@aol.com wrote:
>
> All we need to do to get some sort of revolution out of this is to
unite
> under one same sort of philosophy; PLUR. If we all lived, breathed,
shit, and
> ate PLUR we could really make that difference that we all want to
make! But,
> I also believe that timing is everything! In the 60's there was
quite a
> movement and it was squashed by the government before it ever really
made a
> difference, we need to remember that the government is still in
control, and
> that all the people in control of that government, for the time
being, are
> the same people, with the same ideals that squashed that first
movement. We
> need to proceed with caution and work subtly. Just a thought...
> 
> 
> PLUR
> 
> Pyro
> 


i don't think a revolution is necessary. what would you want to
achieve? 

i think ben and i and the whole circumstances of our stay here are
proof of the global unity of the rave movement. we might differ
slightly in musical taste and cultural heritage but the fact that we
could simply contact ravers in sf and ask if we could come and stay w/
them (you) shows that PLUR exists.

there will always be conservative, pleasure-hostile groups and people
but i've given up on being a missionary long aga. if they want to be
miserable, let them.

and when it comes to government, i think people don't pay much
attention to governments these days anyway. governments run by big
business have become so detached from the people. they are not part of
the people and if we can we ignore them because they don't make much
sense outside of their countryclubs.

raves might be illegal but they are still happening and growing.
(some) drugs (at least in europe) are on the way to becoming
legalized. just keep doing what you want to do as long as it doesn't
hurt anybody or stops others from doing what they want to do.
government? what's that?

iris

p.s. to be honest i don't think we could get a revolution together.
slow reformation maybe (as the evolution of culture does anyway), but
revolution....?

On Fri, 27 Jun 1997, Jay Wiley wrote:

> Don't Put That in Your Pipe and Smoke It!
> 
> Compared to heroin and cocaine, many people--scientists and teenagers 
> alike--consider marijuana a relatively benign substance. Two new 
> studies in tomorrow's Science demonstrate, however,that marijuana's 
> effects on the brain are disturbingly similar to those produced by 
> highly addictive drugs. The findings may help scientists devise better 
> strategies for treating marijuana dependence, for which some 100,000 
> people in the United States alone seek therapy each year.

a rescent study has shown that sex causes your brain to release dopamine 
and serotonin, two neurotransmitters known to produce feelings of pleasure.
these reactions in the brain show simmilarities to those reactions caused 
by heroin and cocaine. it is these reactions, causing a heightened 
feeling of euphoria, that cause people to scurry back for more, thus 
addiction is inevitable. due to these new findings, your government is 
working on passing a bill that will outlaw sex. our children need 
to be protected.

get it?

      Well, kiddies!  I kinda pulled a disappearing act for a while.  I
left the list without an appropriate goodbye.  I'm sorry.  My bad.  I
had to deal with my life.  Anyway, things are better now and I'm back to
succeeding in school (I'm transferring to U.C. Berkeley!  Wahoo!) and
I'm getting my car back with a new engine, so now it looks like I can
come back and party with you guys every once in a while!  Yeah!  So I
decided to resubscribe to the list (remember me?  It's the one and only
SmileGrl1!), but if you want to send any mail that is specifically meant
for me, please send them to either <JewelMae@aol.com> or
<SmileGrl1@aol.com>.  It makes life easier for me when I don't have to
dig through the posts for personal mail, so thanks in advance.
       Now I was hoping to be out this weekend with my days without my
car finally coming to an end.  Unfortunately for me, my car was supposed
to be finished today and now it won't be done until Monday...  sniff,
sniff.  I was going to ask you all to come celebrate my birthday with me
at @spire's "In the Beginning", but it doesn't look like I can even get
down there now that my car's still in the shop.  I wanted more than
anything to be surrounded by my friends and family on my birthday this
weekend, but instead I'm stuck up here in the middle of nowhere doing
nothing.  I live in the Jamestown/Sonora area and the closest greyhound
station is at least an hour away and the Bay Area is 2 hours away!  Matt
and Stefi said they'd come get me if my car wasn't done, but someone
owes Matt money and he can't come up here until he has money for gas for
the trip up here.  So whoever out there owes him money, please give him
his money so that they can come up here and get me and make my birthday
special for me!!!!  Anyway, if there are any beautiful people out there
who are anywhere near me that would like to come get me, I'd really
appreciate it.  I'd be very generous with the hugs, smiles, candy, good
vibes... and let's not forget money for gas!!!  Oh, and since this would
be one of the most wonderful birthday presents, I'll even let you use my
vibrating hair-brush (ever get a head massage while you're tripping?
well this is even better!).  I know it's a lot to ask, but I've only
been out to one party (Warmth 2) in the last 3 or 4 months and I really
wanted to be with you guys for my birthday, and now I'm just bummed
about the whole thing... If any of you have any suggestions on how to
resolve my dilemma, please call me at (209) 984-3918 or, if that's busy,
call (209) 984-5151.  Or if all else fails, e-mail me at my AOL address
that I mentioned earlier (not the one I'm posting from).  Like I said,
it's a lot to ask, so I'm not getting my hopes up, but I miss all of you
so much and I hope my weekend gets better.  Well, that's all for now,
except my "thought for the day" that I put below.  (Remember those?)  I
hope this finds everyone doing well and living life fully.
                                       Cherishing PLUR,
                                                  Julie Mae
                                        A.K.A.  SMILEGIRL

                                                                     ~~
Aldous Huxley

cc: bert@laren.k.easynet.co.uk
Subject: Re: acid rave culture - my theory 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 11 Jul 97 22:14:22 EDT."
             <970711221420_-57272114@emout20.mail.aol.com> 
Date: Sat, 12 Jul 97 08:45:16 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



> All we need to do to get some sort of revolution out of this is to unite
> under one same sort of philosophy; PLUR. If we all lived, breathed, shit, and
> ate PLUR we could really make that difference that we all want to make! But,

The big problem is that mostly people shit PLUR.

Why not join unto an existing movement with an equally preposterous
notion that we all unite under the word Jesus. Not the deeds of jesus,
not the thoughts of jesus, not the ethics or mores of jesus. Just say
the word, while you keep on acting hateful, selfish, ignorant, divisive
-- but not to "your own" just to everybody else that doesn't believe or
doesn't share a particularly condoned lifestyle/credo/fashion/ethos. To
follow this path, get thee to a Baptist revival immediately. 

> I also believe that timing is everything! In the 60's there was quite a
> movement and it was squashed by the government before it ever really made a
> difference, we need to remember that the government is still in control, and
> that all the people in control of that government, for the time being,

No, the 60's squashed itself because people found out that the
beautiful "peace and love" world they had hallucinated for themselves
through drug abuse, "free love" and general shirking of
responsibilities -- all these things had consequences that caused the
movement to fall in on itself... Because, after looking at the big
picture, it was a very selfish movement, prone to decadence and decay,
disease and illness,  posturing and lies, lots of talk, and little
effective action.

In fact the only people that succeeded to change the world out of the
hippie movement did so through some very old fashioned, very american
techniques -- hard work, individualism, idealism & being at the right
place at the right time (e.g. Jobs/Wozniak and all the other
hippy/geeks that have revolutionized the world with personal computing
and brought multimedia connunications to the masses)  and politicians
like Bill Clinton who were willing to fake the pose needed to be
popular during all time periods (i'm sure he was all PLUR-spouting and
love-bead-bangled fduring the 60's, and he's equally full of shit
during the 90's -- whatever makes him seem "groovy" enough to get
elected to the most people most of the time). 

Any changes that happened as a result of the 60's hippy movement were
evolutionary and not revolutionary. The hippies didn't effect the
changes directly, but society changed through a very slow & painful
transformation brought about by discussion, fighting, politics,
warfare, killing, etc between the establishment and the rebels...

Basically, if you wall yourself off in PLUR-ville, you will become
ineffective at change. Ravers will never make a majority, you'll never
be able to dose the world so that everybody shares a consensual
hallucination about how the world should be. You're going to have to
work with the establishment under their terms if you expect to get
anywhere. Yes, this sucks and it's hard -- it's called reality.

Also, to the outside world, all this PLUR-spoutin' looks pretty
irrelevant. Maybe it even seems as ridiculous as the hippies "peace and
love" soundbyte while images of Altamont danced on America's TV
screens. "The people" still hear about the OD's at raves, the suicides,
the stabbings, and the squalid lifestyles of drug abusers. So the
reality is that there is no shining example of "a better way" to hold
up as a model for how to live correctly.

PLUR is a word. An ideal. You can't be it, you can't live it, you can
just talk about it and chastise other people for not being up to this
impossible ideal. We've already been through 2000 years of this
self-torture via Christianity and it's need to grade people against an
unattainable metric of a sin-free life, whether or not you were
sin-free enough to go to heaven, and whether you could measure up to an
idealized image of a man-god, Jesus' , and his supposed beliefs. This
kind of ethical self-flagellation brings about a lot of pain and
suffering that is, IMHO, detrimental to humanity. It ignores human
nature, and the fact that we're all animals trying to survive in a
sometimes brutal&inexplicable world.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Sat Jul 12 12:24:49 1997

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: emdash@grin.net (e.menon)
Subject: Re: acid rave culture - my theory
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

At 8:45 AM 7/12/97, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>Why not join unto an existing movement with an equally preposterous
>notion that we all unite under the word Jesus. Not the deeds of jesus,
>not the thoughts of jesus, not the ethics or mores of jesus. Just say
>the word, while you keep on acting hateful, selfish, ignorant, divisive
>-- but not to "your own" just to everybody else that doesn't believe or
>doesn't share a particularly condoned lifestyle/credo/fashion/ethos. To
>follow this path, get thee to a Baptist revival immediately.

eek - had to read that one twice to get the preposterous! the problem with
all of these movements is the 'holier than thou' attitude - 'this is the
_only_ way to create change... i'm right and you're wrong and sinful for
not agreeing with me.' i'm still all for the democratic ideals (the real
ones) - respect ppl for their differences. and of course, the christian
dogma of 'do unto others' which kind of emcompasses this democratic notion
- would you really want someone with disagreeable ideals trying to force
you to see things their way? debating them is one thing, but force is
another. like in _the last supper_ (the movie) - you can't go around
killing ppl who don't share your beliefs. this is obviously extreme, but
there are better ways of invoking change.

>No, the 60's squashed itself because people found out that the
>beautiful "peace and love" world they had hallucinated for themselves
>through drug abuse, "free love" and general shirking of
>responsibilities -- all these things had consequences that caused the
>movement to fall in on itself... Because, after looking at the big
>picture, it was a very selfish movement, prone to decadence and decay,
>disease and illness,  posturing and lies, lots of talk, and little
>effective action.

was the hippie movement really about political change? there were a lot of
political activists during that period, fighting for human rights, era,
peace, etc... but i don't think they were the ones doing all the drugs and
free lovin'. the ppl who were spending their time wearing black arm bands,
protesting the policies of the time, they were the ones that enacted
change. not the ones who were tripping their faces off.
>
>In fact the only people that succeeded to change the world out of the
>hippie movement did so through some very old fashioned, very american
>techniques -- hard work, individualism, idealism & being at the right
>place at the right time (e.g. Jobs/Wozniak and all the other
>hippy/geeks that have revolutionized the world with personal computing
>and brought multimedia connunications to the masses)  and politicians
>like Bill Clinton who were willing to fake the pose needed to be
>popular during all time periods (i'm sure he was all PLUR-spouting and
>love-bead-bangled fduring the 60's, and he's equally full of shit
>during the 90's -- whatever makes him seem "groovy" enough to get
>elected to the most people most of the time).

i'd call it the human rights movement, or something other than the hippie
movement. the hippie movement, like the rave culture, was a hedonistic
thing - personal, somewhat selfish, and not having to do with the politics
of the time. how many raves (with the exception of kerry darling) are
really out there fighting to change things? you can't do this when you're
fucked up on drugs. plur is not political, imo. it has to do with what's
inside of each of us... it's an attitude that affects our outlook. but an
attitude can't change the world. really. only hardcore action can instill
changfe, and for this, folks, you have to stop talking and do something.
what is it that you want to change? plur says nothing of what policies need
to be changed. you want equality? go fight for it. peace? protest in active
ways. you merely want the right to party your asses off? a nice want, i
agree, but completely selfish and having nothing to do with political
issues. please. read your history books. read the newspaper. decide what it
is that you're unhappy with and _do_ something about it. organize a
protest. write your congress people. vote. write letters to the newspapers.
and if there's something you can do that is a little more direct - say you
want to end domestic violence - volunteer! stop sitting on your asses and
murmering 'plur'. this does nothing.
>
>Basically, if you wall yourself off in PLUR-ville, you will become
>ineffective at change. Ravers will never make a majority, you'll never
>be able to dose the world so that everybody shares a consensual
>hallucination about how the world should be. You're going to have to
>work with the establishment under their terms if you expect to get
>anywhere. Yes, this sucks and it's hard -- it's called reality.

i'm still confused about what the issue of change is here ... plur? what
does this mean? what are you protesting? to reiterate, plur, to me, is a
personal thing. it's how one looks at the wprld. and i do believe (i'll
give it this much), that outlooks are contagious - if i treat the hooker on
my corner with respect, perhaps she'll pass that feeling on. if i stop
flipping off idiot drivers, perhaps they won't do the same. i think that
these energies spread - hence the 'do unto others'. and if anything, it
does some good for your own psyche. you will feel better for respecting ppl
who are different, rather than bashing them, which really doesn't hurt
them, it only hurts the basher. but beyond this, it's ridiculous to think
that this will actually change anything. anyway, i don't want to change
other ppl. they are who they are.... respect them for their choices. i'm
sure a lot of ppl would disagree strongly with the choices i've made, but
i'd like them to look to me with respect because i've found a way of life
that works for me. but this is so selfish, and has nothing to do with
changing the world. the rave movement, again, is a selfish, hedonistic
movement. selfish in that we want to live a certain lifestyle.
not that we don't help others when they're in need.... but selfish in that
we're pretty selfish as a group. don't know if that makes sense, and i'm
sure someone out there is going to misunderstand what i'm saying, but
wanting to party to me is a pretty irrelevant desire in the overall scheme
of things. i posted something a while back about a group of ravers in the
uk who are actually using their parties to establish change - setting up
communal housing and such from the profits - i guess the only way i can see
raving as a way to change things is to actually use the proceeds to benefit
something.
>
>Also, to the outside world, all this PLUR-spoutin' looks pretty
>irrelevant. Maybe it even seems as ridiculous as the hippies "peace and
>love" soundbyte while images of Altamont danced on America's TV
>screens. "The people" still hear about the OD's at raves, the suicides,
>the stabbings, and the squalid lifestyles of drug abusers. So the
>reality is that there is no shining example of "a better way" to hold
>up as a model for how to live correctly.

is the outside world even aware of the term plur???

>
>PLUR is a word. An ideal. You can't be it, you can't live it, you can
>just talk about it and chastise other people for not being up to this
>impossible ideal. We've already been through 2000 years of this
>self-torture via Christianity and it's need to grade people against an
>unattainable metric of a sin-free life, whether or not you were
>sin-free enough to go to heaven, and whether you could measure up to an
>idealized image of a man-god, Jesus' , and his supposed beliefs. This
>kind of ethical self-flagellation brings about a lot of pain and
>suffering that is, IMHO, detrimental to humanity. It ignores human
>nature, and the fact that we're all animals trying to survive in a
>sometimes brutal&inexplicable world.

and again, the holier than thou attitude. the hypocracy is almost amusing.

enough said, i think... i've run out of words.

cheers - e. :)

.............................................................................

"I dont think 'This is my party' is applicable anymore. The party's kind of
over. Now it's more like, 'This is my life,' 'This is my tribe.'"
                                                               - Nan Goldin

"That so few now dare to be eccentric marks the cheif danger of the time."
                                              - John Stuart Mill (1806-1873)

From: "nathan.b.beckord" <nathan.b.beckord@ArthurAndersen.com>

Subject: Pre-Mad dinner/meetup?? + Nikita review
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi Folx!

Seeing as this Monday (7/14) will be the last MAD, that venerable staple of the 
SF scene, what about a dinner or meetup beforehand to send it off with a bang? 
This was discussed a few weeks ago, but I don't know if anything's come of 
it--- Matt, got any plans in the werks?  Let me know if there's something going 
down; if not, how about a rollcall of MAD participants, and suggestions for 
restaurants or a meetup spot?  


On another note, I went and checked out Nikita last night, for the first time 
in about 2 years.  Not bad, I must say, apart from the occasional hassles to 
the gal I was with from overambitious young bucks.  Decent jungle (but LOUD!!) 
in the basement, and the top floor music and crowd was pretty good. It was 
interesting that in one club, there were 4 different scenes going on 
simultaneously-- mellow ppl sitting in booths listening to jungle downstairs, 
cheesier music/ pickupy scene  in the small front room, straight techno in the 
main large room, and great hardcore and a friendly crowd in the top room.  Had 
to take a nap on the leather sofa for awhile around 4, but overall a fun time.  
There's hope for clubs yet..

Peace, Nathan

I had a GREAT time at Karma last night..
GREAT location, air conditioned... didn't this place use to be a juice 
bar??
Admission was a little steep for a Sac rave, but thats ok..

Music was alright..  Not my favorite style, but the DJ's had skills..

There were a lot of people just standing around watching, but there was 
a good vibe on the dance floor...

Those girls dancing with the poles were kinda crazy....
It was a fun night of dancing with good friends.....
I would say the best rave i have been to in Sac..

Gregery

Geez!  I guess I must have been away from the list too long.  Well, even
though I've been part of the SF scene since 1992, I've been living in
Jamestown, CA (near Sonora) almost continuously (with a semester spent
in Hayward as well) since 1994.  I'm almost afraid to admit that even in
the 3 years I've been living so close to Yosemite (about an hour's drive
or less), I still have yet to go.  I've always had friends say that they
would like to go with me, but when it came down to actually going, I've
never gotten any commitments from people.  So now that I have come back
to the list, it was refreshing to see that a group is planning a trip
there!  And it starts the day after I finish my summer session college
courses!  Yay!  What a way to reward myself after a summer spent
studying.  And since I had to miss partying with all of you this weekend
for my birthday because of my car troubles, at least I know that I can
see you guys then!  I miss you guys so much.  It's been too long (3
months).  So let me know the details and I'll meet you guys there!
                                       Always,
                                              Julie Mae
                                         A.K.A. SmileGirl

Yes, Karma was fantastic!

I had soooo much fun.

When I got out of the car, I had this really bad feeling, like something was 
going to go wrong--I thought I was tripping, but my two friends had the same 
feeling.

Got in the party, everyone's standing around, drininking alcohol, about 10 
people dancing.  Whatever.  I'm still tripping, wondering why I spent $12 to 
go to a weak party w/ bad bad vibes in an ex-strip joint/juice bar 
(Tailfeathers!).

Then Rig-A-Tony (that is the first blonde guy who came on, right?) came on, 
and I (and it seems everyone else) just had to dance.  And then bad feeling 
was gone, and the bad vibe was gone.

The people were soooo nice.  I saw/heard of a couple people tweaking HARD, but 
not anything too serious, and there were no medical emergencies (I think).  
And there were some (ahem) older people there, I was thinking I should have 
brought my mom along, but they were cool. I've never felt so good at a party.

But Rig-A-Tony and Karizma were the highlights of the night.  Overall, it was 
a great party, and I don't think I've felt so good at one for a long long long 
time.

xoxo--Miccaela
----------

Vanessa & Miccaela wrote:
 
> It mostly consists of this guy talking.  I'm not too sure about what he's
> saying, but I caught some parts, like "smokin on some weed," and "and over
> here you have . . . "  Then there's the somewhat chorus part that says
> something something, "prepare to dance" (???) and the music goes BOOM--it's
> like a breakdown or something.  I assume it's house music.

trainspotter Pete here  [: P

The song you're talking about is called "flash" by Green Velvet, It is
released on Relief records from Chicago. It is probably the original
version as there are other remixes by  Paul Johnson, DJ Sneak  and
others.  It goes: 
 
Good evening parents,
tonight I'm going to take you on a tour of club Mad.
where all the bad little kiddies go to try  to leave their bodies......
So I've equipped each and everyone of you with your own individual
camera,
so you can take pictures of bad little kiddies doing bad little things ,
for tomorrows paper...

Not here more than 30 seconds and I already see a bad little kiddy doin'
a bad little thing,
He's sucking on a balloon, but this is not a ordinary balloon, its a
ballon filled with a gas called Nitrous Oxide,laughing gas, he he he he
he ha ha
but this is no laughing matter,
camera ' s ready, prepare to flash

And there's more , but you have to hear it, its a very good tune.
I hope this is what you're talking about,
 
Pete
If you can't find it, e-mail me

The desire to have raving be part of a movement comes from a need to
have a "purpose" for raving, perhaps to legitimize it in ones mind.

Raving to me at its core is about personal expression, art, which in
it's purest form is without excess baggage such as a dollar $ign. This
may explain why we view the idea of "mainstream" with a wary eye.
Americans seem to only appreciate art that is "worth" something, just
because someone else said it was good.

Hence, I believe raving in America is the voice of the personal desire
to express oneself, which has otherwise been labeled and sold for $0.99
with a fill-up at AM PM. Personal artistic expression is ravings
purpose.

At 3:29 AM 7/13/97, Pengo wrote:
>The desire to have raving be part of a movement comes from a need to
>have a "purpose" for raving, perhaps to legitimize it in ones mind.

i wrote this to iris in a personal post, and here's my theory on it all:
the protestant work ethic is so engrained in our minds here that we feel
guilty about having fun. raving is a movement, a hedonistic one. but this
doesn't fly here in the us. we don't feel comfortable about shedding all
our mores and having a blast for the sake of having a blast. i was
introduced to this movement by a bunch of foreign students in school back
in '90, and their goal in raving was was to forget about all the pressures
of the 'real world' and just have fun for the night. this is what it's all
about. a hedonistic escape. nothing more. i think that the reason americans
try to give it a political edge is because we feel guilty about being
hedonistic. if there is some legitimate reason we can give to it, it makes
it okay. but that's bullshit. you know, at least for me, this, and my life
in general, has been about questioning the belief systems i have  - where
they came from, why i have them... why the hell do i feel like a bad person
for wanting to party my ass off and not focus all my energies on my career?
it's because i was raised to believe that hard work is the only way to
attain happiness, which is bullshit. i came to the conclusion a few years
back that some of my socialized beliefs do work for me, but some of them
are outdated beliefs that probably didn't work for my parents, or their
parents before them. each generation questions these stodgy ideals, and
takes with them the ones they think will work for them individually. for
me, yes, work is important, but it's not the only thing. it's important to
put aside 'reality' and go nuts once in a while. for me, finding a balance
between all of my needs is the key. i don't see the need to 'excuse' my
desire to have fun. it's a need, and it's a right.

i have said this before: the only way i can see raving having a political
agenda is if the proceeds from a party are used to benefit a needy group.
otherwise, it's all about having fun, entering an altered state of reality.
leave it at that, and enjoy it! it's okay!

>Raving to me at its core is about personal expression, art, which in
>it's purest form is without excess baggage such as a dollar $ign. This
>may explain why we view the idea of "mainstream" with a wary eye.
>Americans seem to only appreciate art that is "worth" something, just
>because someone else said it was good.

it's about having fun. but yes, this is a form of personal expression. hehe
the reason i view the mainstream with a wary eye is because i was the kid
all the popular ppl picked on - i don't trust anything remotely 'popular'.
i like just being myself without the pressures of having to fit into some
sort of clique - i can do this in my chosen career, and i can do this at
parties. i think that probably a majority of us prefer to maintain our
individuality and this 'scene' provides a comfortable forum for doing so.

>Hence, I believe raving in America is the voice of the personal desire
>to express oneself, which has otherwise been labeled and sold for $0.99
>with a fill-up at AM PM. Personal artistic expression is ravings
>purpose.

hmmmm.... maybe for the musicians in the group... and yes, dress is a big
form of personal expression. wrote a thesis on that very subject in school.
but to me, this will always be a place where i can be myself and have a
blast. artistic expression? i'm an artist by trade - i'd rather keep that
out of my partying experiences. :P

cheers - e. :)

                                                               - Nan Goldin

                                              - John Stuart Mill (1806-1873)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Joe Salas <joesalas@earthlink.net>
Subject: rave as movement?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

reading that person's post about how, as americans, we have a need to paste
a reason to everything we do in order to validate it, i can see how that
applies to me. but then ive always been some sort of romantic, raving then
added a streak of idealism to that, what can i say? but ive always tried to
maintain a perspective, and even though one cant help getting caught up in
the emotion of something, ive also at least tried to admit to myself that
im merely caught in the emotion of something, when i am.

nevertheless, i think there is something going on at most raves that can be
spread to the rest of the world, that feels like could change the world in
some way.

what i found at my first rave that i dont find in my normal life is that
unselfishness and lack of judgement, the act that most of us perform of
being nice to somebody, talking to them, hugging them, giving them a piece
of candy, and all for no real reason, just for the sake of being nice.
furthermore, when we do this, we do not exclude anyone, but give it out to
anyone who wants it.

when i first witnessed this, i was shocked at how much i discovered i
really need that sort of situation sometimes, how simple it is, and how
good it makes me feel.

sometimes when i watch the news or read the paper, or hear of awful,
negative events that happen to other people, i wonder that the rest of the
world cannot realize and know the attitudes and actions that permeate the
rave atmosphere. if only people could, living and working, then dying,
would be so much nicer.

we do this every weekend, but it is true that it is probably not going to
change the world. but what i hope is at least happening is that all the
ravers that experience this at parties tries to live it in their regular
daytime lives a little bit, then passes it on to their children. teach them
this attitude, let them know the enjoyment of practicing it for its own
sake, rather than attach some vague, uncertain reward, like going to heaven
when youre dead. then, who knows? maybe in the future, society will be that
much more utopian? and so in that sense, i guess i sortof think of raves as
a kind of movement.

joe

>i wrote this to iris in a personal post, and here's my theory on it all:
>the protestant work ethic is so engrained in our minds here that we feel
>guilty about having fun. raving is a movement, a hedonistic one. but this
>doesn't fly here in the us.

If this is the case then why does raving work in other countries whose
cultures are also steeped in Protestantism ( ie Germany or Great Britain)?
There has to be something more too it than this...Why is it that the more
fucked up a city is the more likely it is to develop a thriving rave scene
( and also one that is based on harder forms of techno )?


Owen Virus

X-Sender: randream@si.UCSC.EDU
To: cathode <cathode@idiom.com>
cc: "e.menon" <emdash@grin.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: acid rave culture - my theory
In-Reply-To: <v03007800afeec9814c31@[206.14.123.16]>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970713200524.25569A-100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



Hi all!  ]=}

 A response;


On Sun, 13 Jul 1997, cathode wrote:

> >i wrote this to iris in a personal post, and here's my theory on it all:
> >the protestant work ethic is so engrained in our minds here that we feel
> >guilty about having fun. raving is a movement, a hedonistic one. but this
> >doesn't fly here in the us.
> 
> If this is the case then why does raving work in other countries whose
> cultures are also steeped in Protestantism ( ie Germany or Great Britain)?
> There has to be something more too it than this...Why is it that the more
> fucked up a city is the more likely it is to develop a thriving rave scene
> ( and also one that is based on harder forms of techno )?

 It seems to be strongly accepted (in academia at least) that the more 
repression (of certain human needs and desires) you have, the more likely 
expressions of the situation will crop up (unexpectdly) in the strangest of 
places.

 The example I learned from was that of Classic Hollywood Horror films 
and gay/lesbian sexuality. In the 30's (the start of Classic Horror for 
Hollywood) we have many Horror movies that treat gay as "other" or 
monsterous. Bride Of Frankenstein is a very good example (check out the 
sterotyped "bad" doctor). The reasoning goes along the lines that gay 
sexuality simply wasn't talked about or accepted in America. This 
repression resulted in an increased desire to expose this lifestyle (by 
Gays) to mainstream America. One avenue was the Horror film. Horror was less 
tightly regulated and there were many Gay directors, screenwriters and 
actors.

 Thje results are often hilarious in some cases. I spent an entire 
quarter of looking at Horror films every week and studying Gay theory. 
Quite the eye opener.

 Hope this helps,

peas,


Ran D. Dreams


				    (Namaste)

                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

Hi all.

Here is an updated vers. of a post i put onto the vrave list a a little 
while ago:

I'm over in the US from London, England until mid September travelling 
all over. Just a DJ & his tunes & a couple of friends looking for some  
fun times & party people. With some chilling out thrown in for good 
measure & good health. So heres the deal...

This is my first time in the US and my first chance to DJ outside of 
London. I play Drum & Bass, chillout & trance/acid techno & I've got a 
few things lined up but i'm looking for some more. At the moment i'm in 
NYC (fun & crazy!) until July 14 then up to the mid west (St Louis & 
Chicago) onto Madison for the full moon (18/19th?) back to MPLS for the 
26th & then onto Oregon & down the CA coast (SF, LA & SD) then to 
Burning Man in Nevada @ the end of Aug & then back to NYC & then home in 
September (haven't decided when yet!)

I also work for a new record co. in London (Seraphim Records) - we're 
putting out some lush, chilled D&B soon and other styles in the future - 
and i'm looking to make some contacts over here. If you DJ, promote, 
distribute, run a store, a record co or know someone who does or 
whatever you will love what i've got with me. I'm not being pushy, its 
just that everyone we play the tunes to loves them! Or maybe you'll hate 
them. It would be quite good to meet someone who does just to balance 
things out a bit!

im also looking for tapes of stuff for future releases on the label


I'm also pushing my flatmate's internet based radio station in London 
(starting soon on www.0171.com - cool site check it out) & DJ agency.

And maybe i'll have a holiday in between. Maybe!

So there you have it. Anyone interested in any of the above? If so, say 
hi. I pick up my mail every other day (ah - the joys of the 'net!)  and 
it'll give me a chance to find out a bit more a bit about the various 
scenes & styles over here or just communicate with some good people.

Is anybody out there??  (sorry for being so corny!)

Love

invisible cola (Rob)

UPDATE ON 14th July:

Well NYC was soooo good. Met lots of excellent people (hi to Dara & all 
@ Breakbeat Science, Astralwerks, Sm:)e, Koncrete Jungle, Jungle Nation 
& Twilo plus all the loverly ravers & jumper i met!),  had some great 
parties & everybody who heard our pre-release CD loved it! Lots of 
interest so Seraphim Records will be droppin' on the US sometime in the 
future. As will our DJs & artists :)

After the craziness of NYC im looking forward to seeing & meeting the 
other parts of this fair land.

Thing is i know San F. & area is going to be just my style so come back 
& say hi. See yous in August :)))))))))


"Be in the game, but not of the game"

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Rave Culture basis for a book by D.Rushkoff
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

This is a groovy book i just read based on SF Rave culture.
 
At first, when i saw the book w/ it~s electric cover and the words
<<Ecstasy Club>> i thought [man, here we go, another sensationalized
book about our scene, with everything blown out of proportion], but i
was pleasantly surprised and immediately became engrossed.
 
Here's the gist...<<when the young, hypertalented idealists who call
themselves ECSTASY CLUB find an abandoned piano factory in Oakland,
they make it the focus of a round~the~clock rave the likes of which
the Bay Area has never seen before [hmm]. They also make the factory a
base camp in their search for a method of time travel [sign me up!]
that combines computer wizardry, esoteric spirituality, and
mind~altering substances [yum, my fave]. The Club's mesmeric leader,
Duncan, and our resourceful narrator, Zach, actually manage to 'break
time' online, only to discover that an unsettling array of characters
has beat them to it. Government [THE MAN] agents, corporate saboteurs,
religious zealots, and even the local cops [no shit!] are suddenly out
to get the Club. As they battle an ingeniously conceived conspiracy,
Zach battles his own growing affection for Duncan's lover [drama!],
Lauren, and begins to wonder whether enlightenment is all it's cracked
up to be.>>
 
So it's pretty well written, i heared Rushkoff talk about his book,
his focus is on <<current counterculture>>, how first it is a <<cult>>
and then becomes <<overculture>> and he talked about our search for
authenticity, he respects Ravers, especially in his interviews since
he talks about the Rave scene an all of its aspects, he's not out to
exploit us, but IMO he's helping in giving an understanding of what
Raving is.

Welp, that~s my $17.50 [cost of the book] Rushkoff's website is listed
under http://www.levity.com check it out if you're curious, and please
email me w/ your <<deep thoughts>>
ciao,
~~ena~

Message-ID: <970713203936_1623366049@emout04.mail.aol.com>
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Last Night.. A raving story(long)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Well, after my ride toyed with Teresa and my hopes for a week as to which
party we were going to.. it all blew up last night.  Originally, way back a
month ago, Teresa and I were thinking, *ok, we'll go to Infectious Grooves.*
Heeheheh.. bad Idea.  Anyway, so along comes @spire, and with my current
financial situation (or lack there of) I thought an outdoor party sounded
like damn good fun!
*So here's the deal..* I tell Teresa.. *We should go to @spire."
But it was really all up to Matt (our ride) because, wherever he goes, we
sortof get taken to. Not that I don't appreciate getting driven around.  I
really do.  But here's what happened...
Matt thought we were going to the Gathering... but there wasn't a gathering
this weekend.  And then he said Intoxication.. which isn't until next
weekend.  SO someone's calander is a little off.  But all we know is we are
MAKING IT TO A RAVE SATURDAY NIGHT.
SO there I am.. sitting in Teresa's room, glitter in hand, when Matt calls.  
*UH.. would you guys mind if we didn't go raving?*
Cuz matt's friend had some DJs coming up to spin and Matt's house was the
perfect location to have it.  But it was a no-win situation.  Either the
house party and no rave for us.. or rave and no house party for his friends.
 So we compromised with the Be home by 3 a.m. thing and decided that's what
time his house party could start.  It was now 8:30, and we still didn't have
a rave to go to.  OUt-A-SIght!  But the voice mail was a message saying to
call back closer to July 12th.  There were only 3 and a half hours left in
the day, and I didn't know how much longer we had to get closer to the 12th.
 
Anyway, so we ended up going to Infectious Grooves.  I was expecting a huge
line, with homie G's all lined up and the whole bit.  But there was virtually
no line.  We got right in the door with some smiles and such from the
cashiers.  There couldn't have been more than 200 people there.  So we look
around as the place starts to fill up.. and find some pure MDMA.  =) No more
bunk E!  I'm seeing a few people I know and dancing around.  I realized I
tune out all bad vibes so beautifully.  Not that there were many.  The
visuals were beautiful.  Except, at one point I looked up and realized they
were showing the opening scene from "Kids".   I ran into part of my candy
raver crew from Area 51.  Hello to: Sandy!  MarQ, Ben, ( and his little bro
Billy) Mars Man, Crisco, Luke Squared, Lisa, Jamie, Sky, and all the many ppl
who are just faces in my head.  I love you all.  And with the E and the hugs
and the "I love you so much" I had a really good night.  DJ Ghost was
spinning some of DJ Dan's "LOose CaBooSe", which was ok, since I love a lot
of those tracks.  Thanx to Crisco for naming his stuffed toy after me.. DOn't
forget her name now!  To the girl on the floor who looked like she passed
out, but once we gave her some water and massages she was ok.  IF I missed
the bad vibe and circle dancing and gangstas I really couldn't care less.
 This is why I love raving.  Just me and my little stuffed Nosy Bear.  Hope
to see you all soon..

       hugs n'Stuff,
           'trice the tekno diva                 <<<<RAVEON>>>>

>>Hi,
>>
>>As you may have seen recently on Channel 4 News or San Jose
>>Mercury News, a beautiful open space on the San Mateo Coast
>>called Cascade Ranch is in immediate danger of development. A
>>grassroots effort to save Cascade Ranch is underway. The
>>Coastside Habitat Coalition is leading this fight.
>>
>>Cascade Ranch is halfway between Santa Cruz and Half Moon Bay
>>near Ano Nuevo State Park.  Development of 112 RV sites, 76 tent
>>campsites, 130 room resort, 12 cabins, 40 room lodge, store,
>>conference center, multiple gyms, 2 pools, tennis courts, etc. is
>>planned for the site.
>>
>>Issues with the proposed development:
>>-------------------------------------
>>   - One of the most beautiful stretches of California coastline
>>and open space will be marred.
>>   - This campsite/lodge can support about 1000 people per day.
>>Neighboring communities are small (<500 people).   Traffic along
>>highway 1 will dramatically incease.  Impact on local communities
>>and coastside ecology will be major.
>>   - An endangered species (San Francisco Garter Snake) and a
>>threatened species (Red-legged Frog) currently inhabit Cascade
>>Ranch and will probably not survive this development
>>   - A large well will be drilled at the site of a former Ohlone
>>Indian settlement.  This is the place where the explorer Portola
>>first encountered the Ohlone Indians in the 1700s.   It is a
>>potentially valuable archaeological site.
>>
>>What concerned people can do:
>>-----------------------------
>>   - Forward this message to others who may be interested.
>>   - See http://www.outre.com/cascade for more info.
>>   - Join the grassroots effort and contribute in whatever way
>>you can.
>>          Address:  Coastside Habitat Coalition
>>                    P.O. Box 71
>>                    San Gregorio, CA 94074
>>          Phone:    (415) 726-0565
>>          E-mail:   sangregoro@aol.com
>>   - Let your representatives and the media know what you think
>>about preserving the coastside.
>>   - Participate in a *nature hike* July 5.  Join naturalist Joe
>>Barnwell to explore beautiful Cascade Ranch State Park which is
>>adjacent to the private development site. This hike is sponsored
>>by the Coastside Habitat Coalition. Suggested sliding scale
>>donation of $5 - $20.  Meet at the San Gregorio General Store at
>>the corner of Highway 84 and Stage Rd. on Saturday July 5 at
>>10:00 am. Call 415-726-0565 for more information.
>>   - Attend the next *volunteer action meeting* on Wednesday
>>evening July 9 at the San Gregorio General Store at the corner of
>>Highway 84 and Stage Rd. at 7:30 pm. Call 415-726-0565 for more
>>information.
>>   - Come out and have fun at the *Coastal Protection Concert*
>>the first weekend in August. The concert will feature hot Bay
>>Area bands including Box Set, Frontmen, Pele Juju, Harmony Grits
>>and Claddagh Band. This concert will raise money for legal
>>actions to save Cascade Ranch. This all day outdoor concert will
>>be held behind the San Gregorio General Store at the corner of
>>Highway 84 and Stage Rd. Call 415-726-0565 for more information.

I have worked in Yosemite for the National Park Service, not the snack
bar or the cafeteria but in search and rescue, with police rangers, and
educational tours and history programs for children.  And I'd like to
give some free advice....
 

     1. if bringing drugs (I don't reccomend) be very discreet... I
     mean  VERY.... what  might be a simple misdemeanor outside the park
     or national forest can be a very big Federal Crime..... and these
     Police rangers usually don't play around.  also the if you have to
     have a court hearing it is done by the federal judge appointed to
     the court in Yosemite and he is not a nice guy to people doing
     stupid things.
     2. try your hardest to carpool into the park... the pollution from
     the cars is killing the trees in the park...especially the
     ponderosa and jefferey pines.... and also, the entry fee was raised
     from $5 - $20.
     3. Try to keep the wildlife WILD.... do not feed the animals... by 
     people feeding them, they are becoming unable to take care of  
     themselves and are not living as long as they should/could...    
     also try to stay on the trails... they are there for your safety
     and  so that the natural beauty of Yosemite stays as untouched as
     possible.

 

sorry for sounding like an old man but that place is one of natures most
beautiful works of art and we must preserve it....
 

scott B.

sbunzey@earthlink.net

>
>PS,  Hey everybody, Pengo talks in his sleep!

well back WAY back when I was 22 I had contacts.  And I used to wonder why
one of them would always fall out at night when I would sleep.  I had
softies that you could sleep with.

Months after I had given up the contacts for a more John Lennonish look
fresh for the 1990's and Green Day 1990, I fell asleep drunk on Lindsay's
floor.  Later on that morning someone told me, surprisingly, that I
actually sleep with one eye open!

Hey Blake, maybe we would be a good act together, my eye flickering, you
doing a presidential state of the union in your sleep and b((merang (he
alwyas comes back to you!) playing his abstract mindbender...

well, it's just a thought.  perhaps it is not profitable enough.  oh well.
time to get depressed, quit dj'ing and appliy for a job at Mickey Dee's.

At 45 I still wasn't the oldest member of
>the list but,...
>
yes, actually I am the oldest one, though I can't prove it to any of you.
I'm actually 320 years old, and I traveled here from the early 25th
century, where me -n- Buck Rogers used to sit around and pound red hook
ales and pick up on Venutian Belly Dancers.

Anyone like B((merang can testify to how much "Star Trek:  The Next
Generation" I watch, so that is proof enough that I was accidentally
teleported back here into the dismal 20th century when I was in a tanning
booth and apparently the operator spilled coffee on the control panel and
it went haywire causing a temporal causality loop that causes me to jump
around the space-time continuim whether or not I am exxing.  Whew.  Did I
say that all in one word?

So does California rEALLY  fall into the ocean?  I'm not saying.

Cause wE are creating our own future, and I wouldn't want to alter the
possible course of history to repeat itself.

I wish I could go back though to get a 1998 horse racing results or
something.

all right blah blah blah.  that's enough chatter.  My theeth are getting
tired, gonna have to go take them out now.

From: mike clay <meclay@ix.netcom.com>

To: Joe Salas <joesalas@earthlink.net>

Subject: Re: rave as movement?
References: <3.0.1.32.19970713175033.006a66a8@mail.earthlink.net>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Since what you said interests me I thought I'd make a comment and
express an opinion....(or two ;-)

Joe Salas wrote:
> 

> nevertheless, i think there is something going on at most raves that can be
> spread to the rest of the world, that feels like could change the world in
> some way.

 Although it might feel like that I really don't think so.... what MOST
people feel (although I can't speak for you) is :

  1) the mind expansiveness of psychedelic drug use (see 60's movement)
    which if it doesn't go beyond "just" taking more drugs leads
    nowhere (see R. Alpert aka Ram Dass)
  2) COMMUNITY!!!  Cities ABSOLUTELY SUCK and SUCK bigtime in their
    community - they DON't have it and it feels lonely!! Pure and
simple.
    Most of my life I've lived in small towns ie under 10,000 people.
    There you know your neighbors etc. Everytime you go shopping you
    meet friends... everytime you do business you meet friends....
    You can leave your doors open...  You know 1000+ people and
    you can share....
    Live with 4000 people and you know 2000 people.... live with 
    6 million and you're lucky if you know 12 (at least well)...
    see my point?
> 
> what i found at my first rave that i dont find in my normal life is that
> unselfishness and lack of judgement, the act that most of us perform of
> being nice to somebody, talking to them, hugging them, giving them a piece
> of candy, and all for no real reason, just for the sake of being nice.
> furthermore, when we do this, we do not exclude anyone, but give it out to
> anyone who wants it.

  What you are feeling here is community... like going down to the local
  market and really talking to the people there, talking to the clerks,
  having them help you because they actually know you... actually
"knowing"
  people when you go somewhere.....
 
  So for an experiment: go to Safeway... pay attention to your time
there...
  How many people do you talk to? How many people do you share something
  with? etc...
  Now consider how nice it is to go to a rave and start meeting lots of
  people who actually want to see you, talk to you etc.  Feels good
  doesn't it! 
  Now go to a club... Well they've got lights and music JUST LIKE a rave
  don't they?  But notice how lonely it is because people aren't
sharing.
  
  So raves aren't special because of lights or music are they? CLubs
have
  that and they aren't special... so I'm not a believer that what
  makes raves special is the "music".... It's the sense of community....
  It's the sharing... It's the fact that the DJ's who play the music
  actually hang out and are part of the community... which feeds back
  and causes you to like their music even more because you know them
  etc.....

> 
> when i first witnessed this, i was shocked at how much i discovered i
> really need that sort of situation sometimes, how simple it is, and how
> good it makes me feel.

  You actually need "community".... some people get it at their local
   church... some people hang out with the new age, yoga whatever
groups...
  some people hang out at schools... and some people hang out at
raves...
  but without the sense of community or "belonging" life is pretty
lonely...

 
> sometimes when i watch the news or read the paper, or hear of awful,
> negative events that happen to other people, i wonder that the rest of the
> world cannot realize and know the attitudes and actions that permeate the
> rave atmosphere. if only people could, living and working, then dying,
> would be so much nicer.
> 

  All these negative things you read about are MOST often (but not
always)
products of large cities with breakdown of community... Jack the Ripper
normally happens in big cities.... bank robbers, drive by shootings
etc...
gang violence etc... these are the products of big cities...

 Of course small towns are NOT utopia... people sometimes go bonkers and
shoot their family... bad things happen... but bad things happen at
these
wonderful raves too.... just not as often in small towns....

  My relatives in small town WV could never understand all the negative
things they read about in the papers... it really wasn't a part of
their world....

> we do this every weekend, but it is true that it is probably not going to
> change the world. but what i hope is at least happening is that all the
> ravers that experience this at parties tries to live it in their regular
> daytime lives a little bit, then passes it on to their children. teach them
> this attitude, let them know the enjoyment of practicing it for its own
> sake, rather than attach some vague, uncertain reward, like going to heaven
> when youre dead. then, who knows? maybe in the future, society will be that
> much more utopian? and so in that sense, i guess i sortof think of raves as
> a kind of movement.

  You might really like living in a small town like Bodega Bay or
someplace
where you actually "knew" people around you.... I guess what I am saying
is that I don't believe raves are going to change the world... they are
just helping you discover how much it sucks to live in a world without
community (which is the way of life in big cities and always was, even
hundreds of years ago)....

  SO people living in small towns across the world already are
"changed"...
they don't need the rave movement to teach them what they already
know...
living in community is the most positive way to live.... we (in the
large cities) need raves to give us a community to hang out in....

 Just my opinion,

 Mike

-- 
     Mike Clay      meclay@ix.netcom.com    (415) 572-8971
**** Alone and Ecstatic a young rainbow learns to levitate. ****

From: macadio <macadio6@rocketmail.com>
Subject: @spire Review (real long)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Hey all you wavers let me tell you about this Misson of ours,

My day starts off good nice sunny morning I am supposed to meet Jer at
City E at 10:00 am. I look at my clock after I shit, shower, shave
etc.. I think Shit it is 10:00 I am supposed to be at city E but as I
am walking out the door I get a call it is Jer saying he is running
late but he will be at City E in a while and tell everyone to stay and
wait till he gets there. I show up and there is No one waiting to move
anything I get my Chai Tea  and boom Jer is there with his truck and
sound system. And with what looks like a small skeleton crew. I think
Alright lets get it started cause we are already running kind of late.
We hang there for a while then we decided to leave. We get to SC kind
of lagging I lose them we are playing pager tag. Then we hook up they
need me to get the generator. Which is a mission to get to the place
to rent it. I look at  my watch and it is like 1:00 I am like "Fuck"
we are way lagging the party was supposed to start at 12:00  so we get
the gene and they get the sound down the Hill (ha, ha, ha,) I think
Kewl I did not have to take the speakers down that steep cliff. So we
proceed to setup and as I am getting the gene out of my Van guess who
rolls up? Who you ask well the beach patrol. And they ask what the
Gene is for and we say for our sound system cause we could not lie and
say for our BBQ or Cars so we asks if we have a permit and we say No
and he says then you have to pack your stuff up and leave. We sit
there for what seems like hours as disapponted ravers show up and we
say we are going to move it to our new secret location. He hang out
some more then proceed to our secret local. When we show up
there,There are some Locks on the gate to the forest location and
signs that say No trespassing. We think Shit our new location has been
busted too. At this point we are really starting to panic we have  car
loads or Ravers that want to party. So we run around for like hours
trying to find a new location. Well actually Jer did we all marinated
at the little mexican restaurant on Highway 1 So finally Jer comes
back at 11:00 PM and says he has found a spot. Keep in Mind this party
was supposed to start at 12:00 in the afternoon. So we go to the spot
and set up and get things going. I have to send a special thanks to
all the DJ's that played they were all good. Shouts goes out to Phil
(pistachio) and Anonymous sorry did not get your real name and there
buddy Jeremy that bought the Dope lights that lite up the beach. Phil
went on playing some good mellow trance I think? then Anonymous busted
some real nice melodic trance. Then I stepped up to the plate and
Played. I hope those that were there liked my sounds? It was good till
the circuit breaker went out twice as I was Knobbing the sound and
Eq's right at the climax of some real good hard Tek rekkids. But it
was fun and everyone was real nice the 300 + plus hard core dedicated
party goers Me and @spire crew would like to thank you. This was Jer
and Arons first party and it fucking rocked!! Even through out all the
problems of some persons trying to get the party busted it still went
off!! better luck next time to the assholes that tried to get it
busted. I wont forget what Jer told me in the begging of our mission.
He said "Macadio I will make sure you spin at this party today. It
will not get busted I will do whatever I have to, to make sure you
play" And he held up on that promise by putting on a phat party Thank
you Jer and I look forward to playing for you and Aron any time. O BTW
thanks to all the crew that helped Vertigo, Adam G, george, the wonder
twin girls and all the rest that I can't think of. Sorry this post is
so long I can keep going but I will stop now. For those of you that
missed out. Sorry but you truely missed out this was a really good
party.

Love ya all,
Macadio

Well folks, this is it. MAD is ending. After tonight, that's it! Sayonara,
Arrive a derci, 
Adios, Cheers, A Slaam A-Laikum,  C-YA!

I just want to thank everyone, especially the punters and gurners who came
out and spent their hard earned money to dance at the club every week. I
really apprieciate the opportunity to be involved in MAD(Thanks Joe!).

Lasting memories from the club:
-Meeting/hanging out with Carl Craig & his girfriend Hannah. Then...
-Carl Playing live @ Madness while Bruce Lee's "Chinese Connection" was on
the big screen(per his request).
-"Dennis Hopper" the security guard.
-2001: A Space Odessey.
-The one kid who NEVER EVER had his ID, or any money who insisted on trying
to get into the club EVERY week!  Most of the time with no luck.
-Star Wars.
-Fred the security guard wearing tampons in his ears one week after losing
his earplugs.
-Alec Empire saying in his teutonic tinged accent, "This is crazy!"
-Driving around SF with Dave Clarke, just listening to him talk.
-"No Eye Contact Man."
-Antonio the batender and his computer questions.
-Menstral Blood discussions w/ Sig.
-Portuguese accents.
-The MAD/Orbital Giveaway night. And the arguments before it.
-Happy Donuts.
-Eddie the security guard.
-Alan Oldham weekend.
-The Final MAD.

See you all tonight!
--Monty

we were not talking about whether and where raving _works_. we were
talking about whether the rave scene could develop into a political
movement. and our theory was that it wouldn't because it's a purely
hedonistic movement w/ no interest in politics. e.menon suggested that
political _justifications_ for raving are sometimes given due to the
feeling of guilt we are all raised w/ in this culture. raves work in
england, in germany, in the u.s. ... as raves, but not as a political
forum. (you must have missed some of the thread of this conversation.
nobody is saying that raves don't work, aren't fun...whatever.)

iris

---cathode <cathode@idiom.com> wrote:
>
> 
> >i wrote this to iris in a personal post, and here's my theory on it
all:
> >the protestant work ethic is so engrained in our minds here that we
feel
> >guilty about having fun. raving is a movement, a hedonistic one.
but this
> >doesn't fly here in the us.
> 
> If this is the case then why does raving work in other countries
whose
> cultures are also steeped in Protestantism ( ie Germany or Great
Britain)?
> There has to be something more too it than this...Why is it that the
more
> fucked up a city is the more likely it is to develop a thriving rave
scene
> ( and also one that is based on harder forms of techno )?
> 
> 
> Owen Virus
> 
> 
>

Wednesday Noon till 1:00 or so...

El Torito - In Santa Clara

Exit Great America (aka Bowers)
Go West (that's right if you're from the North, and left if you're from
the South)
Right on Augustine
Right on Lakeside Drive
2950 Lakeside Drive (just around bend on left side)
Total Driving Time once off freeway is less than 2 minutes!
408-727-4426

Your meal should run about $8.00-12.00, but cheaper plates are available.

I'd love to see you all there... and if you show, I'll tell the story
behind my last post.

a.	I miss Branka, who can never make it on Tuesday.

c.	It doesn't start with a T.

and it's damn hard to eat those free chips with lockjaw.

at 408-435-5259.  Also, if you only get an hour for lunch, we can order
for you, and you just arrive to your hot steaming plate.  Because that's
how much we care...

What i've heard is that it was the switch from psychedelics to speed that
killed it - same as the first raving "peak", circa '91-92 ... whatever -
any movement based primarily on pleasure & desire isn't going to last
anyway - but Rave Culture is something deeper - the resurfacing of the
ancient ways in a new context - what Camille Paglia, Starhawk, etc. have
written about many times - more later ....

raen

the Knitting Factory (I think it is called something like SOundlab).  I   
heard Expo can be good (if it still open) as well if very unfriendly at   
times.  But the fact of the matter is Giuliani has been after many of the   
clubs and shutting them down by slapping them with selling pot.  They   
open up again but they have to do it in underground locations.  Best bet   
is to go to one of the before mentioned clubs and chat up a club kid.  By   
the way, Fez is a great acid jazz club that is always a rocking time.

Cassandra

X-Received: by smtp.kmd-arch.com with Microsoft Mail
	id <33CA72E0@smtp.kmd-arch.com>; Mon, 14 Jul 97 11:41:36 PDT
From: Cassandra Thomas <cthomas@kmd-arch.com>
To: sfraves-owner <sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org>
Subject: RE: rave as movement?
Date: Mon, 14 Jul 97 11:37:00 PDT
Message-ID: <33CA72E0@smtp.kmd-arch.com>
X-Mailer: Microsoft Mail V3.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


I understand the impuldse about small towns-but cities are capable of   
small town feeling-they are called "neighborhoods" places where people   
could walk .6 mi in any direction, get anything they needed, while   
running into their neighbor walking a dog......i have lived in both biug   
cities and small towns...i personally felt more lonely in the small towns   
becuse i ran into an extreme amount of Xenophobia on top of the fact that   
the only real social avenues to get into the VERY close knit social   
fabric of the town was the church and the AMerican Lesion, and various   
other clubs (like the Elks or the MAsons) or the hunting lodge.  Yes,   
small towns can be great but their defintion of community can be very   
exclusive....plus, with the advent of the supremacy of the car...the   
chance meetings of walking into your neighbor are quite lessened...

I love cities like S.F. for the chance meetings that can occur and the   
fact that what I am interested in and what hooks me up with people can   
not normally be found in small town America (at least from my various   
experiences).....community can be found in many ways...i personally feel   
lonelier in the country because i am an urban person....some people feel   
lonely at a rave because they don't like the drugs, they think everybody   
is in their own drug world and they feel excluded,etc....what I think is   
key is finding those things which interest you and link you with other   
people and not being afraid...i knew all my neighbors in New York City   
becuse we all walked are dogs together, got involved with the   
neighborhood assoc. and the tenant group...though we were all very   
different we felt it was all in our common interest to be involved...the   
small towns I have been in everyone preferred to stay walled in their   
respective familial enclaves...it was very hard to be accepted as a   
minority and outsider even though the house I moved into had been owned   
by our family for ten years at that point..

community has to be defined by the values of the society and whether city   
or country, if people are going to be protective and do not see it in   
their common interest to get together they won't ....suburbia exists to a   
great part because people bought the myth that the detached single family   
dwelling which afforded privacy was a great way to bring up a family anf   
offer security (plus a way out of increasingly diverse aka minority   
cities).

IMHO

Cassandra

 ----------
From:  sfraves-owner[SMTP:sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org]
Sent:  Monday, July 14, 1997 10:35 AM
To:  Joe Salas
Cc:  SFraves
Subject:  Re: rave as movement?

Since what you said interests me I thought I'd make a comment and
express an opinion....(or two ;-)

Joe Salas wrote:
>

> nevertheless, i think there is something going on at most raves that   
can be
> spread to the rest of the world, that feels like could change the world   
in
> some way.

 Although it might feel like that I really don't think so.... what MOST
people feel (although I can't speak for you) is :

  1) the mind expansiveness of psychedelic drug use (see 60's movement)
    which if it doesn't go beyond "just" taking more drugs leads
    nowhere (see R. Alpert aka Ram Dass)
  2) COMMUNITY!!!  Cities ABSOLUTELY SUCK and SUCK bigtime in their
    community - they DON't have it and it feels lonely!! Pure and
simple.
    Most of my life I've lived in small towns ie under 10,000 people.
    There you know your neighbors etc. Everytime you go shopping you
    meet friends... everytime you do business you meet friends....
    You can leave your doors open...  You know 1000+ people and
    you can share....
    Live with 4000 people and you know 2000 people.... live with
    6 million and you're lucky if you know 12 (at least well)...
    see my point?
>
> what i found at my first rave that i dont find in my normal life is   
that
> unselfishness and lack of judgement, the act that most of us perform of
> being nice to somebody, talking to them, hugging them, giving them a   
piece
> of candy, and all for no real reason, just for the sake of being nice.
> furthermore, when we do this, we do not exclude anyone, but give it out   
to
> anyone who wants it.

  What you are feeling here is community... like going down to the local
  market and really talking to the people there, talking to the clerks,
  having them help you because they actually know you... actually
"knowing"
  people when you go somewhere.....
   

  So for an experiment: go to Safeway... pay attention to your time
there...
  How many people do you talk to? How many people do you share something
  with? etc...
  Now consider how nice it is to go to a rave and start meeting lots of
  people who actually want to see you, talk to you etc.  Feels good
  doesn't it!
  Now go to a club... Well they've got lights and music JUST LIKE a rave
  don't they?  But notice how lonely it is because people aren't
sharing.
    

  So raves aren't special because of lights or music are they? CLubs
have
  that and they aren't special... so I'm not a believer that what
  makes raves special is the "music".... It's the sense of community....
  It's the sharing... It's the fact that the DJ's who play the music
  actually hang out and are part of the community... which feeds back
  and causes you to like their music even more because you know them
  etc.....

>
> when i first witnessed this, i was shocked at how much i discovered i
> really need that sort of situation sometimes, how simple it is, and how
> good it makes me feel.

  You actually need "community".... some people get it at their local
   church... some people hang out with the new age, yoga whatever
groups...
  some people hang out at schools... and some people hang out at
raves...
  but without the sense of community or "belonging" life is pretty
lonely...

   

> sometimes when i watch the news or read the paper, or hear of awful,
> negative events that happen to other people, i wonder that the rest of   
the
> world cannot realize and know the attitudes and actions that permeate   
the
> rave atmosphere. if only people could, living and working, then dying,
> would be so much nicer.
>

  All these negative things you read about are MOST often (but not
always)
products of large cities with breakdown of community... Jack the Ripper
normally happens in big cities.... bank robbers, drive by shootings
etc...
gang violence etc... these are the products of big cities...

 Of course small towns are NOT utopia... people sometimes go bonkers and
shoot their family... bad things happen... but bad things happen at
these
wonderful raves too.... just not as often in small towns....

  My relatives in small town WV could never understand all the negative
things they read about in the papers... it really wasn't a part of
their world....

> we do this every weekend, but it is true that it is probably not going   
to
> change the world. but what i hope is at least happening is that all the
> ravers that experience this at parties tries to live it in their   
regular
> daytime lives a little bit, then passes it on to their children. teach   
them
> this attitude, let them know the enjoyment of practicing it for its own
> sake, rather than attach some vague, uncertain reward, like going to   
heaven
> when youre dead. then, who knows? maybe in the future, society will be   
that
> much more utopian? and so in that sense, i guess i sortof think of   
raves as
> a kind of movement.

  You might really like living in a small town like Bodega Bay or
someplace
where you actually "knew" people around you.... I guess what I am saying
is that I don't believe raves are going to change the world... they are
just helping you discover how much it sucks to live in a world without
community (which is the way of life in big cities and always was, even
hundreds of years ago)....

  SO people living in small towns across the world already are
"changed"...
they don't need the rave movement to teach them what they already
know...
living in community is the most positive way to live.... we (in the
large cities) need raves to give us a community to hang out in....

 Just my opinion,

 Mike

 --
     Mike Clay      meclay@ix.netcom.com    (415) 572-8971
**** Alone and Ecstatic a young rainbow learns to levitate. ****

MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Adventures _in.the.Beginning_ - @spire story
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Adventures _in.the.beginning_
with stars:
Jer
Aaron
George
Krissy
Euginia
Macadio
Vertigo
AdamG
Todd Manley
Tony (aka Deepfog)
and many many more!!

ok... started out friday night with tons of stuff to do before the
party... pickin' up crap, buying stuff, and stuff and stuff. =) no sleep
for me. Woowoo it's Saturday... day of the party, let's go! 7:30 am, I
get on the move, get everyone together and all head down to meet up at
City E down in Santa Clara. We get outta there with the whole crew and
move out to Santa Cruz to set-up. Finally get to the day party location
around 1ish and start to set up, but dun dun dunnnnnn.... beach patrol
shows up. Let me tell you guys something.... beach patrol sux!!! Now the
adventure begins. We drive all up and down highway 1 with a shit load of
people running from beach patrol, but we out smart 'em and head over to
our forest location to set up for the night party. *BOOM* the place is
locked up and no trespassing signs everywhere. Now check this out....
we've been scoping the place for a week, and like 3 hours before we went
there to set up, we checked it, and it was exactly how we left it. In
between the hours that we checked it and went to set up, someone locked
the place up. *beep beep* *beep beep* pagers go off. Aaron and I check
our voice mails, mine said "are you guys through yet?", Aaron's,
"DENIED!!! you guys will never throw your party!". Seems as if we have
someone trying to stop us. Guess they didn't quite know who they were
dealing with! I do NOT give up, and I do NOT fail, especially when there
were so so many people planning to come out at night! it's about 6pm
now, so we send everyone to hang out at davenport while we take care of
business. 5 of us go all over the place to find another location as
special as the forest location that got popped, but no luck. It's
10pm... time to use the back up location. We go back to davenport and
pick up the 50 or so people there and head on outta there. We way north
of davenport and set up. The crew kicked ass.. they got the sound going
in 30 mins. We send 3 girls down to 7-11 in santa cruz for a map point.
We needed the map point so that our back up wouldn't get busted. Whoever
was screwing with us was checking the VM and tippin off the cops and
beach patrol. 7-11 lasted about 45 mins till it got busted, so the girls
started bouncing all over the place, 5 places in total, where they ended
up in Safeway. hehe our last voice mail said, "go to safeway, go in
safeway, look for 3 girls walking around, ask them for directions." =)
well we pulled it off..... 500 smiling faces out there... awesome
lighting and sound (thanx ari, and the other jeremy who brought the
lights). and it went off from 10:30pm till 8:30 in the morning. Too bad
I missed so much of it though =( I fell asleep hehe. Woke up to Aaron
spinning hardcore at 8am and people still dancing. we clean up and get
outta there.

I'm still tired so I missed a lot of stuff and stuff.

thanx to everyone who came out and sorry to those that couldn't make it
or find it.
special thanx to montery jeremy for working the entrance forever =)
sorry man. thanx to bao for doing that too... thanx to all the dj's who
played and made it out there (anonymous, pistachio, macadio, anakin,
vertigo, li, marty) I fell asleep but I think deepfog spun too.... thanx
to the djs for helping out so so much too! thanx to everyone who helped
clean up. thanx for not making fires and throwing up tents =) thanx to
anyone I missed. and if I did, I'm sorry... i'm just soooo tired hehe.

more on all this later.

love you guys!!!!!!!!! jer - @spire

ps. have faith in us... I know a lot of you didn't come out when you
heard the day party got busted, but we will never ever disappoint, and I
promise you guys that!

till next time, @spire

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Mon Jul 14 15:18:08 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) id PAA09417;
	Mon, 14 Jul 1997 15:18:08 -0700 (PDT)
