	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Mon, 14 Jul 1997 15:17:56 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from digidesign.com (gates.digidesign.com [199.182.65.9]) by digidesign.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id PAA12433 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Mon, 14 Jul 1997 15:18:45 -0700
Message-ID: <n1343228816.22235@digidesign.com>
Date: 14 Jul 1997 15:17:12 -0700
From: "Mark Camp" <campm@digidesign.com>
Subject: Music and Money
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP-MS 3.0.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"; Name="Message Body"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-MIME-Autoconverted: from quoted-printable to 8bit by hyperreal.org id PAA09289
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hello all.  I don't post very often, but I have been a long time member of SFR.  I was off the list for a while and have just recently resubscribed so I wanted to say HI to all of you I know and HI to all that I don't know.

I would like to talk about Music and Money.  If you havnt noticed lately, the music we all hold so dear to our hearts is now getting a lot of attention.  I havnt really decided if this is a good or a bad thing.  Recently, My brother's band, SmashMouth, got a major record deal with Interscope Records.  Their music is your typical KOME 'Alternative Rock'.  And now they are all over the radio, all over the country, with a video soon to be on MTV.  What is so strange about this, is I've been listening to my bro write killer music for years.  But nobody knew, except for the local San Jose music scene that would go out and watch them play.  Now, the same songs that they were playing a year or two ago are all over the radio and everybody loves them.   Why?  Because there is a whole bunch of money behind the band.    I am not saying this is a bad thing.  My bro and all the members of the band are living their dream.  They have accomplished something that doesn't happen to very many people, and they are doing what they love to do.  

OK, lets compare this to techno music (I'm using the word 'techno' as a global music genre term, go ahead and substitute it with house, D&B, ambient, whatever) .  Orbital, Chemical Bro's, Orb, Prodigy, etc.....have all been writing killer music for years (well, maybe with the exception of the Chemical Bro's..).  And they are now finally getting noticed.  Why?  You guessed it.   Some suit wearing exec. in a 20th story office building in LA can make allot of money off of this 'electronica' music.   What really sucks about this, is  for every one artist that gets noticed, there are a hundred that are writing music that blows the Chem Bro's & Prodigy away.  I have friends that live down the street from me that are writing the most innovative music I've ever heard.  But they cant release it because they don't have the money or resources to do so.

I guess you can say I am feeling a little bitter toward the music industry.  It pains me to see very talented artists getting stepped on, while the ones that are 'appealing to the masses' are looked up to.  It just reconfirms my belief that the world, and this country especially, is ruled by money.  Wouldn't it be so much nicer if money was outlawed and the world went back to the trade and barter system?? 

Just a thought.

Peace,

-Mark
Astronout
EAC

everyday we have choices...

to make our little section of the world better or worse...

do you smile at the stranger or ignor them....

do you look at how you are different or how you are alike...

do you judge or accept...

do you let things remain as they are or  do you try to 
make things better...or at least try to find ways to do so...

do you love or hate...

do you buy just one blowpop or do you buy an extra one for 
someone feeling gloomy...

You just have to wait for the technology to improve.  Once the net gets
fast enough, anybody will be able to have worldwide distrobution of their
music without needing any record company or distributer to help them out.

You will probably have big databases of artists that cross reference them
to their styles.  Imagine a search engine where you say "Goa trance with
breakbeats, 132 BPM, no 303's"... and have 14 different tracks pop
up from artist's servers around the world... hear a snippit of all of
them and download those you want.

The recording industry is a dying beast... well, there will probably always
be pop music and cute girls who hook up with talented producers who do
happy sing-along tracks like spice girls... but I think technology will outpace
the record company's ability to successfully sell electronic dance music.

-troy

At 3:17 PM 7/14/97, Mark Camp wrote:
>Hello all.  I don't post very often, but I have been a long time member of
>SFR.  I was off the list for a while and have just recently resubscribed
>so I wanted to say HI to all of you I know and HI to all that I don't
>know.

*** Firstly, Hi  Mark.  Yep, you're older than dirt on SFR...
>
>I would like to talk about Music and Money.
*** SNIP ***
> My bro and all the members of the band are living their dream.  They have
>accomplished something that doesn't happen to very many people, and they
>are doing what they love to do.

*** And that soo cool.  It's very infrequent that people are allowed to do
what they want to do ***

>OK, lets compare this to techno music (I'm using the word 'techno' as a
>global music genre term, go ahead and substitute it with house, D&B,
>ambient, whatever) .
****More snippage ****
> What really sucks about this, is  for every one artist that gets noticed,
>there are a hundred that are writing music that blows the Chem Bro's &
>Prodigy away.  I have friends that live down the street from me that are
>writing the most innovative music I've ever heard.  But they cant release
>it because they don't have the money or resources to do so.

*** The trick is mainly this.  There are people that want to make money
making music and there are those that like making music for music's sake...
The extremely few are people that are able to both make the music THEY
like as well as making it a kind of music that appeals to the masses.   I
guess that's why you see some bands that try to appeal to various audiences
(I.E. Monacos' new CD) and the few that play THIER music ad fu*k the rest
(like The Dwarves)...***

>I guess you can say I am feeling a little bitter toward the music
>industry.  It pains me to see very talented artists getting stepped on,
>while the ones that are 'appealing to the masses' are looked up to.

*** There are always others out there that try to make music for musics'
sake and create thier own scene.  Look @ our own underground.  Aspire,
Pacific, SPAZ, ARM, FTT (to an extent) and the various other sound systems
(ours included) that eat the costs and let us dance and have a great
time... free of charge.  ***

Just my reality,

L-8


"Awaken"

From: Matthew Alan Schwartz <thorfio@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Subject: weekend fun!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9707141513.A17768-0100000@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Oh boy...my first working monday after a weekend of partying...ug...I 
feel like hell *8^)...

	Anyway, after taking last weekend off ( something wich I should
probably do more often :P ) I was back in the scene for yet another
eventful sfraves weekend. I started it off just finishing setting up my
sound system and was really excited to go watch some good DJ's this
weekend, continuing this really cool learning proccess. Anyway, friday
night...1015. This didn't really do it for me. I was told later on Sunday
never to go there when there wasn't a big name DJ spinning and now that I
think about it they're probably right. The music wasn't hoorible, but it
didn't quite go off. Once a DJ started going off it felt like about five
minutes later they would fall flat, pretty much losing my interest. 
Besides the music, I gotta say that the vibe was pretty non-exsistant. I
don't know, maybe I needed to throw down a few beers before I could have
felt it, but I really wasn't in the mood. 

And then Saturday came and the crew from Aspire saved the day! :)

Luckily I didn't plan on going during the daytime so my friends and I 
didn't have to deal with all the annoyances that went on earlier. We got 
there around 11:30 and it was just started to go off!

The music:
Had to be some of the best I've heard in a while! FINALLY got to see 
Macadio spin again...Man, you f-inkg WENT OFF! posing up there like some 
superstar...hehe...love the music! And as for the rest, everyone..went 
off! I think Sat night was the most I've ever danced at a rave yet. Oh 
yeah...for some reason the sound just sounded more awsome and powerful 
the usual...hrrmmm...I wonder why ;)

The vibe:
Living up in Santa Cruz over the past year I've been to just about every 
beach rave that's been thrown up there, and the vibe Sat night was by far 
the best out of any beach rave I've been yet. I did not see ONE  unhappy 
face!

Decorations:
Once again tops the beach rave list. The lights were sweet, and the 
location was prime!

In general:
This was simply an awsome rave, I can't wait for the next! When a beach 
rave is so good that I actually want to stay long enough to watch the 
daylioght slowly arrise, you know something special is goin down. Thanks 
guys!

well....in usual raver fashon we were lagging a bit.....so FF to about
midnight or so when we finally arrived @ the spot. I knew it would be a
great nite when I saw Jeremy (mercutio) helping out with the cars...=)
For a backup location, the crew had done a great job. The little "cove"
area we had was protected, and the ocean was right there. The path from
the cars wasn't long at all, and we were far enough from the road to not
be heard or noticed. (phew)

All of the DJs had great sets...the music was just epic....the speakers
were set up so that there was this one area right in the center where
you could get perfect stereo sound...it was rEally intense.  The crowd
grew and grew and there were so many happy people dancin away under the
stars...(and fog)....the visuals were extra special because they were
partly natural....the lights coming off the ocean were great..the
rainbow light hitting the water and luminating the mist was so cool. I
felt a really good vibe from a lot of people....everyone was so happy
the party was going off......the DJs were rippin it up...and we were
partyin' in the coolest spot! This really was a great party....I think
everyone there had a super time and felt the energy....there was still a
crowd of ppl dancin away at 8am.....nothing like terrorcore in the
morning to knock you senseless. WOW.....

I remember sitting out on this rock that was kinda in the water,
watching everyone dance and hang out....I was able to take in the whole
scene....it was just so great to see all these people out having a blast
at 6am on the beach......<<gush>>

can't even name everyone I saw there....so HI to you all! xtra thanks to
jer for sticking with it and pulling of a great party despite the odds.
YOU Rock!!  Anonymous, Vertigo, Li, Macadio, Deepfog, Anakin,
Marty....damn! you were all really good....everone put alot of energy
into their sets....and the crowd felt it....and gave it back!

Some hilights were....Anakin dancing himself into a hole....Vertigo
sleeping....again. Marty in a tie....Macadio blowing up the
circuts....again.....(that boy need more power!!!) Just about everone
smiling and vibing out all nite long. The location. The sound.....I
could go on and on...a huge shout out to EVERYONE!!

until next time.....

fubari

I resisted for like four days on this thread.

Now I must open my mouth and pull out...

>>>>Andy's Lame Rant on this Topic<<<<

The beats of the late fifties and early sixties were really onto
something, but it was more a reaction that an action.  They were about
fuck the confines of this Leave It To Beaver ideal little pink houses
world.  What can we do to turn this over?  Why do we hate the commies so
much if we all act more like their ideals than they do?

Then the hippies came.  From the dissarray of the beats, a common thread
was established.  People started expeirimenting with communal living, with
alternate lifestyle, with experiemnting with freedom not for the sake of
the experiment, but out of the firm belief that there was a better way.
These "ways" required lots of deviants who pioneered the various
disciplines.  Abbie Hoffman burned money and asked hard questions, Timothy
Leary and Ram Dass pushed the limits of perception, Allen Ginsberg tempted
literature, Bob Dylan twisted music into a new honest folk, literature was
cutting into the fray (it was after all the first salvo, echoing back from
the beats), and probably the most vocal was rock music.  These all rang
true with freedom, with misfit power, and a strange incling that with each
passing day we could take these ideas furthur (sic) and fashion a new
life from it.  We could plant a seed and bear a youth that understood a
new way (flower children).

With all of these fresh ideas, the hippies had what it took.  Many saw the
diversity as threatening and decided to work towards unifying the vibe
(all you need is love, give peace a change) while conflicting messages
came from the dissenters who had made this freedom possible (don't trust
anyone over thirty, spitting on vietnam vets).

Somewhere in this melee people got wise to the fact that a message had to
be put together.

Woodstock nation.

Star children from the black hole to salvation, citizen of the forest and
child of the woodstock nation...

As the fashion and entertainment industries were catching up to hippie
trend, the mentality was sick with dissent.  The ideological quilt of
diversity was pulling at it's own seams.

Mixed messages were being sent by groups like the Black Panthers, the
Yippies, the Communal Hippies, the New Age Reformists, and soon there were
only two types of people left...

Those who kept going and those who gave up.

The media, the same tool that the hippies had used to make themselves so
powerful, had turned the cameras on the real people, and America was
disgusted with what it saw.

Burnouts, venereal disease, bad trips, Altamont, violence, dissent, Kent
State, and an enraged group at the core of it all figuring out what could
be done.  

What does peace do when it has been beaten to it's knees?

This single dillema probably killed the movement in my opinion.  Most
people either bailed out and er... dropped right back in, tuned out
even harder or turned on to start movements that still go to this day.  
The inability to seperate hedonism, idealism and intellectual
and spiritual revolution created the stereotype we have till today of the
hippie.

Out of the core of all of this, suddenly bellbottoms and long hair become
the epitomy of fashion, and this amazing movement ends sickly with a
parody of itself.

Maybe a couple thousand people took CIA acid, but the threat of a team of
Men in Black was more dangerous than anything they could actually do.  The
paranoia, of Protestant guilt catching up with their lifestyles which many
of them did not even understand was too much bear.

Ask yourself if any of this sounds familiar...

Rave is about not having to defend or justify anything, it is living.  For
some of you, you will take what you can and walk away, and to some, you
will live it for a while and it will change you so that you live with it
forever.  Make that change and make it good.

There is nothing sicker than the face of those people who called
themselves hippies and then gave up their bellbottoms for Pierre Cardin
and BMWs later in the 80's.  If you live an honest life now, there's
nothing to hide ten, fifteen years from now.

Or maybe I just want something to type about.

I hope all of us remember what it's like to hug someone you just met, or
to dance like an idiot (albeit an inspired, beautiful idiot) because it
feels good. There is no shame in being yourself, and that means you, and
those all around us.

Therin lies beauty.  Be yourself, whatever that may be, however far it
takes you.

Now can we talk about some parties or something, or is this going to keep 
being a socialogical forum?

AndyW

             <n1343228816.22235@digidesign.com> 
Date: Mon, 14 Jul 97 17:12:01 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


> OK, lets compare this to techno music (I'm using the word 'techno' as a
> global music genre term, go ahead and substitute it with house, D&B,
> ambient, whatever) .  Orbital, Chemical Bro's, Orb, Prodigy,
> etc.....have all been writing killer music for years (well, maybe with
> the exception of the Chemical Bro's..).  And they are now finally
> getting noticed.  Why?  You guessed it.   Some suit wearing exec. in a
> 20th story office building in LA can make allot of money off of this
> 'electronica' music.   What really sucks about this, is  for every one
> artist that gets noticed, there are a hundred that are writing music
> that blows the Chem Bro's & Prodigy away.  I have friends that live

This has, unfortunately, always been the case. I've watched friends and
family "on the bleeding edge" of music get burned out for not having
the time, money, or recognition to follow their art. Or simply lose the
motivation to slog through a "day job" just so they can spend all night
in a recording studio and get dissed by the same mindset record execs
that thought the Beatles sucked back in the early 60's, before they got
signed. It's no wonder the artists that do make it have such ridiculous
primadonna attitudes -- it's just payback for the shit that they had to
live through before they got famous.

People just don't get it, until it's too late. And then the new art is
just treated like a fad and exploited/stripmined until the artform is
but a mockery of the original intent. And then it's time to struggle,
and move on to something new.

ANd then, a few years later, a big record company does a big commercial
push on a band with crappier songs, less musicality, and jumping on a
once-avant garde bandwagon a few years too late. THat's life. It sucks.

But let's not dwell on the negative :-)

On the other hand, when said musicians kill themselves or wind up in
insane asylums, or collecting garbage, or driving cabs... and by some 
miracle, they come back into recongition among the trainspotters...
then  you can always say, yeah, i knew so and so and saw them back when
they played in a small club. And point to a collection of potentially
rare albums that are now worth money to other trainspotters, even
though you picked them up for a few pennies when the record store was
trying to get rid of them so they could stock more of the current fad
of the time.

Besides, it's just so cool to have the rare pleasure of knowing some
group that no longer exists, because their genius was totally ignored
by record companies ... e.g. in the "pop" genre, the band "Big Starr"
(the Replacement's deification of Alex Chilton notwithstanding) ... or
in Funk, the group "Mandrill" or "The Fatback Band"...

On the bright side, at least with "electronica" becoming a reconizable
genre, those of us that have been tinkering w/ electronic music for
many years now at least have a label under which to describe the things
we waste large amounts of our time and money on, seemingly for no
professional or personal benefit whatsoever other than the acquisition
of a bunch of knowledge and techniques that most people find akin to
the joys of stamp collecting.

But at least with the fact that this kind of music is at least a
"genre", one may have hope for greater glory, or at least, to make a
few kids bug out to the beats, as opposed to covering their ears as
they flee from the awful noises coming from one's synths and samplers.

Please remember that just a few short years ago, people thought popular
music *HAD* to have a guitar player *AND* one or more vocalists (no
matter how painful and dissonant their crooning (e.g. Grateful
Dead))... when you think of that, you have to realize, we've come a
long way baby!

NP: Mandrill, "Can You Get It (Suzie Caesar)" (1978). BMG Records, UK.

--------------------
Date: 14 Jul 1997 15:17:12 -0700
From: "Mark Camp" <campm@digidesign.com>
Subject: Music and Money
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Hello all.  I don't post very often, but I have been a long time member
of SFR.  I was off the list for a while and have just recently
resubscribed so I wanted to say HI to all of you I know and HI to all
that I don't know.

I would like to talk about Music and Money.  If you havnt noticed
lately, the music we all hold so dear to our hearts is now getting a
lot of attention.  I havnt really decided if this is a good or a bad
thing.  Recently, My brother's band, SmashMouth, got a major record
deal with Interscope Records.  Their music is your typical KOME
'Alternative Rock'.  And now they are all over the radio, all over the
country, with a video soon to be on MTV.  What is so strange about
this, is I've been listening to my bro write killer music for years. 
But nobody knew, except for the local San Jose music scene that would
go out and watch them play.  Now, the same songs that they were playing
a year or two ago are all over the radio and everybody loves them.  
Why?  Because there is a whole bunch of money behind the band.    I am
not saying this is a bad thing.  My bro and all the members of the band
are living their dream.  They have accomplished something that doesn't
happen to very many people, and they are doing what they love to do.  

OK, lets compare this to techno music (I'm using the word 'techno' as a
global music genre term, go ahead and substitute it with house, D&B,
ambient, whatever) .  Orbital, Chemical Bro's, Orb, Prodigy,
etc.....have all been writing killer music for years (well, maybe with
the exception of the Chemical Bro's..).  And they are now finally
getting noticed.  Why?  You guessed it.   Some suit wearing exec. in a
20th story office building in LA can make allot of money off of this
'electronica' music.   What really sucks about this, is  for every one
artist that gets noticed, there are a hundred that are writing music
that blows the Chem Bro's & Prodigy away.  I have friends that live
down the street from me that are writing the most innovative music I've
ever heard.  But they cant release it because they don't have the money
or resources to do so.

I guess you can say I am feeling a little bitter toward the music
industry.  It pains me to see very talented artists getting stepped on,
while the ones that are 'appealing to the masses' are looked up to.  It
just reconfirms my belief that the world, and this country especially,
is ruled by money.  Wouldn't it be so much nicer if money was outlawed
and the world went back to the trade and barter system?? 

Just a thought.

Peace,

-Mark
Astronout
EAC

--------------------

At 11:19 AM 7/13/97, cathode wrote:
>If this is the case then why does raving work in other countries whose
>cultures are also steeped in Protestantism ( ie Germany or Great Britain)?
>There has to be something more too it than this...Why is it that the more
>fucked up a city is the more likely it is to develop a thriving rave scene
>( and also one that is based on harder forms of techno )?

for one, i don't think these countries place such an emphasis on _work_.
this is a combination of the protestant roots and a capitalist society.
don't europeans get ourtageously long vacations where we only get 2 weeks
per year? i can only speculate from my own personal experience, and that is
that europeans in general  party _way_ harder than your average joe
american. they have learned, somehow, to leave work at work, and to
concentrate on playing when it's play time. i just don't see that as a
prevalant thing here.

as far as fucked up cities go.... hmmmm. food for thought. i had always
attributed it to the weather (until i came here) - in comparing the great
lakes region, and the uk, where the weather sucks and the parties fly, to
tx, where (imo) the parties aren't all that.... well, the weather makes ppl
depressed, and maybe in the same way so do socio-economic problems, so ppl
feel the need to create an altered state of reality.... their own
controllable niche. hence the wild parties. just speculation tho!

cheers - e. :)

For those who are interested, I'm in the process of putting together 
a deal with a local computer company who is setting up their server 
to put together a Real Audio server which would allow budding artists 
to hold Concerts and invite people from Music Magazines without them 
expending 500$ or more on a plane ticket just to hear you..

The time to the Real Audio server would be 'rented' or scheduled some 
way between those people who were interested..

If anyone is interested in this idea and would like to support my 
goal, I'd love to hear from you, and what kind of music you do etc...

Date: Mon, 14 Jul 1997 18:01:01 -0500
To: mike clay <meclay@ix.netcom.com>, Joe Salas <joesalas@earthlink.net>
From: emdash@grin.net (e.menon)
Subject: Re: rave as movement?
Cc: SFraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Precedence: bulk

key:    mike: >
        joe: >>


At 10:35 AM 7/14/97, mike clay wrote:
> Although it might feel like that I really don't think so.... what MOST
>people feel (although I can't speak for you) is :
>
>  1) the mind expansiveness of psychedelic drug use (see 60's movement)
>    which if it doesn't go beyond "just" taking more drugs leads
>    nowhere (see R. Alpert aka Ram Dass)
>  2) COMMUNITY!!!  Cities ABSOLUTELY SUCK and SUCK bigtime in their
>    community - they DON't have it and it feels lonely!! Pure and
>simple.
>    Most of my life I've lived in small towns ie under 10,000 people.
>    There you know your neighbors etc. Everytime you go shopping you
>    meet friends... everytime you do business you meet friends....
>    You can leave your doors open...  You know 1000+ people and
>    you can share....
>    Live with 4000 people and you know 2000 people.... live with
>    6 million and you're lucky if you know 12 (at least well)...
>    see my point?

this lack of community is so prevalent now.... funny, i feel it less
actually now that i'm living here in sf - in tx, it was so bad. i always
felt like the jetsons, sort of - have my little isolated apt., get in the
isolated car and drive to my isolated office. at least here in a large
city, there _are_ neighborhoods - it's up to you to make them your
community. i actually do know the grocer on the corner, the ppl in my
bldg., the regular bums on the street.... a community doesn't just happen.
but you can make it happen, anywhere.

and Joe Salas wrote:
>> what i found at my first rave that i dont find in my normal life is that
>> unselfishness and lack of judgement, the act that most of us perform of
>> being nice to somebody, talking to them, hugging them, giving them a piece
>> of candy, and all for no real reason, just for the sake of being nice.
>> furthermore, when we do this, we do not exclude anyone, but give it out to
>> anyone who wants it.

i really believe that if you act this way in your day-to-day affairs,
you'll begin to sense this all the time. talk to ppl. share. smile at
strangers. it comes from within - nobody is going to hand it to you. it's
obviously easier at a rave where this sort of thing is the norm, but you
can spread this feeling into your daily existence.

and i should add - this you sensed at your _first_ rave. one, ecstacy
really amplifies these feelings. _hugely_. and when a whole group is
feelings these things amplified - what a way to create an instant
community. two - and there was some discussion of this earlier - you do
come down off the pink cloud eventually. it is so funny to see ppl for the
first time on e - they love _everybody_. i don't feel like getting into it,
but as much as i love raves, there is an awful lot of real life going on
within as well. cliques, crime, etc.

>> when i first witnessed this, i was shocked at how much i discovered i
>> really need that sort of situation sometimes, how simple it is, and how
>> good it makes me feel.
>
>  You actually need "community".... some people get it at their local
>   church... some people hang out with the new age, yoga whatever
>groups...
>  some people hang out at schools... and some people hang out at
>raves...
>  but without the sense of community or "belonging" life is pretty
>lonely...

this is a human need - a need for connection. read jane jacobs on urban
sociology. you can get this both in and out of raves. this list even is a
community. but i can't stress enough that if you walk outside and meet your
neighbors, the local vendors, you'll get this sense at home too. and that's
where it's so important. if indeed you want to use your raving experience
to 'better mankind' - get out and join your community. make yourself known.
not only will it make your life more pleasant, it'll probably be safer as
well.

>> sometimes when i watch the news or read the paper, or hear of awful,
>> negative events that happen to other people, i wonder that the rest of the
>> world cannot realize and know the attitudes and actions that permeate the
>> rave atmosphere. if only people could, living and working, then dying,
>> would be so much nicer.

again, it's up to you to create this atmosphere. where ever you are. it's
not something that will be handed to you on a silver platter.

>  All these negative things you read about are MOST often (but not
>always)
>products of large cities with breakdown of community... Jack the Ripper
>normally happens in big cities.... bank robbers, drive by shootings
>etc...
>gang violence etc... these are the products of big cities...
>
> Of course small towns are NOT utopia... people sometimes go bonkers and
>shoot their family... bad things happen... but bad things happen at
>these
>wonderful raves too.... just not as often in small towns....

see, the thing is, big cities have small towns - called neighborhoods -
within them. and (yawn) this is where the change will happen. it won't
happen if we wall ourselves off in our little rave community.


>> we do this every weekend, but it is true that it is probably not going to
>> change the world. but what i hope is at least happening is that all the
>> ravers that experience this at parties tries to live it in their regular
>> daytime lives a little bit, then passes it on to their children. teach them
>> this attitude, let them know the enjoyment of practicing it for its own
>> sake, rather than attach some vague, uncertain reward, like going to heaven
>> when youre dead. then, who knows? maybe in the future, society will be that
>> much more utopian? and so in that sense, i guess i sortof think of raves as
>> a kind of movement.
>
>  You might really like living in a small town like Bodega Bay or
>someplace
>where you actually "knew" people around you.... I guess what I am saying
>is that I don't believe raves are going to change the world... they are
>just helping you discover how much it sucks to live in a world without
>community (which is the way of life in big cities and always was, even
>hundreds of years ago)....

not so. maybe in your neighborhood. again, read jane jacobs. visit some
neighborhoods that have strong community networks. they really do exist. sf
is a fabulous city in this way - not like some other places where
everything is so sprawled out. you have neighbors. you have community. it's
up to you to utilize it.

>  SO people living in small towns across the world already are
>"changed"...
>they don't need the rave movement to teach them what they already
>know...
>living in community is the most positive way to live.... we (in the
>large cities) need raves to give us a community to hang out in....

and i disagree. ;) maybe if you're viewing a community as a place where
everyone has the same likes/dislikes, i suppose. but what a boring
community that would be. the first key to a vibrant community is diversity.
celebrate it.

cheers - e. :)

And what is up with Jonathan Wishnev on the turntables???

At my party on Friday night he pulled some pioneering tricks out of his
sack.  He is the very first RETRO techno DJ that I've ever heard, OR heard
of.  Everyone else is manically zooming to the record store for the brandest
newest, hottest off the pressest, and Jonathan's digging for the oldest!

I've heard of DJ's playing an old rave song now and again, but kicking 'em
for an hour +?   Salud to Jonathan for clever back-assward thinking.

And what is up with the kill tricks at the end of your set, Jon?   Flicking
the Line Switch like Carlos on crack!

Very chancey.
I like it, a lot.

heavylove,

	'Lo there, SFR's!  dr. XeNo, here jest giving a small lowdown on how IG

waz lining up.  I usually dig much more plurry events than the sorta
breakdancing set that seemed to be the majority here.  But the lineup waz
jest too grt ta miss, so we checked it out.  Good thing, too, the muzaq waz
phat!!!  Jeno and DJ Ghost were incredible as waz everyone else.  Jeno
fully amazes me, since I've now heard him bust some incredible sets of
Trance, Underground and Breakbeat.  The sets usually switched between some
trance or goa, to breakbeat, tekstep and other D & B.  Ghost even managed
to perfectly mix a Cypress Hill tune with the rest of his set!  I met two
grt gals that were there sober, as I always am, and saw one SFR laminate,
tho the gal, Christi wasn't a member.  Anyway, props to Ghosttribe, tho the
water could have been definent'y cheaper, if not free!  Take care...

Date: Mon, 14 Jul 1997 18:07:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>
Message-Id: <199707150107.SAA28600@klaatu.autodesk.com>
To: foolish_fish1@juno.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: Music and Money
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

> I dont think it is money ...

	I'd have to agree. It's not primarily money that's the issue.
It's *fame*, or *celebrity*. Basically, what it boils down to for the
most music buyers is that they're not going to buy something they've
never heard (or heard of). That means that bands have to become famous i
to sell records. And for labels it comes down to "if we pay the money
to get this band on the radio/MTV, how many people are going to buy it."
And the result is that most bands have an average sound that appeals to
the average buyer.

	One of the things that's cool about the techno scene is that
people are more interested in what they *haven't* heard. I'm not hold-
ing my breath waiting for the major labels to figure out how to deal
with that.

	Or did you guys all run out & buy the chemical bros & prodigy
records already?

Precedence: bulk

I read an interview in the San Fran Examiner a few weeks ago with Douglas
Rushkoff and he expressed in a few words what I've been trying to tell my
parents for years--why we go to raves . . .

"I wanted to focus on rave culture as a milieu becuase that is where I see
most of the progressively evolutionary conscious forms of spirituality
today.  It is a place where science, technology, global culture and youth
culture meet as a spiritual pagan ritual.

"It is the closest thing to a religious experience that I have ever had.
There is a magic moment that can happen at a rave--at 2 or 3 in the
morining, when everyone is dancing, you experience a feeling of collective
organism [orgasm?], and I think people who have had that experience see the
world differently afterward.  They don't see the world made up of
individuals vying for power, but rather they see it as one throbbing thing."

Well put, Doug!

back in the "good 'ol days", record companies used to be owned and run by
musicians(gee- what an unusual concept). all types of bands could, and would,
get signed. the emphasis was on musical creativity and deversification. 
  unfortunately, the record companies started losing money. soooooooo- along
came the suits, who took over the record companies and turned them into the
money making, bubble-gum music producing-( i know, there are many
exceptions)-entities that they are today. they don't give a rats ass if the
band has talent or not-all they see when they look at a band is dollar signs.
the more dollar signs they see, the better chance the band has of getting
signed. what else can one expect of a bunch of lawyers put in charge of
art!?!
	 		oh well- thats my rant and rave(he he-he said rave) for the day
						later, stillwind

From: "lara at vibe.org" <lara@vibe.org>
To: sf-jungle@saturn5.com
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: DJ SCIENCE :)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.970714222900.11034H-100000@linux.announce.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

If I were to be stuck on a deserted island for the rest of my life, this 
tape would definitely be the one to accompany me. Science drops some of 
the nastiest beats, with some of the smoothest, well-thought-out mixes 
I've heard in a long time.
	His tracks pile up nastier and thicker one by one -- 
starting off with optical's eerie "to shape the future" and thus throws us 
into the mix on the darkside with masta ak,decoder, tech itch, ed rush, 
zenith 
and roni size to name a few..  speaking of roni size, big massive ups to 
science for throwing NEW FORMS in the beginning of the flip side, with 
some beautifully intelligent and strong lyrics.. 
I swear to god this shit is DOPE!
the second side rocks my ass even more than the first -- sample warfare 
-- warped basslines beyond beleif -- I couldn't ask for anything more.
	So if you're out, or you run into Alex Ward aka SCIENCE anywhere, 
pick up one of his tapes -- it's well worth your while.. Shit it's more 
than worth your while, it's your obligation and duty as a true junglist 
to pick up this tape and listen to it from start to finish over and over 
again to give mad respect and props to the man.
I shit you not.
-+- looking forward to the day she can sit on a deserted island and step 
all the day long -+-
lara

Hey all,
 I had time to scribble a brief messageand still without the time to go
into any great detail about my adventures towards the promised land, I
thought I might express some pent-up frustrations I have with stuckedness.
It has been over a month since our planned departure date and we have been
to the Pacific and back... You may ask; why? So many worldly possessions...
"necessities"? Even though I have successfully gotten rid of about half of
my stuff... There is still so much of it to pack and move... And the
remaining bits of improvements on the house, which I must soon sell... Not
to be a downer or anything, but sometimes, I simply feel like I'm stuck...
I try to get things done, without straining too much or slacking, either...
But things NEVER go as planned and it can be frustrating... especially hard
when leaving a great bunch of people and  looking forward to joining an
even greater number of good people, only to be held captive, by the tasks I
set for myself... Ah,well, I suppose that everything happens as it is
supposed to... And everything is just "doin' it's thing". Well, We plan to
leave tommorrow... I hope we can pull it off. :)

Love going out to alla ya,
 m

He/She tells a story within the set that expresses the feelings of how they're feeling at that moment.

Here is a review of the Love Parade by Minh.  Sounds fun, but a bit 
commercial.  So huge though...

Nathan
To: nathan b. beckord
cc: 
From: minhqle @ uclink2.berkeley.edu (MellowDrama) @ internet
Date: 07/14/97 01:45 PM
Subject: (long) 12.7.97 Love Parade Report!

Saturday 12.7.97 Berlin Love Parade,



 Well folks, I survived another Love Parade and haven't slept in
three days.  The parade this year was different from last, somewhat worse,
but ohhhhh, all those parties afterwards!  Unfortunately, I was too
stressed out from school to go to all of them :(
 Okay, apparently, the numbers of people for this year is 1-1.5
million participants.  Advertisers and media folks here love to use the
term "ravers" to describe everyone, but that is far from the truth. I
would say 1/4 of the crowd were clubbers, 1/4 "normalos", 1/4 vendors, 1/4
random "Fussball jerks", and some actual ravers mixed in between.  Don't
get me wrong, there were really nice people there overall, but there was
always the exception (European soccer fans are the worst).
 The route this year started at Ernst Reuter Platz again (same as
last year), but continued on past the Siegesaule (big upside down Mariachi
type monument in the middle of the Tiergarten/park) towards Brandenburg
Gate, and circled back towards the Siegesaule.  The parade started at
14:00 and lasted till probably midnight or past (I believe there was a
free open air at the Siegesaule endpoint again).  The logistics were
different this year in that instead of having all the wagens (roughly 40?
The sign-up fee is a purported 4,000 DM to 40,000 DM; can't verify it
either way) following each other, there were three-wagen groups that were
separated 'bout 15 minutes from each other; total LAG!  As the last wagens
started coming up, people were already making a mass exodus towards other
places. The most disturbing thing, is the rampant commercialization of the
whole event.  Cars had bigger "FILA", "PIONEER", "MARLBORRO", etc. signs
than club identification tags.  I just didn't feel comfortable worshipping
the "FILA" wagen as compared to the let's say, Trance truck, etc.; it _is_
about the music, afterall.
 Each year the parade gets worse and worse; I'm afraid of what it
would be like next year.  Believe it or not, the parade started off quite
small years ago as a demonstration against descrimination, racism, sexism,
destroying the environment, etc. (basically PLUR-y type things), but has
lost much of its original purpose.  It should be called the Skin Parade
and meant to celebrate consumer culture and the massive amounts of litter
that 1 million people produce.
 There is a "Hate Parade" which started off as a counter-demo
against the commercialization of the parade (same time, same day,
different location) plus other stuff, but I missed it, and I don't
particulary like Gabba or Hardcore that much.  
 Enough of the baggin', here are the good points:

Free open-air at the end
Chillin' in the Tiergarten
Meeting old comrades
Hangin' with friends
Making new contacts
The parties afterwards
Perfect weather
All the beautiful people 

 My recommendation is: go see the start if you really want to (it
will be crushingly uncomfy), set up home base at the Siegesaule, bring
food and _alot_ of water (extortionist prices), return to Ernst Reuter
Platz at roughly 22:00 for an excellent mini-party, and lastly, friends
are the best way to go, and try to avoid the massives afterwards if
possible (they are a rip).  The absolute BEST GOA FESTIVAV/RAVE was
"Nation of Godwana" with this line-up: Sven Dohse, Tsuyoshi Suzuki, Mark
Allen, Mahasukha, Bimmel, The Chemist, Bass Dee, Thsa'ba, & Rolle.  
Too bad SF's own Goa Gil was spinning at a different venue.  My friend
Clare said it was held outside the city limits (free shuttle service) and
was held in a field within endless fields, and was comparable to Burning
Man.  She also swears by Tsuyoshi Suzuki, and apparently, he is coming to
San Francisco sometime this August, don't miss him--unless you are at
Burning Man, that is!
 The best guide to the scene and all the parties is in "Flyer".  It
is free and the size of a flyer (but a small booklet), a bit hard to find,
but all the cool places have it; published every three weeks.

 Well, that's it folks, I am presently in the middle of papers
(Germans apparently don't write their term-papers till the end of the
semester), and my next conquest (hopefully) will be New York City in seven
days.  I will be back in August and hope to meet some of you Net-izens
then....

 
:)
M&m

Subject: (BSP) Aware Environments Mission Statement (Rough Draft)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

hello happy people...

i am up at 2am cause i've been reflecting on the great weekend i've had.
just.jer threw a great party this weekend.  my opinion is that anyone that
would cut his methods down of how he organized this event are simply
jealous because they maybe don't have the same type of drive and motivation
that jeremy does.  @spire went off.

anyway, the reason for my email...

I started Aware Environments to promote aware environments.  Are you with
me?  Part of Aware Environments is about throwing really high quality raves
that cost money to go to, but make you feel like you've spent your money in
the right place.  Now I've just started throwing them and not everything
has been perfect, but bear with me.  Part of my reason for taking a small
breather from throwing a party is so that I can singlehandedly go through
each step and learn what i think should and should not happen.

Another aspect of my business is promoting the use of naturally based
consumer products and natural herb supplements for promting longevity of
the mind, body and spirit.  I'm not a doctor and I don't have any degrees
in nutrition, but I strive to teach based upon what I have learned.  If I
don't know the answer to something, I will tell you rather than try to make
up something out of thin air just to get you to buy my products.

I don't have employees, only business associates that are independent of
me.  I don't plan on having employees at all, except in some special cases
where I might throw a large party (this would not be a Warmth party,
because Warmth is Spencer's baby and that's his decision on what he wants
to do with it) and need to hire people, but that's only like a one time
deal.  I work most closely with people that are willing to invest in
themselves and in their future. Because we can't throw big fat parties on a
regular basis if we're constantly worrying about whether or not our next
paycheck is going to cover the next phone bill or whatver may be pending.

I hope there are not too many people offended by this blatant self-promo of
my business, but a lot of you have asked me what I do, and, well this is
basically it.  I'm always looking for new people to hook up with that can
either be a customer of my products and services or for us to make some
kind of exchange that doesn't involve money at all.  Eventually I would
like to know so many people that I would never have to set foot in a store
again, because I can call so-and-so for this thing and so-and-so because
she sells insurance or whatever.

If you are curious and would like more detailed info about the products and
services I can offer you or think you would like to do something like this
yourself, please email me privately and we'll talk.  I love meeting new
people, and email is a really great way to do this.  Again, I hope I'm not
stepping on anyone's boundaries because of this.  But really.  the SFR
people I have met of late have been some of the most top quality open
minded people that i have met since i have been raving since 1991.

i love you all and i hope to hear from some of you in private.  it's up to
you.  :]

Love, dEEpfog
PS-  Call the Aware Environments private bat line to hear my favorite song
of the week!  415.595.3427

Hi everyone,

I want to take a second to tell you about my night! :)

I drove to the city around 10:45 to pick up Beth and a friend of hers.
Then we cruised down to VSF and got in line. We were afraid that there
wasn't going to be any room left inside, or if there was that we'd be
sardines. Time passed and pretty soon we were inside. The first thing I
noticed was that there were tons of people from all walks of life. It was
pretty interesting. Sometimes when you are so into an artist you forget
about all the other peopel who are also into him/her. Moments later we
were in the main room dancing to DJ BLAME. It was SUPER HOT in there and
was totally uncomfortable. :( After about 30 minutes we had to go to get
some air! So we walked up to the roof and chilled for a bit. A few moments
before we went upstairs I recognized a familiar face that lives on the
wallpaper of the server I manage work... LTJ BUKEM! And only a few people
were recognizing him. I couldn't resist so I walked up to him and
introduced myself. I told him how much I enjoy his music and that I've
introduced a lot of friends to it. I shook his hand and exchange smiles
with him. At about 1:45 I went down into the main room to prepare for a
real treat. Fifteen minutes later he was up there spinning some BEAUTIFUL
music. He's so calm and smooth. "Thanks, mate", where the words that left
his lips as I shook his hand. He has such a smooth and relaxed aura (sp?).
It was amazing... His set was fantastic. I loved how people cheered during
the phases. Unfortunately the power or something was going out and every
oonce in a while the decks would stop. But he just smiled and continued to
mix... and we all cheered in support of this extremely talented human
being.  His set ended at about 3:35 and a few of us shook his hand and
exchange smiles and words. I thanked him for the beautiful set and walked
to my car. It was definately worth getting 3 1/2 hours of sleep...!! :)

Hi to all the SFRAVERS I saw there... and Hi to all the ones I didn't!
Next time he comes around you've got to see him... ! This was the best $7
I've spent in my life.... I would have paid tons more to see him spin.

Props to Funky Tekno Tribe.


               ((((   (((   ((  (  byroni  )  ))   )))   ))))

Well folks, last night was the last session of MAD and I must say that it
was one of the best times I had.  For as much as I wished I could've
watched LTJ Bukem, I must say that MAD rocked the house last night.  At
first it seemed kind of slow and lame with a small turnout (duhh, that's
what happens when you're the fifth or sixth person there.)  But within a
hour or so, it was going off.

I have to give PHAT props out to all the DJ's.  They did a great job. 
Joe Rice's set was incredibly good.  You know, last night was so awesome
that it has caused me to be in denial.  Could somebody explain to me why
there are no more MADs?  

Well, N E Ways, it was a great night.  All except for my injury I
sustained in my calf muscle from dancing too much.

See ya'll later.

P.S.-- Hey Byroni, dude, I saw Tiffany there last night.

dErEk

That's a huge problem, because this is an industrialized society
based on commerce and free enterprise.  Our society (into which
we had the misfortune to be born) attacks us with that ideology
from every angle, trying to tell us that we WANT to be a part of
it, that it's good and fun to play the corporate games, step on and/or
ruin our neighbors in order to advance ourselves (which really
means in order to make someone else more wealthy), and to die
with the most toys.  We live in a sick society, and it's not going to
get well until there is some sort of significant change in our systems
of government and commerce, which are so often hand-in-hand.

There it is,
Eric

well, to sum things up...last night was magical...
not only were there all walks of life @ ULTRA to see the Logical
Progression Tour (LTJ Bukem, DJ Blame, MC Conrad, DRS), but
there was a definite mystical energy in the air....
to those of you who couldn't make it last night, shame on you...
as i told many of my friends there "this is history in the making".
i was in sheer awe to see one of the pioneers of modern drum & bass
that i couldn't resist to press palms wid da man dey call Bukem...
a friend who frequents club VSF on friday nights remarked that he
has never seen the place so jam packed with people, and of all
things on a Monday night!
yes it was like a sauna, yes there were TOO many peeps, and yes
there were hundreds of smiles all united under one thing, the music...
much props also goes out to FTT for managing to import such talented
artists to come out to San Francisco and perform for us...
however, i hope the numerous technical difficulties that was apparent
throughout the night didn't leave a bitter taste with the Logical
Progression
crew...
thanks again to Bukem, Blame, Conrad, and DRS for putting the widest smile
on my face last night...have a safe journey and hope to see you back in the
very
near future...


d0u8l3 J;)

calling the cops on our party.

when we pulled over to get a burrito?  hee hee ha ha.  that core group of
people that sat there patiently waiting for you to come through was a group
that all got to know each other a little better.  i mean, i had the chance
to hang out with Macadio and AdamG. and just talk in a way that I don't
normally get to at parties because of the music distraction.

this party has become a pretty big subject of discussion.

it is and i don't really give a crap.  let them try.  we'll just throw
another underground next month on the same night as their masive.  there's
only 24 hours in a day and only 7 days in a week.  there are 5 billion
people in the world and something like 5.5 MILLION people in the Bay Area.
I think both parties could afford to be well attended.

so whoever tried to bust jer's party, may your wife divorce you.  or some
bad karma shit happen to you.  like your hands get cut off in a train
accident so you can't spin.  eww!  imagine that.  sitting there lookin at
the tables but you can't use them.  that's torture.

Hello Sfraves,

	We are pleased to announce the following party...

			On the weekend of August 15th - 17th,

Harmony will be teaming up with the Pacific Sound System, Cloud Factory,
and the MAD Crew to bring you a very special family gathering.

We have a 180+acre site right smack in the middle of the redwood forest.
The party will run from Friday afternoon, all the way until Sunday
afternoon (with breaks for sleeping). You are encouraged to come up Friday
and spend the entire weekend with us. However, if you do, you are also
responsible to bring your own food! This is very important! Bring enough
food to last you through the entire trip! There is plenty of free fresh
mountain spring water (the kind you pay $1 for in the store), as well as
tons of places to hike and camp. On site, there are hot and cold showers,
as well as enough fully plumbed rest rooms for the entire weekend. (no
portopotties!!!) Together, we will be supplying two sound systems (dance),
and one ambient/meditation area. 

This is going to be sooo much fun!!! There are much more detail to come, so
please keep your eyes and ears open! We will be selling a limited number of
presale tickets for this party, but they are not available yet. But as soon
as they are, we will tell you! See ya soon!!!

Peace and love

I was just kiddin' guys =) hehe.... I'm not really pissed off... I love
the adventure of raving.... i love it when things don't go as planned,
but I was upset that a lot of people were let down when they couldn't
find us. =( sorry guys... next time we'll have a better plan! =) and I
know karma will take it's toll on the guys who messed with us... how
could it not! I think this is a turning point for the UG scene..... too
much bad stuff has happened at parties in the past month or two... for
some reason I feel like the spell has been broken and it's time for the
UG scene to flourish! here we go ending the summer with a big BANG!
Can't wait! =) much love to you guys, and thanx for all your support!
damn  I'm so in love with the scene it's not even funny! right now I
should be sooooooooooo tired and not even able to function, but the
energy I feel from this passion for the scene is putting me on turbo!

weeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee, jer - @spire

if Rodney King were a raver, he'd say, "can't we all just rave on?"

Subject: Re: rave as movement?
X-Sender: 109p54n4u306@mail44.internetmci.com

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


>>living in community is the most positive way to live.... we (in the
>>large cities) need raves to give us a community to hang out in....
>
>and i disagree. ;) maybe if you're viewing a community as a place where
>>everyone has the same likes/dislikes, i suppose.  but what a boring
>community >that would be.

You CAN build a community, with careful planning . . . just because you
live somewhere means you are going to be able to be friends with the people
in your neighborhood.  Even if you are an accepting person, it doesn't mean
your neighbor is.  But you can, over a course of time, build a community.
4 years ago, 5 of my friends, all that I met at a rave or through a raver,
found an accepting safe neighborhood that we felt comfortable in, and we
rented a house.  4 years later, in the five mile vicinity, there was 12
"rave" houses and 2 warehouse lofts.  There was nothing boring about it . .
. Just because we all had one thing in common (our love for techno music),
didn't mean we were much the same after that.  Their were students, clerks,
producers, barristas, druggies, straight-edgers, a pro photographer, a
Dungeons and Dragons addict, snowboarders, etc.  They were all ages, races,
and income brackets.  It was great!  All the Charly Brown's came together
and built a neighborhood . . .

Gabber Girl

e-mail:gabbergirl@internetmci.com

>exploit us, but IMO he's helping in giving an understanding of what

Ouch - based on the snippets quoted by the SF Weekly over the last couple
of months, it's a pretty outlandish book using the sf rave scene as a
backdrop for a pretty wacked out plot.

rather unflattering (in a backhanded-compliment-sorta-way) picture of the
SF "cyber" culture circa 1991/1992.

To each their own I guess.

Subject: Thank you MAD!
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

It was a beautiful site- Joe, Monty, Sho, and Alex, all sloshed on
champagne, fighting against the evil Overlords of the Bahia Cabana to play
their last 30 minutes together as Mad.  The lights went on one by one, but
the dance floor stayed packed.  There was no stopping them this time.  They
took turns throwing down classic tunes one after the other, all of them
perfect ending tracks- but no one wanted it to end!  Even when the music
stopped, the cheers and screams forced an encore.  Finally, at 2:30, we
said goodbye to an era of Bay Area techno...

Thanks guys, we're gonna miss you... ~sniff

-Seth

Received: from beachbum.HIP.Berkeley.EDU (beachbum.HIP.Berkeley.EDU [136.152.30.95]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.8.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA16941 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Tue, 15 Jul 1997 16:29:21 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <2.2.32.19970715233459.00a6a6a8@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
X-Sender: cnielsen@uclink4.berkeley.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.2 (32)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 15 Jul 1997 16:34:59 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: cricket <cnielsen@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Why do we love this music so much?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

hey all! it's me, cricket, back from the dead to humbly ask for a favor.
see, i'm in summer school right now and have to write a paper about *our*
kind of music. the paper is essentially about a type of music that you feel
really communicates with the listener and evokes strong emotion. for me,
chosing the type of music was completely easy and obvious, but relating to
my professor exactly WHY this music makes me feel the way it does is a lot
harder. i mean, what IS it about this music that makes me get up and dance
no matter how tired i am? what IS it about this music that gives me chills?
what IS it about this music that has the power to get every single person on
the dance floor jumping, yelling, whistling, hugging, smiling, and feeling
the same way at the exact same time? i know what it is when i listen to it-
it's in my heart- but it's hard to put in to words. which is where you guys
come in.....i wanna know, i want you guys to tell me (and the list) why you
love the music. why is it so powerful?
how would you explain it to someone who just hears random electronic noises
instead of the harmony that's really there? any input, thoughts,
experiences, ideas  -anything - would be GREATLY appreciated :) thanks!

*much love*
cricket ;)

*** Hey, I remember you...  You went down south I believe.

Anyways,  Let's see.  Since I DJ lots of styles of Techno I look for mixes
that give me that tingly chill that people can associate with either a
subtle wind breeze or the feeling of an E-shiver.   I guess to make it
short its the tracks that put a series of noises / notes that evoke such a
feeling of love, sadness, happiness or just a wacky acid line that makes me
want to jump around like a lil maniac.
(And thats the run on sentence from hell).


Anyways, hope that helps!


l-8

"Awaken"

cricket wrote:
> for me, chosing the type of music was completely easy and obvious, but relating to
> my professor exactly WHY this music makes me feel the way it does is a lot harder. 

Here is a web site that asks that very question "WHY???"  It is focused
on Goa Trance, (my personal favorite) but you could probably stick any
sort of "rave" style music in the place of the words Goa Trance and have
a good description of Why...  There are many people's eloquent responses
to what it is about the music that makes them love it so much, and maybe
their words might inspire your ideas for your paper.  I hope it helps.  

http://www.third-eye.org.uk/trip/why.html

love,
Amy

     The first time I heard a techno(or insert your own descriptor here) 
     record spin( I was sober mind you! ;> ), I was hypnotized. Here's a 
     consent beat, never-ending for 6-8 hours, with a very complicated 
     structure. At first, I didn't realize the hundreds of people next to 
     me, moving along the same beat, hearing and feeling the bass along 
     with me. It's a moving experience to someone who has never been that 
     close or sync'd with so many loving people. Sometimes, I don't believe 
     people actually realize the skill and emotion a DJ will put into a 
     show. REALITY CHECK: When you're dancing and sweating throughout the 
     night and into the morn, DID YOU HEAR THE MUSIC STOP???? 
     
     I hope you get a good grade, and if you have a cool teach, take 
     him(her) to a party! Feel it!


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Why do we love this music so much?
Author:  cricket <cnielsen@uclink4.berkeley.edu> at Internet_mail
Date:    7/15/97 4:34 PM


hey all! it's me, cricket, back from the dead to humbly ask for a favor. 
see, i'm in summer school right now and have to write a paper about *our* 
kind of music. the paper is essentially about a type of music that you feel 
really communicates with the listener and evokes strong emotion. for me, 
chosing the type of music was completely easy and obvious, but relating to 
my professor exactly WHY this music makes me feel the way it does is a lot 
harder. i mean, what IS it about this music that makes me get up and dance 
no matter how tired i am? what IS it about this music that gives me chills? 
what IS it about this music that has the power to get every single person on 
the dance floor jumping, yelling, whistling, hugging, smiling, and feeling 
the same way at the exact same time? i know what it is when i listen to it- 
it's in my heart- but it's hard to put in to words. which is where you guys 
come in.....i wanna know, i want you guys to tell me (and the list) why you 
love the music. why is it so powerful?
how would you explain it to someone who just hears random electronic noises 
instead of the harmony that's really there? any input, thoughts, 
experiences, ideas  -anything - would be GREATLY appreciated :) thanks!
     
*much love*
cricket ;)

Subject: Re: Why do we love this music so much? (worth reading ; )
References: <2.2.32.19970715233459.00a6a6a8@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

What is music?

I think music is the only representation of something perfect (unless
the  DJ trainwrecks) . When you listen to music it is based on math, it
is patterns that go in formations. Even classical music follows this
rule, if one note was out of place, a person who is really listening to
the music, can tell something is wrong.

When we listen to music, perhaps we visualize it as the only form of
perfection we are exposed to on this planet. The way music makes up feel
is more mysterious;  certain tones, chordes and arrangements make us
feel differently,  for example listen to a  motion picture, close your
eyes and listen to the music, and I'd bet you will be able to tell
emotions such as fear, love , celebration , wonder and many others.
Perhaps it is the different audio frequencies that act on certain areas
of our brain. 

We all have music in our heads, and since we are not telepathic (that we
know of) the most effective way to communiacte our feeling and emotions
is through music.  And when fellow people know  almost exactly how you
feel or what state of mind you're in, it brings the human race closer to
understandin each other.

Ok, that's my thoughts on the matter.

Pete

again to just ask,  in the remote possibility that someone PLURR'y
enough might take a little time to come and pick me up on the way
down...  I am in such a remote location that the nearest hiway is
more than 6 miles away,  and the nearest town is about 30 miles.
Squaw Valley has 4 buildings,  and if you blink your eyes,  you'll
miss it.    This place brings a whole new meaning to the term "Boonies",
but at least I can live here phore free.   If anyone that knows me is
interested in wanting to know how I managed to get here,  please Email
me privately.

will be goa trance in the finest way,  with DJ's from both San Diego and
LA....

down,  from some sources that know.   If this is true,   I would really

to get out and dance in the woods....

Message-Id: <2.2.32.19970716062350.006eb658@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
X-Sender: lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.2 (32)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 15 Jul 1997 23:23:50 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: chris <lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: my wacky weekend
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

        hey, I just had a weird weekend of spinning, dancing, and trying to
setup two parties, one on Saturday and the other on Sunday.

        On Saturday me and a bunch of other bored Berkeley people decided to
throw a party with all the equipment and setuff we had lying around, and did
it in the basement of Cloyne Court(which houses 150+ people, so it's a huge
basement called "The Dungeon"). It was fun, but while Thomas Trouble(who
went first) was spinning, an amp exploded! I was sort of excited at first
because it was cool and not my amp, but then I realized the sound level
dropped and now all we had was bass. Hardcore is boring with just bass, so
we had to scavenge for another amp. We eventually found someone with a huge
stereo that had a 200 watt amp and it worked, so it all turned out good.
Kraig spun some psychadelic trance that had everyone moving for a while,
then Kenny came on with some deep house. Unfortunately it went later and I
didn't get to spin, but my buddy Restive did a nice job of confusing the
group with some electro and acid-breaks before the night ended.

        On Sunday another friend had a party in Berkeley, in his basement(of
a building which his parents own). He calls his party 'Imogen'. It's a cool
place, with a very unusual vibe(mostly hardcore and gabber fanatics). I spun
there last weekend and I was excited to do it again, but this time I figured
tech and darkstep would mesh easier with the crowd. It was really cool for a
while, but too many DJ's who wanted to spin showed up so I only go to go for
45 minutes. I was glad people were dancing for a while, Greta went on after
me with some cool downtempo stuff, then the party go shut down. Oh well.

        Yay Berkeley underground! Go gabber and hardcore! Hey, I haven't
heard to much of it around, so it's weird seeing a party with two gabber,
one hardcore, and one jungle DJ. 

        -chris

Dan wrote:
> 
> In your most humanistic terms possible, define love.


some say love, it is a river, that drowns the tender reed
some say love, it is a razor, that leaves ur soul to bleed
some say love, it is a hunger, an endless aching need
i say love, it is a flower, and you its only seed

its the heart afraid of breaking, that never learns to dance
its the dream afraid of waking, that never takes the chance
its the one, who won't be taken, who never learns to give
and the soul afraid of dying, that never learns to live

when the nite has been too lonely, and the road has been too long
and you think that love is only for the lucky and the strong
just remember, in the winter far beneath the bitter snow...
lies the seed...that with the sun's love, in the spring...
becomes...the rose. 

sound familiar.....


love is intangible....a feeling within that can make you laugh, cry or
happy  or sad....
....and sometimes...not all the time....love hurts....
(right orSon?)

maD luvin 

ma6s
-- 
~the moon goddess~
he whom speaks to me in the right voice is he whom i shall follow

Hmm, good one, good one! I define love as two things: First, in the most
natural ways; it's what drives you to feel biased towards that which might
otherwise make you feel indifferent, or even selfish. and Two; that which
makes you feel strife for that which you might not otherwise feel so strongly
about... Just a quicky for now, I haven't smoked anything yet!

this is what how i felt about it acouple years ago!


  Love cannot hurt me, 
                         I'm numb to it's sweet kiss. 
                         I will not let it bleed my soul 
                           Or Posion me with bliss. 

                           Love cannot touch me 
                         My disquise is too complete. 
                    My walls are raised, all weapons bared 
                             I taunt it in defeat. 

                           Love cannot mock me 
                          I'm wise now to its ploy. 
                      No facade of joy can hide the truth 
                             I will not be it's toy. 

                            Love cannot reach me 
                            So armored in my sin 
                         Alone I sit, forever damned 
                     and dream what might have been..... 

                           Love..cannot save me.

Leigh I read you this one time, the question has been how can we define
love?  How San Francisco.

~~~
How do we work this thing.  It isn't perfect., in fact, even the
scaffolding is drifting away.

When we aren't looking.

When we talk, we sound as though it won't go on without us.

It is immune  and invulnerable.

The laws that string us up are not within it.  It was created.

It is not destroyed.

Not like a circle or a cycle or a timeline.  It started with an end to
nothing.  Radiating at every possibility from a single...

not a point...not some stellar ultra-dense non-existant matter...

not from primordial...we cannot explain what no one prophet purports to
understand.
~~~

That poem was not about love, but then again it was.  It was about life.
But love IS life.

QED, mothafucka!

PAX,
MAX

I thought this was worth noting:)  Ravers take over Berlin!!! Yeah!


BERLIN, Germany (Reuter) - The sun blazed down on the world's largest 
techno music
party Saturday as an international crowd of up to one million people 
boogied and sweated
through the center of Berlin for the city's ninth annual Love Parade.

Ravers came from around the world to dance behind 38 brightly decorated 
floats equipped
with turbo-powered sound systems down a four-mile stretch of an 
eight-lane boulevard
which leads from the landmark Brandenburg Gate.

``We came because it's something you just have to experience,'' said 
Cornelius Hummel, a
19-year-old student from Stuttgart dressed in a Scottish kilt and 
bug-eyed sunglasses.

``You can't find this kind of euphoria anywhere else,'' said Karl-Hans 
Mayer, 50, a Berlin
cameraman who has attended the parade nearly every year. ``You simply 
cannot beat it.''

As temperatures climbed to almost 86 degrees F, first aid workers said 
they had treated
over one hundred people for dehydration and heatstroke, but added nobody 
had been
seriously injured in the huge crush of dancers.

The annual event, which last year drew 750,000 people, attracts fans of 
techno, a mix of
thundering beats and repetitive electronic riffs supplied by disc 
jockeys and their enormous
sound systems.

Overcrowded buses, trains and cars with visitors from across Europe 
bound for the parade
caused traffic jams across the country's highways and up to two-hour 
delays at Berlin's
main train station.

Some new arrivals held an impromptu ``rave'' Friday evening in front of 
the Zoologischer
Garten station soon after stepping off the platforms, while 3,000 others 
hijacked the posh
Kurfuerstendamm shopping avenue for an all-night party.

Most accommodation has been booked for weeks with people coming from as 
far afield as
South Africa, Australia and the United States. The Love Parade appears 
to have become
an essential stop on any backpacker's European tour.


______________________________________________________

From: "pjcrow" <pjcrow@ix.netcom.com>
To: <Sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Bukem plays billards or pool?
Date: Wed, 16 Jul 1997 07:20:49 -0500
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1157
MIME-Version: 1.0

------=_NextPart_000_01BC91B8.C9146BE0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

My first Ultra exprience and I must say, IT WAS HOT!!!  

I was chillin' in the pool room waiting for my turn- just kickin' it, and
who pops his head in?  Bukem!  He's all, "pool aight!"
I said to him, "you're Bukem, yeah?  I hear you're the BOMB!"
He smiled at me with his gold tooth and we started shootin' the shit...
during which time I asked him if he wanted to play pool.  Once again- out
came the gold tooth with a very quick response, "YEAH, tha'd be GREAT!"  I
didn't have the nerve to tell him to put his quarters on the table and wait
like everyone else- it was BUKEM.  That would have been very, very,
BAD-FORM!!  Since I was next on the table, I gave it up as a token of the
VIBE he created for me, and the VSF/ULTRA-insomniacs!!!!    I told him
since I was giving up: sleep, $7 cover, countless bottles of water for me
and everybody in my crew (15 total by nights end), and the drive to SF from
SJ and then back after I recovered from the heat-stroke of the main
floor...  He smiled- shook my hand and said, "thank you, thanks SF for
coming out for his set!!!   And he MEANT it TOO!!! 

So his turn came...  he won...   The it was my turn to cue against him.... 
I was a pretty close match too.  When our round first started, the pool
room had a few people in it.  But towards the end of the game- the room was
packed with onlookers.  Bukem playing pool- people just stared with mouths
open...  I had him against the ropes!!  I had one left then the eightball,
he had two more then the eight...  I had a long green shot for the corner
pocket, and what does he do...  Seconds before I hit the cue ball- he put
two of his fingers in the hole I'm shooting for and started twinkling them
around.  Of course, I miss and totally set him up to finish me off!!!!!  I
look up and at him with a smile and say, "Bukeeeeeem.... BAD FORM!!!"  He
grabs his stomach with laughter- walks over, high-fives me and says, "sorry
Mate couldn't help it!"  I just smiled as he cleaned me off the table...  I
wished him luck with his set and left the table.  

I was up front for his whole set...  He noticed me as he was gig'n with a
smile.  I don't know what happened but, shortly after, he hit the turntable
his hand making the record skip...  He shock his head and put it right back
in the GROOVE!!!!  Then it hit me, those were the same two fingers he
twinkled as I was shotting....  'Poetic Justice' I thought too myself... 
But I was over it thereafter!!! He had me in a DEEP JUNGLE TRANCE!!!  [:)> 
 

Thank You Bukem!!!  YOU ARE THE d'BOMB!!!!!!!!

slow roasted wed in SJ-   then Nikita on fri.

c 'eah  then....   Ces and Candice roll on by!!!!

peace

jaE
------=_NextPart_000_01BC91B8.C9146BE0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

To Joe & the list:

    Thanx joe, for your gentle reminder about why I (& many others)
started &are still going to raves.  I remember the joy I felt to find
such unjudgemental , unique, and happy people. To be a part of something
that, I too , felt had the power to change the world for the better.

 Today however,the power I felt the parties and the community to posses,
in my eyes has faded.  Drugs, commercialism, the new Generation gap our
scene is experiencing & constant antagonism by authorities has worn down
the appeal & the spiritual experience I once felt when I went to
parties.  My friend Jason consoles me by reminding me that nothing can
ever be as good as the first time, but I feel that the parties & the
people have changed and if they can get worse.........they can also get
better.

---Dan <daniel@best.com> wrote:
> In your most humanistic terms possible, define love.

it's when:

* you're happy waking up to his dragon breathe kissing you in the  
morning.
* his fuzzy butt is actually kinda cute
* his gas problems doesn't phase you anymore
* he thinks you're sleeping and hugs you and kisses you on the
  cheek and talks about how much he loves you and wants to be with 
  you for the rest of his life. "i love you sweetie. we're gonna have
  lots of pretty babies. i think i'll name him nathan sativa
ferreira..   no? how about cannibis sativa ferreira? he's gonna be a
pimp cause   he's gonna look just like his dad yeah! hehe"
* your heart aches when you're not with him
* you don't mind doing little things for each other like run to lucky's
  at 4 in the morning if she wanted chocolate hohos.
* you can trust each other to go to raves and E balls and not cheat on
  each other

actually i can go on and on and on but that's just my definition of 
marital love. :I

veann =)

guest on the panel on stage????

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


have you priced a grand piano recently?? you can get a car cheaper than
a grand piano...

nowadays, you can find "digital pianos" that multisample a real grand
piano for a lot less $$$ than a real piano. check out roland, yamaha,
kawai, and general music. 

or get a good sampler, and a high quality multisampled digital soundbank
of a grand piano.

of course, the "hardwired" digital pianos sound a bit more realistic
since they emulate the sympathetic string resonance you get on a real
piano.

best thing about a digital piano is that you don't need a whole room
to fit it. you can move it in the trunk of your car.

just a thought. yeah, nothing is better than the real thing, but sometimes
you have to compromise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
