Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

HOORAY!  As much as we all love a little refried delight, we're gonna give it
a rest...

Monday July 21st
Approx 12-1

SUSHIIIIIIII!  (Let's get ready to rumblllllllleeeeee!)

They've got teriaki and tempura too!

How to get there...

>From 101 or 280:
Get on 880 going north (Oakland)
East on Brokaw (thats a right if you came FROM the south and left FROM north)
About five blocks down you will hit Lundy 

At this intersection there will be a strip mall-thing on your left.
Many of the signs are written in english and again in some Asian language.
Go to the big red sign that reads
TOKYO SUSHI

RSVPs would be cool so that I can give them a good warning.  Write to my work
account frosting@juno.com or call (408)984-6360.

Can't wait to see you all!!  (Go to Kismet tonight!!)

Hug like you mean it...

>:) Amber

        i currently freelance for a magazine called _soma_ and we're sort of
        re-working things there. our target audience is 20-35, and i'm
curious -
        what do ppl like to read about? they're printing a lot of fluff right
        now, and i know that the mag could be so much better... so i'm
        wondering: what sorts of things make you pick a mag up? (other than
        techno) what interests you, and what do you actually read?

someone to go out and shoot things that we need shots of!). also, we need a
pool of illustrators. interested? email me privately.

have absolutely no use for. do any of you? i'll give you a good deal for

Well, I'm not actually going to try to define such a concept that is
defined differently by each individual for his or herself.  Love means
too many things to count, much less try to put into one single
all-encompassing framework.  Love just is, and despite its diversity in
practice and meaning, there is one thing I will say about it that I
think everybody would agree on.  Love is beautiful.
                                       ~  Julie Mae
By the way, I felt like including a quote below that I thought was
appropriate:

"Love gives not but itself and takes not but from itself.
 Love possesses not nor would it be possessed;
 For love is sufficient unto love."  ~ Khalil Bibran

massive undergrounds in the enchanted forest

When you plant lettuce, if it does not grow well,
you don't blame the lettuce. You look for reasons
it is not doing well...it may need fertilizer, or more
water or less sun. You never blame the lettuce.
Yet if we have problems with our family, we blame
the other person...But if we know how to take care
of them they will grow well,like the lettuce. Blaming has
no positive effect at all, nor does trying to persuade
using reason and arguments.

No blame,no reasoning, no argument, just understanding.

if you understand and you show that you understand
you can love and the situation will change.

-thich nhat hahn

On Fri, 18 Jul 1997, Vanessa & Miccaela  wrote:


> 1.  Yes, I was wayyyyy off topic w/ my post.  Going off on my tangent.  But I 
> don't think there would have been _as much_ fuss about what Ray said if he 
> said "UG parties shouldn't be on the same night as each other" or if he was a 
> UG promoter.  

I agree with the first part of this. If Ray had said that UG's shouldn't
be on the same night, he wouldn't have gotten as much flak. But there
is a definite reason behind this. What you are seeing is resentment of the
sentiment he is expressing because of the fairly obvious reasoning behind
it, that is that he feels that UG's are cutting into profits, or
somehow "messing with" his parties. 

> I think a lot of people on this list have a lot of hostility 
> towards massives and I wanted to address that.  If you look at the posts 
> you'll notice that they say things like "if I was a UG promoter I'd make sure 
> my events were on the same days as massives so only the true ravers would come 
> out" or "I just don't like to go to massives." 

If you look at the responses, I think it is pretty obvious that they are
sarcastic retorts to the assine statement that UG's should be on the
weekdays as to not interfere with the massives. Sarcasm can sometimes be
hard to catch via this medium.

> 2.  You don't have to go to massives.  You don't have to pay $20 to go to a 
> party you don't think you can have fun at.  You don't have to do anything.  
> But don't complain about the way massives are if you aren't even trying to 
> make them any better.  

*MY* biggest problems with "massives"(read high $$$ parties) is virtually
all of them make claims to be about things or causes other than their
primary mission which is to turn a profit. If the promoters of these
parties were honest, I would have *0* and I mean *0* problems with these
parties and the people behind them. Instead you get a bill of goods about
how the party is about togetherness, bringing all types of different
people together to share in some awe-inspiring spirtual mindfuck that will
change them forever, or for some cause or another which some unknown and
undisclosed amount or percentage of their profits are going to, etc. etc.
ad nauseum. All of this is secondary to their primary goal which is to
make money. As long as these types of deceptions continues, I will always
speak out against the promoters that engage in this behaviour and parties
they throw. I would hate the thought that some unwitting person would
believe that they would have to spend $25 to have a good time at a party
with the diversity and quality of many of the low-cost parties around... 


> And don't complain when "those people" that go to  massives start coming
> to the UG parties.  Because they will.  And then you won't have to pay
$3 to go to a UG party you don't think you can have fun at.  
> You can stay at home.

My, we are most demanding aren't we? If "those people" are the same
clueless fucks that tag, steal other peoples' things, O.D. on 15 different
drugs and expect someone else to deal with their sorry asses, *THEY* can
stay at home. 

> 3.  Back on the topic--I was appalled at some of the posts directed at Ray.  
> Regardless of how true anything you said might have been, you had no business 
> posting it to the list.  Those posts merely expressing disagreement were fine, 
> but personal attacks don't belong on the list.  Act your age.

Rather you think it belongs on the list or not, I am going to relate the a
couple of things that really struck me negatively in a conversation that
Ray and I had via email the last time a similar subject came up and I got
into it with him. Perhaps others have had conversations with him, or
know things that explain the reaction and the statements of others. I can
only speak for myself:

Ray made a statement that a particular party he was throwing was a 
"partial proceed" to some charity. I asked him what percentage. He refused
to tell me, and used many of the same "you don't know me so how can you
talk shit about me" arguments that he made this time around with other
folks. After several rounds of back and forth, Ray said that if I came to
the party, he would tell me just how much he was donating to charity.
READ: I would have to pay him the price of admission($20 or $25 I forget)
for him to tell me what percentage or amount he was donating to charity. I
can't say I hold too high of an opinion of Ray, but it is for a reason. A
reason, not some rumor that a friend of a friend heard. 

Ray, if you have another take on the exchange, and/or think I am being
unfair, please share your thoughts with us. I have the emails, and would
be happy to post them to the list with your permission of course. And
spare me the alligator tears....

					Black Adder

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Fri Jul 18 07:48:59 1997

	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) id HAA10605;

          by precipice.v-site.net (8.8.4/8.8.4) with ESMTP
	  id HAA11071 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Fri, 18 Jul 1997 07:56:21 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Fri, 18 Jul 1997 07:56:21 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <v03102800aff4c76867dd@[205.162.25.58]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@nexsys.net>
Subject: the last word on UG's and massives.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

This whole massives vs ug's thing is another discussion from the past.
Funny how some things will never die.  And beleive me, we'll be discussing
this again sooner than we all expect.  With that in mind, I really didn't
mind Ray's comments.  I thought, from my reading that what he was proposing
was not just some edict to boycott or tell people what to do, although it
could have easily been construed that way.

I saw it more in light of a conversation I had with a prominent promoter
some time ago when I first got involved in SF UG/dance Culture.  I was in
wonderment at all the "competition".  I mean, parties going on all at the
same time, double booking of Dj's , the whole thing.  I also remember
mentioning to this person how great it would be if the promoters cooperated
more.  This promoter replied "I tired, but people just won't give up thier
ego's.  It'll never work."  The translation, which I found out much later
was "Hey, you're right, people should move thier parties since I'm throwing
one.".  I knew then I understood what all of this was about, at least for
some people.

Anyway I think the best way to foster something that you like is to either
support those events that emobody the ideals you have within yourself, or
start a party with your ideals in mind.  Simple, if Ray want's to start a
trend, then let him step forth and do so, I aks any others who have such
notions to do likewise.  That is the only way to change things often
enough, it starts with you.

As for promises on flyers and the general bullshit of "flyer philosophy", I
pay about as much attention to that as Willie Brown's promises (how things
change over time, eh?).  It's just an advertisement wrapped up and
disguised as good will, all for the sake of your dollar, and often, all too
often, that is what all of this boils down to.  Yep, people do it for love,
no doubt, but few and far between are those who would sacrifice thier
earnings and material wealth consistently to make others happy.  And free
parties DO cost money...everything costs money, nothing is free.

Even if one were to do a series of freebies, who is going to spin that will
attract the hundreds that may be down for a free party? (there have been
free parties thrown, and since there are no "name" Dj's nobody shows up)
Dj's personality is at an all time high, and the premium is steep
(although, dig this, MUCH CHEAPER than the heyday).  But there is always
fresh talent and there will alwys be people who want free, it's human
nature (although you get what you pay for often enough).  Now if someone
wishes to point out Sunset as an example, the guys who play at that party
are working DJ's who have no other obligations on that day.  True
selflessness is hard to find in our very capitalist society.  It is
impractical in this system.  Although quite doable.

As for specific days, i understand.  The weekend is money time, and to many
people's suprise there are PLENTY of DJ's who have to support families and
themselves.  Free parties destroy that capability to support themselves
while making others happy.  To me this is the one part of our society where
you are actually getting something for very few $$$'s.  $25 for a party?
Big f-ing deal.  Break it down by hours, let's say 8 hours you're talking
$3.15 per hour.  That is CHEAPER than going to the movies ($3.75/hour),
cheaper than a good dinner here in the city (I never eat cheap), cheaper
than E (which at $20/hit lasts about 4 hours you're talkling $5/hour). The
scene is a part of a larger capital driven machine and it acts accordingly.
I'm over the too expensive, or the other cost concerns.  People need to pay
because the money is not only going into the pocket of promoters (who often
get paid last), but to those people who bring us joy and can only do it by
spending cashish, the DJ.  So I can dig, from a certain perspective why Ray
might feel like this or anyone else who may make money via dance culture.
The weekend is payday, and that is how most of the DJ community lives.

So if he or anyone else wants to start a trend, they are welcome, throw a
series of freebies during the week, then do your money weekend, and good
luck.  It is certainly no worse than the calls for boycotts because of $'s,
and you get your dream realized, maybe.

Tangent (as if I'm just arriving at one): If you can't afford the $$$'s it
takes to go out, there are alternatives; cheaper parties, or no partying at
all, just getting together  with some other friends and chilling listening
to music and talking.  Now that's just as good as boom boom for 8 hours.
Sometimes ;).

Well, I'm done, poke me with a fork.

Much peace,
John

P.S.  BTW, I am one of those who thinks that if you really feel that way,
then fine, do something about it.  As for how others should act & do?  Set
the example and maybe others will follow.  Over and audi...



"If I have seen farther than you,
it is by standing on the shoulders of giants" - Sir Isaac Newton

On Fri, 18 Jul 1997 foolish_fish1@juno.com wrote:

> massive undergrounds in the enchanted forest
> 
> When you plant lettuce, if it does not grow well,
> you don't blame the lettuce. You look for reasons
> it is not doing well...it may need fertilizer, or more
> water or less sun. You never blame the lettuce.
> Yet if we have problems with our family, we blame
> the other person...But if we know how to take care
> of them they will grow well,like the lettuce. Blaming has
> no positive effect at all, nor does trying to persuade
> using reason and arguments.

Or maybe we can blame the 40 foot high rutebega that's blocking the sun,
or the soldiers who put salt in the ground, or the dog that always sits
on it... or maybe it's just crappy lettuce.

I think massives and micros and UGs and beach parties and beer busts and
frat parties can all peacefully coexist.  I know the large crews look out
for each other's dates, I know the small crews look out for each other's
events when possible, and as long as we keep the intentions good we'll be
fine.  I believe the point was made that we've seen some bad intentions,
so we need to go past idealism and see if there's a way to deal with it.

Just to clear the air, Vlad was never the person suspect by the @spire
crew of tampering with them.  I think we've seen some good points all
around, and I'd hate this to be viewed in retrospect as another massive
vs. UG war, because it's about as useful as another round of tastes great
vs. less filling.  The point was about the ethics of people throwing
parties, and we got some interesting insights.  I for one learned a
little.

> No blame,no reasoning, no argument, just
understanding. > 

Sounds like a nice dream.  Too bad that without blame, many people would
act very irresponsibly, without reasoning nothing would make any sense
other than that dictated by those who know what's "best for us",
and without arguement there would be no consensus (which is what our more
beautiful collectives run by).

> if you understand and you show that you understand
> you can love and the situation will change.
> 

And you can walk into the slaughterhouse knowing that nice man who feeds
you would never think of hurting you.

We need to keep our ideals, while still maintaining a degree of self
protection.  It would be nice to tell the police that "yes, this is a
rave, but it's a carefully thrown rave", but we can't.  We just lost a
location that way recently...

In the real world, there is bad intent, there is greed, and there is
distrust.  Only by being aware and dealing with the outside world can we
be effective in creating environments that are outside of those
influences.

The defenders of the faith live with a foot in each world,and their heads
teetering between.  We don't get spaces by going on about how beautiful
this warehouse will be with tons of people dancing about (usually), we get
them by waving money.  The trick is letting the dream of collective
consciousness, natural peace and the beauty of dance navigate their
actions, and not the material concerns of the "other side".

A tip of the hat to the partythrowers who don't suck, regardless of how
big or small their parties are.

Peace,
AndyW

Hello everyone.  I think that this thread has been beat down soo much that
everything that has been said has been said already.  But, Just to add a
bit of my perspective, I'd like to say this...  I'm one of those nutty folx
that LIKE to help, set up and tear down an event.  I enjoy staying pretty
much sober in the case of cops dropping by and having to act fast to keep
em from finding us or if a speaker goes out, EQ dies, whatever.  I enjoy
running with different crews, both established and up-in-coming...  Both
Massives and UG's.  But eventhough I enjoy helping, DJing and dancing @
such events.  I'm still wary and selective as to which crews I assoicate
myself with...

Why?

Because of thier true intentions of throwing a party.  Im a promoter too.
Like Jer, Vlad, Greg, Ethan, Leslie and the soo many others that pepper
thier post with either blainant or hidden BSPs.  And I'll usually promote
the parties I just GO to and have no association with as well.  But when a
promoters eyes are opened as to WHY a crew is throwing this party to do
such and such instead of this or that...  Well it getts hazy and confusing.
I remember seeing a few newbe crews out there that once they see the cash
flow in...  Well prioirites change.  And once the scene figures this out,
the backlash can be severe.
Other crews have to get rid of "Stuff" and so the party is built around the
dispensions of such items. Some parties are thrown for the sheer beauty of
danicing and listening to kick ass DJ's spin kick ass music. And some
people are out to make a name for themselves or thier crew.

You know what I say....

It's summer.  Fuck it. Go out, have a ill time.  True partygoers,
scensters, ravers... you KNOW where the real party is @...  Be it at
_ORBIT_, _LETTIUCE DANCE_ , _WALLY WORLD_ or _TRAINWRECKS ON THE BEACH_.  A
massive warehouse full of screaming dancers or a house party with 20 or so
people.  You create that vibe withing you, and whatever you do that vibe
will express itself.  If someone is F***ing with you, then deal.  I've been
threatend with arrest, hidden in a dumpster, watch (Helplessly) as a tide
almost washed away a sound system "oh I guess the tide didn't come in yet
after all...".
And the most recently was the snafu of trying to move all the wires from a
burnt out surge strip to another surge strip...  DURING THE MIDDLE OF A
PARTY (talk about pressure).

But to any of those big time producers out there that feels to be compelled
to "toy" with undergrounds, well what is rightfully derserved will come to
you.  Secrets in the scene do not stay secret for too long....

And on a lighter note... All of those involved with Rebel Alliance Sound
(or who want to be)...  Drop me a lil note.  It looks like a nice space has
opened up and the accounting dpartment is telling me that I can live my
life again off or Top Ramen for another two months after another party...
=)    =)    =)    =)    =)    =)    =)    =)    9=6    (=    (=    (=    (=
(=    (=    (=    (=

"Target date.... August"

L-8.



"Awaken"

	  id OAA10567;
	  Fri, 18 Jul 1997 14:49:46 -0400 (EDT)
Date: Fri, 18 Jul 1997 14:49:46 -0400 (EDT)
Message-ID: <970718144943_-224346165@emout10.mail.aol.com>
To: Pengo@ten.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Economics.....(new thread?)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


In a message dated 7/18/97 4:52:07 AM, you wrote:

<<Economics effects us all. A good economy is what makes it possible for
people to have excess money to spend on records so they can become DJs
so we can have raves in the first place.
>>

Possibly, The logic of that statement is flawed, but have you ever *really*
wondered about that? I think it's actually more crucial that those events
that *can* pay their DJ's actually do so. *That* is more important to keeping
things fresh in the scene while the promoter uses his/her money wisely so
that they can continue to provide quality events(whether free or paid) in the
first place.

But please consider this:

 We're supposed to be experiencing a boom in our economy, the likes of which
analysts havent seen since the post-WWII era, right? The dollar is very
strong world wide against everything(with the exception of the Deutsch Mark,
I think). If this is true, then it may follow logically that if I live in
this country, not only will I have more money to spend(if I have any money at
all, that is!), but will things will be cheaper to buy, especially things
that come from outside the US.

So, here's my question: WHY IN THE F**K AM I STILL SPENDING UPWARDS OF $11
SOMETIMES TO PURCHASE *ONE* 12'' SINGLE? Every DJ/import record collector on
this list knows exactly what I'm talking about here. You have to be born
eyeless to miss the fact that import record prices have gone through the roof
in the past couple of years, while domestic prices have only gone up a little
bit. And what makes me particularly suspicious is the fact that I go to
different record shops and see the same records being sold for totally
different prices. For example, I was at a well-known, immaculately kept
record store in SF last week. There was a 2x12''  import on the Defender
label called "It's a DJ Thing pt 5." The price tag was $13.99. A few days
later, I was in Berkeley at a record store known for it's um...urges(?) and
the very same record was $23.99!

I worked at a distributor I know what happens to the records and how much
they cost before they get to the retail outlet. Can someone provide an answer
as to why when I used to go to buy imports they were $8.99 and now can be up
to $11.99, and why back in the days, domestic singles cost me $4.99 and now
cost $5.99? Am I barking up the wrong tree or what?

--Monty

i have to totally agree with monty here.....i have to actually put off
some other expenses JUST so i can buy records.  I have like a $40-60 a
week record habit and it's killing me.  I get like 3-5 records now
when i used to get and get 6-10 for around the same price.  It's
ridiculous.

The problem is that they have us (well atleast me) by the b*lls.  I
mean...what choice do i have...not buy records anymore???

I have, however, come up with 1 solution.  And that is to buy used
records...i now spend $0.95 to $3.95 per record and am quite happy. 
Sure, i may not get all the *new* stuff all the time...but i've found
some kick-ass used records.

one broke dj.....

8)`
dan




---Tekno313@aol.com wrote:
>
> 
> In a message dated 7/18/97 4:52:07 AM, you wrote:
> 
> <<Economics effects us all. A good economy is what makes it possible
for
> people to have excess money to spend on records so they can become
DJs
> so we can have raves in the first place.
> >>
> 
> Possibly, The logic of that statement is flawed, but have you ever
*really*
> wondered about that? I think it's actually more crucial that those
events
> that *can* pay their DJ's actually do so. *That* is more important
to keeping
> things fresh in the scene while the promoter uses his/her money
wisely so
> that they can continue to provide quality events(whether free or
paid) in the
> first place.
> 
> But please consider this:
> 
>  We're supposed to be experiencing a boom in our economy, the likes
of which
> analysts havent seen since the post-WWII era, right? The dollar is
very
> strong world wide against everything(with the exception of the
Deutsch Mark,
> I think). If this is true, then it may follow logically that if I
live in
> this country, not only will I have more money to spend(if I have any
money at
> all, that is!), but will things will be cheaper to buy, especially
things
> that come from outside the US.
> 
> So, here's my question: WHY IN THE F**K AM I STILL SPENDING UPWARDS
OF $11
> SOMETIMES TO PURCHASE *ONE* 12'' SINGLE? Every DJ/import record
collector on
> this list knows exactly what I'm talking about here. You have to be
born
> eyeless to miss the fact that import record prices have gone through
the roof
> in the past couple of years, while domestic prices have only gone up
a little
> bit. And what makes me particularly suspicious is the fact that I go
to
> different record shops and see the same records being sold for
totally
> different prices. For example, I was at a well-known, immaculately
kept
> record store in SF last week. There was a 2x12''  import on the
Defender
> label called "It's a DJ Thing pt 5." The price tag was $13.99. A few
days
> later, I was in Berkeley at a record store known for it's
um...urges(?) and
> the very same record was $23.99!
> 
> I worked at a distributor I know what happens to the records and how
much
> they cost before they get to the retail outlet. Can someone provide
an answer
> as to why when I used to go to buy imports they were $8.99 and now
can be up
> to $11.99, and why back in the days, domestic singles cost me $4.99
and now
> cost $5.99? Am I barking up the wrong tree or what?
> 
> --Monty
>

                     BBQ & BEATS Campout
August 8th - 10th   Fri, 11pm  to  Sun 6pm
DJ's for the weekend will be, in no particular order..

Main Area
BioJeff, Joe Rice, Monty, Henrik, Goldilox, Tom, Greg Sandler, Matt Schmitt
Li, James, Vertigo, Siphon, Andy W, Science, Micron, Stillwind, Macadio,
Todd Manley, Forrest Green, Knucklehead, Jonathan, DJ, Fat Tony..and more TBA

Ambient/Chill Area
C-Lab, Dionysus Dreams, Lola, Jon Logan..and more TBA


        The BBQ & BEATS crew would like to offer you a choice. If you
attend our campout and bring your own food to eat, then you can come enjoy
the weekend for free. If you'd like the BBQ & BEATS crew to feed you, then
we are asking for a $10 donation that goes toward your food. You'll have a
choice between ribs, chicken, hamburgers, hot dogs, or veggie burgers or
veggie hot dogs, and maybe even some spaghetti and stir fry, some kind of
salad and another side dish as well as a soft drink. If we do the spaghetti
and stir fry, there will be vegan friendly servings of spaghetti and stir
fry also. This should make the veggie and meat eaters both happy.

We will also be flippin pancakes, eggs, and potatoes for Saturday and
Sunday breakfast. With the main meal going for most of the afternoon on
Saturday until it starts getting dark.  If you don't get the ticket that
includes meals and would like to have the breakfast we cook. Alittle
donation to help cover cost will be great during the campout. But we won't
turn you down for breakfast food, unless we run out of course.  The main
meal will cost much more and we ask if you plan on eating the main meal
too, then we suggest a donation of $10 to cover cost, but we do encourage
you to get the ticket for meals before the campout so we can plan and have
the correct amount of food for those with the tickets for meals. We will
have two tickets available soon. One for people bringing there own food and
one for people wanting to eat the food we bring.

We have thrown several free daytime parties with lots of food for all to
enjoy for free.  We would love to do this for the Campout, but 2 days worth
of food for everyone can be expensive, not including other cost for
throwing this event.

So the choice is yours, let us cook for you, we ask for a $10 donation to
buy your food. You supply your own food, then come and enjoy for free.

Tickets will be available shortly,  again there will be two different
tickets. One for those wanting us to cook, and the other will be for those
bringing there own food.

We hope to see as many of you come and enjoy the weekend with us. We will
be sending out info about how to get your tickets soon.  We will also have
an info number to get the details shortly, so keep your eyes and ears open.

In the meantime, feel free to check out the BBQ & BEATS Homepage
(http://www.bbq-beats.org) for any updates. We will soon put up the details
about the tickets and how we will work out the food. If you have any
questions feel free to ask.

We thank you for all your support on our past events and hope you can come
out and spend the weekend with us.

Take care...




*****************************************************************
                         Tim (knucklehead)

  BBQ & BEATS Home Page:  http://www.club.net/~knucklehead/BnB  moving soon!!
  New Home for BBQ & BEATS:  http://www.bbq-beats.org   under contruction!!

On Fri, 18 Jul 1997, Phil Lockwood wrote:

> 
> > I worked at a distributor I know what happens to the records and how much
> > they cost before they get to the retail outlet. Can someone provide an answer
> > as to why when I used to go to buy imports they were $8.99 and now can be up
> > to $11.99, and why back in the days, domestic singles cost me $4.99 and now
> > cost $5.99? Am I barking up the wrong tree or what?
> 

The record prices are adjusted for inflation *8^)...I really don't think 
there is more to it then that and maybe a little rise in demand...but 
then again, that could also be due to Inflation-Higher Wages-I can buy more 
records-Demand records increases-retail stores think "Hey, we can charge 
more money for records"-inflation .......etc


Stay Cool!

Leslie Ayres wrote:
> 
> I had a dream last night that there was a town with ten churches, and
> the
> Baptist Church, which was small and had little money, got upset
> because the
> Catholic Church was spending so much on its new building that some of
> the
> parishoners actually wanted to go to Mass to experience the opulence,
> which
> would mean even less money in the collection bowls.
> 
> Then the Christian Scientists anonymously called the building
> inspector to
> report a possible hazard in the Unitarian Church, and when he came and
> shut
> down the church on Sunday morning, they were there handing out
> directions to
> the Reading Room.
> 
> Meanwhile, the Seventh Day Adventists were issuing press releases with
> unsubstantiated and unverified rumors about how the Methodists were
> underdeclaring the money received in the collection each week, and the
> Jews
> were holding a meeting to see if they could keep the Buddhists next
> door
> from chanting during Friday night services, because the noise
> disturbed them.
> 
> Thankfully, I woke up, knowing that dream was ridiculous because truly
> spiritual people would never behave that way, because they know that
> all
> beliefs deserve respect, and that if you don't respect other's right
> to
> believe differently than you, then you're missing the point.
> 
> Then I checked my email, and what a nightmare.  The church of the
> massive
> was being attacked through innuendo by the church of the
> free-beach-party,
> and the church of the old-school-underground was being attacked by the
> church of the massive, and the church of the old-school-underground
> retaliated with some "he-said-she-said" accusations of its own.
> 
> As a "churchgoer" who considers herself a contributing member of all
> of
> these "religions," this is so disturbing.
> 
> This is yet another example of how divisiveness hurts our scene as a
> whole.
> Certainly we can't expect that all promoters have the same motivations
> and
> priorities.  But, in a scene that theoretically is based on a shared
> love of
> music and dance and the coming-together of like-minded people, it
> would seem
> obvious that learning to respectfully work together is a priority of
> the
> highest order.
> 
> Nobody "owns" this scene.  Nobody has a "right" to stop someone else
> from
> throwing a party on any particular night.  And *nobody* has a right to
> make
> slanderous and libelous statements in a public forum without
> substantiating
> them.
> 
> How about let's leave the rumor and innuendo to the tabloids, and act
> like
> responsible and admirable adults, giving others the respect that we
> would
> like to receive from them.
> 
> If anyone thinks that the only way they can "succeed" is to try to get
> someone else to "fail" ... or that they can only be right by making
> someone
> else wrong... then think again.
> 
> The real way to success is by *being* successful, by behaving in an
> honest
> and pure way, by considering the effect of your actions on others, and
> by
> being the kind of person who is worthy of respect.  Show that you are
> worthy
> of being treated with respect through every action, every word, every
> deed.
> 
> The way to have other promoters respect your party is by respecting
> them,
> and respecting their events.  When conflicts arise, talk about it, try
> to
> work it out.  Sabotage is never acceptable, whether it's by anonymous
> phone
> calls complaining about a "competitor's" party, or by posting
> unsubstantiated rumors on SFRaves.
> 
> If you're a promoter in this community, then you have a responsibility
> to
> set and maintain high standards of behavior.  We all win when those
> standards are met, and we all lose when petty ego-driven issues get in
> the
> way.
> 
> Optimistically,
> 
> Leslie
> 
>   .................
>   [888888888888888]
>   [888888888888888]
>    \8888888888888/
>   __/============\__
>  0000000O000000000000
>  ;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
> 
>       <O>  | --<
>    o       |      o
>    (O    ._|.     O)
>       ( ______/ )

I hear you guys on that one it seems like I am trying to buy more and
more rekkids each week. But good thing for me is that the Metallic
industrial Tekno that I like to play is kind of rare with the

just about the same with the exception of $1 like for instance the
store I shop at come to think of it they should make me a co owner
cause I spend so  much in there Solid Grooves I can get a rekkid there
for like $10.90 and see it in the city for $11.90 So I have not really
noticed any real price gouging. That is just what I have noticed.

hello to all my fellow $BROKE$ d.j.'s out there,

i have a suggestion that y'all might be interested in.  get a business
licence for your dj services. the cost of the licence is only 50-75
dollars(depending where you are). with this you can:

1. order direct thru distributers(nemisis,intergroove, watts, etc.)
	a. this means you can pick up new wax for 3-6 bucks!
	b. contact the distributers(the #'s are usually on the bottom of the
sleeves) 		   and ask them to send you their faxes. if you have trouble
getting their #'s, e-	   mail me privately and i'll try to help you.
2. use expenses (money spent on records, gas getting to parties, phone calls
to        	promoters,etc.) as tax write off's. the federales give you 1 or 2
years b-4 you 	are supposed to make a profit.

you'll have to pay taxes on any money you make, but payin' taxes on a gig
that you only got a couple bucks for is totally worth the money you'll save.

well, take it easy and happy spinnin',
			stillwind

On Fri, 18 Jul 1997, knucklehead wrote:

>                      BBQ & BEATS Campout
> August 8th - 10th   Fri, 11pm  to  Sun 6pm
> DJ's for the weekend will be, in no particular order..
> 
> Main Area
> BioJeff, Joe Rice, Monty, Henrik, Goldilox, Tom, Greg Sandler, Matt Schmitt
> Li, James, Vertigo, Siphon, Andy W, Science, Micron, Stillwind, Macadio,
> Todd Manley, Forrest Green, Knucklehead, Jonathan, DJ, Fat Tony..and more TBA
> 
> Ambient/Chill Area
> C-Lab, Dionysus Dreams, Lola, Jon Logan..and more TBA
> 
> 
>         The BBQ & BEATS crew would like to offer you a choice. If you
> attend our campout and bring your own food to eat, then you can come enjoy
> the weekend for free. If you'd like the BBQ & BEATS crew to feed you, then
> we are asking for a $10 donation that goes toward your food. You'll have a
> choice between ribs, chicken, hamburgers, hot dogs, or veggie burgers or
> veggie hot dogs, and maybe even some spaghetti and stir fry, some kind of
> salad and another side dish as well as a soft drink. If we do the spaghetti
> and stir fry, there will be vegan friendly servings of spaghetti and stir
> fry also. This should make the veggie and meat eaters both happy.
> 
> We will also be flippin pancakes, eggs, and potatoes for Saturday and
> Sunday breakfast. With the main meal going for most of the afternoon on
> Saturday until it starts getting dark.  If you don't get the ticket that
> includes meals and would like to have the breakfast we cook. Alittle
> donation to help cover cost will be great during the campout. But we won't
> turn you down for breakfast food, unless we run out of course.  The main
> meal will cost much more and we ask if you plan on eating the main meal
> too, then we suggest a donation of $10 to cover cost, but we do encourage
> you to get the ticket for meals before the campout so we can plan and have
> the correct amount of food for those with the tickets for meals. We will
> have two tickets available soon. One for people bringing there own food and
> one for people wanting to eat the food we bring.
> 
> We have thrown several free daytime parties with lots of food for all to
> enjoy for free.  We would love to do this for the Campout, but 2 days worth
> of food for everyone can be expensive, not including other cost for
> throwing this event.
> 
> So the choice is yours, let us cook for you, we ask for a $10 donation to
> buy your food. You supply your own food, then come and enjoy for free.
> 
> Tickets will be available shortly,  again there will be two different
> tickets. One for those wanting us to cook, and the other will be for those
> bringing there own food.
> 
> We hope to see as many of you come and enjoy the weekend with us. We will
> be sending out info about how to get your tickets soon.  We will also have
> an info number to get the details shortly, so keep your eyes and ears open.
> 
> In the meantime, feel free to check out the BBQ & BEATS Homepage
> (http://www.bbq-beats.org) for any updates. We will soon put up the details
> about the tickets and how we will work out the food. If you have any
> questions feel free to ask.
> 
> We thank you for all your support on our past events and hope you can come
> out and spend the weekend with us.
>

At 3:10 PM -0700 7/18/97, macadio wrote:
>Hi My name is Macadio and I am a Vinyl Addict!!!
>
>I hear you guys on that one it seems like I am trying to buy more and
>more rekkids each week. But good thing for me is that the Metallic
>industrial Tekno that I like to play is kind of rare with the
>exception of Missle rekkids which I hate. So for me it is hard to find
>good rekkids One thing I have noticed is for me the Prices have been
>just about the same with the exception of $1 like for instance the
>store I shop at come to think of it they should make me a co owner
>cause I spend so  much in there Solid Grooves I can get a rekkid there
>for like $10.90 and see it in the city for $11.90 So I have not really
>noticed any real price gouging. That is just what I have noticed.
>
>Peace,
>Macadio
>_____________________________________________________________________

11.90 for 12"'s? Hmm, a bit steep, especially considering that all the
stores pay the same prices... We try to sell stuff for 8.98 and 9.98 at the
store I work at (Drop Beat), with only French imports generally going 10.98
or 11.98. (German and French imports tend to be higher cost than UK
records, with the French being most expensive) The prices charged to stores
tend to vary .50 either way depending on the week and the distributor, but
I haven't noticed a trend towards more higher prices overall...

There are a couple of UK mail order places that can be worthwhile... The
people that do the Juno weekly new release list offer records to the US at
ukp3.75-4.50, or roughly US$6.30-7.60. If you order several records at a
time and can get decent shipping prices it's possible for the total price
of each record to average around $8, not a big reduction, but still
noticeable, and some  of those records don't get picked up by the US
distros. Their published shipping rates are a bit out of hand, so I haven't
ordered them, but I've had good luck with 4th World, a shop in Scotland.

Joe

(:Joe Rice:___________:ambient@netcom.com:___________:joe@justiceleague.com:)

The Facts of Life:

. If at first you don't succeed, skydiving is not for you.

  Deja Moo: The feeling that you've heard this bull before.

. Psychiatrists say that 1 of 4 people are nuts. Check 3 friends.
 If they're OK, you're it.

. It has recently been discovered that research causes cancer in rats.

. Always remember to pillage BEFORE you burn.

  It may be that your sole purpose in life is simply to serve as a
warning
  to others.

  Paul's Law: You can't fall off the floor.

do something that does it artifcially over again in a harmful way?"

At 2:49 PM -0400 7/18/97, Tekno313@aol.com wrote:
>In a message dated 7/18/97 4:52:07 AM, you wrote:
<snip>
>So, here's my question: WHY IN THE F**K AM I STILL SPENDING UPWARDS OF $11
>SOMETIMES TO PURCHASE *ONE* 12'' SINGLE? Every DJ/import record collector on
>this list knows exactly what I'm talking about here. You have to be born
>eyeless to miss the fact that import record prices have gone through the roof
>in the past couple of years, while domestic prices have only gone up a little
>bit. And what makes me particularly suspicious is the fact that I go to
>different record shops and see the same records being sold for totally
>different prices. For example, I was at a well-known, immaculately kept
>record store in SF last week. There was a 2x12''  import on the Defender
>label called "It's a DJ Thing pt 5." The price tag was $13.99. A few days
>later, I was in Berkeley at a record store known for it's um...urges(?) and
>the very same record was $23.99!
>
>I worked at a distributor I know what happens to the records and how much
>they cost before they get to the retail outlet. Can someone provide an answer
>as to why when I used to go to buy imports they were $8.99 and now can be up
>to $11.99, and why back in the days, domestic singles cost me $4.99 and now
>cost $5.99? Am I barking up the wrong tree or what?
>
>--Monty

Nope, but there is a solution to the problem.  Why not get a bunch of us
record geekouts together and , get this, start a company and start buying
our own records.  It's cheaper in the long run (I mean those guys are
getting rekkids @ 3.99 - 4.99, imports are usually going fo 6.99 and up.
That is one solution to the problem, put or financial resources behind one
another to help each other out.  The upside is that not only do we get good
prices, but the promos and white labels will start flowing in like water.
We could then sell these back to record stroes at a gain.  Put the money
BACK into the collective to purchase more choons.  Now I know that most of
these distributors require acertain amount of purchase, but look at this.
If each of us is spending $60/week on records, and there are let's say 10
of us, that is $600 per week.  Any distributor would kill to have that
steady stream of business.

I am 100% down for this solution.  Why?  I work first off, secondly I don't
have time to go around and shop each week, and next the prices get to me
too.  If anyone else is down I think this is a great solution to our
problem.  Anybody up for it?

Just food for thought.

Peace,
John

P.S.  Group economics is the ONLY way to get over these days.  if we team
up and pool our resources to a common end we can all be winners.

Pax out.


"If I have seen farther than you,
it is by standing on the shoulders of giants" - Sir Isaac Newton

In a message dated 7/19/97 5:21:32 AM, you wrote:

<<you'll have to pay taxes on any money you make, but payin' taxes on a gig
that you only got a couple bucks for is totally worth the money you'll save.
>>

This situation is a possible catch-22 for people like myself who have been
playing records and getting paid for it since 1989. What if I get audited?
 Will they root out some information that leads them to the conclusion that I
should pay back taxes, retro to 1989? It's a gamble for sure. 

And the business license thing is a good idea, if it could actually work. You
see, I know that when people used to call me when I worked at the shite
record distributor that I was employed at and told me they had a store and
they wanted to start ordering from me, They would fax over a copy of that
business license. Then they would start ordering, but they always got busted
because no individual is gonna do the same type of ordering that a retail
store will. Stores by like 10's and 15's of the same record. Individual DJ's
dont. And as we were relatively lenient on folks who used to run this
scam(because we were so desparate for money in order to pay the people we
owed money to) I know for a fact that people like Watts and Nemesis wont fall
for it. I know legit stores that are having a hard time trying to get these
people's attention, much less getting them to send these very real stores
faxes every week to sell records with.
--Monty

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: Economics of record buying
In-Reply-To: <v03102800aff633694537@[205.162.25.58]>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970719124143.16630B-100000@am.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

In response to your notion that records are to expensive, one might want 
to take into consideration a couple of issues.

1) In order to keep inventory as current as you buyers expect, we have to 
have records shipped to us fed-ex, or 2nd day UPS. When this is happening 
from the east coast, that can add as much as $1.00 to the price of a record.
Depending on the exchange rate between the dollar and the different 
European currencies, this makes import vinyl as much as $8.00 before it 
even goes to the shelf.

2) The typical mark-up in this business is 50%...about half of the 
mark-up in any other retail business.

3) On top of providing new vinyl every week, most stores provide 
listening stations, which have to be maintained.

4) If you go into a record store and listen to 50 records, but you only 
like 5, you can leave spending about $50. If you were to order 
blind, without the ordering background and experience that we feel we have, the 
ratio of songs you like versus those you don't will probably decrease. My 
point being that in the end it is definitely cheaper to buy from the 
store than to take your chances on random selections off of distributor 
faxes. 

Keep in mind that the record stores you are a bit fed up with are 
supporting our scene as much as anyone else. You get party info from 
them. You see your long lost friends at them...and they allow you to 
perpetuate your biggest addiction.

I've tried the group ordering thing before opening a record store. Some 
weeks it worked out for some people, and other weeks it sucked for 
everyone. In the end, we didn't feel that it was worth while. Try it, and 
maybe your experience will be different. If anything, it might be worth 
jsut getting a deeper look into the working of dance music.

good luck.

E.S.

At 2:44 PM 7/19/97, Tekno313@aol.com wrote:
>In a message dated 7/19/97 5:12:31 PM, you wrote:

><<I am 100% down for this solution.  Why?  I work first off, secondly I don't
>have time to go around and shop each week, and next the prices get to me

>problem.  Anybody up for it?
>>>
>
>I'm down to do this like Brutus! It can be done. The only thing is, would we
>be able to access more than one distributor ? I'm sure the people involved
>enjoy a variety of music. Hell, I'm sure some non-DJ folks who buy CD's and
>stuff just for listening at home wouldnt mind getting in on this.
>--Monty


Well I didn't want to get into this due to well... I'm currenlty working @
a record store now...  But what it sounds like you all want to do is form a
record pool.   It's not too hard to actually do, granted that some NAMES
need to get put on the roster.  What a record pool is (And im sure most of
you know this):
        -Record companies make limited promotinal pressings of all thier
_HOT_ songs (Currently on my hit list is Monacos "What do you want from
me?" trance mix)
        - Selecet copies go to Established Record pools that have DJ's in
various circuts (mainly Clubs and Radio, but mobile DJ's are not uncommon)
to put the tracks on "Heavy rotation" thus allowing the consumer to want
to: see the concert, buy the album, ect.
        -DJ's get into a pool sorta like a fitness membership (Monthy dues
~~90$ or so. Plus startup)
        -DJ's fill out surveies on crowd response and rotation which is
sent back to the record company.

I have many good friends that established the SO-BAD (SOuth Bay Area Dj
Assoc) record Pool in SJ, which consists of djs in radio (Kmel, Ksol, Kllc,
and Kits) as well as club dj's (like Julis Papp and Bad Boy Jess).  Again,
it can be done, and gettin a Phat stack of 20+ records every two weeks
(from domestic labes like Ovum [Wink], Artista [Robert Miles], Nervous,
Elektra [Shamen]) is KEWL too.

But the drawbacks are:  Not every record you get would you play.  Some are
worth less than the vynal it was pressed on.  I've yet to see CD pools
(Sorry CD DJ's). The pool would have to be diverse (else you'd have every
DJ playing the same songs over and over and over and over and over and over
and... well you get the picture.  Usually to get into a record pool the DJ
has to show that he/she's established, and most importantly...  Record
companies tend to want to SEE how the consumer will have access to buy a
finished good (Album).  The last argument tends to kill the prospects of
imports cos many imported tracks don't appear @ , say, Tower or The
Warehouse....

And also A record pool is a bussness.  Many hours are used to establish
contacts, pickup and deliver crates of 12's as well as the mountain (And I
MEAN mountian) of paperwork required to keep the bussness running.

But if you're gonna do it, might as well do it right....

P.S. Sorry to hear about the Viberation thingy...  But it was sorta funny
watching cars zoom back and forth from location to location (Myself
included)  in the wee hrs of the morning...

L-8.

"Awaken"

>Well I didn't want to get into this due to well... I'm currenlty working @

Not to be blunt but this is exactly what I'm not talking about.  A record
pool is way too much work for people who work (like myself).  I am familiar
with this type of solution and it basically sux.  There is NO GUARANTEE, as
you said, that you will get what you want.  Basically what I want to do is
open a record store without a storefront, whose purpsoe is to get records
cheap.  There would be NO INVENTORY since we would order direct the wax we
want, we would cut out the record store shopping altogehter since we would
be getting exactly what we order, and we would have no overhead, except for
that of yearly taxes.  When divided among 10 people that's about $80/year.
Not bad considering the thousands you save by incorporating and splitting
the costs.

forget the record pool idea.  For less work and hassle it is better to
incorporate.  The other thing is that if some members were so motivated, we
could open our own records store and just add to the competiton.  There's
more flexibility to incorparating, getting a tax id and ordering rekkids
than just forming a record pool which has, at best, mixed results.

Thanks for the input though anakin, greatly appreciated.

BTW for all:  People are becoming millionaries as this stock market keeps
climbing.  I for one am sick of working while the "man" gets rich.  I am
down to use my money this year to make myself some more money or at least
stretch my dollar.  If anyone is interested in forming an investors club to
get in on this hot market, or has a place where they can point me to info
on starting one please get in contact with me via mail and let's get to
work.  I am motivated, have some capital, and am ready to get things moving
asap.  Get in touch.

Peace,
john

gotta work it out....

Subject: Re: Economics of record buying
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


In a message dated 7/19/97 9:21:04 PM, you wrote:

<<In response to your notion that records are to expensive, one might want <<
>to take into consideration a couple of issues.<<
>1) In order to keep inventory as current as you buyers expect, we have to<< 
>have records shipped to us fed-ex, or 2nd day UPS. When this is happening <<
>from the east coast, that can add as much as $1.00 to the price of a
record.<<
>Depending on the exchange rate between the dollar and the different <<
>European currencies, this makes import vinyl as much as $8.00 before it <<
>even goes to the shelf.<<

Are you joking? Please.....You dont HAVE to have your records shipped Fed-Ex
or 2nd Day UPS. Stores do it because all the other stores do it, not because
they have to or because DJ's demand that they do that.

>>2) The typical mark-up in this business is 50%...about half of the 
mark-up in any other retail business.<<

This doesnt excuse the fact that many people *still* feel as though they're
paying more than they should be for their records, many of which can be
wrought with fingerprints, warped and/or water damaged and still sold as
brand new.

>>3) On top of providing new vinyl every week, most stores provide listening
stations, which have to be maintained.<<

That is a choice the retailer makes. If they want to sell their wax, it's
smart for them 
to provide listening stations. I feel that the listening station thing isnt
essential though.   Why should the patron have to pay for that?  Dont you
think that that should be chalked up as a regular business expense and not be
passed on to the consumer?

>>4) If you go into a record store and listen to 50 records, but you only 
like 5, you can leave spending about $50. If you were to order 
blind, without the ordering background and experience that we feel we have,
the 
ratio of songs you like versus those you don't will probably decrease. My 
point being that in the end it is definitely cheaper to buy from the 
store than to take your chances on random selections off of distributor 
faxes. <<

I guess, but what if everyone was more educated on the music, read a little
more than just XLR8R and URB's often times dated record reviews (due to some
of the unfortunate realities of print journalism). We would get our more of
our money's worth, right? And I know plenty of buyers who fack up and order
shite records. And who is forced to pay for those mess ups in the long run?
The consumer. 

>>Keep in mind that the record stores you are a bit fed up with are 
supporting our scene as much as anyone else. You get party info from 
them. You see your long lost friends at them...and they allow you to 
perpetuate your biggest addiction.<<

First of all, I never said I was fed up. I was just looking for answers and
wanted to spark discussion I think hasnt really been broached here before.
Second of all, Not all of our local stores give a fack about our scene. There
are many that do, though. Ameba was a shining example of this. But this fact,
along with your points about getting party info from stores and seeing our
long lost friends at stores has nothing to do with the fact that I, along
with most of the DJ's I know fell as though records are too expensive. 

When was the last time you ever saw one of your favorite DJ stores have a
sale on its new inventory?

--Monty

Subject: Review of DNA,Suger Shack, Release and Review requested for Heaven 19 at Compadr
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Went to DNA on Friday. Band was great but club was too crowded. Couldn't move
on the dance floor and it was over 100 degrees upstairs. No ventilation, no
fans..total disregard for the patrons Spencer. And can you add a few more
toilets. With all that water we drink we spend half our night waiting in line
for the bathrooms. Suggestion: Increase your cover and charge for water and
use the money for airconditioning, fans and more toilets. DB Hayes spun some
great tunes after the live band went off. But too hot and too crowded to
enjoy it.

Went to VSF (Sugar Shack) on Saturday. Brought eight friends, got a booth and
then listened to heavy slow house music. The setting and ambiance were great
but the music sucked. The dance floor was empty. We asked the DJ (James) if
he could spin a few higher energy tunes but he said flately...no. He didn't
seem to care that no one was dancing so we took our money and went to
Release. Great as always on a Saturday night. Nabil..you are doing a great
job. But you also need some more bathrooms. The girls have to wait over a
half an hour and are afraid to take E and water for fear of not making it to
the bathroom in time. Otherwise it is still the best club for Saturday night.

Heaven 19 at Compadres...Sebastion, who puts on Indulgence at Starlight on
Wednesday nights put on this gig. Anyone go? Any reviews would be
appreciated.

Anyone go to Holy Cow? Reviews please.


Neal....Venture forth and dance

To: Eric Ryan Spire <soundz@cats.ucsc.edu>
From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@nexsys.net>
Subject: Re: Economics of record buying
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

At 12:56 PM -0700 7/19/97, Eric Ryan Spire wrote:
>In response to your notion that records are to expensive, one might want
>to take into consideration a couple of issues.
>
>1) In order to keep inventory as current as you buyers expect, we have to
>have records shipped to us fed-ex, or 2nd day UPS. When this is happening
>from the east coast, that can add as much as $1.00 to the price of a record.
>Depending on the exchange rate between the dollar and the different
>European currencies, this makes import vinyl as much as $8.00 before it
>even goes to the shelf.

Understood.  I really don't care about when I get the record as long as I
get the record.  I do not need to get everything the next day.  So with
that in mind our overhead wouldn't be as much as you predict.

>
>2) The typical mark-up in this business is 50%...about half of the
>mark-up in any other retail business.

This is not true.  You are implying that there are other businesses that
charge 50% over, and yes they exist, but for the most part markups of
27-40% are most common.  Records, because the people who order them usually
have no idea, have poor inventory mgmt, don;t understand what people want
and what sells often carry large amounts of inventory.  Something the
collective will NEVER have to deal with.


>
>3) On top of providing new vinyl every week, most stores provide
>listening stations, which have to be maintained.

Qualification:  Most people carry crappy listenting stations which are
cheap and rarely listenable over the "hosue" sound system which is often
played too loud to hear the record.  Once again, something the collective
will avoid.  No listening stations, no overhead.

>
>4) If you go into a record store and listen to 50 records, but you only
>like 5, you can leave spending about $50. If you were to order
>blind, without the ordering background and experience that we feel we
>have, the
>ratio of songs you like versus those you don't will probably decrease. My
>point being that in the end it is definitely cheaper to buy from the
>store than to take your chances on random selections off of distributor
>faxes.

Eric, not to be blunt, but you're stating what we already know.  And I've
been buying records and been in the biz before house music was around for
the most part.  Obviously we would not be ordering blind, obviously we know
distributors who want to do business with us, obviously the people who join
our little group will know what they want to order and do not and have not
relied upon the, er, expertise of the store owner.  Which is often not to
my tastes and RARE is the storeowener who is really in touch with his/her
buying public.  They sell records to as many people as possible.  Little
time to become expert in what *I* want.  Now Darrin & Barry of Tweekin &
Primal repestively have thier pulse on thier buyers tastes.  Others just
carry huge amounts of unmovable inventory.  I am to the point , for the
most part, where I can pick and know what I want, moreso than someone
working in a rekkid store.

As for faxes, consider this, If I am working with a distributor giving them
some $600/week in business I will bet the farm I get those lists faxed to
me on time everytime.  Few are the stores who deal with a signle
distributor in such money volumes week after week.  I am talking upwards of
$600/week.  I think there are plenty of distributors who would love to have
that business.  I can think of two right off the top of my head.

>
>Keep in mind that the record stores you are a bit fed up with are
>supporting our scene as much as anyone else. You get party info from
>them. You see your long lost friends at them...and they allow you to
>perpetuate your biggest addiction.

And at a profit.  I would rather pocket that money and get what I want
everytime.  Sonce I don;t have long lost friends I doubt a record store or
a party will ever replace the good old telephone.  Anyway...


>
>I've tried the group ordering thing before opening a record store. Some
>weeks it worked out for some people, and other weeks it sucked for
>everyone. In the end, we didn't feel that it was worth while. Try it, and
>maybe your experience will be different. If anything, it might be worth
>jsut getting a deeper look into the working of dance music.

Maybe it was the people you were dealing with, maybe it was the money (were
you ordering $150 worth of $600 worht of records a pop for instance).  I
think that anyone interested in my idea will have thier eyes wide open and
be experienced in record buying.  The only thing it will give us greaster
insight into is the sleazy world of music and it's denizens at the other
end.  I just want to save $$$ otherwise.  And this I am well prepared to do!

>
>good luck.
>
>E.S.

Thanx,
John


"If I have seen farther than you,
it is by standing on the shoulders of giants" - Sir Isaac Newton

I totally agree with Eric Spire. IF you think record stores don't 
need to this or don't have to that whats the point of a retail store? How
often do you buy records? I mean if your a regular vinyl connoisseur
you would go back often and would want new records to listen to.
So someone would have to pay for the shipping of UPS or FED-EX.
Actually alot os DJs I know when they order something, they want
it ASAP. And you mentioned something about records having finger-
prints, being warped and water damaged, why dont you check you records
to see if its damaged before you put your money down? You do have the
choice!
Those people I know who own record stores do give a fuck about the
"scene"  or else they would not be DJs, promoters or producers in the
scene.
peace,
RACHEL

Well as me and my three friends pull up at about 12:30 we are  greeted by a
popo hangin at the door. it was then that i got the feeling that this wasnt
going to be one of the most memorable nights. as we walk up to the entrance
we are stopped by some oversized rent a cops where we are then patted down
and I had my bag searched. Then as we walk up to buy our tickets, we find out
that its $25!! if we hadnt driven 40 mins to get there, we would have turned
around and gone home. anyways we walk in and see a bunch of OG's posted up at
the entrance staring at us like were some kind of freaks. werent many people
dancing, just a lot of standing.  the lights and visuals were the most
positive part of the party, the fx were amazing. i cant say as much about the
music though. there were a few good sets, but most werent worth dancing to.
inside it was like 100 degreez and after paying $25 to get in, you'd expect
to atleast get free water, but we didnt. it was 2$ a bottle. after going
through my pockets in the morning, i realized i spent $50 last night!!!! 25
on the ticket, 5 on water, and 20 on other necessities.
overall, was it worth the 25 dollar cover? hell no
-blake

From: "vlad 008" <trip008@hotmail.com>
To: Tekno313@aol.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: Economics of record buying
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Sun, 20 Jul 1997 17:26:21 PDT
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



>In a message dated 7/19/97 9:21:04 PM, you wrote:

>Are you joking? Please.....You dont HAVE to have your records shipped 
Fed-Ex
>or 2nd Day UPS. 


> I feel that the listening station thing isnt
>essential though.   Why should the patron have to pay for that?  Dont 
you
>think that that should be chalked up as a regular business expense and 
not be
>passed on to the consumer?


    Basically, yes the stores don't HAVE TO do anything.  but in order 
to better service their customers, who often want the ltest tracks and 
also want to be able to listen to the product b4 buying instead of 
getting any random crap, they provide all these options.  if a customer 
did not feel that the $10 a record was worth all of these options they 
would not buy records.  people only buy things if they feel that in some 
way they are getting their money's worth.

    As for business expenses, if a business needs to pay more random 
expenses as overhead, that obviously must be passed on to the consumer.  
Overhead is always figured into the merchandise price as well as the 
actual cost of the product.  If people didn't care about the top new 
recent tracks, or listening stations, they could buy records at tower 
that sells them for cheeper.  it's the consumers choice.  better service 
= higher price.
-vlad
trip008@usa.net

______________________________________________________

Question for SFRavEs Celebrities (at least the beautiful people that shine
through in my life). . .

"What do the famous SFR celebrities eat for breakfast?"

AndyW.:  "Coffee.  Lots of it."

just.jer:  "Breakfast?  Where are you going for breakfast?"

Beth Jackson:  "Probably not much today, some fruit would be nice."

Paula:  "What were you guys going to get me?"

Jeremy (CFC):  "A smoothie every morning.  Honey nut Cheerios  with fruit
and with rice milk."

Sabin McCloud:  "Generally I get up so late I eat lunch."

Astronaut Scott (Scott Free):  "I'm only half-alien.  The other half
monkey."  =\

Scott Nelson, Master of Ceremonies:  "I don't know.  It depends.  It
just...depends."

Well...

Rumor has it that at the CFC 4-year, they will have automatic escalators to
take you up and out of the sand-pit.  They will be built underneath the
sand so that when it is running it will lOOk like the sand is mOVing.

well, maybe not.

but perhaps if you didn't go and can take the next year or so to like get
in gOOd cardiovascular shape, you might like be into these folx's
anniversary parties.

Parking!  How cool.  Plenty of it.  We really pulled the wool over their
eyes.

Sand.  There was defintely no shortage of sand.  I am like covered... From
head to toe in sand.  No, don't worry.  It didn't get in some places.
Whew.

Muzik.  Um...except for it like getting distorted on the speakers a few
times, the music  was nice.  It was nice to go to one of these shindigs for
once where they are not playing
fry-your-brain-well-before-your-drugs-kick-in acid trance (...please micron
don't kick my ass!)  ALL NIGHT LONG with no break.  arrgh.  no, they had
different styles all night.  course stonies a pretty neato dj and sorry
josh i missed yer set again, but i know we'll still be tearin it up one day
at a Let Freedom party together or some shit like that.

Vibe.  I don't have much to say about it.  No words to say...it was nice
and relaxed like all the Cloud Factories...=[]

Scenery.  Oh.  I forgot to mention!  I like gave in to adrenalin
junkieness!  I rolled down the sandy hill like all the other natural high
freaks were doing. These girls were screaming at me as I took the Nestea
plunge.

Taco Bell:  Oh, yeah.  we stopped at Taco Bell on the way back.  Probably
not the most nutritious food, but grubbin nonetheless.

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

oh, yeah, and it was danny's first successful beach party.

and he finally did end up getting sleep!  =]

welp.  gotta dive!  -=dEEp=-

have your friends bummin 20 tell next payday. So you got it easy.

: Well as me and my three friends pull up at about 12:30 we are  greeted by
a
: popo hangin at the door. it was then that i got the feeling that this
wasnt
: going to be one of the most memorable nights. as we walk up to the
entrance
: we are stopped by some oversized rent a cops where we are then patted
down
: and I had my bag searched. Then as we walk up to buy our tickets, we find
out
: that its $25!! if we hadnt driven 40 mins to get there, we would have
turned
: around and gone home. anyways we walk in and see a bunch of OG's posted
up at
: the entrance staring at us like were some kind of freaks. werent many
people
: dancing, just a lot of standing.  the lights and visuals were the most
: positive part of the party, the fx were amazing. i cant say as much about
the
: music though. there were a few good sets, but most werent worth dancing
to.
: inside it was like 100 degreez and after paying $25 to get in, you'd
expect
: to atleast get free water, but we didnt. it was 2$ a bottle. after going
: through my pockets in the morning, i realized i spent $50 last night!!!!
25
: on the ticket, 5 on water, and 20 on other necessities.
: overall, was it worth the 25 dollar cover? hell no
: -blake

hello everybody-
	just wanted to take a minute to let everybody know about our bus
trip/themecamp to/at burningman this year.  SO REAL is organizing a bus trip
to burningman this year. if at all possible, please consider this option. the
less cars that are out there, the less impact we'll have there will be on the
environment. it'll also be a fun ride and we'll all be able to meet new faces
and friends.  if you don't take the bus, please try to carpool.
	SO REAL will also be putting together a themecamp this year. the theme is a
21st century cafe.  we'll be playing the best of all styles of electronic
music while in a cafe setting (along with all the lights and decorations that
make for a gnarly night of techno!). for dj listing check out the sfraves
calendar.
	for more info. check out the SO REAL web site:
	www.ecst.csuchico.edu/~ben/burn/index.html
hope to here from you all, Peace Love Unity n RESPECT

						stillwind

Message-ID: <19970721151906.10714.rocketmail@send2.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [204.94.209.1] by web1; Mon, 21 Jul 1997 08:19:06 PDT
Date: Mon, 21 Jul 1997 08:19:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: Alex Ward <djscience@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Re: Economics of record buying
To: Eric Ryan Spire <soundz@cats.ucsc.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk






---Eric Ryan Spire <soundz@cats.ucsc.edu> wrote:
>
> In response to your notion that records are to expensive, one might
want 
> to take into consideration a couple of issues.
> 
> 1) In order to keep inventory as current as you buyers expect, we
have to 
> have records shipped to us fed-ex, or 2nd day UPS. When this is
happening 
> from the east coast, that can add as much as $1.00 to the price of a
record.
> Depending on the exchange rate between the dollar and the different 
> European currencies, this makes import vinyl as much as $8.00 before
it 
> even goes to the shelf.

The dollar is the stongest it has been in years!! I remember when
imports went up from $8 to $9 to $10...the record stores all told me
it was the weak dollar. Is anyone interested in passing the SAVINGS to
the customer now that this trend is reversing? Hell no.


Now I know that for the most part, the record price thing is an
institutional problem...more on the shoulders of Watts and Nemisis
than anyone else. However, the fact still remains that there are
record stores in the city which sell their stock for a full dollar
less than anyone else. How do they do it?? 

They have listening stations...how do they do it??

My impression is that they're more commited to the true vinyl junkie.
Pure and simple. Along the way, their low prices also pull in more
business. 

Anyways, record stores need to start talking to their disributors,
asking them what's up. It is nothing less than extortion charging so
much for 2 SONGS. Like myself, at least 90% of dj's out there are
home-bound and are buying plates out of the love for the music. They
will rarely or never play out, if they do, they probably won't get
paid, and if they do, they consider themselves the luckiest people in
the world...getting paid for playing records...what a silly idea:)

This isn't a back-ally addiction, this is a passion and art and it
saddens me to see is expoited in such a fashion.

-tired of the runaround-

SCiEnCe 
_____________________________________________________________________

into my life, and i love them all. a few of them have already been

at feel
good experience (which incidently happened on my last night in cali...). we
talked
for a really long time, and at the end of the night when i was starting to
realize
that i wasn't going to see a lot of people for a very, very long time...i
was so so
sad, but dustin brightened up my morning by giving my his badass
kaleidoscope straight
from his own keyring. i carry that with me every day, and when the longing
gets too
intense...i break out the 'scope and dream about the parties and people
over in cali.
lots of huggies to you dustin. and best wishes to both amanda and dustin,
you guys
are truly beautiful!
