Received: from munch.gene.com (munch.gene.com [128.137.49.5]) by genie.gene.com (8.8.5/8.7.3) with ESMTP id JAA08184 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Mon, 21 Jul 1997 09:39:25 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from goumada@localhost) by munch.gene.com (8.8.5/8.7.3) id JAA06544 for sfraves@hyperreal.org; Mon, 21 Jul 1997 09:39:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Beth Jackson" <goumada@gene.COM>
Message-Id: <9707210939.ZM6793@munch.gene.com>
Date: Mon, 21 Jul 1997 09:39:23 -0700
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.1 10apr95)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Weekend in review
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Friday night started off totally cool with my getting a ride down to SC with
Pengo.  It totally sucks that Viberation got busted, but I did get to see some
friends and hang out in a parking lot in Santa Clara.  After this night I was
sure that I could navigate all the major freeways in the South Bay.


Saturday drove down to Monterey for the CF Three Year Anniversary party.  I
_loved_ this party.  The location was great - a big round sandy crater with
little torches around the perimeter of the party.  On one side was a really
steep dune that people were rolling down all night.  It was also cool to sit up
there and look down at all the happy people and have the ocean behind you.


The vibe was immense.  Those CF people are *tight*.  We were still going off at
10:30 in the morning and didn't want to leave!  Highlights:

Breakfast survey with dEEpfog
Putting stickers and a candy necklace on AndyW [Hey, anybody wanna make him
some fuzzy pants?  =)]
Sitting around the fire with WonderPaula under a towel
Big group hug/Scott Nelson sandwich
Rolling down the hill [Yeah, I did it too.  And I had sand everywhere.]
Jer showing up at 6am
Breakfast  [Can we get a table for 40, please?]

The music was awesome, I thought all the DJs had great sets.  Big thanks to
Forest who was throwing down when I arrived, James Christian, inTIMidator, Sho,
Stonie, Cloud and Swoops for rocking my world.  I danced so much that night -
especially after I discovered the piece of plywood!

Props to the CF family.  It was a night to remember.


Happy Monday, everyone.

Love,
b.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Mon Jul 21 09:42:38 1997

Date: Mon, 21 Jul 1997 09:41:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: Alex Ward <djscience@rocketmail.com>
Subject: friday night follies and CF 3-year.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Sorry to be blunt-

Friday night was a fucking disaster.

3 parties got busted. Cops and rangers were sweeping down the coast
form half-moon bay to santa cruz. They were working late shifts to
make the point that the beaches were now off limits. 

On behalf of the Viberation crew, I'm sorry if you were out there in
friday. Hundreds of unhappy ravers were roaming up and down the
30-mile stretch of coast hoping for a relocation of at least 1 of the
3 parties. We tried our best, but decided to call it quits at 4 am.

So, thank goodness for the cloud factory. My happy family of
dream-makers pulled it off again and we partied in style. 

We had SO many people to help set up. Everyone was smiling, many
dancing (some nekkid). I made it through a couple hours before I
passed out, sleep-deprived in a tent overlooking the gathering.

I think we went till 10:30 or so, and only stopped b/c we were so
hungry. 

I had a fabulous time, thanks guys:)

-SCiEnCe

_____________________________________________________________________

	  Mon, 21 Jul 1997 12:49:34 -0400 (EDT)

Message-ID: <970721124848_784906975@emout06.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: review-HIGH NOON
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

and so the story goes...

Well, those SRC boys set up on this rad little beach located on the
Sacramento River, which was nice since it was hot as hell out there. There
were also a lot of boaters who were parked on the beach for the day. Most of
these people were getting heavily intoxicated(all right, straight-up drunk)
which made some of them quite belligerent. The cool thing was, for every
group of them that threatened us if we didn't turn it down, another group
came up and threatened us if we didn't turn it UP. Who says house music isn't
universal? Well- we compromised and left the volume where it was at.
Everybody that came was having great time just chillin' on the beach, dancin'
in the sand, and gettin' some sun. About 6:30pm the cops came in response to
a noise complaint. They were pretty cool tho and explained to us that we
could continue, but if they got called again it would get serious. Well...we
persisted on w/ the lowered volume. Everything was goin' fine 'til about 8
o'clock. It was half an hour into my set when i smelled somethin' burnin'.
One of my flippin' monitors was on fire! Those were some hot-ass beats i
geuss. The surrounding people dealt with it immediately and we kept on
rockin'. The SRC guys decided to shut down at about 8:30 out of consideration
for the neighboring houses. This was en excellent idea since half way thru my
last record someone came running over to tell us that the cops were back.  We
shut down and high-tailed the equipment up a side-trail back to the cars
while the police were walking down the main path. The cops came down and told
us that they had another call. We said were done and would be out of there in
about 10 min. In return they gave us 2 min. to beat it. Adrenalin does
wonders for your ability to move, I'll tell ya. All in all, everyone there
had a great time and all the dj's were playin' some great sunday afternoon
grooves. Hats off to John , Raju, Chad, Scott, Mia and everyone else that
helped make this event happen .
	Well, another one down. Next one's in 2 weeks(we'll find a new space!). 

	love all, stillwind

From: "nathan.b.beckord" <nathan.b.beckord@ArthurAndersen.com>
Date: 21 Jul 97 10:08:05 
Subject: rvw:Boat Party (short)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Boat Party kicked ass!

Norm y Rhoda picked me up about 7, and we gots to the docks by 7:30.  It was 
sold out, but we hung around looong enough, and after the ticket holders, VIP 
list, guest list, boat crew list, Presidential list, and several others were 
done, they let everyone else on (I don't think they had to turn anyone away).  
We missed the actual sunset as it was too cloudy.  However, the boat took a 
nice cruise out and under the GG Bridge.  It was packed, but not quite 
claustrophobic.  Fatty disco/funk tunes came from the second deck, which then 
gave way to housey hip hoppy stuff, then a live act.  The first floor pounded 
out techno beats without stop.  The trip was long--  did we go to Visalia and 
back?  j/k but there was a neat mix of funky folx on board which made it a good 
time.  Overall, a very very fun party.  Sunsets are my favourite parties, and 
since they've given so much for free, it always feels good supporting their 
for-pay events. Woo hoo!

Yep, the boat party rocked. John Howard played a great set, and Loran
(sp?) is a great up-and-coming DJ who plays jungle-I-can-dance-to and 
is quite entertaining to watch as well (he goes apeshit behind the
decks). This one was actually a few notches better than some of the
other boat parties I've been to, though most Sunset boat parties tend
to be great. Good vibe too. Not the smarmy exclusive kkkandy raver vibe
like you find at supposedly "cool" UG events -- the Sunset vibe
welcomes all, irrrespective of age, fashion statements (or lack
thereof), color, sex, orientation, ugly, pretty, normal, wierd,
tweaked, tripping, sober, drunk, or whatever. 

Sunset is definitely up there w/ other SF "must see" events (Stompy,
Wicked, Funky Tekno Tribe)...

PS: I picked up a flyer for the next Stompy @ VSF -- Sun Aug 3 "Noon
til then" (which usually ends up being 9 or 10 PM). DJ's are Jonene,
Preston. Special guests are Johnny Fiasco (*), Tres Manos. Plus Kevin,
James, Gavan. Johnny Fiasco should be quite interesting -- Stompy
always seems to get a good big name outof town DJ. But who is "Tres
Manos" from Boulder Colorado??

=)

I was definitely glad to have been able to make it to this party. Yes, the
asking price was extremely steep ($25) but I do have to say that it payed
off. The "hard room" had some kewl jungle and the "soft room" busted out some
groovy house. The vibe in the soft room was incredible. There were so many
smiley people and everyone was moving. I was up dancing on one of the box
thingys so I was able to get a view of the entire place. I think the party
peaked @ around 3 when the vibe in the "soft room" was so thick and the
glowsticks were flailing everywhichwaywhere!!!!!!

I went with three of my greatest friends and we all had an amazing time. I
hope everyone else that went to the party did too. For those that didn't make
it, I hope you had an awesome time doing whatever you did on Saturday night.

Sm;)e baby, SM:)E DAMMIT!

            ~LaUrEa~

Holmann, Hutch wrote:
> 
>        LANGLEY, VA--After months of eager anticipation within
> the nation's ghetto communities, the Central Intelligence
> Agency unveiled its 1998 line of addictive drugs Monday.
> 
>       "The wait is over," CIA Director John Deutch said at the
> festive drug launch, simulcast on giant-screen TVs throughout
> Watts, Cabrini Green, Newark, and other urban areas.
> "Inner-city Americans now have four exciting new ways to
> narcotize themselves, with the quality of product and wide
> distribution they've come to expect from the CIA."
> 
>       Reaction to the new drugs (see sidebar) was
> overwhelmingly positive. "They had a tough act to follow after
> crack," said New York-area Mafia boss Alfonse DiBiasi,
> Deutch's close friend and former college roommate. "But this
> new stuff is just as cheap and every bit as addictive. We're all
> very excited."
> 
>       President Clinton praised the CIA as well. "This is a win-win
> situation for all Americans," he said. "Inner-city Americans will
> receive the powerful drugs they love, and the CIA will raise the
> funds they can't get from Congress to get their Jonestown
> mind-control experiment up and running again."
> 
>       The new drugs are supported by months of CIA testing to
> ensure maximum potency and addictiveness. Focus groups,
> consisting primarily of homeless men and street orphans culled
> from ghettos around the country, were housed in an
> underground research facility beneath CIA headquarters in
> Langley, VA. Only after six months of exhaustive
> experimentation on members of this target demograph, who
> sampled hundreds of drugs, were the final decisions made.
> 
>       "Everybody loves me because I am so beautiful. Anything is
> possible. I am going to live a very long and happy life," said
> Oakland, CA, native Charles Simmons, who spent 10 weeks
> testing Blue Glass, the CIA's new smokable euphoric drug.
> Simmons then leapt out a window to his death.
> 
>       "I they I drugs these are very feel good right," said Dwayne
> Woodson of Bronx, NY, another CIA test participant. "Pork
> chops three for $2.99."
> 
>         CIA officials said that testing is necessary
>    in order to avoid releasing potentially
>  dangerous substances into the ghettos. "One
>  initially promising drug was later discontinued
> due to undesirable side effects, such as increased intelligence and feelings
> of love for
> others," said Dr. Harold Vandermeer, head of the CIA's narcotics development
> team.
> 
>       Initial product rollout began this week in the ghetto neighborhoods of
> Los Angeles,
>   Detroit and New Orleans, with all residents receiving a special
> drug-sampler pack in the mail,
>  including a full-color, English-Spanish promotional pamphlet and
> instructional videotape. If
> the market response is as favorable as the CIA expects, the drugs should be
> available in
>  every ghetto in the nation as soon as August 1.
> 
>   "I thought I'd never say this," Deutch said, "but put down that crack
> pipe,
> ghetto-dwellers: You're going to love these new drugs."
>     Deutch went on to state that none of the above events "ever happened"
> and
> categorically denied any CIA connection with the new drugs.

You forgot one Minor Detail,

You have to have a minimum $2,000 order from most Dist. at least that
is what I heard. In addition to that I doubt they will sell to a
person that is only buying 10-20 rekkids a week it is not worth there
time or yours. it is not worth the hassle of going through that.
Unless you have plenty of $$ and dont have a job it is worth it. Also
I have talked to the local rekkid store that I pay rent on since I am
a valued customer and the profit margin is not that high and you have
to put up with a lot of shit.

But then again I could be wrong that is just (IMO) -Dennis Miller

Macadio




---Stillwind5@aol.com wrote:
>
> hello to all my fellow $BROKE$ d.j.'s out there,
> 
> i have a suggestion that y'all might be interested in.  get a
business
> licence for your dj services. the cost of the licence is only 50-75
> dollars(depending where you are). with this you can:
> 
> 1. order direct thru distributers(nemisis,intergroove, watts, etc.)
> 	a. this means you can pick up new wax for 3-6 bucks!
> 	b. contact the distributers(the #'s are usually on the bottom of the
> sleeves) 		   and ask them to send you their faxes. if you have
trouble
> getting their #'s, e-	   mail me privately and i'll try to help you.
> 2. use expenses (money spent on records, gas getting to parties,
phone calls
> to        	promoters,etc.) as tax write off's. the federales give
you 1 or 2
> years b-4 you 	are supposed to make a profit.
> 
> you'll have to pay taxes on any money you make, but payin' taxes on
a gig
> that you only got a couple bucks for is totally worth the money
you'll save.
> 
> well, take it easy and happy spinnin',
> 			stillwind 
>

Date: Mon, 21 Jul 1997 13:40:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>
Message-Id: <199707212040.NAA19909@klaatu.autodesk.com>
To: Vibepool@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: Did anything happen last night?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

> Why are all the cool outdoor places being found out by those who don't want
> us to dance?

	Ok, as one of the people involved in one of the parties that
got busted Friday nite, here's my take on the situation ...

	There've been too many parties in the same few locations on
the beaches of southern San Mateo county. The local residents are 
pissed. They pass the heat on to the cops, the cops pass it on to us.
What comes around, goes around. It isn't about massive promoters calling
the heat on us, it's about good party spots getting over used & burned
out.

	Of course, our little party (the one in that dusty grove, not
on the beach) probably wouldn't have been found if a bunch of people
from the busted beach parties hadn't decided to caravan over there
en masse, thereby leading the cops who busted the beach party right
to us. It would help if ravers would use their brains every so often
in these situations, but maybe that's too much to ask.

	Time to spread it around & find some new outdoor spots, people.

	Rob

To: macadio <macadio6@rocketmail.com>, sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

You're right, distributors will require some sort of considerable volume (at 
least to get a worth while price).  But, you over looked to important 
points: one pro- one con:

1) You wouldn't have the hassles and costs of a store (rent, theft, 
security, replenishing stock, displays etc) if you were indep. or working as 
a small co-op.  big +
2) if DJs worked as a buying co-op you would need a re-sellers licences to 
buy from the distributor (especially if you want to look like a business). 
 This isn't difficult but a lot of resposibilty for the person with their 
name on the paperwork! The CA state board of equalization can be very nasty 
 ;-(  to whomever they think owes them money.  trust me on this one.  big -

Thomas
 ----------
From: macadio
To: Stillwind5; sfraves
Subject: Re: Economics.....(new thread?)
Date: Monday, July 21, 1997 3:56PM


You forgot one Minor Detail,

You have to have a minimum $2,000 order from most Dist. at least that
is what I heard. In addition to that I doubt they will sell to a
person that is only buying 10-20 rekkids a week it is not worth there
time or yours. it is not worth the hassle of going through that.
Unless you have plenty of $$ and dont have a job it is worth it. Also
I have talked to the local rekkid store that I pay rent on since I am
a valued customer and the profit margin is not that high and you have
to put up with a lot of shit.

But then again I could be wrong that is just (IMO) -Dennis Miller

Macadio




 ---Stillwind5@aol.com wrote:
>
> hello to all my fellow $BROKE$ d.j.'s out there,
>
> i have a suggestion that y'all might be interested in.  get a
business
> licence for your dj services. the cost of the licence is only 50-75
> dollars(depending where you are). with this you can:
>
> 1. order direct thru distributers(nemisis,intergroove, watts, etc.)
>    a. this means you can pick up new wax for 3-6 bucks!
>    b. contact the distributers(the #'s are usually on the bottom of the
> sleeves)             and ask them to send you their faxes. if you have
trouble
> getting their #'s, e-     mail me privately and i'll try to help you.
> 2. use expenses (money spent on records, gas getting to parties,
phone calls
> to           promoters,etc.) as tax write off's. the federales give
you 1 or 2
> years b-4 you     are supposed to make a profit.
>
> you'll have to pay taxes on any money you make, but payin' taxes on
a gig
> that you only got a couple bucks for is totally worth the money
you'll save.
>
> well, take it easy and happy spinnin',
>              stillwind
>

Tony Giovannini wrote:
> 
> Don't
> 
> I've learned that people will only help themselves when they want to.
> 
> sad but true.

I agree. If, for example, a person abuses drugs because of self-esteem
problems (which is often the case) you can be supportive of them as a
friend to help them feel better about themselves. Only then will a
person care about themselves enough to make the choice to end it. But
telling someone directly about their problem will only push them away.

Subject: about friday night...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org

On behalf of myself and the crew I'd like to extend a big apology for those
who tried to make it out to viberation friday night.

While the whole evening was truly discouraging for a lot of people, we are
trying our best to take it as a learning experience. It's easy to point
fingers and make assumptions, I believe it's more a matter of striving
harder to find the delicate balance our gatherings have in this world.

It is likely that we will be taking our parties below the SFR list. If you
would like to be informed about our future plans, please respond to this
message with your email or snail mail addy (or both) and we'll be sure to
let you know.

Thanks again for your support, and be sure to look out for the BBQ and
Beats campout - August 8th to 11th plus Harmony, Pacific, Mad, and CFC
coming together for a very special event the following weekend.

much love and energy.

Terry

--------------------------------------------*viberation*-------
 http://www.cyborganic.com/people/lachim/viberation

Subject: DJ CD's for SFRavers

A DJ at one of the hottest dance clubs told me that alot of DJ's subscribe to
a service called Promo Only. I just subscribed to their Import Series (they
also
have a Club Series). They send you (and all the other DJ's) compilations of
promo CD's that are sent to the DJ's by the record companies. Their web site
is www.promoonly.com. Very kewl stuff.

I also purchased the three CD set from interhit records. All great dance mix
cd's. Their web site is www.interhit.com. A subscription to their DMA
Magazine gets you two free CD's. One from Club Bash in Miami is awesome. The
other is a rap crap jungle thing that sucks.

Last but not least for all you wannabe DJ's. Bought two Import series CD's
from REMIX Central (websire www.remix-central.com). Great techno dance stuff.

Venture forth and Dance

From: Adam Mednick <sfrave@rocketmail.com>
Subject: ukscene vs sf scene
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Cc: uk-dance@uk-dance.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/html; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

first of all, please respond to my posts personally as well as on the lists, because i'm not subscribed to sfr while i'm abroad to control the volume of messages while i'm paying 5 pounds an hour at internet cafes.

SF vs UK.......

I've been in the uk for close to a week now.  Where is the underground that everyone is talking about?  I was at the blue note last week, and I spent two nights this week at club 414.  The music was phenminal, but the vibe was.... missing.  Now don't get me wrong.  I've met loads of nice people here, and at clubs as well.  But It's nothing like back home.  In SF, the rave scene and the club scene is two different worlds.  Different music, different people, differnt cup of tea.  The "Undergound" of sf is a tight knit community of people working together for what we call PLUR.  This is something that the uk has seemed to have forgotten about.  For the UK people, plur stands for Peace, Love, Unity and Respect.  It is a motto that we try to live by.  When you go to an undergound event in SF, you are always surrounded by smiles.  You are always welcome. You are accepted.  You always see people that you know, but you also always meet new wonderful faces.  Here, It seems that Unity is a bit iffy.  Love is only for those w/ girlfriends and boyfriends, and Respect?  I have recieved it only from some.

I have a theory.  Electronic music, dancing, etc. is mainstreem here in London.  Everyone and their uncle listens to house, drum & bass, etc.  They play it in their cars, barber shops, pubs...everywhere.  

Is this the direction the SF scene is heading too?  Is it inevitable?  The dilution of our precious scene?  

I'm sure the underground is here too, but where?  If anyone knows, please drop me a line.

I'm having a fantastic time here in Brittain, i'm meeting lots of nice people, (and staying w/ them) and I love it here.  But (and please exceuse the velveeta) my heart is in San Francisco.  Always.

I love my scene.  I love my music.  I love my community.  

PLUR!  everybody.  please never forget.

--adam--

Hi all!

We got in to Magic Wednesdays during the end of Simply Jeffs set and the
place was pretty packed and the breakbeats were rockin the joint. I guess
Jeff has a new mix CD on City of Angels that just came out and was having
his release party.

Astral Matrix then came on at 12:30 and played a great live minimal housey
set that lasted about 1Hr and was perfectly beatmatched the whole time.
Very  kewl trackky type of stuff. It was great to see the 40-50 people up
on stage with Astral Matrix with nothing but smiles and giving off positive
vibes!!

For those that would like to check out photos of Astral Matrix last night
at Magic Wednesdays, Happy Kat took some nice shots that are now up at:

http://www.fuzzylogik.com

Subject: (bsp) HELP at Wish
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org (SFraves)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain; charset=us-ascii

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Hello everyone,

We are having a problem at Wish.  You see, we are an 18 and over club in San 
Francisco, and our problem is that we _must_ check ID's at the front door. 
 We have recently moved to a much bigger and nicer location than our old 
space at Bahia, (Wish is now at 836 Mission St., btwn 4th & 5th St) and the 
owners/managers at the new space are very strict with checking every single 
ID that comes in the door.

Last week alone, we had to turn away almost 30 people for not having a valid 
ID with them.  I know for a fact that many of these people were over 21, and 
left their drivers license at home!  This just doesn't make any sense to me. 


Please understand, that if it were up to the promoters of Wish, we would 
allow for all ages to be welcome at our weekly.  However, we still have to 
play by the same rules everyone else does, and therefore cannot do throw an 
all ages weekly.

Not only that, but we honestly _need_ every bit of your support to continue 
throwing Wish, every week.  We are currently in our 64th consecutive week, 
and we rely heavily on the advertising of word of mouth through the 
community to promote our club, rather than sending out flyers to every party 
and record store in the bay area.  We believe that this helps keep the Wish 
crowd energetic and fun, and so far we have had good luck with that.  So, 
please please, come out to Wish and see what's happening...

Thanks very much for your time!  See you at WISH!!!

:-)  :-)  :-)  :-)  :-)  :-)  :-)  :-)  :-)  :-)  :-)  :-)

Kenneth Sol
(Promoter-Wish)

DRUG USE does NOT equal DRUG ABUSE...... but there comes a time
when you have to STOP. maybe if its just to take a break. when you
start doing drugs to get F@cked up on purpose everysingle day and
your excuse "its cause its the summer" that I don't consider good
thinking. DRUGS are very delicate things that need to be handled with
care. You you are unlucky, you won't notice the changes yourself, but
those around you will.

I'm not talking nescesarily about "Physical"harm...think about what
all this drugs are doing to your mind every single weekend... 

I personaly chose to STOP. mainly cause it wasn't the same anymore.
it was all a waste. too much $$$, coming home every weekend f@cked up on
something, huge black bags under my eyes, loss weight, corrupted
sleep/wake patterns, depression. It feels soooooo much better to me
to come home clean and sober rather than f@cked up on something  all
wasted out from the night before :) :)

I also stop'd cause it was starting to become a vicious trap, to me
at least. I must agree, drugs changed me in very good ways and I'm
grateful that
I was able to experience that :) I was able to see myself from the
outside and
worked on changing the things I did not like... they made me a better
person inside as well
as the outside ;)

I do have to say, even tho it might hurt, you can't change someone into
not doing drugs. You just gotta suffer through it and let them suffer
the consequences eventually. I'm going through it...and it hurts.

its hard to see how your friends waste away, in the vicious cycle.
its not cool to see your friends on drugs everyday...or almost everyday.

Not trying to start a flame war :)
just my dollar fifty ;).....

[*hugs*]
Pablito

As far as I know, most distibutors don't mind small orders, but the
additional shipping costs will negate the discount unless you make a
substantial order.  You can order lots of great Detroit stuff direct from
Submerge (www.submerge.com).  In general, though, I've been disappointed by
orders I've made directly from distributors because I haven't been able to
hear the tracks first.  Even with labels and artists that I buy every
release from and *know* I like, I inevitably end up with the stinkers when
I order direct.  So I've decided that the small markup of the record store
is worth it for the ability to listen first.  Plus, most stores struggle to
survive as it is, so I think it's good to support them.

-Seth

At 05:14 PM 7/21/97 -0700, you wrote:
>
>You're right, distributors will require some sort of considerable volume (at 
>least to get a worth while price).  But, you over looked to important 
>points: one pro- one con:
>
>1) You wouldn't have the hassles and costs of a store (rent, theft, 
>security, replenishing stock, displays etc) if you were indep. or working as 
>a small co-op.  big +
>2) if DJs worked as a buying co-op you would need a re-sellers licences to 
>buy from the distributor (especially if you want to look like a business). 
> This isn't difficult but a lot of resposibilty for the person with their 
>name on the paperwork! The CA state board of equalization can be very nasty 
> ;-(  to whomever they think owes them money.  trust me on this one.  big -
>
>Thomas
> ----------
>From: macadio
>To: Stillwind5; sfraves
>Subject: Re: Economics.....(new thread?)
>Date: Monday, July 21, 1997 3:56PM
>
>
>You forgot one Minor Detail,
>
>You have to have a minimum $2,000 order from most Dist. at least that
>is what I heard. In addition to that I doubt they will sell to a
>person that is only buying 10-20 rekkids a week it is not worth there
>time or yours. it is not worth the hassle of going through that.
>Unless you have plenty of $$ and dont have a job it is worth it. Also
>I have talked to the local rekkid store that I pay rent on since I am
>a valued customer and the profit margin is not that high and you have
>to put up with a lot of shit.
>
>But then again I could be wrong that is just (IMO) -Dennis Miller

>Macadio

Keep it surreal.

To be able to think like a child, the essence of my goal.  To see what is
THERE instead of what I expect.  To hear people's words individually, and
then not take unmeant meaning from them.

To delve into the mysteries of the tailside of a penny.

To run a lot, and drink water messily, and then run some more.  Fall down,
GO BOOM.  Get up, and CHARGE CHARGE CHARGE.  To sing three words to myself
for an hour.

Babbling.  Band-aids are for wimps.  Rubbing salt in cuts.  Kicking rocks.
Chasing cattle.  Jumping off things.  Making hoooo-hoooooo noises.

But NOW......

It's different.  The more we learn the less we CAN learn.

So then we eat a grip of mushrooms.

'Let's pretend we're pregnant cats!  I'm a black one!  (run)  You've got
bad luck, BAD LUCKY BUTT!'

THE END.

Yours truly, 
Max McCauley
Grade 5

From: "lara at vibe.org" <lara@vibe.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: the most loving person...
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.970722001808.4918D-100000@linux.announce.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

you mean i only get to pick one?
i sat here trying to think of the most loving person in the world and i 
started to cry.
I couldn't pick just one. I love so many people.. I realized.. There are 
SO MANY BEAUTIFUL LOVING CARING PEOPLE in this scene, AND in the world. 
Sure, there's alot of negative shit, which I've been down about lately, 
but yanno, there is alot of GOOD out there. 
	Amanda, she has done for me what no one has ever done for me in 
their lives. She's gone out of her way for me, only my mothers have done 
that for me (yes, i have 2). When I am feeling down, she not only talks 
to me and reassures me, she tells our friends to cheer me up as well, 
which is a sweet thing. She goes out of her way to make me smile, and I 
love her for that. I love her for her consideration, warmth, loving, and 
beauty that shines from within. When I feel that I'm alone in the world I 
just have to think of Amanda and I know that I'm FAR from alone.
	All of you are beautiful loving and caring people, I wish I could 
name you all but in fear of leaving people out or embarrassing others, I 
just leave it at that. And I have to say that my birth mother, and 
adoptive mother have played incredibly positive and loving roles in my 
life, I owe the both of them more than my life.
	There are a couple of you that stand out in my heart, you know 
who you are. I talk to you every day. You tolerate my bitching, my lack 
of sanity, and my obsession with jungle. I love you guys for being there.
	SO THERE I DID MY MUSHY SHIT.
NOW CAN I SAY *BIG UPS TO THE TRUE JUNGLISTS?!??!* :)~
(what a tacky way to end this thread)
lara
(rennigade junnlist onna loose)

of sanity, and my obsession with jungle. I love you guys for being there.

Mayan Prophecy foretells a thinning veil,
Beginning this month.


>From the Celestine Journal, by Ann Buzenberg.

Ancient prophecies interest many of our celestine Journal readers, so
this
month an event foretold by the ancient Mayans of Mexico may fascinate you
as it did me.

On New Year's Day of the Mayan Calendar, which falls on July 26th, 1997.
It
is said that a thinning of the veils will occur between our Material
third
dimension and the fourth dimension- the afterlife dimension explored in
The
Tenth Insight.
The Mayan calendar calls July 26th 1997, Kan HO (yellow overtone seed
day).
 Prophecy says on this day, access to the fourth dimension is opened to
humans. To celebrate this opening, Mayan calendar followers plan a
celebration in Mexico City, in Japan and locations worldwide.
To learn more, we spoke with Bonita Luz, an American transpersonal
psychotherapist who has studied traveled and worked in Central and South
America.
"I've been interested for years in the ancient indigenous prophecies"
Bonita says, "especially those of the Inca, Maya, Hopi and Cherokee,
because they say similar things about these times we now live in. My
inner
knowingness always whispered, 'Pay attention-these prophecies carry the
message of hope for our times."
Bonita has studied with Mayan elder Hunbatz Men, author of Mayan Science
and Religion
She is excited about this Yellow Overtone Seed Day.
"On this day, the prophecies of Pacal Votan indicate that a gate of time
will open, causing a mind shift to occur.
Mind shift, for me, means a conscious shift of dimensions, taking us from
third dimension reality   the mechanistic, material world, with all it's
ego-based drama, fear and illusion   to a higher dimension of
consciousness. This is the dimension where we raise our energies up to
live
in a place of LOVE, HARMONY, PEACE and BALANCE =  a consciousness of our
higher self that is free of the web of third dimension illusions. We can
then, for the first time, become truly effective in this world   We can
be
in this world, but not of it.
"According to the ancient Mayan calendar and also modern science, we're
near the end of a 26,000 year cycle, in what the ancients called the
Shift
of the Ages, a time of great change," says Bonita. "The day-long global
peace meditation known as the Harmonic Convergence, August 16-17, 1987,
began an intense 26 year transition period which ends in the year 2012
and
closes the 26,000 year cycle. In this cycle, we begin stepping into what
the Mayan call the New Itza Age  an age of Light and Wisdom in fourth
dimensional consciousness. AS FORETOLD, THIS TRANSITION PERIOD IS A TIME
OF
PURIFICATION AND INTENSIFYING ENERGY FREQUENCIES. It is a time for us to
WAKE UP to REMEMBER WHO WE REALLY ARE and begin to INTERGRATE with our
Light Bodies, and REATIVATE our natural telepathic abilities. Wisdom and
focus is needed through this evolutionary transformation. By 2013, we
reach
a new reign of enlightenment, living a new dream".
Synchronistic modern scientific discoveries which correspond to these
prophecies seem to come Bonita's way. At Ft. Lauderdale,FL, planetarium,
she heard astronomers verify that we are ending a 26,000 year cycle they
call the Wobble Effect  Earth's elliptical rotation around the central
su=
n
of our galaxy.
Then the April 29,1997, New York Times' front page featured an article
about astro-physicists discovering a fountain of invisible, high
frequency
energy rays spraying out from the center of our galaxy. Scientists
measure
them as gamma rays  light particles or photons produced by colliding
electrons and anti-electrons. "For me, this is physical evidence of the
Galactic Light Beam, which the Mayan prophecies predict our Earth is
going
through at this time," Bonita says.
Scientists point out that if this spray of energy ever reaches Earth, it
will cause no harm, Bonita believes, however, that these light particles
do
affect us directly, and that many of us now are feeling these intensified
energies in our physical bodies. "The energies of the cosmos are aiding
us
in that mind shift for which we have longed," she says.
"One of the key things I learned studying with the Shamans," says Bonita,
whose graduate studies ten years ago took her deep into Peruvian Jungles,
"was the importance of our intention and our willingness to invite the
spirits to communicate with us. Now the energies are with us for a mind
shift  both the increasing light energy from the Galactic center and the
energy of Yellow Overtone Seed, which opens the inter-dimensional
doorway.
When we synchronize our intention and willingness with these energies,
amazing results are possible. When we gather as a group and set a
collective intention, even more amazing things are possible.
Bonita plans to lead a spiritual journey to Mexico on July 24-August 7,
in
order to do just that. August 6 is another auspicious day known as Blue
Electric Eagle Day. The last time this day fell on August 6 was in 1945,
when Hiroshima was bombed. Another Blue Electric Eagle Day was August 16,
1987, when the Harmonic Convergence was held worldwide. "It is important
to
bring the peaceful Harmonic Convergence energy into this August 6 to
clear
the energy of Hiroshima," Bonita believes.
 or the Maya, science and spiritual cosmology were inseparable. Their
highly precise calendars chart the past and predict the future, using
cycles within Galactic cycles and synchronization's with planets and star
systems  especially the Pleiades. Bonita believes that we can learn from
these cycles and calendars.
"Palenque is a beautiful, most sacred center where the veils between
worlds
is thin. Much of our work, individually and collectively, will be here,"
Bonita says of the group journey.
Mayan prophecies foretold of this time when we would return to the sacred
sites to retrieve the secret knowledge encoded in the stones, glyphs and
pyramids to reawaken the memories and powers that have been dormant in us
for so long
"NOW IS THE TIME"

Hey. I am in summer school this summer. SUX!! And we are studying
religions now and we had to do a report on a religion of our choice. So
I thought about it and i put down Technoshamanism as the religion i
would research.

The teach said that wasn't a religion, and I told him he was nuts
because It was a branch of Shamanism. He said Okay fine and he told me
that if it was a religion that I had to do a 5 page report. 

So yesterday i tuned in a 5 page report on raves. And believe it or not
I looked up Technoshamanism and it really is a religion. Look it up on
Hyperreal.

No matter what your birth religion is, raves are a religious ceremony.
Some people may think that its just caca BS but think about it.

What's our place of worship? A rave.
What's are our commandments? PLUR
What is the point to our religion? To enlighten ourselves and our hearts
through dancing to the rhythms of life.

What we are doing truly is a religious ceremony. This made me realize
that raves aren't just something we do for fun. They are a way of life.

Something to think about

Luv,

Subject: Re: Economics.....(new thread?)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I
I use to have a small business selling tapes and cds at the swap meet. I had
a seller's permit which was really easy to obtain.....the only thing you have
to have is a name for your business. I went through a local distributor,
which did require a large initial order of over $1500.....but....after that
initial order the required minimum amount was only $100. They also took
returns......95% on tapes and cd's....80% for vinyl...which would go towards
your next order. That was in 1989.
As for the State Board of Equalization......they send you something at the
end of the year to figure out the sales tax you owe the state. I added up all
of my purchases, added about $50 to make it look like i was trying to make a
profit, times it by the tax amount at that time......then wrote the check.
That is the part where it can get tricky. If you were to start this now,
July, I am sure there will be people who aren't going to be around at the end
of the year when it is time to pay taxes. Then like stated in an earlier
reply, whoevers name is on the sellers permit can end up getting stuck with
alot of shit.
Whoever decides to start this is going to have to do alot more than they
think. It will be a business whether you like it or not. The same person will
have to do the ordering, have to get the money from all of the people ahead
of time, which will include taxes, have to return any money left over due to
out of stocks on orders, you will have to divide the shipping costs between
all of the people placing an order, and you will have to distribute the fax
from the distributor to everyone so they can see what they want to order. Oh,
and what about the records they send to you because the ones you ordered
weren't in stock?? Who gets the promo's?? How do you know if you are going to
like a record, if all you know about it is what the distributor wrote on the
fax.....usually about three lines.....and always positive....cuz they want
them to sell. 
If your lucky the distributor you go through might have a web page, with
soundbites, that you could order from.......and that would change everything.

sorry for the ramble.......by the way, this was my first post to SFR.....I
recently moved up here from Southern California (Laguna Niguel, South Orange
County)
Hello :)

Brian
aka dj smile

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Deepfog wrote: 
>drugs are wRONG!!!  =[


Wrong?

I don't think so.

I think they are and intergral and important part of our community. 
I think the rave community was built on friendship, music and drugs.
Destructive and problematic sometimes - sure.
But partying sober and partying _not_ sober are two totally different 
experiences. 
Parties that really GO OFF do so because of many people in altered 
states.


Joel

In any case whether substances are a part of a persons good time or not to
each his own.  I don't feel any of us have the right to preach what we
should or shouldn't do at events or with each others lives in general.  The
only concern I have is substance abuse and individuals that are not aware
or educated in twisting their bodies chemistry.

I'm not sure I 100% agree with the "events that go off are the ones with
altered states".  Sure they have a thick vibe and they are a blast, but
I've been to plenty of events that have gone off and most people are sober
and are enjoying it just as much as being altered.  Its really up to the
people and promoters and the vibe they bring.  The substances are just a
surface escape.  It goes deeper than that for most people I know.  But I
won't get into that.

Lets just kick back and enjoy our selves.  I feel we are over analyzing and
feelings start to get ruffled...

Good day!


Siphon

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: drugs drugs drugs.
References: <3.0.3.32.19970722110337.00a75e40@domain.net>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

the problem with drugs is not the use of them, but the abuse of them. 

people may try to brainwash you into thinking that all using is abusing,
but it's not true. the trouble occurs when one becomes consumed by the
usage. it's that point when you can only perceive having fun when
altered. it's as though you personally can't have fun anymore and you
have to call up your unsober self to do it for you. when all you can
think about is how and when you are going to be able to have *fun* again
is when you should realize that you are drowning. 

					-liz

on 07/22/97 10:25 AM liz wrote...

>the problem with drugs is not the use of them, but the abuse of them. 
>
>people may try to brainwash you into thinking that all using is abusing,
>but it's not true. the trouble occurs when one becomes consumed by the
>usage. it's that point when you can only perceive having fun when
>altered.

And abuse is generally classified as usage in a manner that a doctor 
would not approve of, right?  Of course, those who abuse drugs like to 
alter this definition so it doesn't include them.  A person who does E 
once a month might define abuse as doing E once a week.  Or someone who 
does E once a week might define abuse as doing something that is 
physically addictive.   etc etc etc.

Subject: Purchasing Turntables this weekend - Need Advice

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org

Hi SFraves,

After some failed attempts to hook up with a few people over the net
on the purchase of some turntables, I have decided to just drive up to
Berkeley or SF this weekend to buy them NEW.

I want to buy turntables for two primary reasons - I want to make mix
tapes of all sorts of music (drum&bass, post-rock/mathrock, guitar
ambient/drone) for myself and my friends - and I need a record player
because I don't have one.

So can those of you out there well versed with the technicalities and
justifications of what to buy and what to avoid please help out a
newbie?  I've been told by a number of DJs that Technics 1200's should
be the turntables I buy, and the mixers have been a jumble of names
that i can't remember.

Price really isn't an issue, since I've already conceded to buying
NEW, but if you know of a location that has good prices, I'll be ever
so grateful. 

thanks much, peace.

- DJ Newbie

This sounds really beautiful, but I am really worried that this is not what
Yosemite needs -- a bunch of ravers descending on a beautiful natural
place, taking a lot of drugs, trampeling the environment, and leaving trash
and cigarette butts everywhere in their path.

Am I a cynic or a realist? :-( I really hope for the best but I have been
one of the last persons at too many parties picking up HUGE piles of trash
left behind by thoughtless ravers, and it really saddened me.

Please add me to the mailing list, I promise I don't leave trash in my
wake, and I really love Yosemite.

     the stuff in redbull, it called 'taurin' (not caffine).in some 
     european countries (austria, netherlands) the have a red bull version 
     with more taurin. in germany we have a version with less taurin. a 
     actual cocktail is red bull with vodka.
     its true that you go really speedy with this stuff, but you can also 
     get very aggressive.
     When you need a stronger energy drink take 'flying horse' or 10 
     caffeine tabs (its cheaper, and is also legal).
     harry

Wayne, don't worry... there isn't going to be a bunch of ravers
descending upon Yosemite Valley...
(the entire group numbers about 20 people now)
And its not that much of a party... Saturday I'm leading beginning
climbing and rapelling "classes" for those who
Are interested.... and on Sat night we're heading outside the park to
BLM land where we are going to all camp 
together and play Some music... really low key though... and we're
bringing tons of trashbags and plan to be very respetful
Of the environment-Sunday there is a bunch of us heading to hike the
halfdome trail... so its really not
A party-more like a cool mellow camping trip with ravers from both
lists-a great chance to talk, share,
And grow in one of the most beautiful places on earth (besides the
Trocadero or the San Bernadino Sports Arena) (hee hee

Hey Adam, I just got back from spending close to 8 months livin in Fulham,
London.  There is definately a scene there.  The partys start down by club
606, that is down Fulham Road, ya know where Sid and Johnny formed the Sex
Pistols, a left on Broadway and down toward the Brittain Gas Co.  606 is a
pretty cool jazz bar, met many a raver there.  from there it is about a 5-10
minute walk to the Derby cafe, by the mini grand prix raceway.  try going on
a saturday nite at ~ 11pm you can not miss the lights thumps etc.

When in doubt goto The End, a nite when LTJ is spinning, ask for Slim, lanky
brit type.  he will hook you up.  

PS Manchester goes off.  Try Sankeys

liz wrote:
> 
> the problem with drugs is not the use of them, but the abuse of them.
> 
> people may try to brainwash you into thinking that all using is
> abusing,
> but it's not true. the trouble occurs when one becomes consumed by the
> usage. it's that point when you can only perceive having fun when
> altered. it's as though you personally can't have fun anymore and you
> have to call up your unsober self to do it for you. when all you can
> think about is how and when you are going to be able to have *fun*
> again
> is when you should realize that you are drowning.
> 
>                                         -liz
See my view on drugs is also dont abuse them. I don't really see them as
a drug if used properly. I know that a certain drug has helped me
realize things on a hihgly positive scale and have changed me into a
much much more open minded and positive loving person. If used as
self-medication drugs can work wonders. Abuse is a really problem!!
Luv,
Paul

Welllllll..... I must agree with Blake, $25 was toooo much to pay. This party
was nothing near the last one, but it had it's good points. I didn't care for
the music as much as I could have, and the chill room was anything but chill,
but the vibe was descent, once you got past the wardens at the door, and
after you got over the shock of hearing that it was $25. They should have
made that more clear. Besides all that, I had a great timE! Went to the
afterparty too, where they charged us $5 to get in, but since I had my
laminate, they gave us a good group rate. Oh well, all in all I had a good
time, and was glad to have gone and met all the smiles that I got to meet.
That's my report....

deepfog fwded:
>>It seems that they are trying to introduce to your typical listener who is
>>used to pearl jam "electronic music" that is, ummm, not necessarily bad, but
>>well, basic.  you know, the commercial stuff you can buy at best buy.
>>Chemical brothers and prodigy (which I thought sounded like your average
>>"alternative rock, devo wanna be, minus the guitars) FSOL, etc.

this cat refers to fsol as "basic"??!!

future sound of london may be well known, but they are well known not
because of catchy marketing schemes and catering to the mtv generation, but
because they create ground breaking, innovative, creative and beautiful
soundscapes that are quite deserving of the public eye.  i consider their
music anything BUT basic.  just because an artist is recognized by the
mainstream does not mean that their expression is "basic"....

on a similar note, just because something is underground and not well known
does not mean that it is good music.  like the mainstream scene, i hear
plenty of ug music that is pure rubbish.

fsol strives beyond every endeavor with each successive album they release.
if this person actually listened to the music he was making a judgment
about, he would know this quite well....

lifeforms as a piece of ambient experimentation is ahead of its time, and
set the stage for much in the ambient genre.

isdn is conceptually intriguing and pretty darn funky to boot.

accelerator as a dance album is extremely cohesive and better than many
techno artists could release on the whole.

dead cities as a concept album is absolutely brilliant.

let's *know* the music we are making sa generalization about before making
the generalization, please.

that is all.

love,
lola

>    Pengo> someone directly about their problem will only push them
>    Pengo> away.

>	I agree. They will see you as a busy-body holier-than-thou
>type and stop listening to you at all, nomatter how good a friend you
>might have been in the past... And that is assuming that they really
>do have a problem and that the original poster didn't just feel that
>someone doing drugs at a rave or wherever was a problem in itself
>which I don't think was ever answered...
>
>	Marisa


Hello everyone, its jsl's girlfriend, Megan, again.  This conversation has
disturbed me and I feel the need to respond.

While I agree that people will only stop abusing drugs when they,
themselves, are ready, I disagree that, as a friend, you can't have
influence on them.  Granted, you may be pushed away.  This is what drug
addicts do; sometimes they don't even need a reason.  But is that the real
issue?  As a true friend, your concern for the abusers opinion of you
should not override your concern for thier safety.  What is friendship,
anyway, if we can't talk to eachother about the hard stuff?

There are ways to communicate concern without coming off as pushy.  Focus
on the positive things you like about the person & why their drug abuse may
be threating those qualities.  No matter how much they resist hearing you,
don't let them get away with hurting themselves.  Speaking up will at least
let them know that someone notices what they are doing.  (Sometimes the
only reason for drug abuse is the pursuit of attention.)  A little nudge
from the outside can spawn a great recovery.

If you consider yourself a true friend, you owe it to your friend to try to
help them.  Your help may be refused but you've got to, at least, try.
They may push you away initially, but believe me, in the end, they will
remember the people who challenged their destructive behavior.  And they
will come back to thank you.  If they push you away and you never hear from
them again, their problem is probably bigger than you want to deal with,
anyway.  Do you really want a chonic drug abuser in your life?  Is that
friendship?  I don't think so.

And yes, I know all of this from experience.  I've been on both sides of
the equation.  And I remember the people who challenged me.  I didn't want
to hear what they were saying, but it needed to be said.  I am forever
grateful to them for helping me pull my head out of my ass.  I couldn't
have done it alone.

Thanks... that's all til the next time I poke my nose in.
Megan

"If I have seen farther than you,
it is by standing on the shoulders of giants" - Sir Isaac Newton

X-Juno-Line-Breaks: 0-7,11-23,25-34,39-40,44-48
From: drek1@juno.com (Derek J Fieldsoe)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

>future sound of london may be well known, but
>because they create ground breaking, innovative, creative and 
>beautiful
>soundscapes that are quite deserving of the public eye.  i consider 
>their
>music anything BUT basic.  just because an artist is recognized by the
>mainstream does not mean that their expression is "basic"....

AMEN!!!  I swear I have never been so fascinated with a music group
before.  These two guys have always been able to set the standard for
what techno is going to become.  There work is very groundbreaking and
also allows other techno groups to follow their ways.

>fsol strives beyond every endeavor with each successive album they 
>release.
>if this person actually listened to the music he was making a judgment
>about, he would know this quite well....

So very TRUE.

>lifeforms as a piece of ambient experimentation is ahead of its time, 
>and
>set the stage for much in the ambient genre.

Show me any FSOL album that isn't way ahead of its time in one way or
another.

>isdn is conceptually intriguing and pretty darn funky to boot.

Good music after the herb.

>accelerator as a dance album is extremely cohesive and better than 
>many
>techno artists could release on the whole.

Did you know that shit (accelerator) was released in '92?  Compare that
dance music to anything else around that time.  They sound so much like
what we listen to today proving that they set the standard for techno
today.  If it wasn't for groups like FSOL, techno would never evolve
nearly as fast as it has in the last 5 or 6 years.

It's groups like FSOL that make me love ambient so much.  I mean, my
little goal is to someday get a couple turntables along with a mixer. 
The only problem is that I don't know if I want to spin ambient or GOA
trance.  It's groups like FSOL that make me want to spin ambient.

Well, good bye everyone and ya'll have a good day.

dErEk

soundtrack to COOL WORLD... "papua new guinea". God I love that song. They
are so talented.

And to continue what Drek was saying... Oop!.. that's Derek.... I think
it's really cool how an artist can compell you to spin a certain kinda of
music. It's that connect you make with the music that makes you a DJ....
the love you feel for it, the way it touches your soul...

I wish you guys could have been inside me to feel the
joy/ecstacy/happiness/serenity I felt when I heard LTJ BUKEM spin live....
man... I can never get enough...... in fact I'm listening to it right now
at work... :) This CD is going to have grooves in it soon...

I hope you all have a really nice day.. and learn something knew about
yourself.... and perhaps understand yourself more....

---Byroni

Subject: $25 Trend what is going on??
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hey everybody,

I just wanted to voice my opinion on a little thing that is starting
to become popular and you all guessed it (Drum roll please) the $25
dollar party trend it seems that the last few big parties have been
asking for $25  and from what people have posted it seems like they
were not even worth $20 let alone $25 This is real distrubing to me
cause productions have gotten smaller and shitter and prices have
gotten higher. I remember back in the day when some promoters charged 
25 at least the party was worth it like FTT did some partys for that
price but they put a lot into there parties by having tribal dancers
good lights visuals lasers etc?? and at one FTT I remember they had a
30 Ft. Alien that spit out fire in the middle on the night and I just
said Damn this was worth my money. Now some promoters put a lot into
there parites and offer several arenas of dance music and bouncy
castles and ferris wheels and stuff like that so I understand them
charging a high price but for people that don't have all that just a
big wherehouse with minimal lights and stuff it upsets me. I dont want
to point any fingers or anything but it is just sad. Now I have helped
out with some big parties and stuff so I have a general Idea of how
much a big party cost and I just dont see the justifaction in charging
$25 if Harmony can do a big party with 2 sound systems 2 multi colored
lasers chill area and all the other amenities and still charge $20 I
think everyone else can as well I know for a fact that there party
cost plenty and they may have not made a lot of $$ or even any at all
but they put on a good party. And isn't that what it is about?  I am
starting to ramble so I will shut up know I just think it is sick that
these people are in some cases raping there patrons. I know some one
will probably flame me for my views but that is Ok cause I am not
accusing any one promoter if your shit is real you have not need to
defend yourself. 

Peace love,
Macadio

Cieba, Vajra, Abstrakt, Garth, Neal, Anon, Tracy, Flux, Olivia,

Quadrant, Soulstice, Karma Moffet, Baktun 13, More....

of alternative means of getting up there.

went up to Shasta, it was mindblowing.  This should also be as if not
more amazing-- our tribes are coming together to make this happen.

In my humble opinion, the only party that is worth that kind
of $$ is The Gathering.  Or a multi-day extravaganza like the
upcoming Harmony Anniversary (no, that's not a plug...or is it?).
It appears that the people who set admission prices are not
keeping the target market in mind: mostly youngish people with
mostly limited incomes (if any).  I've seen far too many $15 parties
as well, some of which I attended, and came away feeling that I
didn't get the most bang for my buck.
Well, enough of that.  Just thought I'd add some change...
Peace,
Eric

to get a higher sample rate, stereo file that is huge and takes all
night to download. That's what sleep is for -- so you can upload and
download big files :-).

-In case your getting this twice, sorry ,but I don't think that it
actually got sent the first time-

Boy is that one a tuffy! There are a lot of people who I feel have been
there for me when I needed them. Out of all of them. The most I am
gratful to are.

Victoria, Anny Ting, & Russ.
They have been there for me at times when It was really tough. I don't
think I could have continued without them being there.

Victoria: I have known since 3rd grade and we have been good friends for
many years. She brought me to my first party and has always chosen me
over her mom and given me a place to sleep when I needed one. She was
there for me when i needed to talk to. I know I can forever count on
here any time any day. And she can count on me to no matter what.

Anny Ting: A great friend to talk to when I have been having emotional
problems. Helped me sort out feelings and she has always seemed to make
me feel better. This is one of the few people in who's arms I cried in.

Russ: What can I say. For the short time I have known him, he has been
there for me during and indredibly difficult, and scary acid trip. He
kept me sane and held my hand all the way through. He has also helped me
out with many things and I don't think he realizes how mush I appreciate
his friendship.

There are a whole lot of people that I love a lot also. Too many to
name, but It could be fun to try. 

Love,
Paul

P.S.

Oh and Leslie has been there to make me grow up and realize how dumb I
was and to give me many chances. This may not sound like good things to
do, but sometimes we need to be told straight out. I love her and always
feel safer knowing she is at a rave.

Heck, there's even been parties with, top notch DJs, 3 sound systems;
lights, lazers, and all the trimmings for, what? - $5.

Raves don't have to be a business; that many of them are represents nothing
more than a decision by that promoter to treat it as such.

I'm not opposed to raves that are run as business ventures, some dear
friends make their living this way, but the world also very much needs
raves that come from a different place.

How nice that here in the bay area we have a wealth of both to choose from.

see ya
ethan

between the loop, they seem to occasionally put on a scifi-flick
outtake ("i am locutus of borg, resistance is futile")... then i heard
a station id where they said "this is kbgg... we now return you to our 
irregular programming"). 

i also saw something in the paper about how darien o'toole (the
attitude with ovaries morning talk-show person) got the boot from KBGG
since they're changing format to "adult contemporary" or something like
that.

i never listened to that station before, but one thing we don't need is
another adult contemporary station. i was kinda hoping they'd have a 24
hour techno/electronica station. now that'd be a good format for radio,
'cept it would be hard to do a smooth mix if you had to interrupt your
progression with some dinglebutt screaming "COME TO GRANDMA'S USED CAR
JUNK-SHION AND PICK UP A NEWLY REFURBISHED JAGUAR/BMW/MERCEDES TODAY SO
YOU CAN MACK ON ALL FINE GOLD DIGGERS OUT THERE" every 5ive minutes...).

<< SIGNS THAT YOU ARE TOO DRUNK:
  
  You lose arguments with inanimate objects.
  
  You have to hold onto the lawn to keep from falling off the earth.
  
  Job interfering with your drinking.
  
  Your doctor finds traces of blood in your alcohol stream.
  
  Career won't progress beyond Senator from Massachusetts.
  
  The back of your head keeps getting hit by the toilet seat.
  
  Sincerely believe alcohol to be the elusive 5th food group.
  
  24 hours in a day, 24 beers in a case - coincidence?? - I think not!
  
  Two hands and just one mouth... - now THAT'S a drinking problem!
  
  You can focus better with one eye closed.
  
  The parking lot seems to have moved while you were in the bar.
  
  You fall off the floor...
  
  Your twin sons are named Barley and Hops.
  
  Hey, 5 beers has just as many calories as a burger, screw dinner!
  
  Mosquitoes catch a buzz after attacking you
  
  At AA meetings you begin: "Hi, my name is... uh..."
  
  Your idea of cutting back is less salt.
  
  You wake up in the bedroom, your underwear is in the bathroom, you fell
  asleep clothed. - hmm.
  
  The whole bar says 'Hi' when you come in...
  
  You think the Four Basic Food Groups are Caffeine, Nicotine, Alcohol, and
  [Women or Men].
  
  Every night you're beginning to find your roommate's cat more and more
  attractive.
  
  Roseanne looks good.
  
  Don't recognize wife unless seen through bottom of glass.
  
  That damned pink elephant followed me home again.
  
  Senators Kennedy and Packwood shake their heads when they walk past you.
  
  I'm as jober as a sudge.
  
  The shrubbery's drunk from too frequent watering.
  
  You wake up screaming "TORO TORO TORO!" in the middle of the night.

my 98.1 experience....12:20pm thru 1:10 pm
<enter vehicle>
 tink..tink bwooossh tink tink bwooosh...for so long..they were then
sampling both the Apollo 13 mission as well as the MIR transmissions.
even over each other...  then back down to tink..tink bwooossh tink tink
bwooosh. finally  they began to break in with a radio tuning
sample."twweek woooonk....tweek..woooosssseeeaaarrr pop! ....then"
"you are witnessing the birth of a new radio station......what you hear
today will change tomorrow. this is ......w>>>"
(couldn't make out the call letters)
<exit  vehicle....eat lunch>
burrito....yum ;)
<enter vehicle>
after getting back from lunch I heard them annoucing their new radio
station again.....
(and once again I couldn't make out the call letters)

then finally they busted into some music. =(

I think it was Funkytown......hmm....could be another 70's station. I
only heard 2 tracks...both disco esque......kinda a letdown after all
that cool space stuff....
<exit vehicle>
well....the samples and the minimal background stuff was really
cool.......still hoping for the late nite programming  to be a bit more
do de do do..dwooo   "out there"

fubari

---

...(1) We are actively seeking a new tenant to assume the lease on our space
here at 654 Mission. (Please see the message following for complete
details; please contact me immediately if you or your company might be
interested.)

(2) Our servers may be moving from our 654 Mission location to a new
colocation facility at some time during the evening of Thursday 24 July....

The Cyborganic Community has been especially cool to the Rave Community
allowing us to do parties, dinners and planning meetings there.  If
you get a chance to thank any of them, I would strongly suggest it.  Even
though it was used a lot, 654 Mission hosted some of the best parties
this city has seen recently.

Saturday July 26, approx 7 PM

DIRECTIONS:
>From 280 -  go north on 880 (Oakland) and follow directions below

>From 101 -  go south on 880 (Santa Cruz) and follow dirctions below

>From 880 --
Take the Alameda exit (turn right if you are coming FROM the north & vice versa)Less than a mile down turn left at the light for the Alameda (not a typeo!!)
You will immediately see a sign for SAFEWAY on your left, cut through the 
parking lot in front of the Safeway (it's small)
Turn left at the road on the other side - NOW PARK

My small apartment complex is the only thing behind the Safeway.  
2750 Park Ave #6 (just go to the loud place)

I know the directions sound kinda sketchy, but I swear it is easy to find
and you will always know if you are on the right track!

another local DJ talent, Fubari, will be spinning in his place.  And Jelo,

their GIGANTIGUS sound system, playing at my place.  (Yipee!)

if you have any questions or somethin' (408)984-6360

Its true - check out the web site for the pictures, video and t-shirt...


<<Our subject today is lighting charcoal grills.  One of our favorite 
charcoal grill lighters is a guy named George Goble (really!!), a 
computer person in the Purdue University engineering department.
     
Each year, Goble and a bunch of other engineers hold a picnic in West 
Lafayette, Indiana, at which they cook hamburgers on a big grill.  Being 
engineers, they began looking for practical ways to speed up the 
charcoal-lighting process.
     
"We started by blowing the charcoal with a hair dryer," Goble told me in 
a telephone interview.  "Then we figured out that it would light faster 
if we used a vacuum cleaner."
     
If you know anything about (1) engineers and (2) guys in general, you 
know what happened:  The purpose of the charcoal-lighting shifted from 
cooking hamburgers to seeing how fast they could light the charcoal.
     
>From the vacuum cleaner, they escalated to using a propane torch, then
an acetylene torch.  Then Goble started using compressed pure oxygen, 
which caused the charcoal to burn much faster, because as you recall from

chemistry class, fire is essentially the rapid combination of oxygen with

a reducing agent (the charcoal).  We discovered that a long time ago, 
somewhere in the valley between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers (or 
something along those lines).
     
By this point, Goble was getting pretty good times.  But in the world of 
competitive charcoal-lighting, "pretty good" does not cut the mustard.
     
Thus, Goble hit upon the idea of using - get ready - liquid oxygen.  This

is the form of oxygen used in rocket engines; it's 295 degrees below zero

and 600 times as dense as regular oxygen.  In terms of releasing energy, 
pouring liquid oxygen on charcoal is the equivalent of throwing a live 
squirrel into a room containing 50 million Labrador retrievers.  On 
Gobel's World Wide Web page (the address is http://ghg.ecn.purdue.edu/), 
you can see actual photographs and a video of Goble using a bucket 
attached to a 10-foot-long wooden handle to dump 3 gallons of liquid 
oxygen (not sold in stores) onto a grill containing 60 pounds of charcoal

and a lit cigarette for ignition.

What follows is the most impressive charcoal-lighting I have ever seen,
featuring a large fireball that according to Goble, reached 10,000 
degrees Fahrenheit.  The charcoal was ready for cooking in - this has to 
be a world record - 3 seconds.
     
There's also a photo of what happened when Goble used the same technique 
on a flimsy $2.88 discount-store grill.  All that's left is a circle of 
charcoal with a few shreds of metal in it.  "Basically, the grill 
vaporized," said Goble.  "We were thinking of returning it to the store 
for a refund."
     
Looking at Goble's video and photos, I became, as an American, allchoked 
up with gratitude at the fact that I do not live anywhere near the 
engineers' picnic site.  But also, I was proud of my country for 
producing guys who can be ready to barbecue in less time than it take for

guys in less-advanced nations, such as France, to spit.
     
Will the 3-second barrier ever be broken?  Will engineers come up with a 
new, more powerful charcoal-lighting technology?  It's something for all 
of us to ponder this summer as we sit outside, chewing our hamburgers, 
every now and then glancing in the direction of West Lafayette, Indiana, 
looking for a mushroom cloud.>>

Hey, I've listened to 2 types of music that are both supposed to be happy 
hardcore, and I was wondering which one of them is _really_ happy hardcore, or 
if maybe they're both are happy hardcore, just different types of it or 
something like that . . .

Anyway the first type I heard was this CD called "Happy 2b Hardcore."  It just 
sounded like diva house music sped up really fast, and it was super happy.

The second type I heard was a import CD compilation I just bought called the 
"Best of Happy Hardcore."  This sounded like jungle, as in there was hella 
breakbeat, but not as dark or angry as some jungle tends to be.  It had a more 
complex sound than "Happy 2b Hardcore," which is a little repetitive.

So which of these is true happy hardcore?

And can anyone recommend some good happy hardcore CDs that I can buy?

Thanx a million
xoxo--Miccaela

At 12:59 AM 7/24/97 -0400, you wrote:
>hey i'm missing 103.1 groove radio too....i recently moved up to the bay area
>from orange county and it's hell not having that type of music on the
>radio!!!  Swedish Egil, Mohammed , Holly Adams...Jeff K....Geez, half my
>friends like make tapes for their lunch groove...
>is there a station comparable to the Groove up here in the Bay??
>Help me.....=)

Well, as far as I remember when I was last in LA, Groove Radio was playing
almost all very commercial, very OVERground house and dance music.  I once
heard Joey Beltram's "Energy Flash" mixed in, but it was quite a shock.
The rest of the time, I had a difficult time stomaching most of what they
play.  It seemed like a cool idea to have a dedicated "dance" station, but
I'm extremely disappointed by the result.  

We actually have quite a bit of underground electronic music on the radio
up here.  There's an extensive listing on the sfraves calendar:

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi#radio

My personal pick would have to be Shortwave on Sunday nights at KALX 90.7fm
in Berkeley, but that's because I dj there :)  The number of electronic
radio shows has grown significantly in the last year though.  Almost all on
college stations as well, which means NO commercials :)  And don't forget
the Beta Lounge webcast.  Lots of great stuff to choose from, I'd say...

-Seth

Yeah Groove Radio plays all your favorite over played tracks... mostly 
cheese-ball commercial house and cheese-ball trance.  

BUT

The thing is I probably wouldn't mind most of the tracks on Groove if I 
didn't hear them once an hour (or more) every time I turn the station 
on.  

Really really late at night/early in the morning they spin more 
underground stuff, and on Sunday nights there are some really cool shows 
like the Groove Radio International countdown.  All-in-all you wind up 
realizing that they need to pay their bills just like any other radio 
station, but at least some really good stuff is getting some airtime.  

They have realAudio from their web page, I think... www.grooveradio.com

:)

-------------------------------------
UncleNoah
"Still Behind the Orange Curtain"

> 
> Anyway the first type I heard was this CD called "Happy 2b Hardcore."  It just 
> sounded like diva house music sped up really fast, and it was super happy.
> 
> The second type I heard was a import CD compilation I just bought called the 
> "Best of Happy Hardcore."  This sounded like jungle, as in there was hella 
> breakbeat, but not as dark or angry as some jungle tends to be.  It had a more 
> complex sound than "Happy 2b Hardcore," which is a little repetitive.
> 
> So which of these is true happy hardcore?
> 
> And can anyone recommend some good happy hardcore CDs that I can buy?
> 
> Thanx a million
> xoxo--Miccaela

thanks for the info....I only knew Groove Radio as a show on wednesday or
mabye it was friday...dunno....nites. It used to start at like 1:30 am and
go till 3 or so. It was hosted by the Sweedish Eagle or Egil (sp>?) It was
the "countdown"....he'd mix the top 20 or so tracks from the Intnl.
charts...some of the tracks rocked...and I hear them all over the place,
others were ok....This was while I was living in Boulder, CO. ...so some
local radio station was cool enough to carry just the countdown show once a
week. 
>grin<  its all coming together now.....

fubari

From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
To: "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Groove Radio 103.1fm, LA, CA
Date: Wed, 23 Jul 1997 23:41:30 -0700 (PDT)


Yeah Groove Radio plays all your favorite over played tracks... mostly 
cheese-ball commercial house and cheese-ball trance.  

BUT

The thing is I probably wouldn't mind most of the tracks on Groove if I 
didn't hear them once an hour (or more) every time I turn the station 
on.  

Really really late at night/early in the morning they spin more 
underground stuff, and on Sunday nights there are some really cool shows 
like the Groove Radio International countdown.  All-in-all you wind up 
realizing that they need to pay their bills just like any other radio 
station, but at least some really good stuff is getting some airtime.  

They have realAudio from their web page, I think... www.grooveradio.com

:)

-------------------------------------
UncleNoah
"Still Behind the Orange Curtain"

Vanessa & Miccaela wanted to know...

>Hey, I've listened to 2 types of music that are both supposed to be happy 
>hardcore, and I was wondering which one of them is _really_ happy
hardcore, or 
>if maybe they're both are happy hardcore, just different types of it or 
>something like that . . .
>Anyway the first type I heard was this CD called "Happy 2b Hardcore."  It
just 
>sounded like diva house music sped up really fast, and it was super happy.
>The second type I heard was a import CD compilation I just bought called the 
>"Best of Happy Hardcore."  This sounded like jungle, as in there was hella 
>breakbeat, but not as dark or angry as some jungle tends to be.  It had a
more 
>complex sound than "Happy 2b Hardcore," which is a little repetitive.
>So which of these is true happy hardcore?

to be quite frank, i haven't heard either of the albums. but from the track
listing on "happy 2b hardcore", it doesn't really sound like a good hh-album.
but then again, that's just what i think. =) but hh these days has a lot of
breakbeats in it. basically, the typical hh song is a straight 4/4 beat, you
get some sped-up vocals, and a breakbeat. and if you're lucky, there's a
piano riff thrown in there somewhere. =)))

>And can anyone recommend some good happy hardcore CDs that I can buy?

sure can. check in the import sections and see if you can find:
rave collision (compilation on broken beats records)
anything with dj paul elstak (his first mix cd is amazing)
anything with dj slipmatt

want more recommendations? lemme know. =)

*huggies*
jonas THE HAPPYBOY. =)

<snip>
...
E>The second type I heard was a import CD compilation I just bought called the 
E>"Best of Happy Hardcore."  This sounded like jungle, as in there was hella 
E>breakbeat, but not as dark or angry as some jungle tends to be.  It had a more 
E>complex sound than "Happy 2b Hardcore," which is a little repetitive.
E>So which of these is true happy hardcore?

  Well, depending who you ask, people have lots of ideas about what happy
  hardcore is. Currently the sound of happy hardcore is (IMO) similar to
  the sound of UK hardcore circa early 90's. Happy Hardcore generally
  (at least in S.Cali) isn't associated with Jungle, ALTHOUGH - I have in
  my possesion a 'happy hardcore' tape that I mail ordered from some DJ
  from New Jersey two years ago which contained a lot of junglish tunes in
  it, which I am really opposed to (at least under the name HH). IMO,
  the CD with the divas sounds more like 'true' HH.

		  http://www.ravenetwork.com/~hardcore

E>And can anyone recommend some good happy hardcore CDs that I can buy?

  I always liked Happy Rave '95 despite the fact that I obtained it
  through Columbia House. Its kinda housey though at points. Otherwise,
  its a REALLY good compilation of HH.

  Laurence
