De-Lurking:  I saw this in the L.A. Dining and Nightlife, "bombastic
sounds of house music" Oh! Brother!  Any comments?






                    Raves and Groovers

                   "Nearly a decade ago, house music fans crammed into
                      warehouses
                    and other unconventional spaces around the world  
                      dressed in gym
                    wear, especially anything by Adidas, and T-shirts 
                      and accessories
                    depicting Sesame Street, Dr. Seuss and Disney     
                      characters. Their
                    parties were called raves, and they were one-night
                      celebrations in
                    the name of technology, peace and global
community. 

                    The raves dwindled, especially in L.A., as police 
                      became more
                    savvy on how to bust them. Most were, after all,  
                      held illegally.
                    Gangbangers also crashed the party, having no     
                      concern for the
                    message of unity and peace. 

                    It's doubtful that groovers have had as much of an
                      impact
                    internationally as yet. But signs indicate that
this                     is a regenerated,
                    if not slightly revamped, version of rave culture 
                      that began taking
                    shape a couple of years ago. As for when it
decided                      on a name, no
                    one can guess. 

                    Groovers' uniform of their culture is actually a  
                      hodgepodge of
                    pieces from various sports. "Doing battle" means  
                      competition, but
                    their activity of choice is dancing. The          
                      electronically hypnotic,
                    sometimes bombastic sounds of house music serve as
                      their
                    soundtrack. Though no one can say for certain when
                      groovers
                    emerged, the elements that define them are not
new. 

                    Clubs and parties were once affectionately called 
                      raves, but the
                    term has fallen out of vogue due to its           
                      mainstreaming and has yet
                    to be replaced." 


Peace All - "Old Schooler Back into Lurk Mode"
LuckE

1st time I ravEd? Aberigionee(sp) at the acme building.

 Hmmm.. Well.. Although people seemed really peacefull and conciderate. It
seemed to me that no one was looking for new friends. They seemed to have
there's and. Well.. I felt like I was pretty much butting in.
 Was 1st time E'ing, felt great. The feeling of floating was phat. Can't
say it felt quite the same agian. It's all down hill from there.. I
remember looking around..Some people looked pretty messed up from abusing E
for to long.  Desided I was going to NOT do it as much as they seem to
have, but ended up doing to much anyways from there on out.
 I noticed people breakdancing..That was a major blast from the past.
 Couldn't keep these two guys from breathing down my neck wispering. Made
me paranoid so I moved elsewhere, because they made me feel like I was
going to be a victom of some gang initiation. I never would of thought
then, that today I would need a rear view mirror.
 I noticed a cute girl giving me the winks. Couple minutes later I noticed
she had some guys hand up her skirt.
 1st time listening to techno.. And found it captivating. Now it's a part
of me, that seems to take up most of my mental resources when it's around.
Making it hard for me to concentrate on much more than te music.
 I noticed that NO ONE was "stomping there feet to the beat" And I had SO
MUCH fun that night. I remember on the drive home...I mentioned to my
friend Wayne about no one stomping there feet to the beat. And I told Wayne
I was going to make the foot stomping dance very popular.

One things for sure. Going to that first ravE didn't make me think I was
going to start smoking agian.



True story.
I don't lie. Unless you ask me what drugs I am on..
Jeff
  
----------

  Get on 880 south which will turn into HWY 17 over the santa cruz mtns,  
Once you are in SC take the Half moon bay (HWY 1 North) exit then just 
keep on going for probably a total of 7 miles or so then there will be 
the shittiest looking, thrashed van on the right of the road just past a 
white reflector like fence,,, park down the road right before it you'll 
see our cars probably( the green piece of Honda with the crap inside and 
the other(have no clue,,think Impulse or something?)park infront of us 
okay...Cross hwy 1 and there is a little trail inbetween bushes and 
stuff, about 15 ft, later you'll see the train tracks...The trail 
continues, but splits off into a fork,,,go down the trail on the right 
that goes down and walk 1-2 hundred yards then you'll be at the 
beach,,,We will be to the right,, youll hopefully see a fire and people 
running around naked :)
Have fun & good luck...This message will self destruct once you hit the 
delete button,,,I guess that wouldn't be self destruction though huh?  
Later
      BaBy DAN

Subject: Road RAGE=BAD karma
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Thu, 24 Jul 1997 14:14:50 PDT
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

    I have a good story to tell everyone, one in which ocurred to me 
early this morning...wish it didn't.  I woke up to work the early shift 
at City Espresso around 6:45 am, took a shower by myself,  got dressed 
in my own clothes and headed out the door.  I sat in my luxurious, 
aqpple green '81 Honda and turned the corner with my cigarette dangling 
ever so gently from my lips. 
    I was sure that I was going to have a great day at work despite the 
sleep deprivation and the fact that I have an oil leak in my car.
    When I turned the corner,  I did not see this beautiful white Ford 
Escort rearing up on my haunches like a bat-outa-hell.  I turned onto 
Lawrence xpwy as usual, except for the fact that there was a blond 
bearded, white-trashy piece of ass staring at me with the most evil 
looking  grin,  the same guy in the Escort.  He was about  a foot from 
my bumper(obviously he did not see my bumper sticker which states: 
"Don't tale gate me or I'll flick a booger on your windshield")  He was 
probably too close to see it.  
    We were stopped at the stoplight and he, of course, being right 
behind me, sticks his head out of his window as if he were going to 
start yelling at me or something, which he did propmtly after he hauked 
a big lugie on my rear windshield.  I replied,  "What the Fuck do you 
think you are doing Mother Fucker?....We exchanged a few words like 
"@$#%#!~~!@##@$##$%$@#$%^^%%^&&&%^*&&()&^**^)%#@@##" and he quickly sped 
off. 
   I was trying to think what type of person he must have been and what 
his occupation might be...I was pretty sure he must be a high school 
guidance counselor...I don't believe that I was the reason for this 
outrage, it must be bad sex or his impotency, dunno.  
   To tell everyone the truth, I had to stop myself from stepping to his 
low by slamming on my breaks as my vehicle quickly started going 
backwards towards him.  Boy it would have been fun though,  but I'll 
save that for people like him.  
  15 dollars in tips later, I am happy as can be, and if I ever see that 
guy again, he left something on my car   :) 
                                     Peace to All,
                                        BaBy HueY

______________________________________________________

Yeah!  Here, here!  Aging ravers unite!

And on the whole candyraver tip...

I've found myself referred to as a 'candyraver' lately - presumably b/c I
"attacked" someone with a candy necklace and stickers.  =)  Does wearing some
stickers, glitter and giving out candy make me a candyraver?  I personally
associate that with the ravers that totally get into it and are over the top a
la Paul Hayden, Ivan, etc...

Lovinhugs,

 Vital selections from all corners of the Drum'n Bass world. Support
the 
 SF jungle underground!
 
 -------------------------
 
 Elements of Noise- Torch- Smokers Inc.
 
 The Elements are a couple of the most prolific producers over the
past 
 couple years. From their smooth trancy tracks of old, to their
techstep 
 of new, you can always count on quality and boom on the dance floor. 
 This 12" is really out there! The A-side is a dark, sinister track,
but 
 it starys away from the distortef bass that they commonly use. Nope, 
 this is DEEP. Halfway through this one, it breaks into this string 
 section and then slowly builds with metalic half-beats, eventually 
 rolling down into a dark pit of dispair. Really next level shit!!
 
 Nico & Makai- Omen- NU Black
 
 Tech step pioneer and german nu-schooler combine to form a wacked out 
 track on the No U-Turn sub label. Wikid distorted melody, and
clanging 
 drums make this one a stomper.  Signature Nico bass line drills into 
 your head, just the way they want it to. Wikid.
 
 Future Forces Inc.- Triton- Hardware
 
 The FF team takes a different direction on this long awaited single. 
 Triton has a long drony intro with no bass which eats up half the
side.  The drop is nice and dark with a jumpy break. Flip side is much
   mellower than anything they've put out. A nice deep analogue
bouncer.
 I'd tell you to watch out for'em, but they're already here.
 
 Codename John- The Warning- Metalheadz
 
 Couldn't even begin to explain how incredible this Grooverider track
is.  I don't know if I'll ever drop this on a dancefloor, but this is
the  most interesting, devilish stepper I've heard in ages. Along the
same lines as the R.Size and Shadow 100 remix, this track takes you on
a real journey. Deep as Phuck, you have to hear it to beleive it. The
flip  side, Structure of Red, not only has the coolest title I've
heard, but 
 drops you into a dark trancy place only Groove can take you. Big Up
the 
 Godfather.
 
 Elements if Noise- Warning- Bassrush US
 
 Domestic 2-tracker from the Elements. Dark and supah tough!! Both
sides 
 feature trancy synth lines which drop into hard mashing workouts. If
you like your techstep, you can't miss this one.
 
 DJ Die- Reincarnated- Ful Cycle
 
 Smooth remix by Bristol massive resident. More drums than the
original, 
 and a smoth jazz sample to round things out. Not massive, but
definately the shit.
 
 Mix'n Blen #3 Promo
 
 Wikid new squelcher from Kenny Ken's camp. A-side is an energetic >
analogue stepper. B-side is a massive tearout for the jumpers.
 
 Nasty Habits- Shadoboxing relick- 31
 
 Big up the D O C. Takes his classic tune and injects amen fill while 
 tweaking the droney bass line. Wait till halfway through when the
record skips in time...over the top! B-side is a smooth stomper with
punchy bass hits. If you were at Ultra, you heard this one.
 
------------

-peace-

SCiEnCe
_____________________________________________________________________

Ah, my deflowering.  Yes, I remember it well...

Friends and Family, July 1997 [at the ripe, almost old age, of 28].
FUCKING AWESOME!!!!!! I have changed my personal mantra from "I am my
own sysadmin" to "I am a raver".

So, OK.  I knew a few people who were going to be there, and I went with
a new friend and two total strangers, as my G was setting up the party
[which, of course, is how i found out about it in the first place]  What
I got was an amazing environment, complete with kids of all ages, music,
images, black-lights, beanbag chairs, public sex, crrrrrazzy candies
and lots of interesting conversations.

Music and DJs and Wayne [the nicest big-guy I've met in years] aside,
think about it.  This is an "underground", "subversive" culture which
essentially defines itself by screaming "HERE WE ARE" - the
differentiations in uniforms [goa, candy ravers, glitter guys and girls,
ex-deadheads, blah blah blah] were so interesting to me, because they
aren't, uh..., subtle?

I was essentially separated from the small group i went with for the
majority of the evening, my Gool-guy was either dancing or working, and
you know what?  I can't remember having more fun in, like, a really long
time.  It was like going to an amusement park [only you don't have to
use the bathrooms at the scary Karaoke bar at parks].

There aren't many places left where, essentially, anyone who wants  can
gather for the enjoyment of thoughtful, emotional, experiential and [may
my classical musician parents forgive this] *organic* music.  The way
Ethan created and maintained and changed and developed the experience of
his set is what I remember the most.

So there you have it.  Save for the two little girls (maybe 13) so
freaked out on Sid I felt obligated to act as the adult I am for a few
moments, it was a safe, sane, fun, funny, interesting, compelling and
definitely addictive. I got home at 8:00 am, and I woulda stayed longer,
but I'm not as young as I used to be :-)

**regarding Cunanan***
Cunanan's body was identified earlier this morning.  Some f-cked up
someone at some official something seems to think that, if he was HIV+
that would explain why his profile didn't fit that of any other serial
killers.  Nice, eh?

Gotta go deal with Burningman - aw,yeah!  If'n your'e going, check out
our Lewis Carrol Summer Camp - did anyone say 'eat me'? South Side of
the Plya - play flaming croquet - crawl through the rabbit hole, smoke
with the caterpillar on the 5' mushroom....

Kate

  gating people with bumper stickers like 'I hate tailgaters'. Oh well.
  Never was the kind to descrate other people's cars though.

E>I was trying to think what type of person he must have been and what his
E>occupation might be...I was pretty sure he must be a high school
E>guidance counselor...I don't believe that I was the reason for this
E>outrage, it must be bad sex or his impotency, dunno. 

  Definately impotency.

  PLUR! =)
  Laurence

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Thu Jul 24 16:49:19 1997

Dreamer wrote:

> 
> So, as someone who just heard his first rave music a couple of months
> ago, Maybe you can explain - What's a candyraver?  :)
> 


Due to popular demand, (Okay like 6 people). Here is the 

The Complete Raver Personality Guide!

So You can have all of it to keep, sleep on, or just delete, hoping I never
write anything again.

Sorry about the formatting, I can't seem to fix it without having to redo 
the whole thing.

Nailvarnish

You just thought nobody was watching you.......but you were wrong.




Come on admit it, you all old folks out there you were once a:

SEPTEMBER CHILD!

How to spot one: All their gear is new. Clean shoes, brand new Adidas 
back pack, perfect parting everytime (Female).

Where to find them: In every big undergrounds, and clubs.

They always appear:     Just after the summer, either they were introduced
to the scene in the holidays or at the beginning their first year in university.

Internet characteristics: Their account has edu behind it.
Their post consists of Lot of "I LovE you all"
"It was so fluffy and PLURry." "I have nEvEr had 
 friEnds like this.   They always capitalisE thEir Es.

Pros:           They are grEat to look at. They givE you candy. They makE
you smilE bEcause you havE lost that innocEncE.


Cons:           They're annoying when you're pissEd off and recEivE an
Email from them, e.g.. "It's all abovE lovE. pEace" In other
words what you say don't count." ThIER posts are hard to rEAd, with the big Es
all over it. 

 They don't know the difference between trance and breakbeat
if it hit them. SO they resort to posts on NNR things.

What they become:       Usually they drop out of the mailing list and you
never hear of them again because the e has worn off. 

They become cynical and complains like the rest of
us, after being  flamed one too many times, and been ripped off and
given crap drugs, and gone to bum parties..

Don't feel bad if this is YOU! Everyone gets their turn.....

                        ___________________________________


After the September Child stage there are many other variations!!

The Old Sckooler: circa 89-92.

How to spot them:       Their clothes have a washout look, the prints of
the T-shirt are faded and have dates that say: 1991. 

Where to find them:     In the background, in the dark, at the ticket booth
and All the anniversary raves celebrations.

Internet characteristic:        They hardly posts (because every thread
they have seen already) but when they do it's to correct 
someone's misinformation.
(See grouch)

Pros:           They answer all your rave related questions. They know the
cultural significance of the fifteen minutes solos. They
remember 15 minutes solos!
They have cool stories to tell, esp ones like, "It used to
be $5 to get in and you get free water." 

Cons:           They complain ALL the time. About how the scene was better,
(See quote above).How the ravers now don't have the have the
same attitude.Sometimes they post you realize your
smallness. They remind you all the time they've been around.

Sometimes they also are......

The happy-43-year-old OLD skooler.

How to spot them:       Their age, pretty obvious really. They dance the
way THEY want, usually having to give them lots of space.

How you find them:      Usually with their spouses, or they're telling you
their spouse tells them to grow up!. In the midst of all
these young people that worship him or
her for his/her longevity. Still dancing when all
the 20 year old have had it.

Pros:   You can't believe they are still at it! 
You want to be like them.

Cons:      If you're not paying attention and get a glance of
them, they make you think of your parents at home,
wondering what you're up to.

                        __________________________________________________



Edition 3: This is no necessarily evolutionary, but you have to reach the
first to get to 2 and 3. Here we have the ultimate raver, the
about-burnout-raver, the born again raver.

THE ULTIMATE RAVER:

How you spot them: The have all the clothes that you want. They have more  
glow sticks, and bike lights on their bodies then even the 
average raver. In the day, they look the same, sans
glow sticks and bike lights.

Where you find them: EVERY rave. Seen dancing anywhere there are strains of
techno, by their car,  down the street, anywhere.

Characteristic:   They are always there. When they wake up the first
thing they do is put hard trance on and play it real loud.

Pros:           Best person to call when you want to go out. They'll always
go with you, and they know where it Is. They give you warning
and directions to secret parties. You can count on them
being there. They lend you lots Of tapes.

Cons:           The can become About-burnout-raver (see below). They don't
understand when you're tired, or don't want to go out.

                Pray they don't live in the apt above you.

                                __________________________________________


The About-burn-out raver.

How you spot them:      They look more ragged than their 12 year old teddy
bear. Their shoes are a non-discript colour of blah.
They haven't washed their hair for a month, in fact
they haven't done that to their bodies or
clothes for a while either.

Where to find them:     Again at every rave. But this time, really really
at every rave.
Including clubs on the weekdays, and cafes that
play techno in the afternoon.
        
Characteristics:        They are always high, coming down or about to come
up. When they laugh it's a full body laugh where
their heads flip backwards, and thier jaws lock. They
know everybody.

How you find them:      In the day, SLEEPing, among a pile of water
bottles, and fliers and  miscellaneous MESS. In fact
they can trace each bottle to the specific
rave they were at. They are tired all the time until they                 
get to one.

Pros:           The are great fun. They always can find you the drugs you
want, and it would be great. Sometimes they give you some free. 

Cons:           They never have any money except to go to raves and for
drugs. Keeps borrowing from you, for  important things such as
food, rent, and cigarettes. 


What happens to them:   Usually a hiatus where they sit in front of the
computer and lives in the rave mailing  lists,
and seems quite bitter about not going out, but
not having the energy or money.Become a
born again raver (see below). 

Worst case scenario:     Rehab, or parents.


                              
_____________________________________________


THE BORN AGAIN RAVER. (Straight edge)

How to spot them: They are walking in a straight line. They
TELL you.

Internet characteristics:       Their posts usually contains some promotion
of raving sober

Characteristics:      They are clean. They leave at 5am. They
always have a bemused look when you see you fall
over, or curled up in the corner, or bowing to the speaker.


Pros:  No more fights about who's driving home. He or she always
does. 

Cons:  You are aware that they will remember things that you don't
or pretend not to. The can laugh at you and there is nothing you
can use as ammunition.

________________________________________________________________________

THE INTERNET RAVER PERSONALITY.


The Grouch:
There are usually a few long term grouches on each mailing
list. But the grouch bug catches everyone at somet ime. Another
characteristic of the grouch bug  is that you have
specific-topic-grouches. Like the commercialization
grouch, the PC grouch, the drugs grouch, the music grouch, 
the I HAVE SAID THIS BEFORE LETS NOT HAVE NRR POSTS grouch. 

Where you find them:    Only found on the internet

How you can spot them: They are telling someone what they wrote
was wrong, stupid, or ignorant. They correct
all misinformation printed in the list, and
then say, "Grrrr look it up on the hyperreal
web page, before you posts, the address is: 
                               
http://hyperreal.org.everything/youneedto/know/andmore"
                                Their posts are over 6000 words each time. 
                                THEY USE A LOT OF CAPITALS TO MAKE THEIR POINT!!

Non internet characteristics:   They are actually quite pleasant, 
                                intelligent human beings that hardly ever
yell.  But somehow change once they sit in
front of the screen and can be anonymous! 

Pros:       If you support the point they are making for that
day, you're happy because you know you don't even need to say
anything, because this person will say it all for
you, in 6000+ words.

Cons:   If you get on the wrong side of the debate, you
know you'll be in it for at least 5 days, always defending yourself,
because the grouch is great at finding hidden text in
your words that you didn't even know exists. It's
really annoying to delete a hundred posts a day                        
because you really don't care about the topic, in fact by then the         
subject line has nothing to do with the content. 

Also known as:  Depending on your point of view on the debate, the grouch
could also be seen as "The person who is right." "The
person who is overreacting." "The Flame monger." or just
plain dumb.


The grouch has a mutual dependency with the peacemaker. 
Neither can exists without the other, like the hippo and that bird that
sits on it's back. Or the screen and the hard drive. 

                ___________________________________________

The Peace Maker

Where you find them:    Again on the internet

How you spot them:      They are silence for a long time during a debate,
and finally their name pops up and inevitably the post
would start of with: "I really want to stay out of this
but............." followed by, "I want to remind
everyone..." Key words founds in the 
posts are: "Respect," " Off-line," "Think," and
"community,"

Pros:           They help end that one post that has been taking up
bandwidth or days. You are even sick of reading the subject heading,
let alone opening the msg. They may save you, if you're the one being
flamed.

Cons: When it's directed at you!
        You have been riled up to the point of no return, and the grouch
bug has caught you. YOU JUST DON't WANT TO STOP! In fact you have been
enjoying, flaming this person, and the Peacemaker will remind you that you
have been behaving like a fool in  public even though you've been
sitting at home.

The evolutionary of a thread.

1) E posts something
2) Grouch descends and tells E what is wrong with it.
3) E becomes upset, and writes something in retaliation.
4) Grouch slams what E said.
5) X times a number of people join in on either end. 
6) Both Grouch and E are trying to defend their points. E has now caught 
the grouch bug. 
7) Nobody actually knows who's writing what. There are too many forwarded 
arrows, little comments.
8) K flames T about something E said.
9) E flames K, T, L and the WHOLE DAMN List.
10) Grouch his/her  camp posts anti E comments,
11) E and his/her camp does the same.  
12) By this time, there are four different threads all regarding the 
same topic.
13) PEACE MAKER COMES IN.
14) Second PEACE maker comes in.
15) People start to shut up, because the weekend is about to arrive and 
there have better things to do.



Sample Posts

Subject: DJ Gear for sale, (CHeap!)

Content:


I don't want to get into this, but I would like to remind everyone to 
take a deep breath. We are a community of people that needs to respect 
each other. THINK.  Please take this off line. PEACEMAKER,Love,  Unity , 
repeat.


----------------------------------------------
"I had a dream...."
Grrls domination Inc. Tel 911-4657
fax: 911-4675
--------------------------
>>>>=\I WANT TO SAY THIS IS AN NRR POST, AND I HAVE SAID THIS BEFORE.(The nrr grouch)

>>>>>>Ya know you loud
>>>>>>mouth bastard, You are *+NOT** in a raving for the
>>>>>>                  *____ right____* 
>>>>>>>reason. Mayb

>>>> I want to ask what are the right reasons to rave, music, the drugs, what. When I use to rave it was about the music...now...it's about drugs." 
(born again raver) 

>>FUCK OFF YOU DICKe if you need to find something else to do because WE 
>>>>>>>don't 
>>>>>>>want (((YOU))) here. Fucking idiot. 


>> NO! We want *EveryonE hErE! We lovE everyonE, the scEnE is about lovE!*(SEptEmber child) PLUR

>>>>I want to put in my 2cents, I think the topic we are talking about is... I really support, em who am I supporting? 

>>I didn't say that! SHE did!!!!!
>>> It's me and I said that, and not him!

>>>>>This thread has come out before, many times and as I remember lasttime, we >>>>>agreed that there are too many diverging opinions, and
decided that we weren't >>>>>going to fight about this anymore. I know that
there are many new people here. >>>>>(old skooler) 



I can't believe you actually 
>>>>>>*liked*
>>>>>that song and bought the album. You are _*_NOT_*_ a sane human being."

(list of names, that are now completely disconnected to the body)

_________________________________________________________________

After the internet break. Lets get back to the run of the mill everyday
raver.


The DJ

How to spot them:       One shoulder is lower than the other. They have bad
posture from bending over their decks. They always have
an entourage surrounding them. Managers, friends
that needed to get in free,groupies of the male  or
female persuasion. With their gear.

Where to find them:     Behind the decks, or hanging out with other DJs.
They NEVER dance. Behind their decks at home.

Characteristics:        They are either ultra arrogant, or they are really
cool. There is never an in-between.

Pros:  We NEED them. If they're good, they make you
ecstatic. You life depends on them.When they are
starting out, they give you tapes, they play at your
parties all for FREE.

Cons:  When they suck, your life feels like it's over. If
they're your friends you never see them, because they
are either playing, or practicing.They don't go to
the raves unless they're playing at it. you don't go out
with them and when you go to the one they're playing at they are           
surrounded.

                       
____________________________________________________



 Drug Dealer


Where you find them:    Near the doors at the parties, in parking lots. Or 
quietly by themselves looking around for people. 

How to spot them:   The usually yell something subtle like"EEEEEEEE"
 Or the grab you and say, "I like
your jacket. Do you want some E?" Usually
appears standing alone and sober.
        
Cons:           When you're already high, they keep asking you, "Are you
sure? I can give you five and take $2 off."  because you might be so
fucked up you buy it anyway. If they're your friend you never
know if you want to give them a ride of not, due to the possession laws.
        

Pros:           Well it's quite obvious really.

Worse case scenario:    Bum drugs, i.e. it's a pain killer, or has heroin
or PCP.

Complaint:      I remember the days when you could talk down the price of a
pill to $15,if you said something like, "Come on my boyfriend
use to sell this stuff, I know the mark up. Just because
you're in the know. Now so many people take it they laugh in your
face.

                ___________________________________________________


The groupie, or hanger on.


Where you find them: Around somebody important. Either it be a DJ, a
promoter, and club kid, a drug dealer. Hanging out with the other people
that put on the rave, but isn't actually doing anything. 

How you spot them. The lone person, or two in a group of people with
laminates.

Characteristics:        They try to get into things free. They walk to the
front of the queue, and ask for somebody to the
security guard. They won't talk to you unless you know
someone or is someone. If they do talk to you,they name
drop. You gets extra points for reconising the name, and                  
even more points for saying you know the person. 

Sample monologue:       "Well so I was there in this cafe, and I was having
Sunday lunch with the promoters, yeah, and then Carl Cox
comes over and sits down. Man that was da bomb. You
know him? Good, he is da shits. Funny thing was
there was this guy from Moon shine records, you know,
trying to sigh my friend onto the label. You  know
Moonshine right?"

Pros:   They introduce you to the people you might actually care to meet. 

Cons:   That is if you're cool enough in the first place to deserve to be
spoken to.

                __________________________________________________

The Candy Raver (north cal), Club kid (Socal)  Geographically different
terminology.

Where you spot them: Everywhere in the scene.

How to spot them: You can't really miss them can you? In the 7 inch foam
platforms.Incredible makeup, wigs, fluffy flurry
jackets, lots of lights and glow things hanging of
them.  Glam Glam Glam. Not in addidas because that's
sporty! Don't forget PLASTIC, is the word. They are wearing
clothes and holding things that are great when you're feeling tactile.

What they are not:      Drag queens! They are fantastic creatures of the
night that have no gender indentity.

Pros:   They are so fun to look at! Some of them, have the most interesting
lifes. Go talk to       Trixie who spent some months meditating in a budist
temple in Asia. If you are one, you get in free to events. Sometimes
you get paid to go to them. 

Cons:   When you're their friend, it's hard to get to talk to them, because
everyone else is trying to do the same. They are so visible that
everyone comes by to say "hello."

How they start out:     That sticker thing! The glitter, the sesame street,
soft toys bak packs, teddy bears,  PACIFYERS. 




The Scenester.


Where you spot them:    The occasional large raves, but usually in the
smaller parties or clubs, where no one
goes, especially the early weekday ones. 
Invite only parties with industry suit types (they're                     
sooo hip, they transcend the label of sell out (ahem). Their               
own private parties with  all other scenesters buddies. They               
are always   at raves that have no fliers.

How to spot them: The NEVER wear raver fashion, except the
sunglasses, and  Mondorama   long sleeves
black shirts with the bold colour print 
(orange, lime green,) some trendy trainers.


Occupation:                     Industry types, (but not top five record
companies) They work for MGM, Sony, some
artsy TV film thang or have their own record
labels or  specialty Techno shops. They                                
manage DJs, groups, or are graphic artists, that off course as             
a hobby design fliers. Some are promoters and DJs. 

Characteristics:        They hate ravers. Especially September Children.
Complain about the fashion, and cringe when they see
people on E who runs around raves holding hands. They
are never seen with a whistle. They go to big events
and then talk about how much they prefer the smaller                   
more "intimate" ones.  

Pros:           If you hang out with them enough, you get to be included in
the oh-so-exclusive-scenester crowd. You get to go to invite
only parties. You get free stuff.

Cons:           They never know what to do with their friends who continue
to be unashamedly     "RAVER." (Damn it I like my
pigtails, stickers, glitter AND I like the big events. :P
Suck my left nipple!! Baby!) They hate the people that
support them. Ungrateful bastards.


The GURU spiritualist

Where to find them:     All outdoor raves. In the desert, in the mountains.
The Full moon parties. 

How to spot one:        They look hippyish, but not quite. Real postmodern.
The hard core ones are doing tai chi at sunrise. 

Characteristics:        Herbal drugs! They love that stuff, not to confused
with the stuff on the market like herbal E. They are into
things I can't spell,bought in health food stores.. 
They talk about the energy, and focus, and stuff
like that. They try to find the Goddess somewhere in
the rave. At sunrise, or beach parties, the younger ones yell out          
exaltations, "Sun oh, sun! You have arrived!" or "The sea, I love          
you."

Pros:           They tell you what to eat and what herbal stuff is going to
help your high. If you're into it, you can go off in the search and swap
tips with each other. 

Cons:           Some people are just atheist, non-spiritual beings that are
there to have fun. On Sunday mornings, when they preach, you
wish you had a door to slam in their faces.

                __________________________________________________________

Fashion raver. (The most despicable off the lot.)


Unfortunately will be appearing more and more.

How to spot them:       You just know. They wear glitter, and hello kitty
back packs.Baggy jeans, Vans. The block print shirts.
In the DAY. They are so put together, you know they
haven't been dancing.

Where to find them:     In the mall. In your classroom. In the bank.
Wandering around somewhere. But NEVER NEVER NEVER at
any event.


Pros:   There are none.

Cons:           They are only wearing the stuff because they saw someone
else in them. They read a magazine, and it said that was
cool.They have no idea why you said "hello." They don't know what
the fuck you are talking about when you ask then where they
went on Saturday. They make you think you could actually
talk to them. 

Sample conversation: 

Raver: Hi
Fashion raver: err.
Raver: Where did you go this Saturday?
FR: Yeah, I went to a raving phat party, there were loads of people
scamming and three kegs.
R: ????
FR: We were hard core!
R: Uhuh, so em who's your favorite DJ?
FR: Howard Stern, and em  Adam Carolla on Love Line. I like Dr. Dru but he's 
not really a DJ.
 R: So you don't listen to techno do you?
FR: huh? That repetitive shit. It's so boring. 


:P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P :P
:P :P :P
                                Raver Chiqz

Subject: Re: SRR:  Happy Hardcore Question
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


>Anyway the first type I heard was this CD called "Happy 2b Hardcore."  It just
>sounded like diva house music sped up really fast, and it was super happy.

*kinda long.... *
        Ok... This is just my opinion... I've had to deal with a picky
Happy Hardcore dj, so that's biased my opinions a little ;) . Anyway.. the
HH on this cd tends to be a little cheesy.  Isn't it put out on Sm:)e or
Moonshine?  I tend to find that they like to put out a lot of cheesy songs
sometimes.  Not *all* the time, but sometimes on their big ol mass-produced
cd collections.  Anyway, the HH on this cd tends to be 4-beat style and has
a lot of diva and piano breakdowns.  Not totally the best HH has to offer
but a good sampling of it. I think Anabolic Frolic mixed this one?  Dj's
usually dont have any say on what tracks they mix when the cd is put out by
a big label.


>The second type I heard was a import CD compilation I just bought called the
>"Best of Happy Hardcore."  This sounded like jungle, as in there was hella
>breakbeat, but not as dark or angry as some jungle tends to be.  It had a more
>complex sound than "Happy 2b Hardcore," which is a little repetitive.
>

        When's the copyright year on this one?  Jungle and HH are cousins
of one another and the whole reasons Jungle came into being was the fact
that a lot of people were getting mad over the Cheesy 'Rave' music that was
being played back in 1992 or 1993??  That may be why it started sounding
darker, and it was getting away from the Children's song sounding tunes.  I
guess people got mad after everyone jumped on the bandwagon of children's
tunes and they just got plain repetitive and they were everywhere in the
scene back in the UK.  Anyway, HH can have a breakbeaty sound to it, and
songs that verge on the sounds of HH and Jungle.. or breakbeat as I guess
they called it back then, formed around that time.  I'm not really telling
you a good story right now cuz I just woke up from a nap.
        If you go to www.breaks.com  I think they have a history of jungle
on there and it talks about the 1992-93 era.. and tells you what songs and
artists and dj's were playin around that time.  It's a really good article.
I wrote a report on the history of Jungle music for a paper this past
semester and I found a lot of helpful facts out there on the net.  Check it
out... :)
        As for a good HH tape, I can tell you... go to
http://happy.hardcorps.org   and get a copy of Noahphex's new tape.  or
wait until I get back home and I can dub you a copy of his old tape... '
Sunny Days' by Muppetfucker.  Anyone that hates HH usually loves this tape.
Mixed well.  Enough promotion of my friends.. I'll go back to sleep!
Love Toy :)

------
http://happy.hardcorps.org/sunnye       lovetoy@ou.edu
                Toyacoyah Tha Pocahontas ravah
Occupation: College Student     Major: Music for Non-Majors

Saturday's listings go on forever...  With the good weather, there's more
outdoor events and camping events 'round now too.  A free party in the park
on Saturday is too good to resist (unless you're up in Shasta for the
Gaiamind party), then the On The One party, Abstract Science, and Pro-Soy
all caught my eye.  Crash Worship is certainly a unique experience if
you haven't seen them yet.  Catch either on Saturday in Oakland or Sunday
at the Trocadero...

                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
    
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, July 25th - Das Funk presents _Positive Force_
   Hype, Oliver, Jason Lee, Dan Aguilar, Mike, Dean Kroh, Karizma,
   M-Pact, Kaution, Henray, Costik, Episode, Rage.
   Dress code...strictly enforced. Security Provided.
   8pm- $6. Club Mistique, 7707 Murray Drive, Stockton. 209.615.3703
   209.889.3048

   DJ Silence, Jeremiah, Wizard, Tom, Ima.
   please bring warm clothing, blankets, good vibes, a flashlight and
   fresh water.
   10pm-10am, Free. 408.684.8899

   from those who brought U Hijack
   John Tejada (Palette), Marcus Miller (Cytrax), Sean Deason
   (Matrix/Detroit), Kit Clayton (One Track Mind), Paul Manley (One Track
   Mind), Big Lee.
   $5. 415.208.3418

   Visuals by Lite Brite.
   3-D laser beam light show by Extreme Beam.  Sound by Sonic Punch.

   Goldilox, Kenni, Mofo, Tom, Laron, Dave, Synthesis, PleasureMan,
   Galactic Dreamspell (live), Astral Matrix (live), Family Soul (live),
   Channel 23 (live), Gamma Quadrant (live), Soulstice (live), Karma
   Moffet (live), Baktun 13 (live), more....

   Bring your gear, food, musical instruments, everything you need.
   Mount Shasta area. 415.331.1500x722

   guests. 18+, $4. Blake's, 2367 Telegraph Ave, Berkeley.

   Diablo, Walnut Creek. 510.256.1200

   Perfect, Lauren, guests. 10pm-2am, 21+, Free. Liquid, 2925 16th @ S
   Van Ness, SF.
   
   _ElectroniKa_ - Spesh, Kimon, Gil. Visuals by Hyperdelic.Fantastic
   Vibe.
   5pm-9pm, Free. 111 Minna St, SF.

   donate.
   $7. 415.437.6905 510.674.8663

   weekly. 8pm-10pm, . City Espresso, 5237 stevens creek blvd, santa
   clara. 408.248.4500

   415.289.6897

   wednesday night/thursday morning after Come/Unity.

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Sunday night, 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Jungle/Drum and Bass, Dub and Hard Techno, along with guest DJs
       and interviews.  KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

Date: Thu, 24 Jul 1997 19:04:31 -0700 (PDT)
From: Matthew Alan Schwartz <thorfio@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Subject: Candyravers..my def:
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9707241806.A14668-0100000@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


So I've been raving for a little over a year now so you can take this 
message for what ever it's worth *8^)


In general, a Candy Raver could be described as one who dresses, and acts 
the part of a stereotypical raver at all the parties they go to. They 
wear bright flourescent and neon colors, baggy pants, tons of glow in the 
dark stuff, glitter, etc., and then the one thing that they get thier 
name from...they have tons of candy either in thier possesion or dangling 
from thier clothing somehow. They act in a very energetic, happy 
manner...always smiling, and running around trying to meet people in a 
flash, giving them candy and then taking right off again. They have a 
good intent of trying to keep the vibe of the party as positive as it 
could possibly be, but can be occasionaly annoying when you're having a 
bad time or just simply not feeling as happy as they are :P 

Now, when somebody mentions "candyraver," in thier sentence, they might 
not always be refering to exactly this defintion. Occasionally, 
"candyraver," might be used as a more negative term when someone is 
trying to refer to some younger-teen newbie who is most likely trying to 
fit in at his/her first rave but instead just ends up ruining everyone 
elses time as they overdose on GHB ;) ( it was an example...no flames 
please :P ) 

			OR...

As in Beth's (and my) case, you could say we're like candy-ravers, but 
you would be using the term more losely,. We have been raving for a 
while (therefore might be a little more at ease to go around and meet 
people at raves,) and we also enjoy dressing up for raves!, but you 
couldn't really call us by definition "Candyravers." And the only way to 
truely understand that is to go out and experience some Candyravers first 
hand, and then come and talk to us...

You'll notice the difference...granted it's not a big one :), but you 
will notice the difference.


Hope that helped

Stay Coool!

-Matt...the other one-

Well, I would just like to thank all of you guys who were sending me the
good vibes today.  I swear to god (or that there of), I could just feel
the vibes flowing from all around.  I did pretty good on my tests. (knock
on wood)  My big three hour long interview went very well.  In fact, it
seemed like one of the interviewers (a guy at that) who was giving me a
tour was hitting on me (too bad I'm not gay).  So anyways, the job is
practically mine since there were me and someone else be interviewed for
two jobs.  Another cool thing about this place is that it's right down
the road from the Berkeley Marina.  So if ever there's a Sunset, I can
just cruise on by.

Then I did my presentation in front of class pretty good.  I'm going to
assume I got a high B or low A.  Whatever's clever, I'm not a real big
art fan.

So I would just like to thank all of you because without you it wouldn't
happen.

Oh Yeah!!!  If you're going to True Love, stop by the waterfall/fruit
table sometime between 1 and 2:30 because I'll be chillin there workin'
the table.

Bye

It's too quiet in here.  Somebody say something!  Helllooooooo!  Where
is everybody?  I'm here.  It's Julie Mae and I'm waving to all of you
and jumping up and down because I'm happy as a butterfly.  (I know what
you are thinking, and I am not a candy-raver!)  For all of you who are
wondering why I'm a bit too much on the cheery side for a Thursday
night, let me just tell you...  I got my car back yesterday (haven't had
it since June 10th)... $3400 and a new engine later, I finally get to
come back out to the Bay Area and party!  Let me see, I've been to one
party since April... so by now, you'd be safe to assume I'm going
through withdrawals for all of you.  Oh, and I finished my summer
session college courses today!  Yay!  Three weeks off!  (Seeing as how I
had finals tonight and haven't slept since Tuesday night because I
pulled an all-nighter studying last night, I'd say part of this
cheeriness is resulting from the sleep-deprived delirium that set in a
few hours ago...)  Oh, and of course, we cannot forget that True Love is
this Saturday, and wouldn't you know it?  I'm going to be there!!!  More
on that tomorrow... Oh yeah, and did I mention that it is too quiet in
here?
                                   Smiling brightly,
                                                   Julie Mae

Oh, and yet another dose of the beautiful word:
"Knowing others is intelligence;
 knowing yourself is true wisdom.
 Mastering others is strength;
 mastering yourself is true power."
            ~ Lao-Tzu

From: edleech@juno.com (Ed Leech)

Precedence: bulk

hi 
ben and iris (jarmin@rocketmail.com) here on ed's email account

we haven't heard anything like what us brits would call current happy
hardcore around here. everything that we've come across here under the
label happy hardcore is at least 3 years old, sometimes going back to
when jungle and happy hardcore hadn't split into different types of music
and scenes yet. that's why old hardcore has some jungle beats in it. even
some of the stuff labeled 97 is old. people here aren't into the fast
stuff.
at freedom they were playing a tune that sounded familiar but not quite
right to us and then we realized that they were actually playing it at
the wrong speed (33 instead of 45).
happy hardcore has a 4/4/ beat and a lot of happy uplifting melodies and
lyrics (sometimes at chipmunk speed), 160-190 bpm, the old stuff may be
as slow as 140 bpm.
give us your address and we'll send you a tape or come to true love, find
us, and we'll give you one there (although we've only got the really hard
stuff left now)
or, even better, come to england and we'll take you to a rave, new years
eve maybe? some other people from sf might be coming. (this invitation is
open to all sfravers)
we'll be taking trance home w/ us.

iris + ben

writes:
>Hey, I've listened to 2 types of music that are both supposed to be 
>happy 
>hardcore, and I was wondering which one of them is _really_ happy 
>hardcore, or 
>if maybe they're both are happy hardcore, just different types of it 
>or 
>something like that . . .
>
>Anyway the first type I heard was this CD called "Happy 2b Hardcore."  
>It just 
>sounded like diva house music sped up really fast, and it was super 
>happy.
>
>The second type I heard was a import CD compilation I just bought 
>called the 
>"Best of Happy Hardcore."  This sounded like jungle, as in there was 
>hella 
>breakbeat, but not as dark or angry as some jungle tends to be.  It 
>had a more 
>complex sound than "Happy 2b Hardcore," which is a little repetitive.
>
>So which of these is true happy hardcore?
>
>And can anyone recommend some good happy hardcore CDs that I can buy?
>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org

as i was driving the usual meditative drive to work this morning i found
myself suffering from a new kind of DTs, the DTs that shake you when your
booty has been rockin to the same DnB grooves for the past several
months....and something must be done about this.

basically, to make a long story short, in the past 6 months i have become
mildly addicted to the drum and the bass that makes the peach fuzz on my
arms and the back of my neck get perpendicular.  and i have been listening
to the same 2 mix tapes of absolutely brilliantly dark twisted and evil
DnB.  they are terrific tapes (*plug* mixed by none other than superstar
djs science and re ach *plug*), but i am yearning for some new sounds, and
what better place to turn to than the "underground."  with all of you djs
out there, i was hoping that one of you or maybe even 2 or 3 would stoke me
on a new DnB mixtape.....

i shall erect an altar in your name(s) and forever worship you.  and maybe
even invite you to make a guest appearance on my radio show ;>

thanks in advance.

love,
lola

  Well... I am a candy raver.  And I do not take it as an insult.  Does this
go along with those *raver personality quizes* (is this you?) that went
around a while ago.  Are candy ravers really just all September children?
 I've been wondering lately if you could still classify the people in the
baggy pants and addidas candy ravers because their hair is slicked with
glitter gel and they are wearing a pacifier.  And I also had a conversation
with my friend and our non-rave going friend the other day.  He was asking us
about the attire and such and I realized the girls are the ones that have a
greater tendency to dress in the glittery clothes.  I just enjoy it.  If I
dressed like that everyday (aside from being a megga-phreak [which actually
wouldn't be that bad])  it would make going to raves less of a special event.
 Getting decked out and putting thought into my outfits is part of the
excitement.  It adds to the theme.  You don't have to dress that way and have
your parents wondering where they went wrong.  Just for me, the giving candy
and stickers is part of it all and if I piss people off because I"m always
happy, I'm sorry, but that's just the way I am.  Just a candyravers 2
blowpops....

       hugs n'Stuff,
            'trice the tekno diva               <<<<RAVEON>>>>

 The rythym has control.
 The rythym is inside me.
 The rythym has my soul."

P.S.  I will see you all at true love and I will be wearing my care bear
overalls, bubble necklace, laminates pacifier, chokers, glitter bracelets,
toys and enough candy and glitter to supply the rave community for a week.
 Say hi.. I don't bite.

be cool, but otherwise that ticket is free. The other ticket is for people
that want to eat the food we bring and is $10.  Meals are Saturday and
Sunday  breakfast, (pancakes, eggs, potatoes and fruit.  Also Saturday main
meal from noonish to sunset (ribs, chicken, burgers, hot dogs, veggie
burgers, veggie hot dogs maybe even meat and veggie spagehetti and
stir-fry...as well as the regular bbq side dishes and a softdrink or
something. There will be both meat and veggie friendly foods there so it
will please both groups of people. The spagehetti and stir-fry is up in the
air right now, but I'm trying my best to have it available.

So, if you'd like a ticket please call the VM above around 8pm tonight
(friday) to find out how to get them. If the message doesn't have any info
yet, just keep trying. It will be up no later then Saturday 3pm.

If you have any questions or want to know more about the tickets, please
feel free to ask.


Take care and thanks...

From: SCiEnCe <djscience@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Urb: made me laugh.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

When I first got down to San Diego in 1991, I soon found this wikid
zine called URB. It was hella big and came out on newspaper print. It
detailed pretty much everything that was goin on in S.Cal and was way
on top of things. Over the years, it went through many changes;
getting a glossy cover, featuring more and more mainstram-type
artists. Less personal focus on the scene which fostered its growth. 

Now I rarely ever read it. Although some of the articles are good,
it's just not the kind of vital info I'm looking for. The reviews are
cool, but usually about 2 months dated by the time the magazine
actually arrives in newstands.

Anyways, this week I needed some lunch-reading last week so I picked
up issue 54. Now it does have a pretty cool article on Kool Keith, and
a blurb on Single Cell Orchestra and Jason Mouse, but overall, I was
pretty dissapointed. The last straw came when I flipped through the
reviews and saw 2 records (central fire and dee patton) being reviewed
that were 3 or 4 years old! The reviewer (initials TCR which I assume
is Todd C Roberts the exec. editor) talks about them like they are
new, which I find really disconcerting, considering how long he's been
in the scene.

It made me laugh at myself for spending my money on it.

At least we have XLR8R which manages to do a pretty good job reporting
on an ever-increasing commercial scene with an underground edge.

-peace-

alex

>1. What is the best digital audio manipulating software available?

Dont mean to be Bias or anything, But Digidesigns ProTools in the best, IMHO.  Curretnly, its only on the Mac, so if you're buddy has a PC, I'd go for Cubase VST or Emagic Logic.  Both are Sequencers but have increadable audio editing features.

>2. Are there any software products out there that can change the pitch 
>of a wave file without altering the playing time?

Most Sample Editors will do this.  





Hugs, Diego

> >1. What is the best digital audio manipulating software available?
> Dont mean to be Bias or anything, But Digidesigns ProTools in the best, IMHO.
> 
> -=-=-=-=-=-snip=-=-=-=--=-=snip
> That's the best "AND" most expensive. :)

i wouldn't recommend protools - on either platform.  with that kind of 
sticker price, you could buy a good sampler, a dat, and a 
slidermaster...  if you need the digital editing, buy a scsi connector 
and hook up your k2k (which you can afford by not purchasing protools) to 
your computer.

> >1. What is the best digital audio manipulating software available?
> Curretnly, its only on the Mac, so if you're buddy has a PC, I'd go 
> for Cubase VST or Emagic Logic. 

avoid cubase for pc's - it's a great idea, but my experience has been 
that the damn thing crashes every 5 minutes.  it looked great on the mac 
though - i'd prolly buy it over protools on the mac...  from the little 
i've seen of emagic, it seemed like something by engineers, for 
engineers - slightly clinical...

=)
me

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


ooops... guess i should read the email addresses before replying...  
i don't mean to totally rail on protools, mark - it _is_ good at what it 
does - i just don't feel that the price tag is warranted.  and i'm 
interested in seeing what happens to digidesign when the wave of 
recording systems floods the market - is digidesign finally gonna drop 
their prices to compete?

also, it depends on whatcha wanna do - personally, i'm much more into the 
live/jam session feeling when i'm making music, and i feel that most 
sequencers have pitiful support in this area.  i'd rather lessen my 
production quality a little and gain some more realtime freedom and 
interaction.  for me, music is as much process as product, yet most 
software designers seem only concerned in the bottom line - the "what 
happens when i hit play" mentality of work-followed-by-reward.  why not 
be more concerned with what happens _while_ playing - of reward within 
work?  there's no reason to _not_ have instant (and increasing) 
gratification through music!

music as process is where its at... feedback loops, where there is no 
audience because everyone present affects the outcome.  not some 
orchestrated concert or album or static snapshot, but a continually evolving 
living experience.

-phil

alas, no.  The party is at a warehouse in Oakland, no presale tix.
Here's some basic info, including numbers, line-up and survival options.

It should be monumentally interesting to see the marriage of ravers and
burningpeople [since there won't be a rave at the burningman festival
this year :(]

Kate

         CRASH WORSHIP, MINOR MINOR, JENO, TRENT, JOSH, TRACY, TONY,
>
>          ROB DOTEN AND DUARTE 6
> Admission is $15 - free water
> Party goes BUST-FREE until 6:00 AM
> 415-263-4818   408-535-0404   510-287-8874

***CW Virgin Notes****
 CRASH SURVIVAL GUIDE!!!!!!

     a) bring minimal clothes that you don't care about wearing ever
again
     (cw is not usually a place where i care about my fashion
statements,
     naked is better, though there can be some flying sparks...)

     b) tribal paint or body glitter are nice

     c) bring water (to rinse yourself off with) and a complete change
of
     clothes in yoiur car

     d) no open toed shoes. yoiur feet will get stomped (even though i
     have noted that the crowd is usually supportive if yoiu fall over
or
     get pushed, there are always a couple troublemakers)

     e) earplugs are a good idea, and tie up your hair (it will be
soaked)

     f) remember, these notes are from a vetran, but just like burning
     man, i cannot guarantee anything will or will not happen (including

     orgy-like piles near the front of the stage.......)

     g) leave any sexual inhibitions at home. ;)

     * if you are seeing cw for the first time, i reccomend that even if

     you use drugs(or alcohol), you dont. reasons:

     1)it is very hot and dangerous, and unless you are over 6 foot 3,
it
     is so sweaty and cramped in the front, you will barely be able to
     breathe (even when sober)/ when you are on hallucionegens, you
won't
     be able to tell if you are being burned by flying sparks, or if it
     could be really harmful to you later.....

     2) it is almost impossible to carry a water bottle, and the wine
that
     is usually passed around will only dehydrate you.

     3) it's really cool to see what the show can be like sober...trust
me,
     it's an awseome "buzz" in itself.


general info:
Okay, I'm breaking my temporary vow of silence for a minute to try to
clarify  something.

Crash Worship (tribal party band from San Diego, blah blah y'all know
already) is playing *two* nights in the Bay Area at the end of the
month.

Sat., July 26 -- Location TBA (hint: it's on the CW Web site mentioned
by
Rebecca)
9pm - 6am, $15
Crash Worship ('round midnight) and lots of DJs
This is the gig Hernan posted about from the sfraves list.
Call for info:
415-263-4818
408-535-0404
510-287-8874

Sun., July 27 -- Trocadero, 520 4th St. @ Bryant, SF
Doors at 8pm, $10
Crash Worship and Duarte 6
Tickets at BASS (ssss), some SF record shops, and www.ticketweb.com

It might be fun if lots of folks showed up at the Troc on the 27th in
their
wigs and muumuus. . .

And for you non-Bayareans, here's the rest of their tour schedule (call
to
confirm):

Matthew Alan Schwartz wrote:
> 
> So I've been raving for a little over a year now so you can take this
> message for what ever it's worth *8^)
> 
> In general, a Candy Raver could be described as one who dresses, and
> acts
> the part of a stereotypical raver at all the parties they go to. They
> wear bright flourescent and neon colors, baggy pants, tons of glow in
> the
> dark stuff, glitter, etc., and then the one thing that they get thier
> name from...they have tons of candy either in thier possesion or
> dangling
> from thier clothing somehow. They act in a very energetic, happy
> manner...always smiling, and running around trying to meet people in a
> flash, giving them candy and then taking right off again. They have a
> good intent of trying to keep the vibe of the party as positive as it
> could possibly be, but can be occasionaly annoying when you're having
> a
> bad time or just simply not feeling as happy as they are :P
> 
> Now, when somebody mentions "candyraver," in thier sentence, they
> might
> not always be refering to exactly this defintion. Occasionally,
> "candyraver," might be used as a more negative term when someone is
> trying to refer to some younger-teen newbie who is most likely trying
> to
> fit in at his/her first rave but instead just ends up ruining everyone
> elses time as they overdose on GHB ;) ( it was an example...no flames
> please :P )
> 
>                         OR...
> 
> As in Beth's (and my) case, you could say we're like candy-ravers, but
> you would be using the term more losely,. We have been raving for a
> while (therefore might be a little more at ease to go around and meet
> people at raves,) and we also enjoy dressing up for raves!, but you
> couldn't really call us by definition "Candyravers." And the only way
> to
> truely understand that is to go out and experience some Candyravers
> first
> hand, and then come and talk to us...
> 
> You'll notice the difference...granted it's not a big one :), but you
> will notice the difference.
> 
> Hope that helped
> 
> Stay Coool!
> 
> -Matt...the other one-
OK I like this definition best

__________________________________________________
> 
> The Candy Raver (north cal), Club kid (Socal)  Geographically
> different
> terminology.
> 
> Where you spot them: Everywhere in the scene.
> 
> How to spot them: You can't really miss them can you? In the 7 inch
> foam
> platforms.Incredible makeup, wigs, fluffy flurry
> jackets, lots of lights and glow things hanging of
> them.  Glam Glam Glam. Not in addidas because that's
> sporty! Don't forget PLASTIC, is the word. They are wearing
> clothes and holding things that are great when you're feeling tactile.
> 
> What they are not:      Drag queens! They are fantastic creatures of
> the
> night that have no gender indentity.
> 
> Pros:   They are so fun to look at! Some of them, have the most
> interesting
> lifes. Go talk to       Trixie who spent some months meditating in a
> budist
> temple in Asia. If you are one, you get in free to events. Sometimes
> you get paid to go to them.
> 
> Cons:   When you're their friend, it's hard to get to talk to them,
> because
> everyone else is trying to do the same. They are so visible that
> everyone comes by to say "hello."
> 
> How they start out:     That sticker thing! The glitter, the sesame
> street,
> soft toys bak packs, teddy bears,  PACIFYERS.

This is totally incorrect. It should read like so:

Candy Raver: North Cal & So-Cal

Where you spot them:      Everywhere in the scene. Usually its at
underground in the SF Scene and they are everywhere in So-Cal.

How to spot them:      You can't really miss them can you? In the
colorfully furry pants, or one of the million of bell bottoms with
triangle inserts of so cartoon character fromt he 80's (ie: care bears,
rainbow bright, popples, smurfs, scoobie doo, yoggie, sesame
street),incredible ammounts of gilitter and stickerss,puffy vests, lots
of florescnet necklaces and braclets and a huge wallet chain made of
some kid stuff (blocks, bears, toys) hanging of them.  Hugs Hugs Hugs.
Not in addidas because that's sporty (unless they have furry triangle
inserts).Never tight plastic pants! They are wearing
clothes and holding things that are great when you're feeling tactile.

What they are not:      CLUB KIDS!!! They are fantastic creatures of
the night that have a slight gender indentity that can only be
understood if you are one or know the person.

Pros:   They are so fun to look at! Some of them, have the most 
interesting lifes. Go talk to Trixie who spent some months meditating in
a budist temple in Asia. If you are one, you get in free to events.
Sometimes you get paid to go to them. They have already met everyone at
the rave in a matter of seconds.

Cons:   When you're their friend, it's hard to get to talk to them,
because everyone else is trying to do the same. They are so visible that
everyone comes by to say "hello." They are constantly persecuted by the
Hardcore Kids in the So-Cal scene. They are broked cuz they always spend
their money on clothes, jewelery, or toys.

How they start out:     All it takes is one sticker then its all down
hill from then.

___________________________________________

Club Kid:

Where you spot them:   Everywhere in the scene.

How to spot them: You can't really miss them can you? In the 7 inch foam
platforms. Incredible makeup, faux eyelashes that are a mile long, wigs,
feather boas, tight plastic or lycra pants. Glam Glam Glam. Don't forget
PLASTIC, is the word.

What they are not:      CANDY RAVERS!!! They are fantastic creatures of
the night that have no gender whatso ever.

Pros:   They are so fun to look at! Some of them, have the most 
interesting lifes. Go talk to Trixie who spent some months meditating in
a budist temple in Asia. If you are one, you get in free to events.
Sometimes you get paid to go to them. They can spot anyone in a mile
radius since they are the tallest person there.

Cons:   When you're their friend, it's hard to get to talk to them,
because everyone else is trying to do the same. They are so visible that
everyone comes by to say "hello." Some of them (not all are so into what
they look like to even pay attention to you.

How they start out:     All it takes is 2 inches of foam on your shoe
and its all down hill from then.

__________________________________________________

-Paul

I never really thought of myself a candy raver until people had been
refering to me as one. I was just dressing up to have fun. It is fun to
dress up. But I think its more than dressing up. Its the type of
attitude you have, because if you think your better than everyon else
just because your dressed up colorfully, that is th wrong attitude for
candy ravers. It not about competition, its about bringing in a positive
vibe with the way you are dressed and your pos. attitude of thinking
yoursefl to be on an equal level with all those not dressed as
colorfully. Just because you wear a lot of necklaces doesn't make you a
candy anything. it just makes you a happy raver. And there nothing wrong
with being that at all.

Love,
Paul

  Hey everyone, I haven't posted in so long that today I thought I'd wear out
my limit.  What is it again?  Five posts? Three?  anyways, I figure True Love
is going to be a big SFR fest and I wanna meet you all!  Yay (this would be
the candy raver/ september child aspect of my personality) I Love you and you
are all such beautiful people!  Look for my overalls n'stuff.
Ok.. and on the personality note... I was thinking about the *trendy raver*
and how I so dislike anyone who tries to be something they are not.  With
this contempt in mind I was sifting through trend city (a.k.a. the mall)
 Disgusted with some of the people and clothes hanging about (although I did
find this cool $5 sequin top) I left.  So back at my friend's house I find a
Delia's catalog on her kitchen table.  Whatever.. I'll look through it.  They
not only have their fall line of artificial snowboard wear.  (c'mon, I know
some of you know what I"m talking about.. it's a five-letter word, starts
with pose?) But they also have some chicks modeling baggy jeans with a *SPIN*
hooded sweatshirt and all sorts of shoulder bags.  Then come the girls with
the Japanamation shirts and the Keropi back-packs and I"m thinking.. this is
so the *trendy-never-been-to-a-rave-but-look-like-I-have* person.  That's
about the time I got really disgusted and went home.  ANyways.. that is my
dissapointment for the day.. but I know going to true love tomorrow will make
me happy and I will get to see all you true ravers who love techno.  Whew..
that was a long bunch of bullshit.  see you all soon!

            hugs n'stuff,
              'trice the tekno diva                <<<<RAVEON>>>>

'trice & others,

Don't be too harsh on the
*trendy-never-been-to-a-rave-but-look-like-I-have* folks.

There is an eliminate of poser in us all.

I remember my supreme indignation just last year when Macy's windows
downtown were FULL of raver fashion.  Macy's CAN NOT KNOW WHAT IT IS TO
BE A RAVER!  

At that same time there was a HEATED debate about how great it would be
when rave culture became mainstream, (we should promote it so that every
dancehall in America was a rave,) and what a beautiful world it would be
vs. shhh!: lets keep it our secret underground 'thang.

I really like the underground thing, but I am also grateful to be able
to walk amongst my community of "straights" and not be sneered at
because of my "ravish" wardrobe.

My closet is already too full of my sex kitten (poser!)outfits, jammed
right next to my (poser) business suits, and squished between that is my
(poser)sailing gear plastered with major labels, my (poser)mommy togs
and ballet wear.  (boy, talk about a poser, that's me in ballet class!)

I have a special place for my too-expensive-but-good-poser-wear-Oakly
shades.  You know the ones that have no warranty on their $140.00 (not
even scratch resistant) lenses?

Diana

here's how i see it:
yeah there are tonsa kids running around full "rave gear" on
but we're the ones that know in our hearts what the scene is about 
and the music is the our passion
the love is our passion
and they're OURS to keep and only WE know about it and appreciate it..
and that's what counts most, right?
so let everyone wear whatever they want, even let kids who don't go to 
parties say "yea i rage" or "raves? never been but i want to"
that's their freedom of speech or whatever.
the fashion isn't exactly all the scene is made up of..
as long as they don't destroy our passions..
it's all good :)
keep the vibe alive and keep it UG eh? ;)
xo
lara

High class!

Todays project involves burning steel, gas/alcohol and flame. 

We are providing this for informational purposes only!

First construct a box of the steel mesh they use for hamster cages. Keep 
that cute little door cause you gotta fill the insides with 000 grade 
steel wool.(Home Depot)

Now connect a steel wire or chain to each of two corners. Sorta like a 
purse strap. Bring the opposite ends together and connect them to a 
steel cable.

Fill the box with 000steel wool. Soak with whatever flammable liquid 
works for you. Soak being the operative term.

light twirl in circles make fire art.

This is extremely dangerous. You will get burned. People nearby will be 
burned. My advice is not to try it.

Hernan...pyro with all 10 fingers and no skin grafts.

'trice & others,

Don't be too harsh on the
*trendy-never-been-to-a-rave-but-look-like-I-have* folks.

There is an element of poser in us all.

I remember my supreme indignation just last year when Macy's windows
downtown were FULL of raver fashion.  Macy's CAN NOT KNOW WHAT IT IS TO
BE A RAVER!  

At that same time there was a HEATED debate about how great it would be
when rave culture became mainstream, (we should promote it so that every
dancehall in America was a rave,) and what a beautiful world it would be
vs. shhh!: lets keep it our secret underground 'thang.

I really like the underground thing, but I am also grateful to be able
to walk amongst my community of "straights" and not be sneered at
because of my "ravish" wardrobe.

My closet is already too full of my sex kitten (poser!)outfits, jammed
right next to my (poser) business suits, and squished between that is my
(poser)sailing gear plastered with major labels, my (poser)mommy togs
and ballet wear.  (boy, talk about a poser, that's me in ballet class!)

I have a special place for my too-expensive-but-good-poser-wear-Oakly
shades.  You know the ones that have no warranty on their $140.00 (not
even scratch resistant) lenses?

Diana

Okay... So, are you surprised by this?  Every underground fashion becomes
mainstream and exploited at some point in its career.  And that fashion is
always based on the music of the people.

	*50's R & B
	*60's Freedom Rock
	*70's Disco Inferno
	*80's New Wave & Industrial/Goth

The nighties have probably had more fashion exploitations than all three
previous decades combined.  It's been easy.  There are enough of us
"alternative hipsters" now to break it into a whole bunch of convenient
little categories.  Gangster Rap.  Hip-Hop.  Grunge.  Punk.  Raver.  And
I'm sure that somebody, somewhere is still exploiting the old classic
trends of the past, too.

Ravers have not been around forever and their fashions developed from those
which preceded them.  Ever notice how someone going to a rave and someone
going to a hip-hop show can look an awful lot alike?  Where do you think
those baggy pants came from, anyway?  Personally, I think it's all started
to look very much the same.

But don't stress over this issue too much.  It won't be long before the new
underground trend comes around.  And you can bet that it, too, will
eventually show up at the mall.  You might even learn that the stuff
probably started out at the mall before it made it to the underground.
FILA... ADIDAS... TOMMY HILLFIGER... NIKE ...  The list goes on and on.  A
trend is a trend is a trend.  Why should rave fashion be held any more
sacred than any other trends?

Thanks and I hope everyone has a lovely evening.
Be Safe.
-Megan

"If I have seen farther than you,
it is by standing on the shoulders of giants" - Sir Isaac Newton

"The world of the unknown must always be respected."



adam mednick wrote:

> I've been in the uk for close to a week now.  Where is the
underground that everyone is talking about?  I was at the blue note
last week, and I spent two nights this week at club 414.  The music
was phenminal, but the vibe was.... missing.  Now don't get me wrong. 
I've met loads of nice people here, and at clubs as well.  But It's
nothing like back home.  In SF, the rave scene and the club scene is
two different worlds.  Different music, different people, differnt cup
of tea.  The "Undergound" of sf is a tight knit community of people
working together for what we call PLUR.  This is something that the uk
has seemed to have forgotten about.  For the UK people, plur stands
for Peace, Love, Unity and Respect.  It is a motto that we try to live
by.  When you go to an undergound event in SF, you are always
surrounded by smiles.  You are always welcome. You are accepted.  You
always see people that you know, but you also always meet new
wonderful faces.  Here, It seems that Unity i!
> s a bit iffy.  Love is only for those w/ girlfriends and boyfriends,
and Respect?  I have recieved it only from some.
> 
> I have a theory.  Electronic music, dancing, etc. is mainstreem here
in London.  Everyone and their uncle listens to house, drum & bass,
etc.  They play it in their cars, barber shops, pubs...everywhere.  
> 
> Is this the direction the SF scene is heading too?  Is it
inevitable?  The dilution of our precious scene?  
> 
> I'm sure the underground is here too, but where?  If anyone knows,
please drop me a line.
> 
> I'm having a fantastic time here in Brittain, i'm meeting lots of
nice people, (and staying w/ them) and I love it here.  But (and
please exceuse the velveeta) my heart is in San Francisco.  Always.
> 
> I love my scene.  I love my music.  I love my community.  
> 
> PLUR!  everybody.  please never forget.
> 
> --adam--
> 
> 
>
