Okay, so this will be my first weekend in the Bay area in too damn
long.  I'm leaving in the morning on my first road trip with the new
engine in my car!  Yay!  So, I think I've put it out there loud and
clear that I will be at TRUE LOVE tomorrow night, and that I'll be
making up for my missed birthday at it!!!  So I want to meet all of you
that I haven't met already.  I don't have my laminate anymore, as I
donated it to a new SFRaver back when I unsubscribed and they
subscribed. Now, wasn't that nice of me?  But now they are gone, and my
laminate is gone, and I'm back on!  Go figure!  So Orson, if you read
this, please put one aside for me!!!  Pretty please!  Okay, but until I
get a new laminate, I'll probably wear my Warmth 2 or Symbiosis
laminate, so you'll still know who I am.  By the way, I'll be wearing
cute little low-slung jean shorts with a blue bare-midriff sleeveless
mock turtleneck and white heeled sandals.  Oh, and I have long wavy
chestnut hair and big blue eyes, the color of which you may not be able
to see because my eyes might be too dilated! Oh, and except for the
heels, I'm quite petite (5'2"). And last but not least, I will probably
be wearing some glowy stars next to my eyes, carrying around a plain
black backpack full of not-so-plain stuff, and I'll be one of the ones
with the ear-to-ear grins all night.  But then again, won't we all...
Someone will need to volunteer to massage my facial cheeks, because they
will be so tight from smiling too much all night... LOL.  Anyway, I hope
to see all your beautiful faces on such a beautiful night!
                                 Smiling,
                                       Julie Mae
                          (the one, the only SmileGrl1)
Thought for the day:  You are never given a wish without also being
given the power to make it true.

   For all the people that can be recognized as "customers" when they go 
to a coffee house for a double vietnamese non fat mexican mocha ,oh and 
extra hot, The facts that go on behind the counter just are not shown to 
you folks.  Why do silly day programs called soap operas take places in 
hospitals and funeral homes when they could just film at a coffee shop?
   The other day I was with a couple of friends, one who likes Days Of 
Our Lives and the other just thinks it is so incredibly dumb now he's 
hooked and during that episode, there was a nun who was trying to 
persuade her twin sister (who is actually the same actress, creative 
huh?) to do the "good religious thing"  The actress has the same part of 
her lip snarled so high up that it almost touches her nose, with both 
characters.  My point with this example of almost dual personalities is 
this: The coffee shops are almost entirely ruled by these dual 
personality peoples, I refer to this sort of person as a Gemini.  I'd 
say 3/5 coffee personel are of the Gemini sign, the rest are either way 
whacked in the head, gay(nothing wrong with that) or homeless and wont 
tell the boss.  
    The customer usually sees the happy gemini and the pleasant whacked 
workers trying their best to satisfy them, but uh-oh, watch out because 
if whatever is going on behind the counter comes out in front with the 
customer, consider it a soap.  
    Last night, my friend Sarah came in to my shop and I took my break 
(fourth, actually) I was smoking my cancer stick and telling her that 
all cafe workers should have electrode type thingies attatched to our 
heads with TV monitors up above displaying all that is going through our 
warped minds.  To be honest we would probably lose a lot of clientel but 
at the same time, we would gain the entire viewing audience of Days of 
Our Lives...It would be well worth it I think.
                                    Lotsa Love,
                                       Danny

        trust : updates                               7/25/97

        Our last full-scale event, surrender, was a huge success, thanks
to everyone who contributed to make it such a beautiful experience.  We
ended up loosing us a bunch of money, due to lack of donations.  So we
are going to be putting together some smaller benefit events in the next
few months.  They will be friday night outdoor renegades in the bay area,
and will be denoted as 6.x.  Hopefully we will make back the $4000 we
lost on the surrender, before our next large event planned for spring
98.

        We are exploring many themes for the 6.x series, which will
include an ambient experience in the forest, hardtrance and acid, drum
and bass, and a deep deva disco house torture night.  =)

        Please help to keep the donation and shareware based events in
existance, we are going all out to provide beautiful events at any cost.
We hope to continue offer them relying on free-willed support from
everyone.

        We are going to be using mostly word of mouth, and internet
promotion for these events, to reduce costs.  point your browser at:
www.immersivearts.org, or stay in contact with the underground to learn
all the details as they evolve.


--------------------------

trust donation fund 7.0:

for the 6.x series events, our overhead is:
promotion:  $50.00
gas (for truck and generator):  $100.00

We are also in debt $4000.00 for our last large-scale event: surrender

We have recently started a dedicated permaculture fund, that will
hopefully grow to cover costs for a small eco-rave-village.

All surplus donations go to purchase new and better equipment...

We have recently purchased 2 cyberlights, a controller, and all neccesary
cables and cases.   Total cost approx: $19,000

our next purchase is:
2 electro-voice MT-4L.

These state of the art subwoofers provide 1,600 watts continuous power
per side...  an amazing 5,600 watts peak per side.   the cost of this
equipment is:  $6000.00

Equipment we plan on purchasing in the near future:
2 MT-4H (high box, companion to the MT-4L subwoofer)
4 terrorstrobes
2 more cyberlights

Thanks for your support...  Our (meaning all of our) events will continue
to thrive and grow.

-trust-

----------------------

The Shareware Concept

        In computer software the term "shareware" is used to describe
software that you may use before you pay for it.  This creates a trust
between the creator of the software and the end user, as the software
works whether you pay for it or not.
        We feel that this is an excellent way to throw parties as well.
Instead of charging for our events, to pay our overhead, and work towards
purchasing new equipment, we ask for what the attendees thaught the event
was worth.  this allows the ravers to experience and analyze the event
without having to pay for it first.  it also destroys the possibility of
paying $20 for a horrible event, while opening up the possibility to give
generously, knowing exactly where the funds will go.
        As this concept has not been tested very heavily in the rave
community, many people are unfamiliar with it.  We realize that it may
not work, and we will be forced to charge for our events.  We hope that
this is not the case, and that you, the ravers, will support the
shareware concept, and donate what the event you attended was worth.

------------------------

        trust : NO ATTENDEES ALLOWED

        This and all of our events are based upon particiapation.  When
there is even one person that is not contributing, there is a drainage in
the creative flow, that restricts the attainable energy level.  Our goal
is to raise that energy level by encouraging individual contributions.

        Particiapation comes in many forms, but the primary step is in
the mental picture of the event.  When one views the gathering as a
collective effort, where everyone involved (inculding themselves) is a
vital piece of the whole, an interconnected web is created linking
everyone.  When this interconnectedness is visualized by the whole, it
becomes very real, and nearly unbreakable from outside forces.

        After the relationship between you and the rest of the
particiapants has been established, the focus should move on to personal
creative desires.  All creative outlets you would like to contribute are
encouraged, whether it be providing decorations, singing, photography,
screaming for the acid builds, whatever, please bring/do it.

        As with all underground events there is the possibility of being
visited by people who think what we are doing is wrong and it should
stop.  These people will usually look for the "person in charge", in an
attempt to focus thier destructive energies on this person.  Within our
interconnected web there is not one person responsible, but many people,
everyone is responsible.  You may be approached by such an authority
figure, and you should be prepared to acknowledge your involvement, and
point out everyone else as sharing this responsibility.

        If you would like to contribute to these events, we would love to
have your energies there.


We love you!

  trust

[[sorry, i can't think of anything *more* rave related than techy
discusions about making music -- they don't call it techno for nuthin,
ya know?]]

So what do you all use for MIDI sequencing and audio? (esp synchronized
audio and midi??).

I use Cakewalk Pro Audio 6.0 (http://www.cakewalk.com), but that's just
because i've been using it and upgrading it for very little money since
about 1988. I kind of hate it, mostly because it usually crashes my
computer right around the time i got something good going. i keep on
thinking about trying something else, but i haven't felt like spending
money on cubase or emagic -- i prefer spending it on hardware because
at least with hardware, i can make some noize while my computer is
rebooting :-). Strangely enough, I've been more productive w/ the
braindamaged hardware sequencer on my MC-303 (or my Yamaha SY77) than i
have been in Cakewalk because invariably something goes  wrong or i get
sidetracked figuring out why something isn't working. In fact, if it
weren't for my need to store the gobs of controller data spewed out
when analoguing with my JP8000, i'd probably be perfectly happy w/ a
hardware sequencer.

I wish someone produced a music-making package that didn't suck (on
Linux, preferably, so it didn't crash every time you sneeze). Something
that supported the process of making dance music, as opposed to
orchestrating a bunch of wank for a GM synth card. Cakewalk and it's
ability to deal w/ music as "clips" seems like the right approach, but
its UI is just not quite there yet to make things foolproof and easy,
and neither is the reliability when you're sending out synchronized
digital audio along-side yer MIDI. 

I've seen Protools being used and it looks great but i'm not about to
go out and buy a Mac, and i'm waiting for things to stabilize in
MMX/pentiumville before i go off and buy a PCI-bus computer that'll
support all the new multichannel audio cards such as Event electronics
Darla/Gina/Layla...I currently have a 120Mhz pentium laptop and a
docking station with ISA slots for my Zefiro Acoustics ZA2 audio card
(http://www.zefiro.com) and a parallel port for my MOTU Midi Timepiece
AV).... my opinion is that the PC digital audio workstation concept is
still in its proof-of-concept stage right now, so putting anything
other than a minimal number of $$$ into such a system would be very
disappointing -- you'd be up to your neck in bugs and incompatibilities
and upgrades and crashes.

Sounds like us Sfraves music-makers ought to get together sometime
and jam, or talk, or share, or whatever.

PS: any of y'all have an opinion on MIDI gear i could use to do that
stuttering type gating (transforming) your hear on a lot of classic
techno. Yeah, I could try hammering the volume controller on my EMU
EIIIxp but that's not particularly easy to sequence. On the other hand,
there's the $1200 LA Audio MIDI Gate, which lets you gate/VCA 16
channels of  audio via midi note on/off (much easier to
sequence/synch), but it's  pretty expensive and kinda overkill. Then
there's the Presonus DCP-8 (8 channels, less money), but I'm not sure
if you can level control it quickly enough to get a transformer type
sound. What do you all use? Anybody know where I can pick up an LA
Audio MIDI Gate (or DCP-8) used?

forgot one thing w/r/t the original topic of discussion, which seemed
to be more oriented towards digital audio editing/tweaking/stretching/etc.

Check out Sound Forge 4.0 -- very complicated program, kinda expensive
for a piece of PC software, but it looks like it'll do just about
anything anybody could ever want w/r/t sound editing and processing.

If I keep on having the troubles I've been having with Cakewalk Pro
Audio 6.0's digital audio editing, I may be purchasing it myself one of
these months. Also, check out Syntrillium's Cool Edit Pro.

>From: Paulie824@aol.com
>Date: Sat, 26 Jul 1997 10:29:10 -0400 (EDT)

>Subject: Moo Cow Corn Review
>Sender: mw-raves-owner@hyperreal.org

>
>well... this was our first party,  and it started late.... our tables were
>late showing up... the first room tables showed up at 9:30 and the second
>room tables at 10:30... Justin Long showed up before we opened and offered to
>play since he was in town for his girlfriends birthday.... he bitched at us
>because we would only guest list one person out of the the 3 he wanted on
>it.... he didn;t come back.... oh well... better get to what happened
>inside.... we had to do multiple sound checks... the main mixer didn;t
>respond to the transmitted signal for a while... took no time to fix because
>of French-e... the live pa (Xanthous) had to do a sound check.... that was a
>mess... the signal was everywhere... French-e did a great job to get it
>somewhat level.... the Dj's about gave me a heart attack... they were all
>late... the doors opened at 11:00 (an Hour late) and still no sound from the
>second room.... we had problem after problem with that room... the system was
>provided free by the site... all peavey... one problem... we had no
>compatable cables for anything.... we were using the sites sound systm fo the
>second room and it wasn't compatable with it's self...  finally Seth and
>Frecnh-e got it up... only one speaker out of the 2 stacks...  okay... that
>was the problems... everything went smooth from the opening (in the first
>room anyway) second was just local talent
>
>cylert from St. Louis opened, wow... he was good... i was really happy we
>booked him, BTW way Cylert email me privately good hard techno and hard
>acid... i loved it...
>
>next was fishead... he dropped the hardcore on Louisville... he had people
>dancing all through his set... i was actually surprised (pleasantly) that
>Louisville liked hardcore... he spun a good set
>
>Xanthous was next.... except for their levels being weird every once in a
>while and a equipment failure (their sequencer stopped and decided to reboot
>itself 45 minutes into their set... the really had the crowd moving or a
>while....
>
>Dan Efex came on next... he was amazing as usual.... blasting the trance and
>Louisville at eit up like a hooker with her pimp's pouch.... i loved his
>set....
>
>French-e spun for about 30 minutes after dan.... this might his last time
>spinning in the US people... he is a really good techno/trance dj... first
>time i heard him spin... i was really surprised...
>
>Nitro.... this kid is fucking amazing.... i would say he is the best house Dj
>in the Midwest without a doubt... and man can he scratch.... he is just
>amazing.... the crowd loved him as well....
>
>J-sun finished up the party with a cool little weird ambient set... i enjoyed
>it alot... so did the people that hung around...
>
>well... we threw a $10 party because we knew people wanted cool low priced
>parties with good vibe.... we had a very good vibe inside... the price was
>low... and unfortunatly so was the attendance... we needed 500 people to
>break even at Moo Cow Corn... we got about 200.... we lost 3 grand....  but
>we paid everyone.... well almost everyone... cylert disappeared after his
>set.... send me you addy... you check is waiting....
>
>we still had a great time.... even though we lost mad cash... it just goes to
>show that the music is what it is bout... not the size of the party, i
>figured we would lose money, seeing as how it is our first party... they
>never break even it seems... but i thought more people would show.... no of
>our voice mail ines from other cities had anything about Moo Cow Corn at all
>on it...  oh well... shit happens :)
>
> i spent the night being angry, confused, sad, and eventually happy....  i
>was angry because we got such a low turn out... the more i thought about it
>the more i wondered and got confused.... we all sat around in shock and
>depression for a little while....  then we said fuck it... it ain't about
>money... we just had a great time after that.... and yes we we all sober...
>unlike our police officers we had for security.... they confiscated beer and
>walked around the rest of the night drinking it....
>
>overall i think Moo Cow Corn was a great party, so we lost a little money...
>we expected to.... (not that much of course)... the people that showd we
>great.... the Dj's we great... everyone had a good time... if they didn;t
>like a Dj they would go to the arcade room and play games... (this was part
>of the site, it is a Lazer Blaze... had a cool dance floor too) most peole
>danced the night way it seemed... except for the peole that pay and sit
>outside all night.... oh well....
>
>for those of you who came out and supported our first event thank you very
>much, for thos e of you who didn;t.... you missed a good party with a great
>price, your loss i guess... the evening had it it's ups and downs, but
>overall we (brand x prductions) chalked this up as a great party... judging
>by the responses people told us....
>
>anyone who was at Moo Cow Corn please post a review, we at Brand X
>Productions would like to know in what areas we can improve i to make a
>smoother party for our next event... which will continue to be low cost and
>high quality
>
>peace
>
>paulie
>

right when you make the left. - Go all the way down  - Look for Brick
Building on left hand side between 11th and 12th..

down to you see 12th on you right - Make right on 12th - Go up to 18th
- Brick building is on your left when you hit stop sign.

It is 3:42 a.m. and I just got back from True Love.  My boyfriend and I had
to leave early to spend some lovey, couple time together.  The ceremony was
INCREDIBLE.  The most real and touching ceremony I have ever seen.  The
love was felt everywhere, flowing over everyone.  The ring bearer was
adorable in glow-in the blaclight colors with a gorgeous ring pillow.  The
bridesmaids were darling little faries scatter good will, light, and love.
The bride was lovely in her flowing white gown, and the groom was eqully
lovely in his feather boa.  I have to say a special "hi" to Dave (I think
that's his name), the usher in orange who gave everyone a big ol' kiss as
they went out.  You are the coolest.  The most special moment came before
the ceremony when Laura read a deeply heartfelt speech.  A tear came to
everyone's eyes when she broke down with emotion.  It was an amazingly
beautiful experience, and I thank you for allowing us to share in it Amanda
and Dustin.  I think the ceremony bodes well for an amazing existence
filled with laughter, friends, happines, and (always) TRUE LOVE. . .

My boyfriend, Mac, would like to say something now. . .

i reiterate everything that robin stated.  As well, i'd just like to say
that this ceremony moved me (and everyone there, i believe) in such
wonderful, positive, love-affirming, and life affirming manners.  the
sharing of love, pure love the real thing, was felt by all and sent back at
the beautiful couple.  i'd like, as well ,  to thank all the spectators for
really feeling, really loving and really caring.

and one more from robin. . .

to all who were there: I feel a special bond with you, like we have
witnessed something special and great which has bound us all togehter.
Peace, happiness, and TRUE LOVE to you all. . .

Robin

Hi Everybody-

Sitting here eating an early scramble slam from denny's, I just have to say
that last night was incredible.  I don't think I could possibly sum up the
amount of love in the room when the wedding was taking place.  Hey even the
amount of love before and after the ceremony was incredible.  It was great
seeing everybody I knew, and meeting a ton of new people(way too many to
put into an email).  Special thanks + congrats go out to Amanda and Dustin
(who I finally met) for allowing all of us to be part of this special event
in their lives.  It definitely was true love :)

Now if I can only get some sleep without that music in my head distracting
me too much...

-Todd Manley

Todd,

I know what you mean about the music in your head going on and on!

What a LOVE-filled night!

Crash Worship crashed.  Jeno and Friends ripped! (talk about PLUR; it
was all over the house at 2nd & Jackson in Oakland!  Gangsta's, old
skool raverz, candy-ravers, freaks, goths, metalheads, trash,
princesses, and creeps COEXISTED so PEACEFULLY AND RESPECTFULLY in that
far-too-overcrowded-venue with limited free water.

True Love was loving.  I witnessed your set, & Uncle Noah's set.  Very
stimulating! (Especially for the dude on the bad acid trip...)  I
missed  Amanda & Dustin's nuptials; but the vibe amongst the kids in the
house afterwards was TRUE LOVE!  I don't think I have _ever_ experienced
such a collection of truly happy and considerate ravers!  (Folks, that's
saying something!)

CHI/Universal Fire: Again.  Yet another very happy, wonderful rave
experience!!!!!  What the hell is going on?  Did the Magic Fairy
sprinkle the entire BAY Area with only the best, or was it just the end
of the millennium washing all the regular negative shit from our
essences as predicted?  I fell in lust listening to ???? spin his
happiness.  And it was good.  Very good.

Came home.  Music thrumming trough my system.  Whip up a soy smoothie. 
Release feet from shoes.  Sleep.

I love you all so very much!

But that's me these days,

Diana Greer the converted cynic wearing a sticker on my cast.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Satori and our scene in General(long)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

      First off this is semi-negative and very long. Both of which are not my
fortays. Please read then re read this. I am not trying to initiate anythign
here. If you have a bone to pick, e-mail me PRIVATELY. thanks.......


      I went to Satori last night and came to some serious conclusions. I am
a gumpy old, burned out, raver!!!=( 
    I just don't feel the same way I did when I first started going to
parties. I'm not collecting flyers like a maniac. I'm not dancing my ass off!
Did I lose the love? Did I go thru a phase? OR am I just sick and tired of
the scene in general?
     There are a bunch of reasons why I didn't like last night, as well as a
bunch of things I LOVED last night. There was incredible music, I was
surronded by my friends, and everyone seemed to be having fun.
    BUT, I totally can't stand the fact that my right to personal space means
nothing to promoters. I come to parties to dance and have a good time. At
ALMOST every party at 2nd and Jackson, I find that I have no room to dance,
let alone breath! It gets really nasty in there and very cluastrphobic.
People left and right were pushing each other. Nobody said excuse me, or
sorry.  I don't understand why promoters charge(and I am not trying to beat a
dead horse here) $2.00 for a bottle of water. PLEASE MARK MY WORD!!! I am
going to throw another Famtasia b4 I am off to merry ol England, and I will
sell bottles of water at cost... a mere 30 cents!! Anything more is bullshit!
Cept if you are charging a dollar because you have to pay people who work for
you to sell it and stuff. 
    Crash Worship was OK. During there intro I swiftly left the building
fearing for my life. I almost went up to the fire marshal and said something
to him. There was absolutley NO reason that they should have been spewing
fire onto curtains or throwing firecrackers and flowers into the crowd. They
used a lot of fire and it was insanely dangerous. What if they threw a
firecracker and it went off in front of someone's face, WHILE they were
fucked up, or when they are sober. I think it was totally careless of the
promoters to put the crowd at risk like that. That venue was not proper for
that type of group. But if people didn't give a shit or couldn't see that it
was unsafe and stayed in the venue, then it is there own fault if something
happened.
     Well, I think I have said enough here.. BTW I am really bummed I missed
Rob's set. Can someone please fill me in on how it went? Tony, Jeno and Josh
tore shit up! 





















                                                                     Respect,




















                                                                     Jonathan

Hey John,

Crash Worship is about the moment in which who *you* are gets taken over
[or given to, if you're like me] - the rhytm, heat, spectacle and
experience of something that we have supposedly outgrown as a species:
Surrender.

Does that make sence?  Fire is birth at the moment of death.  Re-birth
at the moment of re-lease. Plus, it's a lot of fun to dance topless in a
sea of bodies, touching and touched as it so happens - and know that you
_are_ safe. [Confession: I got some small burns on my hand and my right
nipple and almost passed out after dancing with the Centaur, but i think
those are definitely prices worth paying.]If you ask me, it's like -
giving into something that is so much bigger than you - not caring what
you look like or smell like or feel like, because every little piece of
what each and every single person does in the experience makes something
so much larger happen.  It's quite Gestalt, actually.

<snip>
There was absolutley NO reason that they should have been spewing fire
onto curtains or throwing firecrackers and flowers into the crowd.
<snip>Are you specifically speaking of the point at which a bunch of us
burned our clothes on the floor?  Just so you know - I saw no less than
two spotters, and they definitely had their eyes wide open on all of us
closest to the flames.

Crash Worship is release and joy and unity, just as so much of what a
good rave vibe is - it's just different.

I see where you're coming from Jonathan.  But I wouldn't say you're "a
gumpy old, burned out, raver" - it seems to me, given what you've said
here - you just don't jive with the CW vibe.

I'm sorry you didn't enjoy your time last nite.  Guess I won't be seeing
you at Burning Man, eh?

Kate

ps - Hernan:  I'm practicing the spray this afternoon :-)

Hello everyone its me Jeremy back again for my night reccalections. I was so
happy to arrive at True Love w/ plenty of time in the day to help set up.
(Thank you Julie Hayes) I said my hello's then went to visit my friends at
Pro-Soy. I love Amanda and dustin so there was no way I would miss tonight
ceremony. My trip to Pro-soy turned from hello's to two hours of sound
proofing the windows upstairs. its all good thought i love ernie, maya, and
rachel too. After some early work at Pro-soy, i treked over to True-Love
worked the final 4 hrs there helping set-up. Following set-up we waited for
people to arrive to some of Siphon's nasty Jungle. Then it was my turn to
work the door, there i was standing outside in my candy-pants greeting the
oncoming traffic of beautiful faces. Nick and i soon finished our shift w/
the help of Blow-Pop Eric, at around 11:30. 

Now it was my time to enjoy the party, when I went out side the vibe, and
Love in the Place was amazing w/ the help of set-up crew. When I returned it
had quadrupled in size, but the vibe only got better. Marty was soon to
finish his set, damn i hate missing marty spin, oh well there will be much
more music later in the night. by 12:00 the mad heads I had hoped for had
arrived bringing there smiling faces and leaving the baggage at the door.
Thank you.  

the ceremony soon arrived for us to see, i witnessed some I thing i could
never forget. Not sayuing I would ever want to, but i never could. It was the
entire scene coming together to for one common cause, Amanda & Dustin's
TRUE~LOVE. There Love filled our hearts as did Lara's beautiful speech, that
helped show a glimpse in to that grrl's amazing heart. i will forever be
proud of you for sharing w/ us so lovely. Vertigo did a outstanding job w/
the ceremony, "You go boy." 

if I thought the vibe was beautiful before, it got soooooooooo much better
following the ceremony. i stayed around for it a bit then it was time for me
to get my fix on Ernie DEAKS. In my point of view he is the best DJ in the UG
scene, and a good friend. I then made the trek back to Pro-soy, I was happily
greeted at the door by my CFC friends. THere is nothing better than having
good friends throughout the scene. I arrived, and Sabin (Cloud) was spinning
some crazy shit. I was mad impressed. However I Deaks was not on for about a
!/2 hour, so i walked around saying "hi" to all my friends over here. I was
in line for the restrooms when i heard someone mixing out of  Cloud's set. I
knew it was time, YESSSSSSSSSSSSSS, It is so phucking hard I danced so hard
my feet still hurt.  I think this was the first time, alot of these heads had
experienced him. It definately is always a experience for me when ernie
spins. following my hard-stepping dancing all i could do is return to True
Love. 

That is where I belonged that night, I couldn't dance anymore, too tired. so
i hung out w/ all of the beautiful people at true love ( Amber, Nichole,
Jennifer, Jamie, andrew, Euginia, Shawn, ari, jeff, and everyone else i
forgot to leave out.I love you too) Then my next mission to find a ride home,
mission accomplished I love you two Kevin, and Jessica. I'm sorry this post
is so full of PLUR, but after last night, nothing else would have done it
justice. I love you Amanda and Dustin.

love~jeremy
~Remember  to Play Nice Sept. 20th~
408.643.8318

for everyone else, this weekend seems to have gone exactly as i had predicted
it, it was epic. after a series of about two not-so-good weekends, i had been
planning on this one to be one of the greatest, with tru luv on saturday (a
wedding at a rave, now what can beat that) and then crash worship today.
yeah, i had an interesting night last night, stuck in the hospital barely on
this oxygen treatment with pnemonia (i would have rather been at true love,
but atleast i had a good looking nurse). and today i'm not allowed to leave
my bed but i can actually breath again. anywayz, i keep reading all these
amazing posts and i hope that maybe after next weekend one of them will be
mine. keep the good posts rolling in.
plur and good health to all

well gotta do somethin.

um...i had a friggin blast at this party.

totally.

my eyes watered as i watched lara, amanda, dustin, um, let's see who else,
um, SPENCER!, um, who else, well i think that's it, get in front of a
microphone and talk in front of 2-300 people.   wow.  that's something i
really can't do.  i'd crack up.

but i can play in front of 2-300 people.  so i did.  and my sets are only
as good as the crowd dancing to them, and let me tell you, i saw a lot of
BUTTS shakin away.

of course, i dunno if anyone noticed me swingin my booty on top of the
chair at the smart drink table.  i figured since there were no cages at
this place where people could show off, that i'd do something similar.

but wow.  karma-wise, i read dustin and amanda's energy as being very clean
and pure.  therefore, they deserved this party to go off and this beautiful
wedding.  one thing i liked was the fact that the wedding was only a very
small part of the whole party.  pretty much after it was over they were
back to doin what they do best.  make other people feel like they mean
something in this world.

see the frog float.

Babs is cool.  So is um...Lisa W.  Kat W. bill...hope...andy
p....pablopop...danny...fubari/jelo conglomerate (hi guys!)...iris and
ben...pengopen...alik e...beth j...jill......

you know what is so funny is i never ventured downstairs more than once or
twice to get water....it lookied like a totally different party down there.
i think that downstairs room should be the ambient room next time.

get vlad to do some mc'ing.

no just kidding.  but the expresso bar would have to be in full effect.

along with the 'assorted greens' menu...

well i guess i thought i had more to say.

but sometimes less is better, wouldn't you agree?  =]

dEEp

Support Organic Foods.

Man, there are some parties that change you.  For example; Superlove,
Eminence (w/ Keoki), Love Affair, and True Love.  These kind of parties
are just so awesome that they just change your point of view towards life
for the better.  True Love last night was one of those parties.  The love
that you actually see floating in the air was just awesome.  It just
reminds me of how wonderful our scene is.  We should be so proud to be a
part of this.  I know that I'll be very proud to describe to my kids what
I did while I was growing up.

That party had absolutely nothing to be ashamed of.  Everything there
wen't perfectly.  First off, I believe it's because it was at Cyborganic.
 God I love that place. :o)  Then every DJ that was there just did an
amzin' job.  That was the first time that I know of that I heard Marty,
and also Anakin, and without a doubt they were awesome.  MACADIO, man,
you were rippin' it up down in the basement.  I swear I've never danced
so much to so many awesome ass tunes.  (I hope I didn't make your head
any fatter than it already is.)  UNCLE NOAH'S set was very lively and
much fun to listen to after one has inhaled a bit of some herb.  I was
having a blast just chillin' and listening to your set.

Then the wedding.  Geeez, that was really great to watch.  Even though I
had one of the worst seats in the house, listening to it was just
beautiful.  Seeing those two so happy to be joined together in the scene
where they both met.  Hey, didn't Dustin propose to Amanda at Cyborganic?
 That is just so cool.  Also, LARA, your poem was very powerful.  I give
you phat props for that material that you produced.

All in all, that was a great party to be at and anyone can consider
themselves lucky to be there.  HEY BYRONI!!!!  You shoulda gone.  It was
such a bomb ass party.

One more, ORSON, where were you?  I looked all over for you.  Matt said
he saw you once but I didn't see  you at all.  Oh well.

And finally, congratulations to DUSTIN and AMANDA.  I wish you two a
happy life together.

Bye Bye

dErEk

What happened to the voicemail for the party for True Love? Just out of
curiosity, what time did the directions to the map point go up at? When I
called I just got a long beep. Due to my confusion, my friends and I headed
out to Oakland to go to Satori. What the hell we wanted to see what all the
hype surrounding Crash Worship was all about.

We saw fire, sweaty naked people, paint encrusted bodies and bobbing
paper-machet heads. SOMEONE PLEASE explain why these people are so
entertaining and appealing. I just don't undersatnd. I'm a very open minded
person, but I rilly couldn't figure out what was so amazing about them.
Anywayz, Jeno, Minor Minor, Josh etc. tore the place up so that made the
night worthwhile. The highlight of the entire event (in my humble opinion)
was in the morning around 4 to 6 when all the people that sat around in the
main room left and awesome progressive busted out and everyone, (the few
left) just grooved on 'till the very end.

I would like to know how Universal Fire was. I would appreciate it if someone
could post a review of that party. I'm rilly happy to hear that everyone that
went to True Love had an amazing time and congratulations to <3Dustin and
Amanda<3!

Hope everyone had a phun philled weekend ;)

*LaUrEa*

Hey everyone.  I'm a sad, sad little tekno diva.  I'm sure you all noticed, I
wasn't at True Love last nite.  I made it to San Fransisco... but that's
another story.  If you want to know all about it you can e-mail me and I'll
tell you.  So with all my true love gear, I ended up going to Satori.  Mebbe
it was the fact that it was my sober nite, or that I wasn't in the place I
really wanted to be.  But this had to be the worst nite of raving in my short
little party life.  Cruising the line, I noticed a bunch of people that
didn't look like the usual crowd.  (going in I had no idea about Crash
Worship or what was going on)  Bunches of naked 50 year old stoned out people
screaming and running around.  Thought maybe they'd stay in their room and
we'd stay in ours.  Oh so Wrong.. The nekkid people ran into the rave chamber
at about 2 a.m. with fireworks, flamethrowers and drums n' screaming loud
enough to scare the DJ into stopping his set.  (that or it just drowned out
the music)  NEways.. After my hair caught some sparks we left..  I'm really
sad that I missed True Love, and I know I looked stupid for crying at Satori,
but that's how I felt.  I need cheering up if anyone feels like e-mailing me.
 That's about all.

          hugs,
           'trice the tekno diva                   <<<<RAVEON>>>>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Sun Jul 27 19:36:58 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) id TAA28223;
	Sun, 27 Jul 1997 19:36:58 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ocf.Berkeley.EDU (dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.191.249])
	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id TAA28208
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Sun, 27 Jul 1997 19:36:54 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from localhost (dlb@localhost) by ocf.Berkeley.EDU (8.7.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id TAA16218 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Sun, 27 Jul 1997 19:36:52 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Sun, 27 Jul 1997 19:36:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Dave Bayer <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
To: "\\SFRaves\\" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: A different take on Satori
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.96.970727184639.15562A-100000@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

What an interesting night. It started out being stuck in a line with all
types of people freezing my ass off as I wore shorts. Finally the line
starts moving and I get to be searched and they look in my bag and ask me
about my sticks which look a little burnt and I say their my jggling
sticks (which they are) and on I go... We get in to a small room with one
stack of speakers arranged to produce a good amount of sound, but no
stereo image which feels a little wierd.

Someone plays for a while and a whole bunch of glittered up people stream
in and dance with wierd looks on their faces which seemed out of place
with the little shiny happy cutsie backpacks they had on. So me and gem
stand around talking and tapping our feet as the room fills and we notice
their is a pretty definite division between people, there are the "ravers"
and then there are those there for Crash Worship (and a few of us that
were there for both)...

Eventually the other room opens and it means we have a chance to get to
the toilets for the first time in many hours... We then notice and comment
on the fact that the free water people are not there and the NomAd
interactive types seem to be selling water for $2 a bottle (I believe
they were smaller bottles than normal, like a 10 instead of a 12 oz).
Later we find that they are taking water at the gate (hmmmm)... Eventually
a band comes on but it isn't crash worship and it seems everything is way
behind schedule and we realize that this is going to be a problem as the
Crash Worship people are not on the same schedule as raver types. Not
only this, but the sound system is distorting to hell (hmmm, or maybe it
was so loud that was my ears,though the wet toilet paper seemed to take
the edge off it).
	So we sit waiting for the band to end as going into the rave room
proved pretty uninspiring... And we wait.... And we hear the glittered up
people in front of us commenting on the girl in front of them who had on a
see thru dress with underwear on under neath and how none of these people
seemed all that (i believe)... And then the band ends, ah ha! And people
start moving forward a bit and then the speaker's erupt forth with..... A
rumblingkick drum... Ohhh gooody... And then some electronic noises, hmmm,
and then its tribal house which certainly isn't what I have heard about
crash worship... And the music seems a far cry from the tribal drumming
and banging and bending that I know cw shall produce and so the housey
stuff just doesn't move me now... Oh well, back to soaking the torches I
suppose...
	I sit and try and talk with the people I was there with, but the
wet toilet paper has does a pretty good job at attenuting the frequencies
necessary to understand human speech, so I sit and wonder how strong the
kersone is smelling for a long long long long time... And then I am
thristy, so off to get some water, but it seems the free water ran out. So
I volunteer to take their cooler and fill it, if they will get me past the
security which was instructed (most likely by NomAd interactive as it was
their security I believe, though I could vbe wrong) to take people's
water. Alas, they are just doing what they have been told to do and they
won't help me out here, so I fork over $2 for some water (which they
seemed unwilling to sell me, must be the dreads or something)... And back
I go to my seat on the cool concrete, in between some raver's who
complained about CW followers and CW followers who have been waiting for
2+ hours for an experience to being (and who are tired of this slow
monotonous music)...
	Eventually I see other torches moving toward the stage and that
means something is going to bne happening... And sure enough, something
did happen... A percession of skilled fire breathers and torch bearers
moved into the crowd followed by the band, and the crowd responded. Fire
has an alluring quality, I think everyone feels, it has the ability to get
your heart beating when a plume of fire rushes up and the heat wave rushes
out. And then the drums pound out rhythums which reminded me of the
festivals in Scotland (hell, the percession remind me of one night in the
woods with torches lit people danced through woods followed by bagpipers
and drummers gathering more people as they wen, down the path to satavi's
sound system, ahhh the memories, but I digress) and the drums pound and
the guitar pitch bends, and the bass makes bass noises and the crowd
dances, no the crowd STOMPS, and people yell and scream, and fire
erupts... And you sweat, and people are packed in close but no one minds
because from that close hot dance, the enrgy builds and builds and
builds (until CW stops or comes up with one of those 4 or so rhythums
that I just couldn't figure out how to dance to)...
	I remember one couple that I coiuldn't surmise whether they were
with the band or not, a guy in black and red and a girl, who knew how to
swing a torch, I wouldn't mind taking a lesson...
	I saw a few people I met up at Fly Ranch over labor day (ok, I
didn't so much as meet them as worked with them, but I have a decent
memory for faces). I saw some raver types picking and choosing their
grinding partners (though very few of them seemed to want the grind, maybe
it's something about the motives, or maybe its something about the fact
that these guys never wanted to get involved with the girl's energy, they
just wanted a thing that moved under their pressure? The same with
half the guys grabbing at the watermoleon woman's ass)...
	There was something about CW which reminded me of what I like
about really good parties, and that is the way the energy builds and what
it builds from, and I fear over time, with everyone focused on making
raves "comfortable" places, this has either been lost or throw to the
side, snd so be it... If raves are a business then safety and
comfortableness of the clients are of the utmost importance. On the other
hand, if raves are a bunch of people with a love of something incommon,
donating forth money so as to split the cost of the event evenly, then
what CW made of the participates of the show seems entirely just what the
crowd ordered up ;)
	Eventually the pounding and banging built itself up in the middle
of the floor and ended with 3 beats of the drums in unison (I think it was
3)... And then the crowd moved away and I rinsed the oils from my mouth
once last time and put the torches away to look down at a most grimmy
floor... I looked under a bit and was told it was doubtful at whether
Minor was going to spin with the layer of crud on the floor, so we headed
out to the car to change clothes and drive home... I just want to know
where the rest of the gunk was, and where I can pick up a water based fire
extinguisher...

dave

	Just when I thought the love was virtually dead in the scene... 
You all surprised me, reminded me why partying was such a big thing in my 
life. you all reminded me why I love being stuck in a hot sweaty room 
with 300 people. Why? LOVE. 
	Amanda and Dustin started a disease that spread so quickly last 
night -- I have never felt so much love in my life! I cried, I cried, I 
cried. Amanda -- you looked so divinely beautiful last night, especially 
after all the stress you had to deal with!! Dustin, you pimp! :)~
	The music was phat, I hafta give Rinse props for getting the 
crowd moving upstairs in a big way, even though a half hour was all he 
had. And Marty, Deepfog (yummy green stuph!) and Uncle Noah.. Rob Rayle.. 
Todd Manley.. MAN I WISH i 
was energetic enough to go downstairs, I'm sure you guys rocked the place 
as well! 
	"ALWAYS." MAN! Amanda and Dustin, your love is so beautiful!
We all witnessed something magical last night. TRUE LOVE MAN! :)~
I want to thank pyro n bruce for the ride home, you guys saved me. I get 
my car next week and owe you guys one :)~
	And for all who showed up, bringing your smiles, open hearts, 
good attitudes.. If I threw any negative attitude up in the air, I 
sincerely apologize -- too many things were going on all at once, and 
when you're doing 5 things at once to make sure your dearest Amanda's 
wedding will go perfect, PLUR is really at the back of my mind. 
	I will truly never forget this night -- Spencer, your joke was 
SOOPERDOPE! And Vertigo.. MAN you ROCK!
And Jil -- the "YOU ARE LOVED" pins were PERFECT! :)~
I could go on forever but yanno, It's time to sleep or something :)~
xo
lara

Jondabomb writes:
+       I went to Satori last night and came to some serious conclusions. I am
+ a gumpy old, burned out, raver!!!=(
  +     I just don't feel the same way I did when I first started going to
  + parties. I'm not collecting flyers like a maniac. I'm not dancing my ass off!
  + Did I lose the love? Did I go thru a phase? OR am I just sick and tired of
  + the scene in general?

I've been at that stage before too man.  Know exactly what you are talking about, and figured I might as well add to your insight.

I've been enjoying the best that SF has to offer since summer 93', and have seen a lot of new and old faces come and go.

I think a lot of us have gone through this phase, brother.  Believe me, I have as well.

Ever been to a party and you were having the shittiest time and asked yourself, "Why am I here?"  Why isn't a nice cozy bed better than being here with a frown on your face, while it looks like others are having the time of their lives? The boom-boom is giving you a headache, the people are vibeless, the music sucks..... sounds familiar?

And how about when you feel so tired at a party, that you just have to go to a corner/chill room and sleep, waking up and the party is over?

When the party's over, the lights come on, and the sun rises, it's a dawn of a new day, and back to the realities of life.

There will always be the scene man.  If you feel like the vibe isn't there, then take a break.
There's such an array of choices that you can find on any given night- so don't limit yourself to one particular choice.  Diversity is life.

Much love man, Mr. 2

On Sun, 27 Jul 1997 TeKnODiVa@aol.com wrote:

>   Cruising the line, I noticed a bunch of people that
> didn't look like the usual crowd.  (going in I had no idea about Crash

	I thought it was the most diverse crowd I have seen in ages which
is what raves were based on, no?

>  Bunches of naked 50 year old stoned out people
> screaming and running around.

	I'm only 23, was sober (except maybe for kersone fumes), and I
still had shorts on (I don't seem to remember seeing any completely naked
people actually). What exactly do you mean by 50 year old stoned out
people screaming and running sround? We as a group built a lot of energy
up in that room and I for one did yell and scream... What was it that
people didn't like about those in the big room? The nakedness? The
stompyness of the dance (I love stompy music, and I believe it is from
this kind of music that the "tribal" connotations come). Is it the age
separation? Sorry, don't know how to fix that... Is it the sexual element? 
That is a part of many people's life and can be viewed in about as many
ways as the use of e. 


>   Thought maybe they'd stay in their room and
> we'd stay in ours. 

	Why segregate?

>  Oh so Wrong.. The nekkid people ran into the rave chamber
> at about 2 a.m. with fireworks, flamethrowers and drums n' screaming loud
> enough to scare the DJ into stopping his set.  (that or it just drowned out
> the music)

	CW broughgt something with them. It dropped what appears to be a
real bomb on numerous people... Now, if ravers are so open-minded, why are
people complaining about a difference of taste like this - why is it just
not your thing, but judged negatively to be "Bunches of naked 50 year old
stoned out people screaming and running around" who seem to be a threat to
ravedopm's very existence...

dave

Subject: Cannabis/Minna/Pro-soy
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain

Hi Folx-

It sounds like it was quite a wild weekend for everyone...we had the 
ultra-lovey True Love wedding (congrats A&D) and the raw wild Satori.  Two very 
different energies BOTH of which IMO are elemental to the scene.  Sometimes 
it's great and good for the spirit to bond with others in a PLURRY state of 
mind, but sometimes ya just wanna tap into raw primal wickedness for release.  
I, however chose the middle path and went to neither, but had a great time 
nonetheless.  The day started out in GG Park for the Cannabis Network party, 
which was mellow and fun.  I couldn't dance for some reason, so just kicked it 
on the grass and ppl watched for awhile.  

The evening rolled around, and because it was the easiest choice,  me n Midori 
went to Minna  A couple glasses of vino and some funky beats were neat, but you 
didn't miss too much.   Walking towards the motosickle parked in that alley, we 
heard beats that were more MY style....bump bump thump bump.  The sign said 
"Private Party", but when we talked to the bouncer (who was really cool, BTW) 
he informed us it was the Pro-soy event.  He let us in without making us go to 
the map point first,  and we went upstairs for some hard fast beats-- jus what 
da doc ordered.  It was surprisingly crowded-- I thought everyone would be at 
TL or Satori-- and there was alot of recognizable faces from the GG party.  Who 
was the gal in the lime green bells and purple tshoes? Pure rave energy.  
Anyhoo, a good time was had by all.  It's great to know that at least 3 events 
went off on the same night all with success!

Now just saving some brain cells for Reggae on the River...anyone else going?  

Peace, Nathan

from gem (getting frustrated reading over dave's shoulder and wanting to
voice some thoughts...sorry about the piggy-backing) 		

 Participating in both CW and raves for several years now, i was looking
forward to Satori as a possibly illuminating and hopefully entertaining
experiment in vibe mixing...

On Sun, 27 Jul 1997 TeKnODiVa@aol.com wrote:

> I noticed a bunch of people that
> didn't look like the usual crowd.  (going in I had no idea about Crash
> Worship or what was going on)  Bunches of naked 50 year old stoned out people
> screaming and running around.  Thought maybe they'd stay in their room and
> we'd stay in ours.

  Conclusions: (being part of the experiment myself obviously skews allthe
data all to hell but...)
  1.) tekno d's and naked people do not mix. Unfortunately, i myself saw
only half-naked people, of all ages (don't know if they were stoned, left
a vital piece of testing equipment behind, but they had at least danced
themselves into a very altered state.is this a state only allowed in the
domain of the glitter encrusted?) However, i observed numerous people of
the raver persuasion who wasted no time in immersing themselves in the
middle of the throbbing bunch of sweaty bodies. they looked pretty
...ah...happy? transported? ecstatic, perhaps? maybe not such an alien
scene for some of us.
 
 2.) some people apparently only feel safe partying in a very well
controlled environment. (happy helmet salesmen, here is your El Dorado!)

3.) some CW followers do not like techno. 

4.) no one caght on fire. at least, not where i was.

5.) taking away  water bottles at the door and then selling little bottles
for outrageous amounts is wrong. at least alert people to this outpouring
of greed on the voicemail, we wouldn't have brought huge bottles with us.
(by the way, who gets them all later?)

6.) CW still plays when the genny goes out.

7.) all of us rave-goers who bought the whole mind expansion thingy we
read
about on the flyers we were given back in the early 90's had an awesome
time. maybe they just don't make rave propaganda like they used to. for
some people, chemicals, tribal music, dancing in a crowd that feels less
like a bunch of people and more like just a vast, vital, kinetic , larger
expression of oneself, and maybe a bit of humanity induced chaos thrown
in, is what we've thrived on. i think those people, no matter what drew
them to this event in the first place, had a good time.
 

>  That's about all.

                                          gem

From: The Grigsbeast <grigsby@netgate.net>
Subject: Will promoters please stop wasting my time? and Satori
In-Reply-To: <970727153943_-1375198302@emout02.mail.aol.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


OK, so I have to give Nomad props for bringing CW out at all, and for a
good location.  HOWEVER, "doors at 9, CW at midnight?"  Doors at 10:30 and
CW and 3:30 is more like it, and the free water ran out in about an hour.
So thousands of people get to sit around for three hours inhaling cigarette
smoke and suffering through the worst opening band in the universe while
paying $2 for 10 oz. of water?  And the directions to the event, involving
a whole TWO TURNS off the freeway, were totally fucked?  And the sound
system was so distorted in both rooms that all the DJ sets sounded the
same?  (WHOOM-WHOOM-WHOOM-WHOOM)  Come on, guys.  No class at all.

CW tore it up, btw, with the best show I've seen them do in several years.
I guess if you don't get it you don't get it.  If you can just let go of
your "oh my gawd, my backpack is all wet, my glitter will wash off, who
_are_ these freaky-looking people", and all the other mother-nagging and
schoolyard cool-paranoia you've internalized, you'll have more fun and be a
better person for the experience.  JSL wonders where all the bras and booty
went?  Right here, sir.  Just let your hair down, shuck your shirt, and
jump in.  And if you can't stand the heat, well, then get out of the oven,
hmm?

Replies to some comments:

>    Crash Worship was OK. During there intro I swiftly left the building
>fearing for my life. I almost went up to the fire marshal and said something
>to him. There was absolutley NO reason that they should have been spewing
>fire onto curtains or throwing firecrackers and flowers into the crowd. They
>used a lot of fire and it was insanely dangerous. What if they threw a
>firecracker and it went off in front of someone's face, WHILE they were
>fucked up, or when they are sober.

They've been doing this for at least eight years and I haven't heard of
anyone getting injured by the fireworks yet (and I've personally been to at
least seven shows in that time, all with plenty of fireworks).  All the
propaganda about "fire is dangerous, you'll hurt yourself" is only
half-true.  Why do you think they soaked the crowd down with fire
extinguishers before they started?  It's a warehouse, for crying out loud.
Concrete DOES NOT BURN, and neither do wet, sweat-soaked clothes.

(If you're not comfortable with what was going on, exercise your right to
leave.  Just don't assume the rest of us need protection.  The whole back
of the warehouse was open to the air so I wasn't worried about getting out
in a panic.)

Cigarettes tossed out windows, however, DO cause fires, like Oakland Hills.
 Dry grass catches fire much easier than wet warehouse.

>I think it was totally careless of the
>promoters to put the crowd at risk like that. That venue was not proper for
>that type of group. But if people didn't give a shit or couldn't see that it
>was unsafe and stayed in the venue, then it is there own fault if something
>happened.

I'll take that risk, thank you.

// grigs



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Sun Jul 27 23:05:12 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) id XAA23580;
	Sun, 27 Jul 1997 23:05:12 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from venus.i84.net (venus.i84.net [206.148.160.4])
	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id XAA23564
	for <Sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Sun, 27 Jul 1997 23:05:08 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from [206.40.40.113] (port26.hypersurf.com [206.40.40.122]) by venus.i84.net (8.8.3/8.8.3) with SMTP id BAA04997 for <Sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Mon, 28 Jul 1997 01:09:45 GMT
Date: Mon, 28 Jul 1997 01:09:45 GMT
Message-Id: <v01530500b0017686a244@[206.40.40.113]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: Sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: anakin@hypersurf.com (anakin)
Subject: Notes from the Dungeon (_Another TL Experience_)...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Well, aboveground, love was in bloom.  The decor was rave wedding caliber.
The lighting spaned from professionals as well as home systems (Thanx Rob
Rayle and Co.).  Smiles, bliss, and yes indeed... True Love....

But something vastly different was abrewing below...

After a walkthrough to the downstars room, well kiddies...  A RAVE WAS
GOING ON!!!!!

>From Pete doing damage to the InSect VS ViRus 2*4 (Yep a classic CD vs
vinyal match with Hard Acid being the Battlefield) in the wee Hrs of the
morning...

First up, Pete:
        -Did an excellent job of bringing the vibe alive. Unfortunatley the
switch on circut #6 had to keep being thrown. (Just too much power for that
poor lil fusebox).  Major props to all the opening DJ's... It's you who
start the flame and set the pace to which all the other DJ's must follow...
And Pete had them moving!   Peeps gruuving to that sick, drippy, breaks and
beats.  Driving the crowd up, breaking them down and building them up
again...

*** (Second DJ review intentionally left blank) ***

And then Macadio:
        - Despite the insurmountable odds (Police, circut switch being
thrown two or three times, and, oh , yeah a wedding).  Macaddy took people
THERE!  (And if you don't know where there is...  Well, some things are
best FELT not SPOKEN).  Some people spend many a years to acquire 1/4th of
the skills being spun by this gentleman.  Coupled with some _KILLER_
hypnotic trance... The Dungeon was begining to live to it's name... A nice
film of persperation acquiring on both floor and ceiling.  Dancers warping
themselves into thier own realities.

Micron had to keep it up,
        - With some new tracks up his sleeve, Dan showed the nature of a
true DJ.  The ability to move the vibe from hard Acidy beats to the melodic
flow of some serious mental trance.  And nicely done with some awe
inspiring flowing tracks. (Bettah put a lock on that record bag Micron =)
)...   4:30 AM and the floor was still packed with glowing vibe filled
Ravers (<---- OR insert YOUR term for positive vibe-filled persons here)!

So a slightly 420'ed Andy W  steps to the 1210's (I should know, cos I
420'ed w/him):
        - The words to Andy's set can be summed up as...  Unexpected.
Nonconformist. Unknowing...
Every time I think that I understand the message Andy tries to weave, he
suprises me anew.  I might of been just phyically drained or mentaly
overstimulated but Andy's set parked my ass and had me thinking Really Hard
(And quiet frankly, I can't remember what the fuck I thinking about!!!).
Props to the man that can sit this dancer!!!

But my mental haze dissapated with a oh-so-famillar sound of HARD ACID!!!
        - The remaining loyal of the underground sweatbox was about to
witness the magic of the InSect Vs. ViRus battle.  It looks as if the
spoils of of that war was our (dancers, that is..) sanity.  Now those two
can cut sheet up!  I saw another electronica wall crumble that night (or
rather should I say morning).  The cutting up and mixing I've only seen
parralled by our scenes' finest breakbeat DJ's.  Breakbeat DJ's cutting up
ACID??? Or Acid DJ's that are demanding respect by exaulting thier skills?
Whichever the case may be, these two were working not with just two
turntables, nor with two CD players... But with BOTH CD and vinyal mediums.
Major props.

I guess The City couldn't handle it either since the Po-po arrived @ 6:45
to say:
        "Party's over folx.  Time to go home...."

Hell no.

RAS commandos were in wait all along and quickly sealed off the bass-ment
from any outside forces and told the DJ's to commence...   How funny it was
to see the dungeon fillup again in the typical,
"just-try-to-stop-this-raver-from-having-a-good-time" fashion.  The
hardcorps were still rocking hard even as the last wax trax was dropped,
and as the undergrounds last tune was being spun I think not anyone truly
realized that the bowels of Cyborgantic will never again be treaded by the
feet raver-kin again.   An era has closed kiddies....  Now you can say,
years from now, that you once rocked in the underground of SF's legendary
Cyborgantic parties.

L-8 (or, untill next weekend...)



"Awaken"

Subject: Crash Worship and burnt out ravers
Date: Sun, 27 Jul 97 23:41:49 -0700
x-mailer: Claris Emailer 2.0, March 15, 1997
From: Alex Rosenberg <alexr@goonsquad.spies.com>
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I must be a burnt out raver as well because I didn't like the show either.

I'm not going to complain about $2 water or starting late or any of that 
because I've lived through a whole year of Chicago-area raves and any 
event in the Bay Area is better than those.

However, I didn't enjoy Crash Worship's performance. I think I would have 
enjoyed it more if it had been outside. Yes, I do "get" the whole primal 
nature of it. If I'm interested in that in the future, I'll go to an SRL 
show. Now that I know I'll enjoy.

>NAKED PEOPLE ARE NOW SCARING THE PLUR OUT OF RAVERS.

Not at all. In fact, I rather enjoy knowing that those folks feel 
"comfortable" enough to get naked. It makes me more "comfortable."

Why didn't I enjoy it? The music wasn't what I had hoped for. (During the 
opening band I commented, "They sound like Bill and Ted practicing.") I'm 
not really that keen on cigarette smoke, let alone the fumes from burning 
fuel-soaked rags and fire breathers. I'm also not keen on 
excessive-alcohol vomiting, of which I was made to bear witness to 
several times. And the last thing I needed was some yahoo trying to sell 
me Special K. Put the whole thing out on the playa or on a beach and I'm 
sure I would have had a great time.

--------------------------------------
|  Alexander M. Rosenberg             |
|  <mailto:alexr@goonsquad.spies.com> |
|  Nobody cares what I say.           |

>    BUT, I totally can't stand the fact that my right to personal space 
means
>nothing to promoters. I come to parties to dance and have a good time. 
At
>ALMOST every party at 2nd and Jackson, I find that I have no room to 
dance,
>let alone breath! It gets really nasty in there and very cluastrphobic.

yes it was crowded but  surprisingly, it was less crowded than other 
events there.  by the time i got there, they only let one person in for 
one person out which helped keep down the number of people.


>People left and right were pushing each other. Nobody said excuse me, 
>or sorry.  

yeah, people there were extremely rude.


> Crash Worship ... There was absolutley NO reason that they should 
>have been spewing
>fire onto curtains or throwing firecrackers and flowers into the crowd. 
They
>used a lot of fire and it was insanely dangerous. 


of course there was a reason.  for entertainment value.  people love 
fire and explosions.  it is a cool visual just as say lasers or 
projection screens.  Also, humans have always liked a slight aspect of 
danger.  it's a thrill.  for the same reason people watch scary movies, 
climb mountains, bungee jump, and skydive.  the fireworks and fire 
breathers were part of the excitement of the show.  In fact the main 
reason why i feel crash worship were so great was because it was so 
interactive with the audience.  just like the rave scene, the show 
wasn't just on stage but everywhere around you.  Also i find it kind of 
funny how a few firecrackers are much to dangerous to have at parties 
and yet toxic chemicals like E and acid are just fine. hmmmm.

later,

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Mon Jul 28 01:08:41 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) id BAA22589;
	Mon, 28 Jul 1997 01:08:41 -0700 (PDT)

	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) id BAA22579

	by hyperreal.org (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id BAA21652

	by CONSTRUCT.NET (8.8.6/2.5) with SMTP id BAA12275
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Mon, 28 Jul 1997 01:00:24 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Mon, 28 Jul 1997 01:00:23 -0700 (PDT)
From: Adam Gould <goolie@construct.net>
To: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: DJ - Satori/Crash Worship [review] (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.96.970728003119.11947B-100000@skippy.construct.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hey y'all. 

Well.

This show has certainly sparked some interesting & illuminating debate.  I
thought I'd add my review into the mix fer the hell of it.  This was
written for another list, but I thought I'd share it with ya.

I really want to underline that the mixing of the tribes (ravers and
primitives) is a *good* thing.  The music of each scene has tremendous
similarity at a very deep level; all you need to to hear it is listen. 
Listen to the beat.  Hear that?  It's trance drumming, and it's a
commonality that spans cultures and time since folks figured out beating a
stick against something sounds cool & could take you somewhere else... 

I was one of those people who went for both scenes, and i wanted to see to
what degree and how well they'd mix.  Yah, there were some sketch points. 
Everything didn't go smoothly, and it didn't help that Nomad put out
flyers promoting the rave with absolutely no mention of CW; i genuinely
think that it sucked that some folks got their rave brownie dosed with CW.
And i also noticed CW flyers for the Satori show that didn't mention any
DJ's at all.  What the fuck?  

Anyway, here's how it wuz accordin' to goolie:


*****************************************


Hey hey boogie bodies.

Well, we came, we saw, we burned, we got in various states of nekkidness,
we became one.

We, in this case, was Katie Z., Eric, and Wayne, although katie and eric
each had possies in tow (hi vagabond jim!) 

I have some rather mixed feelings about last night, but Crash Worship was
awe-inspiring, as usual.  

First, so i can vent, the lameosities:
  * Price-gouging $2 per bottle water (Their cost:  .30).  Few things
    aggravate me more then trying to make a margin on water.  And to add
    insult to injury, the advertised "free water" ran out in about an
    hour.   'Ran out' my ass, fuckers.  Do we look that stupid? 
  * Security armed with handguns
  * Blocked access to the bathrooms ("sorry, the room isn't ready yet) for
    a full half-hour, at least.  Great PR strategy!  Have you even seen
    50 people
    who really gotta go being told repeatedly to wait?  Can you say riot?
  * Crash Worship went on 2 hours late.  
  * Opening band for Crash - oh lord, have mercy.  Is my karma really
    *that* bad?  There wasn't even an opening band on the bill.
  * Nomad group space - this crew has some baaaaad mojo man.  Their
    current tally is 2 deaths at the Splish boat party, and 2 stabbings at
    their last massive at their space.  May it go no higher.  I don't
    think I'll be attending any of their events, unless given very good
    reason (like this show). 

OK, i feel better now.  

As i suspected, both the crowd and vibe at this party were very
interesting, with a fascinating cross section of house homies, candy
ravers, modern primitives, nekkid mud-people, neo-hippies, circle-dancers,
awesome age dispersion (easily teens though fifties).  Their were
definitely two distinct groups:  one to see Crash, the other to hear the
DJ's.  I was worried that the twain would self-select and basically ignore
each other, but there ended up being exactly the kind of
cross-fertilization I'd hoped for.  CW sucked in quite a few ravers of all
kinds from the House room, and at the end of the show, there were a lot of
the CW folks out there dancing away.

The primary similarity between the two (CW and DJs in general), and the
reason why each can interest the other's crowd, is, of course, the trance
drumming, and have I ever told you how much I enjoy commas?  I totally dig
that, I love the convergent validity of the Convergence, the sameness in
the difference, and visa-versa.  

CW Scenes:  
  * There was the Lucky Lady, carried atop her platform by at least
    10 of her paeonic male followers.  Completely nekkid 'cept for a small
    section of glittery cloth covering half of her cute ass and pubes, she
    would sit atop her charges, gyrating and lusting and fucking the
    entire crowd and no-one in particular at the same time.

  * There were the fire breathers and drummers of course, who circulated
    throughout the crowd for most of the show in a scene very reminiscent 
    of Brazil's Carnival. If you were particularly in
    the Zone, as i was, letting yourself go and willing yourself to the
    edge could easily take your right to the heart of the traveling
    drum n flame show.  At this range, the heat and flame could get quite
    intense, and as such there were two water-spotters who's job it was to
    aim streams of water at the burners.  Don't want 'em becoming
    burnees, y'know.  at one point, I was so close to the burners, i had a
    dedicated water stream aimed at me and the burner, else i probably
    would have been burned some.  Amazing and so intense. 

  * Assault on Raver Room - so, there's two main rooms in this joint, see?
    And CW is parading all over the room, leading this motley group of
    sweaty, smelling, flaming, tranced-out screamers from one end to the
    other like some burning man pied piper on acid.  All the sudder, the
    lead drummer/flamers make for the ramp that leads to the completely
    packed other room, where the likes of Tony and Josh are spinnin'
    away.  And we keep going, going, ploughing though
    the pumping, housing crowd like a very hot knife though butter.  Oh
    my, everyone was so loving it!  Right thought circle dancers (AWWWW
    YAHHH! I've always wanted to do that) and CW was so powerful that we
    just about overpowered the DJ sound system with *unamped* drums.  After
    our jaunt, we headed back to our assigned room, but Assault on Raver
    Room is something I've going to really remember... 

  * The Fruit Lady - dunno what else to call her.  Like Lucky Lady, she
    two was born above 10-12 porters, aloft & swimming in/on her platform
    of cut up fruit:  watermelons, pineapples, apples, oranges, you name
    it.  Nakedly wallowing in it all, she had an expression of bliss and
    ecstasy that is so rare to witness...  the crowd would run up and
    assist her in her fruit-smearing activities, spreading chunks and
    seeds all over each other, tossing fruit detritus into the void, she
    loving it as much as the crowd.

  * The bath Lady - also carried all over the floor by porters, taking
    a sudsy bath in a hottub like thing...

  * The Cheerleaders - One dude and one chick, complete with red-and-white
    pom-poms and letterman sweaters, standing atop the tallest bank of
    speakers, cheering the crowd & dancers & drummers & undifferentiated
    mob it all became on and on for the whole show.

I think the most bestest thing i got out of it all with the complete
blurring of the line between audience and performer.  We all became the
show.  Crash Worship demands that you take part and become one.  I dunno
who many of you have read _The Diamond Age_ by Neil Stevenson, but Crash
Worship very very very much reminds me of Stevenson's underground 
Drummers group...

The DJ's were excellent too.  Rob Doten was really hiting it well when we
got in, and Minor Minor was in the middle of a great set when we had to
leave at about 4:30 from overstimulation. 




--goolz

Yes. Because people keep going to parties that are thrown by these folks, 
and others like them who engage in the same practices. This is not
something new. And every time, a couple of people bitch about it, but then
they go to the next party and the same thing happens, and they bitch about
it, but then they got to the next party.... ad nauseum. If you want this
to change you have to let promoters that do this know that you *WILL NOT*
tolerate this, and won't attend their events. And you have to be willing
to follow through on this, no matter what talent they may be drawing.

ARTICLE IN TIME MAGAZINE ABOUT ELECTRONICA

It has a cover of an alien on it and talks about the Roswell Files, but
within its pages is an article about how this summer was supposed to be
the SUMMER OF ELECTRONICA! <kabang>

It mentions that U2 has a great album out called Pop and a great tour
but sales are not doing so well (i don't know what to think about that,
is it worth mentioning?).  It mainly talks about Prodigy and the
Chemical Bros.; they put in a Moby quote; mention that there are about
the same number of electronic music fans in the US as there are Dennis
Rodman fans in Utah.  

Interesting article, look for it.....

>So what do you all use for MIDI sequencing and audio? (esp synchronized
>audio and midi??).

I'm using Master Tracks Pro.  Simply because I've always used it (going all the way back to when I used to have an Atari 1040).  Pro 6 does everything I need in a Sequencer.  Plus, I know it so well that I just havnt bothered to switch over to one of the biggy sequencers. 

>Sounds like us Sfraves music-makers ought to get together sometime
>and jam, or talk, or share, or whatever.

I'd be into this!

>PS: any of y'all have an opinion on MIDI gear i could use to do that
>stuttering type gating (transforming) your hear on a lot of classic
>techno. Yeah, I could try hammering the volume controller on my EMU
>EIIIxp but that's not particularly easy to sequence.

I've done this with CC#7 (volume).  Most sequencers will let you draw in the continuous controller info.    

-M

Thanks for everyone who responded to my questions.  I'm satisfied, because 
your responses (particularly those about the history of jungle/happy hardcore) 
answered a whole lot of questions I've had for a long time.  I'm trying to 
reply to everyone personally but I'm kinda busy these days and it might take 
me awhile.

But the jungle-ish happy hardcore compilation "Best of Happy Hardcore" was put 
out in 1995, but the cover calls the songs "happy hardcore classics," so I 
have a feeling they're pretty old.  No matter, I really like them, as a matter 
of fact I'm playing cd 2 real loud right now.

If anyone wants to pick it up, I found it in the import section of Virgin 
records, although I had to dig through the hidden shelves underneath the 
displays and all that to discover it.  It's called "Best of Happy Hardcore" 
and it's a set of 4 cds, it's yellow, and it's put out by Low Price Music or 
something like that.  It has songs by Red Alert & Mike Slammer, DJ Slipmatt, 
and a whole bunch of people, I can send you a track listing if you like.

But thanx for the recommendations and information, I really appreciated it.  I 
learned a lot.

xoxo--Miccaela

A little while ago there was a thread about how to represent your
emotions over e-mail. I found this little piece of info that might just
help you guys out. Enjoy :)


We all know those cute little computer symbols called "emoticons,"=20
where

:) means a smile and :( is a frown.  Sometimes these are represented by
:-)

and :-(  Well, how about some "ass icons"?



Here goes:


            (_!_)      a regular ass


         (__!__)    a fat ass


              (!)        a tight ass


           (_._)      a flat ass


          (_^_)      a bubble ass


          (_*_)      a sore ass


          (_!__)     a lop-sided ass


          {_!_}       a swishy ass


         (_o_)      an ass that's been around


         (_O_)     and ass that's been around even more


          (_x_)     kiss my ass


          (_X_)     leave my ass alone


         (_zzz_)    a tired ass


         (_o^o_)   a wise ass


         (_13_)     an unlucky ass


       (_Clinton_)   international sign of an asshole




[Note: insert whoever you dislike into that last one]




                             \\|//

L     O     V     E,         (o o)          Y     U     R     Y

-------------------------oOOo-(_)-oOOo-------------------------

EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF EBF

<fontfamily><param>Symbol</param>=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=
=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9=
=A9=A9=A9=A9=A9

</fontfamily>

An incredible gathering in shasta to celebrate the Mayan galactic
new year.....

The following qoute from Shamanic Trance CD give you 
a clue about how this weekend was.

Lets have more raves like this...

"Do you remember the times when we danced around those original
campfires, 
 One tribe united in Spirit, celebrating our connection to each other,
the
 sky our father and the earth our mother.  Dancing gave us power.  It was
 our rite of passage, our shamanic journey into altered states of reality
 where we embodied Great Spirit and the magic of life.  We were the
 American Indians, we were the aboriginals, we were the Celts, we were
the
 Jungle Tribes.  We stomped, we chanted, we raised our arms in the air.
 We were there...and we still are now......

              Let us forever live the eternity of the dance.

         With love, as One, may we always remember the sacred ways.

                           RETURN TO THE SOURCE."
