thought this was kinda funny, passing it along

In a message dated 97-07-29 18:39:18 EDT, VictorHarris_at_BLDG10@ca.slr.com
writes:

<<      
 There are so many Star Trek(tm) spin-offs that it is easy to fool 
 yourself into thinking that the Star Trek vision is an accurate vision 
 of the future. Sadly, Star Trek does not take into account the 
 stupidity, selfishness, and horniness of the average human being.  Allow 
 me to describe some of the more obvious errors in the Star Trek vision.
      
 Medical Technology
 ------------------
 On Star Trek, the doctors have handheld devices that instantly close 
 any openings in the skin. Imagine that sort of device in the hands
 of your unscrupulous friends. They would sneak up behind you and seal 
 your ass shut as a practical joke. The devices would be sold in novelty 
 stores instead of medical outlets. All things considered, I'm happy 
 that it's not easy to close other people's orifices.
      
 Transporter
 -----------
 It would be great to be able to beam your molecules across space and 
 then reassemble them. The only problem is that you have to trust your 
 co-worker to operate the transporter. These are the same people who 
 won't add paper to the photocopier or make a new pot of coffee after 
 taking the last drop. I don't think they'll be double-checking the 
 transporter coordinates. They'll be accidentally beaming people into 
 walls, pets, and furniture. People will spend all their time 
 apologizing for having inanimate objects protruding from parts of their 
 bodies.
      
 'Pay no attention to the knickknacks; I got beamed into a hutch
  yesterday.'
      
 If I could beam things from one place to another, I'd never leave the 
 house. I'd sit in a big comfy chair and just start beaming groceries, 
 stereo equipment, cheerleaders, and anything else I wanted right into my 
 house. I'm fairly certain I would abuse this power. If anybody came to 
 arrest me, I'd beam them into space. If I wanted some paintings for my 
 walls, I'd beam the contents of the Louvre over to my place, pick out 
 the good stuff, and beam the rest into my neighbor's garage.
      
      
 If I were watching the news on television and didn't like what
 I heard, I would beam the anchorman into my living room during the 
 commercial break, give him a vicious wedgie, and beam him back 
 before anybody noticed. I'd never worry about 'keeping up with
 the Joneses,' because as soon as they got something nice, it 
 would disappear right out of their hands. My neighbors would have 
 to use milk crates for furniture. And that's only after I had all 
 the milk crates I would ever need for the rest of my life. 
 There's only one thing that could keep me from spending all my 
 time wreaking havoc with the transporter: the holodeck.
      
 Holodeck
 --------
 For those of you who only watched the 'old' Star Trek, the holodeck can 
 create simulated worlds that look and feel just like the real thing. The 
 characters on Star Trek use the holodeck for recreation during breaks 
 from work. This is somewhat unrealistic. If I had a holodeck, I'd close 
 the door and never come out until I died of exhaustion. It would be hard 
 to convince me I should be anywhere but in the holodeck, getting my oil 
 massage from Cindy Crawford and her simulated twin sister.
      
 Holodecks would be very addicting. If there weren't enough holodecks to 
 go around, I'd get the names of all the people who had reservations 
 ahead of me and beam them into concrete walls. I'd feel tense about
 it, but that's exactly why I'd need a massage.
      
 I'm afraid the holodeck will be society's last invention.
      
 Sex with Aliens
 ---------------
      
 According to Star Trek, there are many alien races populated with 
 creatures who would like to have sex with humans.
 This would open up a lot of anatomical possibilities, but imagine 
 the confusion. It's hard enough to have sex with human beings, 
 much less humanoids. One wrong move and you're suddenly 
 transported naked to the Gamma Quadrant to stand trial for 
 who-knows-what. This could only add to performance anxiety. You 
 would never be quite sure what moves would be sensual and what 
 moves would be a galactic-sized mistake.
      
         Me Trying to Have Sex with an Alien
         -----------------------------------
      
         Me:      May I touch that?
      
         Alien:  That is not an erogenous zone. It is a
                 separate corporeal being that has been 
                 attached to my body for six hundred years.
      
         Me:     It's cute. I wonder if it would let me
                 have sex with it.
      
         Alien:  That's exactly what I said six hundred
                 years ago.
      
 The best part about having sex with aliens, according to the Star Trek 
 model, is that the alien always dies a tragic death soon afterward. I 
 don't have to tell you how many problems that would solve. 
 Realistically, the future won't be that convenient.
      
 Phasers
 -------
 I would love to have a device that would stun people into 
 unconsciousness without killing them. I would use it ten times 
 a day. If I got bad service at the convenience store, I'd
 zap the clerk. If somebody with big hair sat in front of me 
 at the theater, zap!
      
 On Star Trek, there are no penalties for stunning people with phasers. 
 It happens all the time. All you have to do is claim you were possessed 
 by an alien entity. Apparently, that is viewed as a credible defense in 
 the Star Trek future. Imagine real criminals in a world where the 'alien 
 possession' defense is credible.
      
 Criminal:  Yes, officer, I did steal that vehicle, and
            I did kill the occupants, but I was possessed 
            by an evil alien entity.
      
 Officer:         Well, okay. Move along.
      
 I wish I had a phaser right now. My neighbor's dog likes to 
 stand under my bedroom window on the other side of the fence 
 and bark for hours at a time. My neighbor has employed the bold 
 defense that he believes it might be another neighbor's dog, 
 despite the fact that I am standing there looking at him 
 barking only twenty feet away. In a situation like this, a 
 phaser is really the best approach. I could squeeze off a clean 
 shot through the willow tree. A phaser doesn't make much noise, 
 so it wouldn't disturb anyone. Then the unhappy little dog and 
 I could both get some sleep. If the neighbor complains, I'll 
 explain that the phaser was fired by the other neighbor's dog, 
 a known troublemaker who is said to be invisible.
      
 And if that doesn't work, a photon torpedo is clearly indicated.
      
 Cyborgs
 -------
 Given the choice, I would rather be a cyborg instead of 100 percent 
 human. I like the thought of technology becoming part of my body. As a 
 human, I am constantly running to the toolbox in my garage to get a tool 
 to deal with some new household malfunction. If I were a cyborg, I might 
 have an electric drill on my arm, plus a metric socket set. That would 
 save a lot of trips. From what I've seen, the cyborg concept is a 
 modular design, so you can add whatever tools you think you'd use most.
      
 I'd love to see crosshairs appear in my viewfinder every time I looked 
 at someone. It would make me feel menacing, and I'd like that. I'd 
 program myself so that anytime I saw a car salesman, a little message 
 would appear in my viewfinder that said 'Target Locked On.'
      
 It would also be great to have my computer built into my skull. That way 
 I could surf the Net during useless periods of life, such as when people 
 talk to me. All I'd have to do is initiate a head-nodding subroutine 
 during boring conversations and I could amuse myself in my head all day 
 long.
      
 I think that if anyone could become a cyborg, there would be a huge rush 
 of people getting in line for the conversion. Kids would like it for the 
 look. Adults would like it for its utility. Cyborg technology has 
 something for everyone. So, unlike Star Trek, I can imagine everyone 
 wanting to be a cyborg.
      
 The only downside I can see is that when the human part dies and you're 
 at the funeral, the cyborg part will try to claw its way out of the 
 casket and slay all the mourners. But that risk can be minimized by 
 saying you have an important business meeting, so you can't make it to 
 the service.
      
 Shields
 -------
 I wish I had an invisible force field. I'd use it all the time, 
 especially around people who spit when they talk or get too close to my 
 personal space. In fact, I'd probably need a shield quite a bit if I 
 also had a phaser to play with.
      
 I wouldn't need a big shield system like the one they use to protect the 
 Enterprise, maybe just a belt-clip device for personal use. I could 
 insult dangerous people without fear of retribution. Whatever crumbs
 of personality I now have would be completely unnecessary in the future. 
 On the plus side, it would make shopping much more fun.
      
              Shopping with Shields Up
              ------------------------
      
      
          Me:          Ring this up for me, you
                       unpleasant cretin.
      
          Saleswoman:  I oughta slug you!
      
          Me:          Try it. My shields are up.
      
          Saleswoman:  Damn!
      
          Me:          There's nothing you can do to
                       harm me.
      
          Saleswoman:  I guess you're right. Would you like
                       to open a charge account? Our interest 
                       rates are very reasonable.
      
          Me:          Nice try.
      
      
 Long-Range Sensors
 ------------------
 If people had long-range sensors, they would rarely use them to scan for 
 new signs of life. I think they would use them to avoid work. You could 
 run a continuous scan for your boss and then quickly transport yourself 
 out of the area when he came near. If your manager died in his office, 
 you would know minutes before the authorities discovered him, and that 
 means extra break time.
      
 Vulcan Death Grip
 -----------------
 Before all you Trekkies write to correct me, I know there is no such 
 thing as a Vulcan Death Grip even in Star Trek. But I wish there were. 
 That would have come in handy many times. It would be easy to make the 
 Vulcan Death Grip look like an accident.
      
 'I was just straightening his collar and he collapsed.'
      
 I think the only thing that keeps most people from randomly killing 
 other citizens is the bloody mess it makes and the high likelihood of 
 getting caught. With the Vulcan Death Grip, it would be clean and 
 virtually undetectable. Everybody would be killing people left and 
 right. You wouldn't be able to have a decent conversation at the office 
 over the sound of dead co-workers hitting the carpet. The most common 
 sounds in corporate America would be, 'I'm sorry I couldn't give you a 
 bigger raise, but . . . erk!'
      
 And that's why the future won't be like Star Trek.
      
 .......................................................... 
 Written by Scott Adams, published in "The Dilbert Future" by
 HarperBusiness.  Copyright United Media, 1997.  Please keep this notice 
 with the text.
 ..........................................................
       >>


---------------------
Forwarded message:
From:	VictorHarris_at_BLDG10@ca.slr.com
To:	dboyer@BayNetworks.COM, JACKSPLASH@AOL.COM, snomura@mail.arc.nasa.gov,
PAULSINGLA@ca.slr.com
Date: 97-07-29 18:39:18 EDT

     

     
     
There are so many Star Trek(tm) spin-offs that it is easy to fool 
yourself into thinking that the Star Trek vision is an accurate vision 
of the future. Sadly, Star Trek does not take into account the 
stupidity, selfishness, and horniness of the average human being.  Allow 
me to describe some of the more obvious errors in the Star Trek vision.
     
Medical Technology
------------------
On Star Trek, the doctors have handheld devices that instantly close 
any openings in the skin. Imagine that sort of device in the hands
of your unscrupulous friends. They would sneak up behind you and seal 
your ass shut as a practical joke. The devices would be sold in novelty 
stores instead of medical outlets. All things considered, I'm happy 
that it's not easy to close other people's orifices.
     
Transporter
-----------
It would be great to be able to beam your molecules across space and 
then reassemble them. The only problem is that you have to trust your 
co-worker to operate the transporter. These are the same people who 
won't add paper to the photocopier or make a new pot of coffee after 
taking the last drop. I don't think they'll be double-checking the 
transporter coordinates. They'll be accidentally beaming people into 
walls, pets, and furniture. People will spend all their time 
apologizing for having inanimate objects protruding from parts of their 
bodies.
     
'Pay no attention to the knickknacks; I got beamed into a hutch
 yesterday.'
     
If I could beam things from one place to another, I'd never leave the 
house. I'd sit in a big comfy chair and just start beaming groceries, 
stereo equipment, cheerleaders, and anything else I wanted right into my 
house. I'm fairly certain I would abuse this power. If anybody came to 
arrest me, I'd beam them into space. If I wanted some paintings for my 
walls, I'd beam the contents of the Louvre over to my place, pick out 
the good stuff, and beam the rest into my neighbor's garage.
     
     
If I were watching the news on television and didn't like what
I heard, I would beam the anchorman into my living room during the 
commercial break, give him a vicious wedgie, and beam him back 
before anybody noticed. I'd never worry about 'keeping up with
the Joneses,' because as soon as they got something nice, it 
would disappear right out of their hands. My neighbors would have 
to use milk crates for furniture. And that's only after I had all 
the milk crates I would ever need for the rest of my life. 
There's only one thing that could keep me from spending all my 
time wreaking havoc with the transporter: the holodeck.
     
Holodeck
--------
For those of you who only watched the 'old' Star Trek, the holodeck can 
create simulated worlds that look and feel just like the real thing. The 
characters on Star Trek use the holodeck for recreation during breaks 
from work. This is somewhat unrealistic. If I had a holodeck, I'd close 
the door and never come out until I died of exhaustion. It would be hard 
to convince me I should be anywhere but in the holodeck, getting my oil 
massage from Cindy Crawford and her simulated twin sister.
     
Holodecks would be very addicting. If there weren't enough holodecks to 
go around, I'd get the names of all the people who had reservations 
ahead of me and beam them into concrete walls. I'd feel tense about
it, but that's exactly why I'd need a massage.
     
I'm afraid the holodeck will be society's last invention.
     
Sex with Aliens
---------------
     
According to Star Trek, there are many alien races populated with 
creatures who would like to have sex with humans.
This would open up a lot of anatomical possibilities, but imagine 
the confusion. It's hard enough to have sex with human beings, 
much less humanoids. One wrong move and you're suddenly 
transported naked to the Gamma Quadrant to stand trial for 
who-knows-what. This could only add to performance anxiety. You 
would never be quite sure what moves would be sensual and what 
moves would be a galactic-sized mistake.
     
        Me Trying to Have Sex with an Alien
        -----------------------------------
     
        Me:      May I touch that?
     
        Alien:  That is not an erogenous zone. It is a
                separate corporeal being that has been 
                attached to my body for six hundred years.
     
        Me:     It's cute. I wonder if it would let me
                have sex with it.
     
        Alien:  That's exactly what I said six hundred
                years ago.
     
The best part about having sex with aliens, according to the Star Trek 
model, is that the alien always dies a tragic death soon afterward. I 
don't have to tell you how many problems that would solve. 
Realistically, the future won't be that convenient.
     
Phasers
-------
I would love to have a device that would stun people into 
unconsciousness without killing them. I would use it ten times 
a day. If I got bad service at the convenience store, I'd
zap the clerk. If somebody with big hair sat in front of me 
at the theater, zap!
     
On Star Trek, there are no penalties for stunning people with phasers. 
It happens all the time. All you have to do is claim you were possessed 
by an alien entity. Apparently, that is viewed as a credible defense in 
the Star Trek future. Imagine real criminals in a world where the 'alien 
possession' defense is credible.
     
Criminal:  Yes, officer, I did steal that vehicle, and
           I did kill the occupants, but I was possessed 
           by an evil alien entity.
     
Officer:         Well, okay. Move along.
     
I wish I had a phaser right now. My neighbor's dog likes to 
stand under my bedroom window on the other side of the fence 
and bark for hours at a time. My neighbor has employed the bold 
defense that he believes it might be another neighbor's dog, 
despite the fact that I am standing there looking at him 
barking only twenty feet away. In a situation like this, a 
phaser is really the best approach. I could squeeze off a clean 
shot through the willow tree. A phaser doesn't make much noise, 
so it wouldn't disturb anyone. Then the unhappy little dog and 
I could both get some sleep. If the neighbor complains, I'll 
explain that the phaser was fired by the other neighbor's dog, 
a known troublemaker who is said to be invisible.
     
And if that doesn't work, a photon torpedo is clearly indicated.
     
Cyborgs
-------
Given the choice, I would rather be a cyborg instead of 100 percent 
human. I like the thought of technology becoming part of my body. As a 
human, I am constantly running to the toolbox in my garage to get a tool 
to deal with some new household malfunction. If I were a cyborg, I might 
have an electric drill on my arm, plus a metric socket set. That would 
save a lot of trips. From what I've seen, the cyborg concept is a 
modular design, so you can add whatever tools you think you'd use most.
     
I'd love to see crosshairs appear in my viewfinder every time I looked 
at someone. It would make me feel menacing, and I'd like that. I'd 
program myself so that anytime I saw a car salesman, a little message 
would appear in my viewfinder that said 'Target Locked On.'
     
It would also be great to have my computer built into my skull. That way 
I could surf the Net during useless periods of life, such as when people 
talk to me. All I'd have to do is initiate a head-nodding subroutine 
during boring conversations and I could amuse myself in my head all day 
long.
     
I think that if anyone could become a cyborg, there would be a huge rush 
of people getting in line for the conversion. Kids would like it for the 
look. Adults would like it for its utility. Cyborg technology has 
something for everyone. So, unlike Star Trek, I can imagine everyone 
wanting to be a cyborg.
     
The only downside I can see is that when the human part dies and you're 
at the funeral, the cyborg part will try to claw its way out of the 
casket and slay all the mourners. But that risk can be minimized by 
saying you have an important business meeting, so you can't make it to 
the service.
     
Shields
-------
I wish I had an invisible force field. I'd use it all the time, 
especially around people who spit when they talk or get too close to my 
personal space. In fact, I'd probably need a shield quite a bit if I 
also had a phaser to play with.
     
I wouldn't need a big shield system like the one they use to protect the 
Enterprise, maybe just a belt-clip device for personal use. I could 
insult dangerous people without fear of retribution. Whatever crumbs
of personality I now have would be completely unnecessary in the future. 
On the plus side, it would make shopping much more fun.
     
             Shopping with Shields Up
             ------------------------
     
     
         Me:          Ring this up for me, you
                      unpleasant cretin.
     
         Saleswoman:  I oughta slug you!
     
         Me:          Try it. My shields are up.
     
         Saleswoman:  Damn!
     
         Me:          There's nothing you can do to
                      harm me.
     
         Saleswoman:  I guess you're right. Would you like
                      to open a charge account? Our interest 
                      rates are very reasonable.
     
         Me:          Nice try.
     
     
Long-Range Sensors
------------------
If people had long-range sensors, they would rarely use them to scan for 
new signs of life. I think they would use them to avoid work. You could 
run a continuous scan for your boss and then quickly transport yourself 
out of the area when he came near. If your manager died in his office, 
you would know minutes before the authorities discovered him, and that 
means extra break time.
     
Vulcan Death Grip
-----------------
Before all you Trekkies write to correct me, I know there is no such 
thing as a Vulcan Death Grip even in Star Trek. But I wish there were. 
That would have come in handy many times. It would be easy to make the 
Vulcan Death Grip look like an accident.
     
'I was just straightening his collar and he collapsed.'
     
I think the only thing that keeps most people from randomly killing 
other citizens is the bloody mess it makes and the high likelihood of 
getting caught. With the Vulcan Death Grip, it would be clean and 
virtually undetectable. Everybody would be killing people left and 
right. You wouldn't be able to have a decent conversation at the office 
over the sound of dead co-workers hitting the carpet. The most common 
sounds in corporate America would be, 'I'm sorry I couldn't give you a 
bigger raise, but . . . erk!'
     
And that's why the future won't be like Star Trek.
     
.......................................................... 
Written by Scott Adams, published in "The Dilbert Future" by
HarperBusiness.  Copyright United Media, 1997.  Please keep this notice 
with the text.
..........................................................

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org  Wed Jul 30 09:56:44 1997

Received: from [208.202.191.193] (ppp-max2-157.grin.net [208.202.191.157]) by fish.grin.net (8.8.5/8.7.3) with SMTP id JAA27922 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Wed, 30 Jul 1997 09:56:08 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <v01540b03b004fccfe429@[208.202.191.193]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 30 Jul 1997 10:10:37 -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: emdash@grin.net (e.menon)
Subject: nrr: the cyclical aspects of my life
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

are getting so tiring! it seems that a lot of ppl feel comfortable pouring
their souls out on this list, and since i don't have a therapist perhaps
doing the same will help me out here. so here's the scoop: i moved out here
a few months ago, and posted an intro and met some ppl from it. i thought i
had found some good friends.... actually, i met one person who introduced
me to his friends, and they were all around my age, so i thought i had
found some sort of a niche here. well, tables have turned at this point,
and what it all boils down to is the old adage "don't sleep with your
friends". don't. you know, it's weird. 'coz i have in the past, had these
sorts of relationships and we're all still friends. guess it depends on the
person. anyway, since i know of only 2 ppl on this list who know what's
going on, i don't think this is a problem, posting this. besides, i give
these ppl enough credit to form their own opinions of both me and this
other person. so, here i am, back to where i started.... lonely in sf. (and
*you* [k] - my loneliness isn't about you at all! you're my bud - i'm just
rambling at this point 'coz i'd like to meet some more ppl!)

so, if there's anyone out there in the same boat, relatively new to sf, or
not so new.... i work (really) hard, play (semi) hard (i say this 'coz i've
met some ppl out here who make me look like a complete prude!), love to
dance my ass off, what else.... a bit on the older side (25+? i'm 30...).
and girls! why is it that i only get responses from men? not that i mind,
really (most of my close friends _are_ men), but i could use some girl
friends! anyway, i think i make a really good friend if you're a good
person.... it's just that i'm really busy with work, and sort of shy, so i
find it hard to meet ppl. outside of raving, i'm obsessed with the arts,
and sf ballet is performing FREE this sunday if anyone wants to join me!

and the ppl that were interested in SOMA.... please write me as there's
been some major changes.

feeling not so much bitter as much as confused and lonely (had to sign off
like this as i feel like i'm writing dear abby!)

cheers - e. :)

.............................................................................

over. Now it's more like, 'This is my life,' 'This is my tribe.'"
                                                               - Nan Goldin

"That so few now dare to be eccentric marks the cheif danger of the time."
                                              - John Stuart Mill (1806-1873)

>From: Janell Picard <jpicard@acme.nsc.com>
>Organization: Intranet content
>X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.01SGoldC-SGI (X11; I; IRIX 6.3 IP32)
>Mime-Version: 1.0
>To: Daniel Picard <poobear@hotmail.com>
>Subject: a joke
>Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
>Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
>
>Son: Dad, I have a special report for school.  Can I ask you a 
question?
>
>Dad: Sure son, what's the question?
>
>Son: What is politics?
>
>Dad: Well son, let's take our home for example.  I am the wage earner,
>so let's call me the management.  Your mother is the administrator of
>the money, so let's call her the government.  We take care of you and
>your needs, so let's call you the people.  We'll call the maid the
>working class and your baby brother the future.  Understand?
>
>Son: I'm not really sure dad, I'll have to think about it.
>
>That night, the boy is awakened by his baby brother's crying, so he
>went to see what was wrong.  Discovering that the baby had a heavily
>soiled diaper, the boy went to his parent's room and found his mother
>fast asleep.  He than went to the maid's room, where, peeking through
>the keyhole, he saw his father in bed with the maid.  The boy's
>knocking went totally unheard.  The boy went back to his room and went
>to sleep.
>
>The next morning...
>
>Son: Dad, I think I understand politics.
>
>Dad: That's great son, explain it to me in your own words.
>
>Son: While the management is screwing the working class, the
>government is fast asleep, the people are being completely ignored
>and the future is full of shit.

---Troy Sheets <tsheets@saturn5.com> wrote:
>
> 
> It looks like everyone is in the market for 1200's again...

Troy, I just bought some decks last weekend at K&K Music in the
southbay.  They wanted like 550 a piece but Science and I talked the
guy down to like 500.  It was still disappointing because I was
expecting to pay (at most) 500 - but more like 450-475 per table.  

I hear you can get last month's (or this month's) X-celerator (is that
how you spell it?:) magazine and clip out the technics 1200's for 449
coupon from the Trance & Jungle Factory and it to Good Guy's where
they'll match prices in the bay area.  Catch is, Good Guy's will call
and if T&JF doesn't have them in stock, they won't match.  Yikes, I
know.

If you've got a lot of patience, you can probably get them for lower
than what I paid (500), so good luck.

-jspace

ps. did anyone find it really hard to install the cartridges onto the
head rack?  damn, those nuts and screws they give you are way too
small.
It literally took my roommate and I like several hours to assemble my
1200's, no thanks to my Stanton's.

from ProtoLab playing live from  8pm till 10pm at City Espresso,  5237
Stevens Creek blvd, Santa Clara. 408.248.4500. So come and enjoy some
great music and people.

And while your there you can pick up  tickets for the  BBQ & BEATS Campout.
Remember, there are two different tickets. One is for people bringing there own
food, which are free. If you can make any kind of donation to help cover
cost that
would be great but not required. There also will be tickets for those that
want to
eat the food we are bringing, and those are $10. You can checkout the BBQ &
BEATS
webpage...URL in sig...for up to date info.

I can arrange a way to get them to you.

Subject: Re: best price for 1200s 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Wed, 30 Jul 97 10:01:54 PDT."
             <199707301701.KAA07288@atari.saturn5.com> 
Date: Wed, 30 Jul 97 14:52:33 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


I suggest buying them mailorder. I've had good experiences w/ J&R Music
World in NY, and very good experiences w/ "One Call" (aka Huppins HiFi,
Camera and Video) in WA (see URL below). In addition to saving on the
ridiculous 8.25% sales tax, they have very competitive pricing. With
J&R Music World, you can haggle them down a few more percent on some
items, or get them to throw in free shipping (3% of purchase price), or
get them to match some other price. "One Call" includes shipping as
part of the price.

In either case, you can save serious bucks over the prices at a place
like Guitar Center or the Good Guys (both of which are total ripoffs).
Good Guys has a "low price guarantee" but they won't apply it to out of
state mailorder places... combine that with the 8.25% savings on sales
tax and I end up NEVER buying any gear other than cables and connectors
and other widgets at local shops.

Anyways, here's a good listing of mail order retailers
	http://garbanzo.ssesco.com/nau/mailorder.htm

I know that J&R sells 1200's, don't know about "One Call" ...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: "D. Kolin Better" <kolin@verso.com>
Subject: (sorta sp) fashion question
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I know that most of y'all don't like to make an effort to look 'like a
raver', so I'd like to pose a couple of fashion questions:

1) Where do you shop?
2) Do you go for a type of look (hippieraver, candyraver, clubber, mod,
whatever) when you go out to a party or club? If not, can you describe what
you wear when you go out?
3) What clothes do you want and have a hard time finding?
4) Would you buy clothing online?
5) How much do you spend on clothing in an average month?
6) What information would you like to see on a site that sold clothing
online? Club info? UG Party info? Music/DJ info?
7) What accessories would you buy online? Glowy things? Whistles?
Sunglasses? What else?

The reason for these questions? Simple. Profit... pure profit..... greed is
good, greed works.... Oh, wait a second, I'm getting carried away.
Seriously, a partner and I are investigating the possibility of starting an
online store, specializing in club and rave fashions.  For obvious reasons,
we'd like to be as responsive to the scene as possible, and can't do it
without your feedback. So, any thoughts you might have would be
appreciated.

Let me know what you think !! - Kolin

Subject: FYI -- MC-303 mailing list and Web site
Date: Wed, 30 Jul 97 15:24:08 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


I just discovered a good local MC-303 web site and an international
mailing list. http://www.mc303.net/index.html is the URL, and
http://www.mc303.net/maillist.htm is the URL for subscribing over the
web.
 
The site even has links to  good audio samples links so the doubters
can hear that you can have "the sound", plus polyphony,
multitimbrality, and even good drums all in one portable, easily
battery powered box (http://www.acid.demon.nl/).

For manual subscription:
      To manualy Subscribe, Unsubscribe or switch between
      Digest and Active (normal) messages, mail to
      listserver@mail.mc303.net.
      The FROM field of the email message MUST contain your
      email address.
      The BODY (thats where you type your message) MUST
      contain ONE (and only one) of the following commands:

                  SUBSCRIBE groovelist
                  UNSUBSCRIBE groovelist
                  SET groovelist DIGEST
                  SET groovelist ACTIVE

      Post your normal messages to
      GROOVELIST@MAIL.MC303.NET not to the listserver
      address.
      And ofcause, don't send administrative messages to the list,
      use the listserver address.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

------------   ORIGINAL ATTACHMENT   --------
SENT 07-30-97 FROM SMTPGATE (mayer@netcom.com)


I suggest buying them mailorder. I've had good experiences w/ J&R Music
World in NY, and very good experiences w/ "One Call" (aka Huppins HiFi,
Camera and Video) in WA (see URL below). In addition to saving on the
ridiculous 8.25% sales tax, they have very competitive pricing. With
J&R Music World, you can haggle them down a few more percent on some
items, or get them to throw in free shipping (3% of purchase price), or
get them to match some other price. "One Call" includes shipping as
part of the price.

In either case, you can save serious bucks over the prices at a place
like Guitar Center or the Good Guys (both of which are total ripoffs).
Good Guys has a "low price guarantee" but they won't apply it to out of
state mailorder places... combine that with the 8.25% savings on sales
tax and I end up NEVER buying any gear other than cables and connectors
and other widgets at local shops.

Anyways, here's a good listing of mail order retailers
        http://garbanzo.ssesco.com/nau/mailorder.htm

I know that J&R sells 1200's, don't know about "One Call" ...

>I know that most of y'all don't like to make an effort to look 'like a
>raver', so I'd like to pose a couple of fashion questions:

>1) Where do you shop?

Depends on how much money I have in my pocket.  Those "Clothes by the Pound" places are pretty cool.  Ross is also a good hookup for cheap clothes.  dont buy shoes there.

>2) Do you go for a type of look (hippieraver, candyraver, clubber, mod,
>whatever) when you go out to a party or club? 

I've never understood this 'trying to achieve a certain look' with fashion.  I guess I just wasnt raised with a fashion consious outlook on life.  I know what cloths look cool to me, but I dont try to achieve a look.  

>If not, can you describe what you wear when you go out?

The same thing I wear when I stay in.

>3) What clothes do you want and have a hard time finding?

none really.

>4) Would you buy clothing online?

maybe.  I usually like to try stuff on first.  If there was some sort of return policy then maybe I would.

>5) How much do you spend on clothing in an average month?

I dont go shopping for clothes every month.  This month I spent 50 bucks on a pair of shoes.  I need some shirts and socks...

>6) What information would you like to see on a site that sold clothing
>online? Club info? UG Party info? Music/DJ info?

A 'who has bought our clothes' section.  You could have people send in pictures of themselves wearing your clothes (You know, like what they do at Hobee's)

>7) What accessories would you buy online? Glowy things? Whistles?
>Sunglasses? What else?

Backpacks....buttbags.....earplugs...mix tapes....

Hey there. I have a request of all you fine folks. When you are replying
to someone's message, please consider quoting just the relevent parts.
There are are a few reasons for this:

1) It is really annoying(for me at least) to page through a 10 page quoted
   message to see someone put a "me too" or a couple of lines of followup.

2) It saves bandwidth which is at a premium.

3) You will feel better as a human being, and people will find you
   irresistable.

Well no promises on #3... ;-)

			         Black Adder

             <19970731001617.12922.rocketmail@send2.rocketmail.com> 
Date: Wed, 30 Jul 97 17:34:24 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


>I'm just curious - since I have to get a CD player to accompany my
>sound system, I might as well get a CD player which I can use to mix. 
>How much do Pioneer CDJ500mkII's go for a piece?  I'd probably only
>get 1 and not a pair.
>
>The thing is, I just have a shitload of CDs I could use, if I only had
>a Cd player which can do more than pause/play.  

I got my CDJ500mkII's for $599.95 ea.  I personally think they're great
and they sound good too, and they're quite solid.

There was an argument on this list a while back about these players
skipping when the bass is too loud -- like on a 10,000 watt soundsystem
with inadequately compliant isolation... (i have plenty of loudness --
130dB w/o distortion -- plenty of bass, have my speakers on the same
"industrial" shelves as my CD player, and have no problems w/
skipping). 

The other ones to look at (IMHO) are the Vestax (which are cool, but
expensive) and the Denon's (which have a crappy "user interface" in my
opinion). THere's also a new Vestax out which has 2 cd players and a
mixer in one unit for  a lot less money than separate components...
Avoid Gemini, Numark, GLI, etc. (you get what you pay for).

Subject: Re: (sorta sp) fashion question 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Wed, 30 Jul 97 15:07:11 PDT."
             <v03110702b0056b6bac24@[206.245.203.110]> 
Date: Wed, 30 Jul 97 18:04:12 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


> 1) Where do you shop?

COSTCO! (Fuck fashion -- i save my money for electronics and CD's!). 
Ross.
Garage sales.
Used/Consignment stores.
Clothes I pick up when I'm travelling.
Nordstrom's (when they have a sale).
Macy's (when they have a sale).
Random shops that I pass by that have clothing that isn't raver-fashionable
(i buy things that transcend raver fashion, that will remain fashionable
(or uniquely hideous, or simply useful) long after the fashion-du-jour has
become cheezy -- I have yet to buy any clothing at a "raver" shop, and
I doubt I ever will (unless there's a sale, and the clothes fit and 
are good quality).

> 2) Do you go for a type of look (hippieraver, candyraver, clubber, mod,
> whatever) when you go out to a party or club? If not, can you describe what
> you wear when you go out?

I try to look like myself. Pretty much what I'd wear anytime, except
that I like something a little more colorful for going out. Jeans.
SLacks. Shirt or T-shirt. Last rave I went to (Sunset boat party) I was
wearing $20.00 slacks i bought at Costo, a $20.00 cotton hawaiian print
shirt i bought at Costco. And $80.00 Rockport Prowalkers I bought at
Nordstrom's (other than CLark's, these are the best dancing shoe on the
planet). And a futuristic-looking red/shiny metallic "solar alpha" ski
jacket  (Kaelin) that they had on sale at B&D sports a while back
($150.00 for a jacket that normally costs $350.00  -- such a bahgain!).

> 3) What clothes do you want and have a hard time finding?

Diesel Jeans. Too fucking expensive. Last pair I had was great and I
got them in NYC for $40.00 cuz they were on sale.  That, and these very
comfy and high-quality pants you can get in the UK called "Gentlemen's
Breeches" (GB). Clothes by Hugo Boss that isn't overpriced :-)....

> 4) Would you buy clothing online?

No way.  How could you tell if it fit? Being taller and bigger than
most folks, I wear XL or XXL shirts, 'cept that not all XL's are
actually the same size. SO there's no way I'd trust the mfgr's
labelling of something to be indicative of fit. I've even managed to
dissuade my girlfriend from catalog-shopping cuz the product you see in
the picture looks much better and fits much better than the product you
actually get. OnLine is no different than catalog shopping. Don't need
it, don't want it. OnLine is only good for buying CD's,
Audio/Video/Electronics/Computers....

> 5) How much do you spend on clothing in an average month?

$0.00-$50.00, depending on the month. Sometimes more for special
long-term clothing like shoes, jackets, sports clothing, etc.

> 6) What information would you like to see on a site that sold clothing
> online? Club info? UG Party info? Music/DJ info?

There's plenty of this info available in a non-commercial context.
Unless the site had info that was very specific to the goods being
produced and made you *hunger* for the product in an almost
teledildonic fashion, it's not useful. Do you really want to compete
with hyperreal? Here's a site that has made me part with my not-so-hard
earned $$$ http://www.sweetwater.com -- note that it's not clothing.

> 7) What accessories would you buy online? Glowy things? Whistles?
> Sunglasses? What else?

Cables, Connectors. Plugs. Adaptors. :-)

At 6:04 PM 7/30/97, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>> 1) Where do you shop?
>

>Clothes I pick up when I'm travelling.

***  Well, I pick up my clothes in a similar fashion...  When I give 4+
ravers a ride to a local  (I.E. Party) and bring 4+ different ravers
back... I ususally get a collection of clothes, toys, waterbottles and such
left in my car.   So I guess one can say that I keep up with raver trends.
Alltho' I'm not really trying...

>> 2) Do you go for a type of look (hippieraver, candyraver, clubber, mod,
>> whatever) when you go out to a party or club? If not, can you describe what
>> you wear when you go out?

 I shy from the shiny stuff...  I guess that I'm stuck in 1993 when cops
cracked HARD on break-in raves (SPAZ 93-94... the good ole days).  It was
easiest to wear dark jeans and a dark shirt so you can bolt from a busted
party and dissapper in a crowd or alley (Try blending in a group with
bright orange pants, a yello shirt, and 3ft platform shoez).


L-8


"Awaken"

From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@msn.com>

Subject: RE: (sorta sp) fashion question
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

>1) Where do you shop?
Thrift Stores!!!  My favorite is this phatty one on Fruitridge (I live in 
Sacramento), I hear Funk City is pretty good for trendy type used gear but I 
haven't got a chance to really check it out.  For new clothes, I love Ross, 
that store is the greatest, cheap and sorta trendy.  Or the kid's section in 
any cheap ass store--I got this cute & quality Dr. Seuss tee at McFrugals for 
$4.99!!!
>2) Do you go for a type of look (hippieraver, candyraver, clubber, mod,
>whatever) when you go out to a party or club? If not, can you describe >what 
you wear when you go out?
When I go out . . . depends on where I'm going.  I like to go for 70s-ish 
clean cut polyester freak mama, but I've been sporting a lot of jeans and tank 
tops since it's kinda hot outside.  When I'm going to a party I'm usually 
sporting slick comfy yet feminine stuff I can dance in and *bonus* maybe looks 
cool in a blacklight.  Comfort first.
>3) What clothes do you want and have a hard time finding?
Clothes to wear in the heat!  Like I said, polyester just doesn't cut it in 
100 degree weather or a sweaty party in some poorly ventilated crowded 
wherehouse.  I'm usually not looking for certain brand names cuz I'm a big 
bargain shopper, but that usually means I dress a little more originally than 
most folx so that's okay.  I'd still like to find some more neon stuff because 
I love bright clothes in or out of parties.
>4) Would you buy clothing online?
Er, probably not.  Why?  1.  Can't try stuff on  2.  I don't have credit cards 
and those are best for online shopping  3.  How do I know if I send off a 
check that I'm going to get stuff back?  Anybody can set up a website, can I 
trust every one I see?
>5) How much do you spend on clothing in an average month?
$50-$100.  I love shopping, I like to hit thrift shops once a week (new stuff 
coming in all the time).  I'm due for a trip real soon, matter of fact.
>6) What information would you like to see on a site that sold clothing
>online? Club info? UG Party info? Music/DJ info?
Yuck, not really any of those, seems kind of cheesy for a clothing site, plus 
I can get all that kind of info through sfraves, hyperreal, or URB.  Maybe 
some pictures of fashion trends, like some pictures of people at a party, or 
on the street.  Real people, not fashion models sporting unattainable Versace 
(btw a fashion legend) and runway type fashion, but just some regular folks 
walking around living life . . . fashionably.  And other fashion info like 
hair tips or stupid little trends I'll end up following, etc.
>7) What accessories would you buy online? Glowy things? Whistles?
>Sunglasses? What else?
Now I would buy hard to find "rave" gear online, because where the hell else 
are you going to find it?  Like an industrial sized box of 200 glowsticks, or 
a 60 oz. vat of neon green body glitter, or black lights, or those huge 
lollipops you can only get at Disneyland, big bright glowy toys, glow in the 
dark jewelry, and other asinine (sp) wastes of money.

I love clothes!  If this site gets up and running, I might have to go against 
my better judgement and make a purchase . . . 

xoxo--Miccaela

It's 2 am, it's time for me to try to sleep
I feel insomnia tapping at my feet
smiling at Eudora high on life
I listen to mystere all day and night
My best friend yury will leave the country at 11am
In Europe I wish him happiness and fame
He just left my house, I hugged him bye
to bad I smoked that roach, we coulda gotten high
back to the point I was going to make
I should get to bed for tomorrow I shall wake (late)

ok I was going to rhyme the whole thing, but I ran out of rhymes. Who wants
to go somewhere for lunch today (Thursday) around the san jose area? I'm
down for whatever time, whatever place, whatever.
Actually I'm listening to graeme the special edition tape and it's PHAT!!!!
This is the only tape that's so emotional, it made me cry. I know it's
-=*house*=- music, but house has a bad rep for no reason, it's not the same
as it use to be, and all you house haters probably never hear good house
(not to start a flame war or anything :()
anyway, e-mail me, or page me :510-319-0374, and we'll satisfy those cranky
munchies.

i know i know we're discouraged from promoting our own stuff on these lists.

but i've seen ohter people do it, and i just stayed up ALL NIGHT so you
people could have something new and exciting to listen to.  it's now 6:20
am.  curse that santa cruz roasting company.  actually i should thank them
for giving me the stamina to stay up this late.

But if you like bouncy bubbly tripped out sorta but not totally derrick
carter style house and breakbeat, you could be in luck. "Champagne Trance".

No, I wasn't drinking when I made this tape.  But you see, I just dj'd my
first ravE wedding last weekend (hi amanda and dustin 3!  love u!)  and I
just thought champagne reception.

Of course there wasn't much champagne being consumed at this rave wedding.

performance.  This tape was recorded at Ten Forward Studios (my house) in
Belmont, CA.  94002.

through the hassle of doing the record store thing for this one.  Strictly
word of mouth.  And I'm only gonna charge $7, not including mailing cost.

Sorry for the waste of bandwidth, but I thought this would give the kiddies 
something to do when the party ends but thEy're pArty isn't over yet....enjoy!  
Nathan
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

50 FUN THINGS TO DO AT WAL-MART OR K-MART


1. Take shopping carts for the express purpose of filling them and
stranding them at strategic locations.

2. Ride those little electronic cars at the front of the store.

3. Set all the alarm clocks to go off at ten minute intervals
throughout the day.

4. Start playing Calvinball; see how many people you can get to join
in.

5. Contaminate the entire auto department by sampling all the spray
air fresheners.

6. Challenge other customers to duels with tubes of gift wrap.

7. Leave cryptic messages on the typewriters.

8. Re-dress the mannequins as you see fit.

9. When there are people behind you, walk REALLY SLOW, especially
thin narrow aisles.

10. Walk up to an employee and tell him in an official tone, "I
think we've got a Code 3 in Housewares," and see what happens.

11. Tune all the radios to a polka station; then turn them all off
and turn the volumes to "10".

12. Play with the automatic doors.

13. Walk up to complete strangers and say, "Hi!  I haven't seen you
in so long!..." etc.  See if they play along to avoid embarrassment.

14. While walking through the clothing department, ask yourself loud
enough for all to hear, "Who BUYS this junk, anyway?"

15. Repeat Number 14 in the jewelry department.

16. Ride a display bicycle through the store; claim you're taking it
for a "test drive."

17. Follow people through the aisles, always staying about five feet
away. Continue to do this until they leave the department.

18. Play soccer with a group of friend, using the entire store as
your playing field.

19. As the cashier runs your purchases over the scanner, look
mesmerized and say, "Wow.  Magic!"

20. Put M&M's on layaway.

21. Move "Caution: Wet Floor" signs to carpeted areas.

22. Set up a tent in the camping department; tell others you'll only
invite them in if they bring pillows from Bed and Bath.

23. Test the fishing rods and see what you can "catch" from the
other aisles.

24. Ask other customers if they have any Grey Poupon.

25. Drape a blanket around your shoulders and run around saying,
"...I'm Batman.  Come, Robin--to the Batcave!"

26. TP as much of the store as possible.

27. Randomly throw things over into neighboring aisles.

28. Play with the calculators so that they all spell "hello" upside
down.

29. When someone asks if you need help, begin to cry and ask, "Why
won't you people just leave me alone?"

30. When two or three people are walking ahead of you, run between
them, yelling, "Red Rover!"

31. Make up nonsense products and ask newly hired employees if there
are any in stock, i.e., "Do you have any Shnerples here?"

32. Take up an entire aisle in Toys by setting up a full scale
battlefield with G.I. Joes vs. the X-Men.

33. Take bets on the battle described above.

34. Nonchalantly "test" the brushes and combs in Cosmetics.

36. Hold indoor shopping cart races.

37. Dart around suspiciously while humming the theme from  "Mission:
Impossible."

38. Attempt to fit into very large gym bags.

39. Attempt to fit others into very large gym bags.

40. Say things like, "Would you be so kind as to direct me to your
Twinkies?"

41. Set up a "Valet Parking" sign in front of the store. 

42. Two words: "Marco Polo."

43. Leave Cheerios in Lawn and Garden, pillows in the pet food aisle,
etc. 

44. "Re-alphabetize" the CD's in Electronics.

46. When someone steps away from their cart to look at something,
quickly make off with it without saying a word.

47. Relax in the patio furniture until you get kicked out.

48. When an announcement comes over the loudspeaker, assume the fetal
position and scream, "No, no!  It's those voices again!"

49. Pay off layaways fifty cents at a time.

50. Drag a lounge chair on display over to the magazines and relax.
If the store has a food court, buy a soft drink; explain that you
don't get out much, and ask if they can put a little umbrella in it.

*BONUS*  Attempt all of the above during the same visit.

hey guys... I'm going to be leaving my company soon and wanna see if
anyone is interested in my position. You don't need stupid certification
or papers or any crap shit fuck like that =) (I hate that crap, but
still it's a plus), but you do need to know your shit! ya gotta know
computers well, basic and advanced concepts. We use novell 3.11 and
cc:mail r8, we have remote access and ummm video teleconferencing, and a
buncha stuff like that. All PCs (yay!), and ummm running wfw311 on
almost all. You gotta be able to catch on quick and be a good and fast
learner. You've gotta be resourceful. The company is a mortgage/loan
firm, with a pretty impressive computer department. We're family
oriented, and of moderate size (about 100 or so employees). We try to
stay on the leading edge of technology. You need a valid drivers license
and insurance, because we have satellite offices (which mean field work
too). ummm need to be able to build, fix, and troubleshoot PCs. This is
an awesome opportunity for superdooper cool experience. Must dress nice
(we are a mortgage/loan firm), and look presentable. No hats or rave
gear at work. No funky hair or colored hair, no odd piercings,
nananana...

anyone interested? write me back or call me at 408.281.3600 ex.218
between the hours of 10am and 7pm. Best to call me, but you can write
back if you'd like. ummm if you get my voice mail, leave a message and
I'll call you back.

peace and good luck.jer

50 FUN THINGS TO DO AT WAL-MART OR K-MART


1. Take shopping carts for the express purpose of filling them and
stranding them at strategic locations.

2. Ride those little electronic cars at the front of the store.

3. Set all the alarm clocks to go off at ten minute intervals
throughout the day.

4. Start playing Calvinball; see how many people you can get to join
in.

5. Contaminate the entire auto department by sampling all the spray
air fresheners.

6. Challenge other customers to duels with tubes of gift wrap.

7. Leave cryptic messages on the typewriters.

8. Re-dress the mannequins as you see fit.

9. When there are people behind you, walk REALLY SLOW, especially
thin narrow aisles.

10. Walk up to an employee and tell him in an official tone, "I
think we've got a Code 3 in Housewares," and see what happens.

11. Tune all the radios to a polka station; then turn them all off
and turn the volumes to "10".

12. Play with the automatic doors.

13. Walk up to complete strangers and say, "Hi!  I haven't seen you
in so long!..." etc.  See if they play along to avoid embarrassment.

14. While walking through the clothing department, ask yourself loud
enough for all to hear, "Who BUYS this junk, anyway?"

15. Repeat Number 14 in the jewelry department.

16. Ride a display bicycle through the store; claim you're taking it
for a "test drive."

17. Follow people through the aisles, always staying about five feet
away. Continue to do this until they leave the department.

18. Play soccer with a group of friend, using the entire store as
your playing field.

19. As the cashier runs your purchases over the scanner, look
mesmerized and say, "Wow.  Magic!"

20. Put M&M's on layaway.

21. Move "Caution: Wet Floor" signs to carpeted areas.

22. Set up a tent in the camping department; tell others you'll only
invite them in if they bring pillows from Bed and Bath.

23. Test the fishing rods and see what you can "catch" from the
other aisles.

24. Ask other customers if they have any Grey Poupon.

25. Drape a blanket around your shoulders and run around saying,
"...I'm Batman.  Come, Robin--to the Batcave!"

26. TP as much of the store as possible.

27. Randomly throw things over into neighboring aisles.

28. Play with the calculators so that they all spell "hello" upside
down.

29. When someone asks if you need help, begin to cry and ask, "Why
won't you people just leave me alone?"

30. When two or three people are walking ahead of you, run between
them, yelling, "Red Rover!"

31. Make up nonsense products and ask newly hired employees if there
are any in stock, i.e., "Do you have any Shnerples here?"

32. Take up an entire aisle in Toys by setting up a full scale
battlefield with G.I. Joes vs. the X-Men.

33. Take bets on the battle described above.

34. Nonchalantly "test" the brushes and combs in Cosmetics.

36. Hold indoor shopping cart races.

37. Dart around suspiciously while humming the theme from  "Mission:
Impossible."

38. Attempt to fit into very large gym bags.

39. Attempt to fit others into very large gym bags.

40. Say things like, "Would you be so kind as to direct me to your
Twinkies?"

41. Set up a "Valet Parking" sign in front of the store. 

42. Two words: "Marco Polo."

43. Leave Cheerios in Lawn and Garden, pillows in the pet food aisle,
etc. 

44. "Re-alphabetize" the CD's in Electronics.

46. When someone steps away from their cart to look at something,
quickly make off with it without saying a word.

47. Relax in the patio furniture until you get kicked out.

48. When an announcement comes over the loudspeaker, assume the fetal
position and scream, "No, no!  It's those voices again!"

49. Pay off layaways fifty cents at a time.

50. Drag a lounge chair on display over to the magazines and relax.
If the store has a food court, buy a soft drink; explain that you
don't get out much, and ask if they can put a little umbrella in it.

*BONUS*  Attempt all of the above during the same visit.

X-Mailer: Worldtalk (NetConnex V4.00a)/MIME

I thought this was kinda creative -


The European Union commissioners have announced that agreement has been
reached to adopt English as the preferred language for European
communications, rather than German, which was the other possibility.
As part of the negotiations, Her Majesty's Government conceded that
English spelling had some room for improvement and has accepted a
five-year phased plan for what will be known as EuroEnglish (Euro for
short).

In the first year, "s" will be used instead of the soft "c".
Sertainly, sivil servants will resieve this news with joy.   Also, the
hard "c" will be replaced with "k".  Not only will this klear up
konfusion, but typewriters kan have one less letter.

There will be growing publik enthusiasm in the sekond year, when
the troublesome "ph" will be replaced by "f". This will make words
like "fotograf" 20 per sent shorter.

In the third year, publik akseptanse of the new spelling kan be
expekted to reach the stage where more komplikated changes are
possible. Governments will enkorage the removal of double letters,
which have always ben a deterent to akurate speling. Also, al wil agre
what the horible mes of silent "e"s in the languag is disgrasful, and
they would go.

By the fourth year, peopl wil be reseptiv to steps such as
replasing  "th" by z" and "w" by " v".

During ze fifz year, ze unesesary "o" kan be dropd from vords
kontaining "ou",and similar changes vud of kors be aplid to ozer
kombinations of leters.

After zis fifz yer, ve vil hav a reli sensibl riten styl. Zer
vil be  no mor trubls or difikultis and evrivun vil find it ezi tu
understand ech ozer.

        Ze drem vil finali kum tru.


peas    B-)

X-RAYS AT AIRPORTS:  Purchase a large adult bedroom toy.
Wrap it in  a large amount of tin foil.  Secretly hide it in
a piece of the victims carry on luggage.  As it goes through
the airport x-ray machine the contents of the device will be
shielded by the tin foil and will be unwrapped-inspected by
airport security officials.

WARNING: If you don't want to know the secret to this game, don't read 
any further.....

None of the cards are the same.   It's an old card trick.  You 
concentrate on remembering your card and not what the other cards 
were.  As long as they look the same you probably won't notice.  You 
just notice that your card is not there but really none of the 
original cards are there.

last night was the last roots
may it rest in peace
it was the fattest weekly i have ever had the pleasure of attending.

last night was alot of fun Harry Who was the guest and he always brings a
smile to my face with his excellent house grooves

the music was always good at roots (garth,jeno + guest....usually someone
really good)

the vibe was really cool, especially in the beginning and for the last
couple weeks.   sweaty people freaking out at 3am to fat disco grooves,  
in the basement of 1015.

disco glory at its finest!!

personal roots highlights:
*the night that Harvey played right after he released "the bone"   he had
the wicked sound system playing louder than i have ever heard it.

*the night that Garth felt like he was "possesed"   it was epic.   we
reached a special place that night on the dancefloor.

*markie at roots two weeks ago.   i was so stoked.

with, the Off The Streets performance and party, but there's also the
Juggernaut Festival that night with a huge lineup, and several others.

try this one out.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.

     huge! 25 bucks though. Oh well, not an issue. From the recording it 
     tells you that last year 3000 people showed up. DAMN! Very cool, but 
     hectic. The lineup is unbeatable, and some of the attractions sound 
     great. However, this will be a massive party. Lots of people and 
     chaos, which isn't always bad, but could be.

     cool. Not on a grand scale like Juggernaut, which I like, and it's for 
     a good cause. 
     
     I'm unsure of what kind of party I want this weekend. That sucks. So, 
     I hoping the list might be able to sway myself one way or the other.

Get up on it:  TODAY, July 31, the Network Syndicate and Wired Digital proudly present:

	THE BETA LOUNGE!   http://www.betalounge.com/

We will be netcasting LIVE from 5pm-9pm PDT: Special guests today in the lounge are...
 
			******************************
			SKREDDY 57 of the Stellar Trax Sound System
			******************************
			 Also: resident DJs:
			      THE COMMUTER - 313 Technology Express
			       MUDFOOT - Superfuzz Mudstep
			******************************

Oh yes!
We will be hanging out in our chilly room and letting the bass roll for 4 hours of non-stop beats, cyberdelic spatial projections, networked ultraviolent videogames, stream-of-consciousness chat sessions, and whatever you happen to ingest in the privacy of your own node.

Experience the Beta Lounge online:
With high-quality Realaudio, dual floating webcams, and java-based chat: clear your cache and crank up your speakers for the weekly throwdown. Don't forget to get the newest version of the Realaudio Player for free at http://www.realaudio.com/

Also, this week in the Remix: 
Endemic Void (SSR, Crammed Discs) with a 2-hour session of smooth dark drum and bass
DJ Seoul of New York's Shaolin Fist jungle crew
San Francisco junglist Sifu on the new school jump-up tip

note: everything we've ever done is in the Remix - seek and ye shall find Doc Scott, Derrick May, Kid Koala, Shizuo and many more fat sets by spectacular DJs and producers!!!

Coming soon to the Beta Lounge:
- The Sound of the Asian Underground: Talvin Singh, live from Funky Tekno Tribe's Ultra.  For more info visit http://www.funkytekno.com/
- Special live simultaneous cybercasts from Detroit featuring some of the world's top techno DJs and producers, in a cooperative effort with our friends at Sigma 6 - http://www.sigma6.com/ 

All this and more at http://www.betalounge.com/ - jack in and bug out!  And be sure to check out the rest of HotWired 4.0 while you're there, because it's gonna boogie-woogie on your brain!
Dig it: http://www.hotwired.com/.

Quoth Jody Orsburn:
>     I've read alot about Juggernaut!! And it sounds fantastic, sounds
>     huge! 25 bucks though. Oh well, not an issue. From the recording it
>     tells you that last year 3000 people showed up. DAMN! Very cool, but
>     hectic. The lineup is unbeatable, and some of the attractions sound
>     great. However, this will be a massive party. Lots of people and
>     chaos, which isn't always bad, but could be.

Last year's Juggernaut was anything but fantastic. Juggernaut lost their
original space, and had to scramble to find a new one, so the party started
very late. The Mantra room was going off right away, but at that time you
could go to Mantra on any Sunday night, and only pay $5 for the privilege.
The sound in the main room didn't get started until after 2:00am. Many of
the live acts never played.

It is possible that 3000 people showed up: however, I doubt that even 2000
were optimistic enough to stick around for any length of time.

Oh yeah $2.00 water.

lrich                                               standish@sirius.com

Received: from ala-ca16-22.ix.netcom.com (starve@ala-ca16-22.ix.netcom.com [204.32.168.150]) by netcommunications.net (10.1/8.7.3) with SMTP id UAA29643 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Thu, 31 Jul 1997 20:09:47 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Thu, 31 Jul 1997 20:09:47 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199708010309.UAA29643@netcommunications.net>
X-Sender: leslie@netcommunications.net (Unverified)
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 2.1.1
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: 4X4 MONSTER CAMPOUT!!! (BSP)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

The cooperative team of Harmony, Mad and Cloud Factory proudly (and
excitedly) announce ...

               4X4 MONSTER CAMPOUT
               Fri Aug 15- Sun Aug 17
              
               in the Sierras!!!

In honor of Harmony's 4 years bringing us all the happiest parties around,
we're doing a campout in the redwoods of the Sierras!

Picture a private remote campground with 180+ acres of redwoods with a
stream running through it, under the sun in the daytime and the stars and a
full moon at night!  Add all your friends and favorite people, a pumping
dance sound system, plus a magical ambient area under the trees!  

The spot has level tiered campsites, real bathrooms with sinks and showers,
and a stream running through it.  It's private and permitted.... bring your
tent, drink the free spring water (yep, the same stuff you pay to buy in
bottles), and dance and chill with us all weekend.  It's about 2-1/2 hours
from the East Bay (if you follow the directions ;^) and the roads ain't all
that bad, either!

DJs will include all your favorites from Mad (like Ethan), Harmony (like
Greg) and Cloud Factory (like Drenalin) .... plus some special guests such
as members of the UCSC Gamilon Orchestra.  (Once we have the lineup set,
we'll post it.)

We'll start Friday night, and go right through until Sunday morning.... this
will be the mini-vacation of your dreams, I swear.  

There's lots of space, but tickets will still be limited, and the first ones
will be for sale at Sunset on Sunday (look for Brian Behlendorff, Jondabomb
or me, Leslie) for $20.

If you were at the Harmony 3-year (which was amazing) .... this is even
better!  The location is even more gorgeous, and it's set up to accommodate
lots of happy camper/partiers. We are talking raver heaven here, ok?

So call your friends now and make your plans.  If you can't make it to
Sunset, not to worry.... tickets will be available at the record stores
starting next week (we'll let you know where and when).... because we want
all the most positive and happy people to be there to share this special
occasion with us.

If you've never gone to a campout party, it's the bomb.  Time to chill, hang
out, hike, talk and get to know lots of wonderful people. Mark your
calendars and make your plans now. We love you all, and want to see you there!

Leslie
